Nautilus
1D gas-grain chemical model
  • Main Page
  • Modules
  • Files
  • File List
  • File Members
opkdmain.f90
Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 
00002 SUBROUTINE DLSODE (F, NEQ, Y, T, TOUT, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, ITASK, ISTATE, IOPT, RWORK, LRW, IWORK, LIW, JAC, MF)
00003 EXTERNAL F, JAC
00004 INTEGER NEQ, ITOL, ITASK, ISTATE, IOPT, LRW, IWORK, LIW, MF
00005 DOUBLE PRECISION Y, T, TOUT, RTOL, ATOL, RWORK
00006 DIMENSION NEQ(*), Y(*), RTOL(*), ATOL(*), RWORK(LRW), IWORK(LIW)
00007 !***BEGIN PROLOGUE  DLSODE
00008 !***PURPOSE  Livermore Solver for Ordinary Differential Equations.
00009 !            DLSODE solves the initial-value problem for stiff or
00010 !            nonstiff systems of first-order ODE's,
00011 !               dy/dt = f(t,y),   or, in component form,
00012 !               dy(i)/dt = f(i) = f(i,t,y(1),y(2),...,y(N)),  i=1,...,N.
00013 !***CATEGORY  I1A
00014 !***TYPE      DOUBLE PRECISION (SLSODE-S, DLSODE-D)
00015 !***KEYWORDS  ORDINARY DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS, INITIAL VALUE PROBLEM,
00016 !             STIFF, NONSTIFF
00017 !***AUTHOR  Hindmarsh, Alan C., (LLNL)
00018 !             Center for Applied Scientific Computing, L-561
00019 !             Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
00020 !             Livermore, CA 94551.
00021 !***DESCRIPTION
00022 !
00023 !     NOTE: The "Usage" and "Arguments" sections treat only a subset of
00024 !           available options, in condensed fashion.  The options
00025 !           covered and the information supplied will support most
00026 !           standard uses of DLSODE.
00027 !
00028 !           For more sophisticated uses, full details on all options are
00029 !           given in the concluding section, headed "Long Description."
00030 !           A synopsis of the DLSODE Long Description is provided at the
00031 !           beginning of that section; general topics covered are:
00032 !           - Elements of the call sequence; optional input and output
00033 !           - Optional supplemental routines in the DLSODE package
00034 !           - internal COMMON block
00035 !
00036 ! *Usage:
00037 !     Communication between the user and the DLSODE package, for normal
00038 !     situations, is summarized here.  This summary describes a subset
00039 !     of the available options.  See "Long Description" for complete
00040 !     details, including optional communication, nonstandard options,
00041 !     and instructions for special situations.
00042 !
00043 !     A sample program is given in the "Examples" section.
00044 !
00045 !     Refer to the argument descriptions for the definitions of the
00046 !     quantities that appear in the following sample declarations.
00047 !
00048 !     For MF = 10,
00049 !        PARAMETER  (LRW = 20 + 16*NEQ,           LIW = 20)
00050 !     For MF = 21 or 22,
00051 !        PARAMETER  (LRW = 22 +  9*NEQ + NEQ**2,  LIW = 20 + NEQ)
00052 !     For MF = 24 or 25,
00053 !        PARAMETER  (LRW = 22 + 10*NEQ + (2*ML+MU)*NEQ,
00054 !       *                                         LIW = 20 + NEQ)
00055 !
00056 !        EXTERNAL F, JAC
00057 !        INTEGER  NEQ, ITOL, ITASK, ISTATE, IOPT, LRW, IWORK(LIW),
00058 !       *         LIW, MF
00059 !        DOUBLE PRECISION Y(NEQ), T, TOUT, RTOL, ATOL(ntol), RWORK(LRW)
00060 !
00061 !        CALL DLSODE (F, NEQ, Y, T, TOUT, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, ITASK,
00062 !       *            ISTATE, IOPT, RWORK, LRW, IWORK, LIW, JAC, MF)
00063 !
00064 ! *Arguments:
00065 !     F     :EXT    Name of subroutine for right-hand-side vector f.
00066 !                   This name must be declared EXTERNAL in calling
00067 !                   program.  The form of F must be:
00068 !
00069 !                   SUBROUTINE  F (NEQ, T, Y, YDOT)
00070 !                   INTEGER  NEQ
00071 !                   DOUBLE PRECISION  T, Y(*), YDOT(*)
00072 !
00073 !                   The inputs are NEQ, T, Y.  F is to set
00074 !
00075 !                   YDOT(i) = f(i,T,Y(1),Y(2),...,Y(NEQ)),
00076 !                                                     i = 1, ..., NEQ .
00077 !
00078 !     NEQ   :IN     Number of first-order ODE's.
00079 !
00080 !     Y     :INOUT  Array of values of the y(t) vector, of length NEQ.
00081 !                   Input:  For the first call, Y should contain the
00082 !                           values of y(t) at t = T. (Y is an input
00083 !                           variable only if ISTATE = 1.)
00084 !                   Output: On return, Y will contain the values at the
00085 !                           new t-value.
00086 !
00087 !     T     :INOUT  Value of the independent variable.  On return it
00088 !                   will be the current value of t (normally TOUT).
00089 !
00090 !     TOUT  :IN     Next point where output is desired (.NE. T).
00091 !
00092 !     ITOL  :IN     1 or 2 according as ATOL (below) is a scalar or
00093 !                   an array.
00094 !
00095 !     RTOL  :IN     Relative tolerance parameter (scalar).
00096 !
00097 !     ATOL  :IN     Absolute tolerance parameter (scalar or array).
00098 !                   If ITOL = 1, ATOL need not be dimensioned.
00099 !                   If ITOL = 2, ATOL must be dimensioned at least NEQ.
00100 !
00101 !                   The estimated local error in Y(i) will be controlled
00102 !                   so as to be roughly less (in magnitude) than
00103 !
00104 !                   EWT(i) = RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL     if ITOL = 1, or
00105 !                   EWT(i) = RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i)  if ITOL = 2.
00106 !
00107 !                   Thus the local error test passes if, in each
00108 !                   component, either the absolute error is less than
00109 !                   ATOL (or ATOL(i)), or the relative error is less
00110 !                   than RTOL.
00111 !
00112 !                   Use RTOL = 0.0 for pure absolute error control, and
00113 !                   use ATOL = 0.0 (or ATOL(i) = 0.0) for pure relative
00114 !                   error control.  Caution:  Actual (global) errors may
00115 !                   exceed these local tolerances, so choose them
00116 !                   conservatively.
00117 !
00118 !     ITASK :IN     Flag indicating the task DLSODE is to perform.
00119 !                   Use ITASK = 1 for normal computation of output
00120 !                   values of y at t = TOUT.
00121 !
00122 !     ISTATE:INOUT  Index used for input and output to specify the state
00123 !                   of the calculation.
00124 !                   Input:
00125 !                    1   This is the first call for a problem.
00126 !                    2   This is a subsequent call.
00127 !                   Output:
00128 !                    1   Nothing was done, because TOUT was equal to T.
00129 !                    2   DLSODE was successful (otherwise, negative).
00130 !                        Note that ISTATE need not be modified after a
00131 !                        successful return.
00132 !                   -1   Excess work done on this call (perhaps wrong
00133 !                        MF).
00134 !                   -2   Excess accuracy requested (tolerances too
00135 !                        small).
00136 !                   -3   Illegal input detected (see printed message).
00137 !                   -4   Repeated error test failures (check all
00138 !                        inputs).
00139 !                   -5   Repeated convergence failures (perhaps bad
00140 !                        Jacobian supplied or wrong choice of MF or
00141 !                        tolerances).
00142 !                   -6   Error weight became zero during problem
00143 !                        (solution component i vanished, and ATOL or
00144 !                        ATOL(i) = 0.).
00145 !
00146 !     IOPT  :IN     Flag indicating whether optional inputs are used:
00147 !                   0   No.
00148 !                   1   Yes.  (See "Optional inputs" under "Long
00149 !                       Description," Part 1.)
00150 !
00151 !     RWORK :WORK   Real work array of length at least:
00152 !                   20 + 16*NEQ                    for MF = 10,
00153 !                   22 +  9*NEQ + NEQ**2           for MF = 21 or 22,
00154 !                   22 + 10*NEQ + (2*ML + MU)*NEQ  for MF = 24 or 25.
00155 !
00156 !     LRW   :IN     Declared length of RWORK (in user's DIMENSION
00157 !                   statement).
00158 !
00159 !     IWORK :WORK   Integer work array of length at least:
00160 !                   20        for MF = 10,
00161 !                   20 + NEQ  for MF = 21, 22, 24, or 25.
00162 !
00163 !                   If MF = 24 or 25, input in IWORK(1),IWORK(2) the
00164 !                   lower and upper Jacobian half-bandwidths ML,MU.
00165 !
00166 !                   On return, IWORK contains information that may be
00167 !                   of interest to the user:
00168 !
00169 !            Name   Location   Meaning
00170 !            -----  ---------  -----------------------------------------
00171 !            NST    IWORK(11)  Number of steps taken for the problem so
00172 !                              far.
00173 !            NFE    IWORK(12)  Number of f evaluations for the problem
00174 !                              so far.
00175 !            NJE    IWORK(13)  Number of Jacobian evaluations (and of
00176 !                              matrix LU decompositions) for the problem
00177 !                              so far.
00178 !            NQU    IWORK(14)  Method order last used (successfully).
00179 !            LENRW  IWORK(17)  Length of RWORK actually required.  This
00180 !                              is defined on normal returns and on an
00181 !                              illegal input return for insufficient
00182 !                              storage.
00183 !            LENIW  IWORK(18)  Length of IWORK actually required.  This
00184 !                              is defined on normal returns and on an
00185 !                              illegal input return for insufficient
00186 !                              storage.
00187 !
00188 !     LIW   :IN     Declared length of IWORK (in user's DIMENSION
00189 !                   statement).
00190 !
00191 !     JAC   :EXT    Name of subroutine for Jacobian matrix (MF =
00192 !                   21 or 24).  If used, this name must be declared
00193 !                   EXTERNAL in calling program.  If not used, pass a
00194 !                   dummy name.  The form of JAC must be:
00195 !
00196 !                   SUBROUTINE JAC (NEQ, T, Y, ML, MU, PD, NROWPD)
00197 !                   INTEGER  NEQ, ML, MU, NROWPD
00198 !                   DOUBLE PRECISION  T, Y(*), PD(NROWPD,*)
00199 !
00200 !                   See item c, under "Description" below for more
00201 !                   information about JAC.
00202 !
00203 !     MF    :IN     Method flag.  Standard values are:
00204 !                   10  Nonstiff (Adams) method, no Jacobian used.
00205 !                   21  Stiff (BDF) method, user-supplied full Jacobian.
00206 !                   22  Stiff method, internally generated full
00207 !                       Jacobian.
00208 !                   24  Stiff method, user-supplied banded Jacobian.
00209 !                   25  Stiff method, internally generated banded
00210 !                       Jacobian.
00211 !
00212 ! *Description:
00213 !     DLSODE solves the initial value problem for stiff or nonstiff
00214 !     systems of first-order ODE's,
00215 !
00216 !        dy/dt = f(t,y) ,
00217 !
00218 !     or, in component form,
00219 !
00220 !        dy(i)/dt = f(i) = f(i,t,y(1),y(2),...,y(NEQ))
00221 !                                                  (i = 1, ..., NEQ) .
00222 !
00223 !     DLSODE is a package based on the GEAR and GEARB packages, and on
00224 !     the October 23, 1978, version of the tentative ODEPACK user
00225 !     interface standard, with minor modifications.
00226 !
00227 !     The steps in solving such a problem are as follows.
00228 !
00229 !     a. First write a subroutine of the form
00230 !
00231 !           SUBROUTINE  F (NEQ, T, Y, YDOT)
00232 !           INTEGER  NEQ
00233 !           DOUBLE PRECISION  T, Y(*), YDOT(*)
00234 !
00235 !        which supplies the vector function f by loading YDOT(i) with
00236 !        f(i).
00237 !
00238 !     b. Next determine (or guess) whether or not the problem is stiff.
00239 !        Stiffness occurs when the Jacobian matrix df/dy has an
00240 !        eigenvalue whose real part is negative and large in magnitude
00241 !        compared to the reciprocal of the t span of interest.  If the
00242 !        problem is nonstiff, use method flag MF = 10.  If it is stiff,
00243 !        there are four standard choices for MF, and DLSODE requires the
00244 !        Jacobian matrix in some form.  This matrix is regarded either
00245 !        as full (MF = 21 or 22), or banded (MF = 24 or 25).  In the
00246 !        banded case, DLSODE requires two half-bandwidth parameters ML
00247 !        and MU. These are, respectively, the widths of the lower and
00248 !        upper parts of the band, excluding the main diagonal.  Thus the
00249 !        band consists of the locations (i,j) with
00250 !
00251 !           i - ML <= j <= i + MU ,
00252 !
00253 !        and the full bandwidth is ML + MU + 1 .
00254 !
00255 !     c. If the problem is stiff, you are encouraged to supply the
00256 !        Jacobian directly (MF = 21 or 24), but if this is not feasible,
00257 !        DLSODE will compute it internally by difference quotients (MF =
00258 !        22 or 25).  If you are supplying the Jacobian, write a
00259 !        subroutine of the form
00260 !
00261 !           SUBROUTINE  JAC (NEQ, T, Y, ML, MU, PD, NROWPD)
00262 !           INTEGER  NEQ, ML, MU, NRWOPD
00263 !           DOUBLE PRECISION  T, Y(*), PD(NROWPD,*)
00264 !
00265 !        which provides df/dy by loading PD as follows:
00266 !        - For a full Jacobian (MF = 21), load PD(i,j) with df(i)/dy(j),
00267 !          the partial derivative of f(i) with respect to y(j).  (Ignore
00268 !          the ML and MU arguments in this case.)
00269 !        - For a banded Jacobian (MF = 24), load PD(i-j+MU+1,j) with
00270 !          df(i)/dy(j); i.e., load the diagonal lines of df/dy into the
00271 !          rows of PD from the top down.
00272 !        - In either case, only nonzero elements need be loaded.
00273 !
00274 !     d. Write a main program that calls subroutine DLSODE once for each
00275 !        point at which answers are desired.  This should also provide
00276 !        for possible use of logical unit 6 for output of error messages
00277 !        by DLSODE.
00278 !
00279 !        Before the first call to DLSODE, set ISTATE = 1, set Y and T to
00280 !        the initial values, and set TOUT to the first output point.  To
00281 !        continue the integration after a successful return, simply
00282 !        reset TOUT and call DLSODE again.  No other parameters need be
00283 !        reset.
00284 !
00285 ! *Examples:
00286 !     The following is a simple example problem, with the coding needed
00287 !     for its solution by DLSODE. The problem is from chemical kinetics,
00288 !     and consists of the following three rate equations:
00289 !
00290 !        dy1/dt = -.04*y1 + 1.E4*y2*y3
00291 !        dy2/dt = .04*y1 - 1.E4*y2*y3 - 3.E7*y2**2
00292 !        dy3/dt = 3.E7*y2**2
00293 !
00294 !     on the interval from t = 0.0 to t = 4.E10, with initial conditions
00295 !     y1 = 1.0, y2 = y3 = 0. The problem is stiff.
00296 !
00297 !     The following coding solves this problem with DLSODE, using 
00298 !     MF = 21 and printing results at t = .4, 4., ..., 4.E10.  It uses 
00299 !     ITOL = 2 and ATOL much smaller for y2 than for y1 or y3 because y2 
00300 !     has much smaller values.  At the end of the run, statistical 
00301 !     quantities of interest are printed.
00302 !
00303 !        EXTERNAL  FEX, JEX
00304 !        INTEGER  IOPT, IOUT, ISTATE, ITASK, ITOL, IWORK(23), LIW, LRW,
00305 !       *         MF, NEQ
00306 !        DOUBLE PRECISION  ATOL(3), RTOL, RWORK(58), T, TOUT, Y(3)
00307 !        NEQ = 3
00308 !        Y(1) = 1.D0
00309 !        Y(2) = 0.D0
00310 !        Y(3) = 0.D0
00311 !        T = 0.D0
00312 !        TOUT = .4D0
00313 !        ITOL = 2
00314 !        RTOL = 1.D-4
00315 !        ATOL(1) = 1.D-6
00316 !        ATOL(2) = 1.D-10
00317 !        ATOL(3) = 1.D-6
00318 !        ITASK = 1
00319 !        ISTATE = 1
00320 !        IOPT = 0
00321 !        LRW = 58
00322 !        LIW = 23
00323 !        MF = 21
00324 !        DO 40 IOUT = 1,12
00325 !          CALL DLSODE (FEX, NEQ, Y, T, TOUT, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, ITASK,
00326 !       *               ISTATE, IOPT, RWORK, LRW, IWORK, LIW, JEX, MF)
00327 !          WRITE(6,20)  T, Y(1), Y(2), Y(3)
00328 !    20    FORMAT(' At t =',D12.4,'   y =',3D14.6)
00329 !          IF (ISTATE .LT. 0)  GOTO 80
00330 !    40    TOUT = TOUT*10.D0
00331 !        WRITE(6,60)  IWORK(11), IWORK(12), IWORK(13)
00332 !    60  FORMAT(/' No. steps =',i4,',  No. f-s =',i4,',  No. J-s =',i4)
00333 !        STOP
00334 !    80  WRITE(6,90)  ISTATE
00335 !    90  FORMAT(///' Error halt.. ISTATE =',I3)
00336 !        STOP
00337 !        END
00338 !
00339 !        SUBROUTINE  FEX (NEQ, T, Y, YDOT)
00340 !        INTEGER  NEQ
00341 !        DOUBLE PRECISION  T, Y(3), YDOT(3)
00342 !        YDOT(1) = -.04D0*Y(1) + 1.D4*Y(2)*Y(3)
00343 !        YDOT(3) = 3.D7*Y(2)*Y(2)
00344 !        YDOT(2) = -YDOT(1) - YDOT(3)
00345 !        RETURN
00346 !        END
00347 !
00348 !        SUBROUTINE  JEX (NEQ, T, Y, ML, MU, PD, NRPD)
00349 !        INTEGER  NEQ, ML, MU, NRPD
00350 !        DOUBLE PRECISION  T, Y(3), PD(NRPD,3)
00351 !        PD(1,1) = -.04D0
00352 !        PD(1,2) = 1.D4*Y(3)
00353 !        PD(1,3) = 1.D4*Y(2)
00354 !        PD(2,1) = .04D0
00355 !        PD(2,3) = -PD(1,3)
00356 !        PD(3,2) = 6.D7*Y(2)
00357 !        PD(2,2) = -PD(1,2) - PD(3,2)
00358 !        RETURN
00359 !        END
00360 !
00361 !     The output from this program (on a Cray-1 in single precision)
00362 !     is as follows.
00363 !
00364 !     At t =  4.0000e-01   y =  9.851726e-01  3.386406e-05  1.479357e-02
00365 !     At t =  4.0000e+00   y =  9.055142e-01  2.240418e-05  9.446344e-02
00366 !     At t =  4.0000e+01   y =  7.158050e-01  9.184616e-06  2.841858e-01
00367 !     At t =  4.0000e+02   y =  4.504846e-01  3.222434e-06  5.495122e-01
00368 !     At t =  4.0000e+03   y =  1.831701e-01  8.940379e-07  8.168290e-01
00369 !     At t =  4.0000e+04   y =  3.897016e-02  1.621193e-07  9.610297e-01
00370 !     At t =  4.0000e+05   y =  4.935213e-03  1.983756e-08  9.950648e-01
00371 !     At t =  4.0000e+06   y =  5.159269e-04  2.064759e-09  9.994841e-01
00372 !     At t =  4.0000e+07   y =  5.306413e-05  2.122677e-10  9.999469e-01
00373 !     At t =  4.0000e+08   y =  5.494530e-06  2.197825e-11  9.999945e-01
00374 !     At t =  4.0000e+09   y =  5.129458e-07  2.051784e-12  9.999995e-01
00375 !     At t =  4.0000e+10   y = -7.170603e-08 -2.868241e-13  1.000000e+00
00376 !
00377 !     No. steps = 330,  No. f-s = 405,  No. J-s = 69
00378 !
00379 ! *Accuracy:
00380 !     The accuracy of the solution depends on the choice of tolerances
00381 !     RTOL and ATOL.  Actual (global) errors may exceed these local
00382 !     tolerances, so choose them conservatively.
00383 !
00384 ! *Cautions:
00385 !     The work arrays should not be altered between calls to DLSODE for
00386 !     the same problem, except possibly for the conditional and optional
00387 !     inputs.
00388 !
00389 ! *Portability:
00390 !     Since NEQ is dimensioned inside DLSODE, some compilers may object
00391 !     to a call to DLSODE with NEQ a scalar variable.  In this event, 
00392 !     use DIMENSION NEQ(1).  Similar remarks apply to RTOL and ATOL.
00393 !
00394 !     Note to Cray users:
00395 !     For maximum efficiency, use the CFT77 compiler.  Appropriate
00396 !     compiler optimization directives have been inserted for CFT77.
00397 !
00398 ! *Reference:
00399 !     Alan C. Hindmarsh, "ODEPACK, A Systematized Collection of ODE
00400 !     Solvers," in Scientific Computing, R. S. Stepleman, et al., Eds.
00401 !     (North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1983), pp. 55-64.
00402 !
00403 ! *Long Description:
00404 !     The following complete description of the user interface to
00405 !     DLSODE consists of four parts:
00406 !
00407 !     1.  The call sequence to subroutine DLSODE, which is a driver
00408 !         routine for the solver.  This includes descriptions of both
00409 !         the call sequence arguments and user-supplied routines.
00410 !         Following these descriptions is a description of optional
00411 !         inputs available through the call sequence, and then a
00412 !         description of optional outputs in the work arrays.
00413 !
00414 !     2.  Descriptions of other routines in the DLSODE package that may
00415 !         be (optionally) called by the user.  These provide the ability
00416 !         to alter error message handling, save and restore the internal
00417 !         COMMON, and obtain specified derivatives of the solution y(t).
00418 !
00419 !     3.  Descriptions of COMMON block to be declared in overlay or
00420 !         similar environments, or to be saved when doing an interrupt
00421 !         of the problem and continued solution later.
00422 !
00423 !     4.  Description of two routines in the DLSODE package, either of
00424 !         which the user may replace with his own version, if desired.
00425 !         These relate to the measurement of errors.
00426 !
00427 !
00428 !                         Part 1.  Call Sequence
00429 !                         ----------------------
00430 !
00431 !     Arguments
00432 !     ---------
00433 !     The call sequence parameters used for input only are
00434 !
00435 !        F, NEQ, TOUT, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, ITASK, IOPT, LRW, LIW, JAC, MF,
00436 !
00437 !     and those used for both input and output are
00438 !
00439 !        Y, T, ISTATE.
00440 !
00441 !     The work arrays RWORK and IWORK are also used for conditional and
00442 !     optional inputs and optional outputs.  (The term output here
00443 !     refers to the return from subroutine DLSODE to the user's calling
00444 !     program.)
00445 !
00446 !     The legality of input parameters will be thoroughly checked on the
00447 !     initial call for the problem, but not checked thereafter unless a
00448 !     change in input parameters is flagged by ISTATE = 3 on input.
00449 !
00450 !     The descriptions of the call arguments are as follows.
00451 !
00452 !     F        The name of the user-supplied subroutine defining the ODE
00453 !              system.  The system must be put in the first-order form
00454 !              dy/dt = f(t,y), where f is a vector-valued function of
00455 !              the scalar t and the vector y. Subroutine F is to compute
00456 !              the function f. It is to have the form
00457 !
00458 !                 SUBROUTINE F (NEQ, T, Y, YDOT)
00459 !                 DOUBLE PRECISION  T, Y(*), YDOT(*)
00460 !
00461 !              where NEQ, T, and Y are input, and the array YDOT =
00462 !              f(T,Y) is output.  Y and YDOT are arrays of length NEQ.
00463 !              Subroutine F should not alter Y(1),...,Y(NEQ).  F must be
00464 !              declared EXTERNAL in the calling program.
00465 !
00466 !              Subroutine F may access user-defined quantities in
00467 !              NEQ(2),... and/or in Y(NEQ(1)+1),..., if NEQ is an array
00468 !              (dimensioned in F) and/or Y has length exceeding NEQ(1).
00469 !              See the descriptions of NEQ and Y below.
00470 !
00471 !              If quantities computed in the F routine are needed
00472 !              externally to DLSODE, an extra call to F should be made
00473 !              for this purpose, for consistent and accurate results.
00474 !              If only the derivative dy/dt is needed, use DINTDY
00475 !              instead.
00476 !
00477 !     NEQ      The size of the ODE system (number of first-order
00478 !              ordinary differential equations).  Used only for input.
00479 !              NEQ may be decreased, but not increased, during the
00480 !              problem.  If NEQ is decreased (with ISTATE = 3 on input),
00481 !              the remaining components of Y should be left undisturbed,
00482 !              if these are to be accessed in F and/or JAC.
00483 !
00484 !              Normally, NEQ is a scalar, and it is generally referred
00485 !              to as a scalar in this user interface description.
00486 !              However, NEQ may be an array, with NEQ(1) set to the
00487 !              system size.  (The DLSODE package accesses only NEQ(1).)
00488 !              In either case, this parameter is passed as the NEQ
00489 !              argument in all calls to F and JAC.  Hence, if it is an
00490 !              array, locations NEQ(2),... may be used to store other
00491 !              integer data and pass it to F and/or JAC.  Subroutines
00492 !              F and/or JAC must include NEQ in a DIMENSION statement
00493 !              in that case.
00494 !
00495 !     Y        A real array for the vector of dependent variables, of
00496 !              length NEQ or more.  Used for both input and output on
00497 !              the first call (ISTATE = 1), and only for output on
00498 !              other calls.  On the first call, Y must contain the
00499 !              vector of initial values.  On output, Y contains the
00500 !              computed solution vector, evaluated at T. If desired,
00501 !              the Y array may be used for other purposes between
00502 !              calls to the solver.
00503 !
00504 !              This array is passed as the Y argument in all calls to F
00505 !              and JAC.  Hence its length may exceed NEQ, and locations
00506 !              Y(NEQ+1),... may be used to store other real data and
00507 !              pass it to F and/or JAC.  (The DLSODE package accesses
00508 !              only Y(1),...,Y(NEQ).)
00509 !
00510 !     T        The independent variable.  On input, T is used only on
00511 !              the first call, as the initial point of the integration.
00512 !              On output, after each call, T is the value at which a
00513 !              computed solution Y is evaluated (usually the same as
00514 !              TOUT).  On an error return, T is the farthest point
00515 !              reached.
00516 !
00517 !     TOUT     The next value of T at which a computed solution is
00518 !              desired.  Used only for input.
00519 !
00520 !              When starting the problem (ISTATE = 1), TOUT may be equal
00521 !              to T for one call, then should not equal T for the next
00522 !              call.  For the initial T, an input value of TOUT .NE. T
00523 !              is used in order to determine the direction of the
00524 !              integration (i.e., the algebraic sign of the step sizes)
00525 !              and the rough scale of the problem.  Integration in
00526 !              either direction (forward or backward in T) is permitted.
00527 !
00528 !              If ITASK = 2 or 5 (one-step modes), TOUT is ignored
00529 !              after the first call (i.e., the first call with
00530 !              TOUT .NE. T).  Otherwise, TOUT is required on every call.
00531 !
00532 !              If ITASK = 1, 3, or 4, the values of TOUT need not be
00533 !              monotone, but a value of TOUT which backs up is limited
00534 !              to the current internal T interval, whose endpoints are
00535 !              TCUR - HU and TCUR.  (See "Optional Outputs" below for
00536 !              TCUR and HU.)
00537 !
00538 !
00539 !     ITOL     An indicator for the type of error control.  See
00540 !              description below under ATOL.  Used only for input.
00541 !
00542 !     RTOL     A relative error tolerance parameter, either a scalar or
00543 !              an array of length NEQ.  See description below under
00544 !              ATOL.  Input only.
00545 !
00546 !     ATOL     An absolute error tolerance parameter, either a scalar or
00547 !              an array of length NEQ.  Input only.
00548 !
00549 !              The input parameters ITOL, RTOL, and ATOL determine the
00550 !              error control performed by the solver.  The solver will
00551 !              control the vector e = (e(i)) of estimated local errors
00552 !              in Y, according to an inequality of the form
00553 !
00554 !                 rms-norm of ( e(i)/EWT(i) ) <= 1,
00555 !
00556 !              where
00557 !
00558 !                 EWT(i) = RTOL(i)*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i),
00559 !
00560 !              and the rms-norm (root-mean-square norm) here is
00561 !
00562 !                 rms-norm(v) = SQRT(sum v(i)**2 / NEQ).
00563 !
00564 !              Here EWT = (EWT(i)) is a vector of weights which must
00565 !              always be positive, and the values of RTOL and ATOL
00566 !              should all be nonnegative.  The following table gives the
00567 !              types (scalar/array) of RTOL and ATOL, and the
00568 !              corresponding form of EWT(i).
00569 !
00570 !              ITOL    RTOL      ATOL      EWT(i)
00571 !              ----    ------    ------    -----------------------------
00572 !              1       scalar    scalar    RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL
00573 !              2       scalar    array     RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i)
00574 !              3       array     scalar    RTOL(i)*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL
00575 !              4       array     array     RTOL(i)*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i)
00576 !
00577 !              When either of these parameters is a scalar, it need not
00578 !              be dimensioned in the user's calling program.
00579 !
00580 !              If none of the above choices (with ITOL, RTOL, and ATOL
00581 !              fixed throughout the problem) is suitable, more general
00582 !              error controls can be obtained by substituting
00583 !              user-supplied routines for the setting of EWT and/or for
00584 !              the norm calculation.  See Part 4 below.
00585 !
00586 !              If global errors are to be estimated by making a repeated
00587 !              run on the same problem with smaller tolerances, then all
00588 !              components of RTOL and ATOL (i.e., of EWT) should be
00589 !              scaled down uniformly.
00590 !
00591 !     ITASK    An index specifying the task to be performed.  Input
00592 !              only.  ITASK has the following values and meanings:
00593 !              1   Normal computation of output values of y(t) at
00594 !                  t = TOUT (by overshooting and interpolating).
00595 !              2   Take one step only and return.
00596 !              3   Stop at the first internal mesh point at or beyond
00597 !                  t = TOUT and return.
00598 !              4   Normal computation of output values of y(t) at
00599 !                  t = TOUT but without overshooting t = TCRIT.  TCRIT
00600 !                  must be input as RWORK(1).  TCRIT may be equal to or
00601 !                  beyond TOUT, but not behind it in the direction of
00602 !                  integration.  This option is useful if the problem
00603 !                  has a singularity at or beyond t = TCRIT.
00604 !              5   Take one step, without passing TCRIT, and return.
00605 !                  TCRIT must be input as RWORK(1).
00606 !
00607 !              Note:  If ITASK = 4 or 5 and the solver reaches TCRIT
00608 !              (within roundoff), it will return T = TCRIT (exactly) to
00609 !              indicate this (unless ITASK = 4 and TOUT comes before
00610 !              TCRIT, in which case answers at T = TOUT are returned
00611 !              first).
00612 !
00613 !     ISTATE   An index used for input and output to specify the state
00614 !              of the calculation.
00615 !
00616 !              On input, the values of ISTATE are as follows:
00617 !              1   This is the first call for the problem
00618 !                  (initializations will be done).  See "Note" below.
00619 !              2   This is not the first call, and the calculation is to
00620 !                  continue normally, with no change in any input
00621 !                  parameters except possibly TOUT and ITASK.  (If ITOL,
00622 !                  RTOL, and/or ATOL are changed between calls with
00623 !                  ISTATE = 2, the new values will be used but not
00624 !                  tested for legality.)
00625 !              3   This is not the first call, and the calculation is to
00626 !                  continue normally, but with a change in input
00627 !                  parameters other than TOUT and ITASK.  Changes are
00628 !                  allowed in NEQ, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, IOPT, LRW, LIW, MF,
00629 !                  ML, MU, and any of the optional inputs except H0.
00630 !                  (See IWORK description for ML and MU.)
00631 !
00632 !              Note:  A preliminary call with TOUT = T is not counted as
00633 !              a first call here, as no initialization or checking of
00634 !              input is done.  (Such a call is sometimes useful for the
00635 !              purpose of outputting the initial conditions.)  Thus the
00636 !              first call for which TOUT .NE. T requires ISTATE = 1 on
00637 !              input.
00638 !
00639 !              On output, ISTATE has the following values and meanings:
00640 !               1  Nothing was done, as TOUT was equal to T with
00641 !                  ISTATE = 1 on input.
00642 !               2  The integration was performed successfully.
00643 !              -1  An excessive amount of work (more than MXSTEP steps)
00644 !                  was done on this call, before completing the
00645 !                  requested task, but the integration was otherwise
00646 !                  successful as far as T. (MXSTEP is an optional input
00647 !                  and is normally 500.)  To continue, the user may
00648 !                  simply reset ISTATE to a value >1 and call again (the
00649 !                  excess work step counter will be reset to 0).  In
00650 !                  addition, the user may increase MXSTEP to avoid this
00651 !                  error return; see "Optional Inputs" below.
00652 !              -2  Too much accuracy was requested for the precision of
00653 !                  the machine being used.  This was detected before
00654 !                  completing the requested task, but the integration
00655 !                  was successful as far as T. To continue, the
00656 !                  tolerance parameters must be reset, and ISTATE must
00657 !                  be set to 3. The optional output TOLSF may be used
00658 !                  for this purpose.  (Note:  If this condition is
00659 !                  detected before taking any steps, then an illegal
00660 !                  input return (ISTATE = -3) occurs instead.)
00661 !              -3  Illegal input was detected, before taking any
00662 !                  integration steps.  See written message for details.
00663 !                  (Note:  If the solver detects an infinite loop of
00664 !                  calls to the solver with illegal input, it will cause
00665 !                  the run to stop.)
00666 !              -4  There were repeated error-test failures on one
00667 !                  attempted step, before completing the requested task,
00668 !                  but the integration was successful as far as T.  The
00669 !                  problem may have a singularity, or the input may be
00670 !                  inappropriate.
00671 !              -5  There were repeated convergence-test failures on one
00672 !                  attempted step, before completing the requested task,
00673 !                  but the integration was successful as far as T. This
00674 !                  may be caused by an inaccurate Jacobian matrix, if
00675 !                  one is being used.
00676 !              -6  EWT(i) became zero for some i during the integration.
00677 !                  Pure relative error control (ATOL(i)=0.0) was
00678 !                  requested on a variable which has now vanished.  The
00679 !                  integration was successful as far as T.
00680 !
00681 !              Note:  Since the normal output value of ISTATE is 2, it
00682 !              does not need to be reset for normal continuation.  Also,
00683 !              since a negative input value of ISTATE will be regarded
00684 !              as illegal, a negative output value requires the user to
00685 !              change it, and possibly other inputs, before calling the
00686 !              solver again.
00687 !
00688 !     IOPT     An integer flag to specify whether any optional inputs
00689 !              are being used on this call.  Input only.  The optional
00690 !              inputs are listed under a separate heading below.
00691 !              0   No optional inputs are being used.  Default values
00692 !                  will be used in all cases.
00693 !              1   One or more optional inputs are being used.
00694 !
00695 !     RWORK    A real working array (double precision).  The length of
00696 !              RWORK must be at least
00697 !
00698 !                 20 + NYH*(MAXORD + 1) + 3*NEQ + LWM
00699 !
00700 !              where
00701 !                 NYH = the initial value of NEQ,
00702 !              MAXORD = 12 (if METH = 1) or 5 (if METH = 2) (unless a
00703 !                       smaller value is given as an optional input),
00704 !                 LWM = 0           if MITER = 0,
00705 !                 LWM = NEQ**2 + 2  if MITER = 1 or 2,
00706 !                 LWM = NEQ + 2     if MITER = 3, and
00707 !                 LWM = (2*ML + MU + 1)*NEQ + 2
00708 !                                   if MITER = 4 or 5.
00709 !              (See the MF description below for METH and MITER.)
00710 !
00711 !              Thus if MAXORD has its default value and NEQ is constant,
00712 !              this length is:
00713 !              20 + 16*NEQ                    for MF = 10,
00714 !              22 + 16*NEQ + NEQ**2           for MF = 11 or 12,
00715 !              22 + 17*NEQ                    for MF = 13,
00716 !              22 + 17*NEQ + (2*ML + MU)*NEQ  for MF = 14 or 15,
00717 !              20 +  9*NEQ                    for MF = 20,
00718 !              22 +  9*NEQ + NEQ**2           for MF = 21 or 22,
00719 !              22 + 10*NEQ                    for MF = 23,
00720 !              22 + 10*NEQ + (2*ML + MU)*NEQ  for MF = 24 or 25.
00721 !
00722 !              The first 20 words of RWORK are reserved for conditional
00723 !              and optional inputs and optional outputs.
00724 !
00725 !              The following word in RWORK is a conditional input:
00726 !              RWORK(1) = TCRIT, the critical value of t which the
00727 !                         solver is not to overshoot.  Required if ITASK
00728 !                         is 4 or 5, and ignored otherwise.  See ITASK.
00729 !
00730 !     LRW      The length of the array RWORK, as declared by the user.
00731 !              (This will be checked by the solver.)
00732 !
00733 !     IWORK    An integer work array.  Its length must be at least
00734 !              20       if MITER = 0 or 3 (MF = 10, 13, 20, 23), or
00735 !              20 + NEQ otherwise (MF = 11, 12, 14, 15, 21, 22, 24, 25).
00736 !              (See the MF description below for MITER.)  The first few
00737 !              words of IWORK are used for conditional and optional
00738 !              inputs and optional outputs.
00739 !
00740 !              The following two words in IWORK are conditional inputs:
00741 !              IWORK(1) = ML   These are the lower and upper half-
00742 !              IWORK(2) = MU   bandwidths, respectively, of the banded
00743 !                              Jacobian, excluding the main diagonal.
00744 !                         The band is defined by the matrix locations
00745 !                         (i,j) with i - ML <= j <= i + MU. ML and MU
00746 !                         must satisfy 0 <= ML,MU <= NEQ - 1. These are
00747 !                         required if MITER is 4 or 5, and ignored
00748 !                         otherwise.  ML and MU may in fact be the band
00749 !                         parameters for a matrix to which df/dy is only
00750 !                         approximately equal.
00751 !
00752 !     LIW      The length of the array IWORK, as declared by the user.
00753 !              (This will be checked by the solver.)
00754 !
00755 !     Note:  The work arrays must not be altered between calls to DLSODE
00756 !     for the same problem, except possibly for the conditional and
00757 !     optional inputs, and except for the last 3*NEQ words of RWORK.
00758 !     The latter space is used for internal scratch space, and so is
00759 !     available for use by the user outside DLSODE between calls, if
00760 !     desired (but not for use by F or JAC).
00761 !
00762 !     JAC      The name of the user-supplied routine (MITER = 1 or 4) to
00763 !              compute the Jacobian matrix, df/dy, as a function of the
00764 !              scalar t and the vector y.  (See the MF description below
00765 !              for MITER.)  It is to have the form
00766 !
00767 !                 SUBROUTINE JAC (NEQ, T, Y, ML, MU, PD, NROWPD)
00768 !                 DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), PD(NROWPD,*)
00769 !
00770 !              where NEQ, T, Y, ML, MU, and NROWPD are input and the
00771 !              array PD is to be loaded with partial derivatives
00772 !              (elements of the Jacobian matrix) on output.  PD must be
00773 !              given a first dimension of NROWPD.  T and Y have the same
00774 !              meaning as in subroutine F.
00775 !
00776 !              In the full matrix case (MITER = 1), ML and MU are
00777 !              ignored, and the Jacobian is to be loaded into PD in
00778 !              columnwise manner, with df(i)/dy(j) loaded into PD(i,j).
00779 !
00780 !              In the band matrix case (MITER = 4), the elements within
00781 !              the band are to be loaded into PD in columnwise manner,
00782 !              with diagonal lines of df/dy loaded into the rows of PD.
00783 !              Thus df(i)/dy(j) is to be loaded into PD(i-j+MU+1,j).  ML
00784 !              and MU are the half-bandwidth parameters (see IWORK).
00785 !              The locations in PD in the two triangular areas which
00786 !              correspond to nonexistent matrix elements can be ignored
00787 !              or loaded arbitrarily, as they are overwritten by DLSODE.
00788 !
00789 !              JAC need not provide df/dy exactly. A crude approximation
00790 !              (possibly with a smaller bandwidth) will do.
00791 !
00792 !              In either case, PD is preset to zero by the solver, so
00793 !              that only the nonzero elements need be loaded by JAC.
00794 !              Each call to JAC is preceded by a call to F with the same
00795 !              arguments NEQ, T, and Y. Thus to gain some efficiency,
00796 !              intermediate quantities shared by both calculations may
00797 !              be saved in a user COMMON block by F and not recomputed
00798 !              by JAC, if desired.  Also, JAC may alter the Y array, if
00799 !              desired.  JAC must be declared EXTERNAL in the calling
00800 !              program.
00801 !
00802 !              Subroutine JAC may access user-defined quantities in
00803 !              NEQ(2),... and/or in Y(NEQ(1)+1),... if NEQ is an array
00804 !              (dimensioned in JAC) and/or Y has length exceeding
00805 !              NEQ(1).  See the descriptions of NEQ and Y above.
00806 !
00807 !     MF       The method flag.  Used only for input.  The legal values
00808 !              of MF are 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24,
00809 !              and 25.  MF has decimal digits METH and MITER:
00810 !                 MF = 10*METH + MITER .
00811 !
00812 !              METH indicates the basic linear multistep method:
00813 !              1   Implicit Adams method.
00814 !              2   Method based on backward differentiation formulas
00815 !                  (BDF's).
00816 !
00817 !              MITER indicates the corrector iteration method:
00818 !              0   Functional iteration (no Jacobian matrix is
00819 !                  involved).
00820 !              1   Chord iteration with a user-supplied full (NEQ by
00821 !                  NEQ) Jacobian.
00822 !              2   Chord iteration with an internally generated
00823 !                  (difference quotient) full Jacobian (using NEQ
00824 !                  extra calls to F per df/dy value).
00825 !              3   Chord iteration with an internally generated
00826 !                  diagonal Jacobian approximation (using one extra call
00827 !                  to F per df/dy evaluation).
00828 !              4   Chord iteration with a user-supplied banded Jacobian.
00829 !              5   Chord iteration with an internally generated banded
00830 !                  Jacobian (using ML + MU + 1 extra calls to F per
00831 !                  df/dy evaluation).
00832 !
00833 !              If MITER = 1 or 4, the user must supply a subroutine JAC
00834 !              (the name is arbitrary) as described above under JAC.
00835 !              For other values of MITER, a dummy argument can be used.
00836 !
00837 !     Optional Inputs
00838 !     ---------------
00839 !     The following is a list of the optional inputs provided for in the
00840 !     call sequence.  (See also Part 2.)  For each such input variable,
00841 !     this table lists its name as used in this documentation, its
00842 !     location in the call sequence, its meaning, and the default value.
00843 !     The use of any of these inputs requires IOPT = 1, and in that case
00844 !     all of these inputs are examined.  A value of zero for any of
00845 !     these optional inputs will cause the default value to be used.
00846 !     Thus to use a subset of the optional inputs, simply preload
00847 !     locations 5 to 10 in RWORK and IWORK to 0.0 and 0 respectively,
00848 !     and then set those of interest to nonzero values.
00849 !
00850 !     Name    Location   Meaning and default value
00851 !     ------  ---------  -----------------------------------------------
00852 !     H0      RWORK(5)   Step size to be attempted on the first step.
00853 !                        The default value is determined by the solver.
00854 !     HMAX    RWORK(6)   Maximum absolute step size allowed.  The
00855 !                        default value is infinite.
00856 !     HMIN    RWORK(7)   Minimum absolute step size allowed.  The
00857 !                        default value is 0.  (This lower bound is not
00858 !                        enforced on the final step before reaching
00859 !                        TCRIT when ITASK = 4 or 5.)
00860 !     MAXORD  IWORK(5)   Maximum order to be allowed.  The default value
00861 !                        is 12 if METH = 1, and 5 if METH = 2. (See the
00862 !                        MF description above for METH.)  If MAXORD
00863 !                        exceeds the default value, it will be reduced
00864 !                        to the default value.  If MAXORD is changed
00865 !                        during the problem, it may cause the current
00866 !                        order to be reduced.
00867 !     MXSTEP  IWORK(6)   Maximum number of (internally defined) steps
00868 !                        allowed during one call to the solver.  The
00869 !                        default value is 500.
00870 !     MXHNIL  IWORK(7)   Maximum number of messages printed (per
00871 !                        problem) warning that T + H = T on a step
00872 !                        (H = step size).  This must be positive to
00873 !                        result in a nondefault value.  The default
00874 !                        value is 10.
00875 !
00876 !     Optional Outputs
00877 !     ----------------
00878 !     As optional additional output from DLSODE, the variables listed
00879 !     below are quantities related to the performance of DLSODE which 
00880 !     are available to the user.  These are communicated by way of the
00881 !     work arrays, but also have internal mnemonic names as shown. 
00882 !     Except where stated otherwise, all of these outputs are defined on
00883 !     any successful return from DLSODE, and on any return with ISTATE =
00884 !     -1, -2, -4, -5, or -6.  On an illegal input return (ISTATE = -3),
00885 !     they will be unchanged from their existing values (if any), except
00886 !     possibly for TOLSF, LENRW, and LENIW.  On any error return,
00887 !     outputs relevant to the error will be defined, as noted below.
00888 !
00889 !     Name   Location   Meaning
00890 !     -----  ---------  ------------------------------------------------
00891 !     HU     RWORK(11)  Step size in t last used (successfully).
00892 !     HCUR   RWORK(12)  Step size to be attempted on the next step.
00893 !     TCUR   RWORK(13)  Current value of the independent variable which
00894 !                       the solver has actually reached, i.e., the
00895 !                       current internal mesh point in t. On output,
00896 !                       TCUR will always be at least as far as the
00897 !                       argument T, but may be farther (if interpolation
00898 !                       was done).
00899 !     TOLSF  RWORK(14)  Tolerance scale factor, greater than 1.0,
00900 !                       computed when a request for too much accuracy
00901 !                       was detected (ISTATE = -3 if detected at the
00902 !                       start of the problem, ISTATE = -2 otherwise).
00903 !                       If ITOL is left unaltered but RTOL and ATOL are
00904 !                       uniformly scaled up by a factor of TOLSF for the
00905 !                       next call, then the solver is deemed likely to
00906 !                       succeed.  (The user may also ignore TOLSF and
00907 !                       alter the tolerance parameters in any other way
00908 !                       appropriate.)
00909 !     NST    IWORK(11)  Number of steps taken for the problem so far.
00910 !     NFE    IWORK(12)  Number of F evaluations for the problem so far.
00911 !     NJE    IWORK(13)  Number of Jacobian evaluations (and of matrix LU
00912 !                       decompositions) for the problem so far.
00913 !     NQU    IWORK(14)  Method order last used (successfully).
00914 !     NQCUR  IWORK(15)  Order to be attempted on the next step.
00915 !     IMXER  IWORK(16)  Index of the component of largest magnitude in
00916 !                       the weighted local error vector ( e(i)/EWT(i) ),
00917 !                       on an error return with ISTATE = -4 or -5.
00918 !     LENRW  IWORK(17)  Length of RWORK actually required.  This is
00919 !                       defined on normal returns and on an illegal
00920 !                       input return for insufficient storage.
00921 !     LENIW  IWORK(18)  Length of IWORK actually required.  This is
00922 !                       defined on normal returns and on an illegal
00923 !                       input return for insufficient storage.
00924 !
00925 !     The following two arrays are segments of the RWORK array which may
00926 !     also be of interest to the user as optional outputs.  For each
00927 !     array, the table below gives its internal name, its base address
00928 !     in RWORK, and its description.
00929 !
00930 !     Name  Base address  Description
00931 !     ----  ------------  ----------------------------------------------
00932 !     YH    21            The Nordsieck history array, of size NYH by
00933 !                         (NQCUR + 1), where NYH is the initial value of
00934 !                         NEQ.  For j = 0,1,...,NQCUR, column j + 1 of
00935 !                         YH contains HCUR**j/factorial(j) times the jth
00936 !                         derivative of the interpolating polynomial
00937 !                         currently representing the solution, evaluated
00938 !                         at t = TCUR.
00939 !     ACOR  LENRW-NEQ+1   Array of size NEQ used for the accumulated
00940 !                         corrections on each step, scaled on output to
00941 !                         represent the estimated local error in Y on
00942 !                         the last step.  This is the vector e in the
00943 !                         description of the error control.  It is
00944 !                         defined only on successful return from DLSODE.
00945 !
00946 !
00947 !                    Part 2.  Other Callable Routines
00948 !                    --------------------------------
00949 !
00950 !     The following are optional calls which the user may make to gain
00951 !     additional capabilities in conjunction with DLSODE.
00952 !
00953 !     Form of call              Function
00954 !     ------------------------  ----------------------------------------
00955 !     CALL XSETUN(LUN)          Set the logical unit number, LUN, for
00956 !                               output of messages from DLSODE, if the
00957 !                               default is not desired.  The default
00958 !                               value of LUN is 6. This call may be made
00959 !                               at any time and will take effect
00960 !                               immediately.
00961 !     CALL XSETF(MFLAG)         Set a flag to control the printing of
00962 !                               messages by DLSODE.  MFLAG = 0 means do
00963 !                               not print.  (Danger:  this risks losing
00964 !                               valuable information.)  MFLAG = 1 means
00965 !                               print (the default).  This call may be
00966 !                               made at any time and will take effect
00967 !                               immediately.
00968 !     CALL DSRCOM(RSAV,ISAV,JOB)  Saves and restores the contents of the
00969 !                               internal COMMON blocks used by DLSODE
00970 !                               (see Part 3 below).  RSAV must be a
00971 !                               real array of length 218 or more, and
00972 !                               ISAV must be an integer array of length
00973 !                               37 or more.  JOB = 1 means save COMMON
00974 !                               into RSAV/ISAV.  JOB = 2 means restore
00975 !                               COMMON from same.  DSRCOM is useful if
00976 !                               one is interrupting a run and restarting
00977 !                               later, or alternating between two or
00978 !                               more problems solved with DLSODE.
00979 !     CALL DINTDY(,,,,,)        Provide derivatives of y, of various
00980 !     (see below)               orders, at a specified point t, if
00981 !                               desired.  It may be called only after a
00982 !                               successful return from DLSODE.  Detailed
00983 !                               instructions follow.
00984 !
00985 !     Detailed instructions for using DINTDY
00986 !     --------------------------------------
00987 !     The form of the CALL is:
00988 !
00989 !           CALL DINTDY (T, K, RWORK(21), NYH, DKY, IFLAG)
00990 !
00991 !     The input parameters are:
00992 !
00993 !     T          Value of independent variable where answers are
00994 !                desired (normally the same as the T last returned by
00995 !                DLSODE).  For valid results, T must lie between
00996 !                TCUR - HU and TCUR.  (See "Optional Outputs" above
00997 !                for TCUR and HU.)
00998 !     K          Integer order of the derivative desired.  K must
00999 !                satisfy 0 <= K <= NQCUR, where NQCUR is the current
01000 !                order (see "Optional Outputs").  The capability
01001 !                corresponding to K = 0, i.e., computing y(t), is
01002 !                already provided by DLSODE directly.  Since
01003 !                NQCUR >= 1, the first derivative dy/dt is always
01004 !                available with DINTDY.
01005 !     RWORK(21)  The base address of the history array YH.
01006 !     NYH        Column length of YH, equal to the initial value of NEQ.
01007 !
01008 !     The output parameters are:
01009 !
01010 !     DKY        Real array of length NEQ containing the computed value
01011 !                of the Kth derivative of y(t).
01012 !     IFLAG      Integer flag, returned as 0 if K and T were legal,
01013 !                -1 if K was illegal, and -2 if T was illegal.
01014 !                On an error return, a message is also written.
01015 !
01016 !
01017 !                          Part 3.  Common Blocks
01018 !                          ----------------------
01019 !
01020 !     If DLSODE is to be used in an overlay situation, the user must
01021 !     declare, in the primary overlay, the variables in:
01022 !     (1) the call sequence to DLSODE,
01023 !     (2) the internal COMMON block /DLS001/, of length 255 
01024 !         (218 double precision words followed by 37 integer words).
01025 !
01026 !     If DLSODE is used on a system in which the contents of internal
01027 !     COMMON blocks are not preserved between calls, the user should
01028 !     declare the above COMMON block in his main program to insure that
01029 !     its contents are preserved.
01030 !
01031 !     If the solution of a given problem by DLSODE is to be interrupted
01032 !     and then later continued, as when restarting an interrupted run or
01033 !     alternating between two or more problems, the user should save,
01034 !     following the return from the last DLSODE call prior to the
01035 !     interruption, the contents of the call sequence variables and the
01036 !     internal COMMON block, and later restore these values before the
01037 !     next DLSODE call for that problem.   In addition, if XSETUN and/or
01038 !     XSETF was called for non-default handling of error messages, then
01039 !     these calls must be repeated.  To save and restore the COMMON
01040 !     block, use subroutine DSRCOM (see Part 2 above).
01041 !
01042 !
01043 !              Part 4.  Optionally Replaceable Solver Routines
01044 !              -----------------------------------------------
01045 !
01046 !     Below are descriptions of two routines in the DLSODE package which
01047 !     relate to the measurement of errors.  Either routine can be
01048 !     replaced by a user-supplied version, if desired.  However, since
01049 !     such a replacement may have a major impact on performance, it
01050 !     should be done only when absolutely necessary, and only with great
01051 !     caution.  (Note:  The means by which the package version of a
01052 !     routine is superseded by the user's version may be system-
01053 !     dependent.)
01054 !
01055 !     DEWSET
01056 !     ------
01057 !     The following subroutine is called just before each internal
01058 !     integration step, and sets the array of error weights, EWT, as
01059 !     described under ITOL/RTOL/ATOL above:
01060 !
01061 !           SUBROUTINE DEWSET (NEQ, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, YCUR, EWT)
01062 !
01063 !     where NEQ, ITOL, RTOL, and ATOL are as in the DLSODE call
01064 !     sequence, YCUR contains the current dependent variable vector,
01065 !     and EWT is the array of weights set by DEWSET.
01066 !
01067 !     If the user supplies this subroutine, it must return in EWT(i)
01068 !     (i = 1,...,NEQ) a positive quantity suitable for comparing errors
01069 !     in Y(i) to.  The EWT array returned by DEWSET is passed to the
01070 !     DVNORM routine (see below), and also used by DLSODE in the
01071 !     computation of the optional output IMXER, the diagonal Jacobian
01072 !     approximation, and the increments for difference quotient
01073 !     Jacobians.
01074 !
01075 !     In the user-supplied version of DEWSET, it may be desirable to use
01076 !     the current values of derivatives of y. Derivatives up to order NQ
01077 !     are available from the history array YH, described above under
01078 !     optional outputs.  In DEWSET, YH is identical to the YCUR array,
01079 !     extended to NQ + 1 columns with a column length of NYH and scale
01080 !     factors of H**j/factorial(j).  On the first call for the problem,
01081 !     given by NST = 0, NQ is 1 and H is temporarily set to 1.0.
01082 !     NYH is the initial value of NEQ.  The quantities NQ, H, and NST
01083 !     can be obtained by including in SEWSET the statements:
01084 !           DOUBLE PRECISION RLS
01085 !           COMMON /DLS001/ RLS(218),ILS(37)
01086 !           NQ = ILS(33)
01087 !           NST = ILS(34)
01088 !           H = RLS(212)
01089 !     Thus, for example, the current value of dy/dt can be obtained as
01090 !     YCUR(NYH+i)/H (i=1,...,NEQ) (and the division by H is unnecessary
01091 !     when NST = 0).
01092 !
01093 !     DVNORM
01094 !     ------
01095 !     DVNORM is a real function routine which computes the weighted
01096 !     root-mean-square norm of a vector v:
01097 !
01098 !        d = DVNORM (n, v, w)
01099 !
01100 !     where:
01101 !     n = the length of the vector,
01102 !     v = real array of length n containing the vector,
01103 !     w = real array of length n containing weights,
01104 !     d = SQRT( (1/n) * sum(v(i)*w(i))**2 ).
01105 !
01106 !     DVNORM is called with n = NEQ and with w(i) = 1.0/EWT(i), where
01107 !     EWT is as set by subroutine DEWSET.
01108 !
01109 !     If the user supplies this function, it should return a nonnegative
01110 !     value of DVNORM suitable for use in the error control in DLSODE.
01111 !     None of the arguments should be altered by DVNORM.  For example, a
01112 !     user-supplied DVNORM routine might:
01113 !     - Substitute a max-norm of (v(i)*w(i)) for the rms-norm, or
01114 !     - Ignore some components of v in the norm, with the effect of
01115 !       suppressing the error control on those components of Y.
01116 !  ---------------------------------------------------------------------
01117 !***ROUTINES CALLED  DEWSET, DINTDY, DUMACH, DSTODE, DVNORM, XERRWD
01118 !***COMMON BLOCKS    DLS001
01119 !***REVISION HISTORY  (YYYYMMDD)
01120 ! 19791129  DATE WRITTEN
01121 ! 19791213  Minor changes to declarations; DELP init. in STODE.
01122 ! 19800118  Treat NEQ as array; integer declarations added throughout;
01123 !           minor changes to prologue.
01124 ! 19800306  Corrected TESCO(1,NQP1) setting in CFODE.
01125 ! 19800519  Corrected access of YH on forced order reduction;
01126 !           numerous corrections to prologues and other comments.
01127 ! 19800617  In main driver, added loading of SQRT(UROUND) in RWORK;
01128 !           minor corrections to main prologue.
01129 ! 19800923  Added zero initialization of HU and NQU.
01130 ! 19801218  Revised XERRWD routine; minor corrections to main prologue.
01131 ! 19810401  Minor changes to comments and an error message.
01132 ! 19810814  Numerous revisions: replaced EWT by 1/EWT; used flags
01133 !           JCUR, ICF, IERPJ, IERSL between STODE and subordinates;
01134 !           added tuning parameters CCMAX, MAXCOR, MSBP, MXNCF;
01135 !           reorganized returns from STODE; reorganized type decls.;
01136 !           fixed message length in XERRWD; changed default LUNIT to 6;
01137 !           changed Common lengths; changed comments throughout.
01138 ! 19870330  Major update by ACH: corrected comments throughout;
01139 !           removed TRET from Common; rewrote EWSET with 4 loops;
01140 !           fixed t test in INTDY; added Cray directives in STODE;
01141 !           in STODE, fixed DELP init. and logic around PJAC call;
01142 !           combined routines to save/restore Common;
01143 !           passed LEVEL = 0 in error message calls (except run abort).
01144 ! 19890426  Modified prologue to SLATEC/LDOC format.  (FNF)
01145 ! 19890501  Many improvements to prologue.  (FNF)
01146 ! 19890503  A few final corrections to prologue.  (FNF)
01147 ! 19890504  Minor cosmetic changes.  (FNF)
01148 ! 19890510  Corrected description of Y in Arguments section.  (FNF)
01149 ! 19890517  Minor corrections to prologue.  (FNF)
01150 ! 19920514  Updated with prologue edited 891025 by G. Shaw for manual.
01151 ! 19920515  Converted source lines to upper case.  (FNF)
01152 ! 19920603  Revised XERRWD calls using mixed upper-lower case.  (ACH)
01153 ! 19920616  Revised prologue comment regarding CFT.  (ACH)
01154 ! 19921116  Revised prologue comments regarding Common.  (ACH).
01155 ! 19930326  Added comment about non-reentrancy.  (FNF)
01156 ! 19930723  Changed D1MACH to DUMACH. (FNF)
01157 ! 19930801  Removed ILLIN and NTREP from Common (affects driver logic);
01158 !           minor changes to prologue and internal comments;
01159 !           changed Hollerith strings to quoted strings; 
01160 !           changed internal comments to mixed case;
01161 !           replaced XERRWD with new version using character type;
01162 !           changed dummy dimensions from 1 to *. (ACH)
01163 ! 19930809  Changed to generic intrinsic names; changed names of
01164 !           subprograms and Common blocks to DLSODE etc. (ACH)
01165 ! 19930929  Eliminated use of REAL intrinsic; other minor changes. (ACH)
01166 ! 20010412  Removed all 'own' variables from Common block /DLS001/
01167 !           (affects declarations in 6 routines). (ACH)
01168 ! 20010509  Minor corrections to prologue. (ACH)
01169 ! 20031105  Restored 'own' variables to Common block /DLS001/, to
01170 !           enable interrupt/restart feature. (ACH)
01171 ! 20031112  Added SAVE statements for data-loaded constants.
01172 !
01173 !***END PROLOGUE  DLSODE
01174 !
01175 !*Internal Notes:
01176 !
01177 ! Other Routines in the DLSODE Package.
01178 !
01179 ! In addition to Subroutine DLSODE, the DLSODE package includes the
01180 ! following subroutines and function routines:
01181 !  DINTDY   computes an interpolated value of the y vector at t = TOUT.
01182 !  DSTODE   is the core integrator, which does one step of the
01183 !           integration and the associated error control.
01184 !  DCFODE   sets all method coefficients and test constants.
01185 !  DPREPJ   computes and preprocesses the Jacobian matrix J = df/dy
01186 !           and the Newton iteration matrix P = I - h*l0*J.
01187 !  DSOLSY   manages solution of linear system in chord iteration.
01188 !  DEWSET   sets the error weight vector EWT before each step.
01189 !  DVNORM   computes the weighted R.M.S. norm of a vector.
01190 !  DSRCOM   is a user-callable routine to save and restore
01191 !           the contents of the internal Common block.
01192 !  DGEFA and DGESL   are routines from LINPACK for solving full
01193 !           systems of linear algebraic equations.
01194 !  DGBFA and DGBSL   are routines from LINPACK for solving banded
01195 !           linear systems.
01196 !  DUMACH   computes the unit roundoff in a machine-independent manner.
01197 !  XERRWD, XSETUN, XSETF, IXSAV, IUMACH   handle the printing of all
01198 !           error messages and warnings.  XERRWD is machine-dependent.
01199 ! Note: DVNORM, DUMACH, IXSAV, and IUMACH are function routines.
01200 ! All the others are subroutines.
01201 !
01202 !**End
01203 !
01204 !  Declare externals.
01205 EXTERNAL DPREPJ, DSOLSY
01206 DOUBLE PRECISION DUMACH, DVNORM
01207 !
01208 !  Declare all other variables.
01209 INTEGER INIT, MXSTEP, MXHNIL, NHNIL, NSLAST, NYH, IOWNS, ICF, IERPJ, IERSL, JCUR, JSTART, KFLAG, L, LYH
01210 INTEGER LEWT, LACOR, LSAVF, LWM, LIWM, METH, MITER, MAXORD, MAXCOR, MSBP, MXNCF, N, NQ, NST, NFE, NJE, NQU
01211 INTEGER I, I1, I2, IFLAG, IMXER, KGO, LF0, LENIW, LENRW, LENWM, ML, MORD, MU, MXHNL0, MXSTP0
01212 DOUBLE PRECISION ROWNS, CCMAX, EL0, H, HMIN, HMXI, HU, RC, TN, UROUND
01213 DOUBLE PRECISION ATOLI, AYI, BIG, EWTI, H0, HMAX, HMX, RH, RTOLI, TCRIT, TDIST, TNEXT, TOL, TOLSF, TP, SIZE, SUM, W0
01214 DIMENSION MORD(2)
01215 LOGICAL IHIT
01216 character(len=80) MSG
01217 SAVE MORD, MXSTP0, MXHNL0
01218 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
01219 ! The following internal Common block contains
01220 ! (a) variables which are local to any subroutine but whose values must
01221 !     be preserved between calls to the routine ("own" variables), and
01222 ! (b) variables which are communicated between subroutines.
01223 ! The block DLS001 is declared in subroutines DLSODE, DINTDY, DSTODE,
01224 ! DPREPJ, and DSOLSY.
01225 ! Groups of variables are replaced by dummy arrays in the Common
01226 ! declarations in routines where those variables are not used.
01227 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
01228 COMMON /DLS001/ ROWNS(209), CCMAX, EL0, H, HMIN, HMXI, HU, RC, TN, UROUND, INIT, MXSTEP, MXHNIL, NHNIL, NSLAST, NYH, &
01229 IOWNS(6), ICF, IERPJ, IERSL, JCUR, JSTART, KFLAG, L, LYH, LEWT, LACOR, LSAVF, LWM, LIWM, METH, MITER, MAXORD, MAXCOR, &
01230 MSBP, MXNCF, N, NQ, NST, NFE, NJE, NQU
01231 !
01232 DATA  MORD(1),MORD(2)/12,5/, MXSTP0/500/, MXHNL0/10/
01233 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
01234 ! Block A.
01235 ! This code block is executed on every call.
01236 ! It tests ISTATE and ITASK for legality and branches appropriately.
01237 ! If ISTATE .GT. 1 but the flag INIT shows that initialization has
01238 ! not yet been done, an error return occurs.
01239 ! If ISTATE = 1 and TOUT = T, return immediately.
01240 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
01241 !
01242 !***FIRST EXECUTABLE STATEMENT  DLSODE
01243 IF (ISTATE .LT. 1 .OR. ISTATE .GT. 3) GOTO 601
01244 IF (ITASK .LT. 1 .OR. ITASK .GT. 5) GOTO 602
01245 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) GOTO 10
01246 IF (INIT .EQ. 0) GOTO 603
01247 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 2) GOTO 200
01248 GOTO 20
01249 10   INIT = 0
01250 IF (TOUT .EQ. T) RETURN
01251 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
01252 ! Block B.
01253 ! The next code block is executed for the initial call (ISTATE = 1),
01254 ! or for a continuation call with parameter changes (ISTATE = 3).
01255 ! It contains checking of all inputs and various initializations.
01256 !
01257 ! First check legality of the non-optional inputs NEQ, ITOL, IOPT,
01258 ! MF, ML, and MU.
01259 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
01260 20   IF (NEQ(1) .LE. 0) GOTO 604
01261 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) GOTO 25
01262 IF (NEQ(1) .GT. N) GOTO 605
01263 25   N = NEQ(1)
01264 IF (ITOL .LT. 1 .OR. ITOL .GT. 4) GOTO 606
01265 IF (IOPT .LT. 0 .OR. IOPT .GT. 1) GOTO 607
01266 METH = MF/10
01267 MITER = MF - 10*METH
01268 IF (METH .LT. 1 .OR. METH .GT. 2) GOTO 608
01269 IF (MITER .LT. 0 .OR. MITER .GT. 5) GOTO 608
01270 IF (MITER .LE. 3) GOTO 30
01271 ML = IWORK(1)
01272 MU = IWORK(2)
01273 IF (ML .LT. 0 .OR. ML .GE. N) GOTO 609
01274 IF (MU .LT. 0 .OR. MU .GE. N) GOTO 610
01275 30   CONTINUE
01276 ! Next process and check the optional inputs. --------------------------
01277 IF (IOPT .EQ. 1) GOTO 40
01278 MAXORD = MORD(METH)
01279 MXSTEP = MXSTP0
01280 MXHNIL = MXHNL0
01281 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) H0 = 0.0D0
01282 HMXI = 0.0D0
01283 HMIN = 0.0D0
01284 GOTO 60
01285 40   MAXORD = IWORK(5)
01286 IF (MAXORD .LT. 0) GOTO 611
01287 IF (MAXORD .EQ. 0) MAXORD = 100
01288 MAXORD = MIN(MAXORD,MORD(METH))
01289 MXSTEP = IWORK(6)
01290 IF (MXSTEP .LT. 0) GOTO 612
01291 IF (MXSTEP .EQ. 0) MXSTEP = MXSTP0
01292 MXHNIL = IWORK(7)
01293 IF (MXHNIL .LT. 0) GOTO 613
01294 IF (MXHNIL .EQ. 0) MXHNIL = MXHNL0
01295 IF (ISTATE .NE. 1) GOTO 50
01296 H0 = RWORK(5)
01297 IF ((TOUT - T)*H0 .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 614
01298 50   HMAX = RWORK(6)
01299 IF (HMAX .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 615
01300 HMXI = 0.0D0
01301 IF (HMAX .GT. 0.0D0) HMXI = 1.0D0/HMAX
01302 HMIN = RWORK(7)
01303 IF (HMIN .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 616
01304 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
01305 ! Set work array pointers and check lengths LRW and LIW.
01306 ! Pointers to segments of RWORK and IWORK are named by prefixing L to
01307 ! the name of the segment.  E.g., the segment YH starts at RWORK(LYH).
01308 ! Segments of RWORK (in order) are denoted  YH, WM, EWT, SAVF, ACOR.
01309 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
01310 60   LYH = 21
01311 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) NYH = N
01312 LWM = LYH + (MAXORD + 1)*NYH
01313 IF (MITER .EQ. 0) LENWM = 0
01314 IF (MITER .EQ. 1 .OR. MITER .EQ. 2) LENWM = N*N + 2
01315 IF (MITER .EQ. 3) LENWM = N + 2
01316 IF (MITER .GE. 4) LENWM = (2*ML + MU + 1)*N + 2
01317 LEWT = LWM + LENWM
01318 LSAVF = LEWT + N
01319 LACOR = LSAVF + N
01320 LENRW = LACOR + N - 1
01321 IWORK(17) = LENRW
01322 LIWM = 1
01323 LENIW = 20 + N
01324 IF (MITER .EQ. 0 .OR. MITER .EQ. 3) LENIW = 20
01325 IWORK(18) = LENIW
01326 IF (LENRW .GT. LRW) GOTO 617
01327 IF (LENIW .GT. LIW) GOTO 618
01328 ! Check RTOL and ATOL for legality. ------------------------------------
01329 RTOLI = RTOL(1)
01330 ATOLI = ATOL(1)
01331 DO 70 I = 1,N
01332 IF (ITOL .GE. 3) RTOLI = RTOL(I)
01333 IF (ITOL .EQ. 2 .OR. ITOL .EQ. 4) ATOLI = ATOL(I)
01334 IF (RTOLI .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 619
01335 IF (ATOLI .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 620
01336 70     CONTINUE
01337 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) GOTO 100
01338 ! If ISTATE = 3, set flag to signal parameter changes to DSTODE. -------
01339 JSTART = -1
01340 IF (NQ .LE. MAXORD) GOTO 90
01341 ! MAXORD was reduced below NQ.  Copy YH(*,MAXORD+2) into SAVF. ---------
01342 DO 80 I = 1,N
01343 80     RWORK(I+LSAVF-1) = RWORK(I+LWM-1)
01344 ! Reload WM(1) = RWORK(LWM), since LWM may have changed. ---------------
01345 90   IF (MITER .GT. 0) RWORK(LWM) = SQRT(UROUND)
01346 IF (N .EQ. NYH) GOTO 200
01347 ! NEQ was reduced.  Zero part of YH to avoid undefined references. -----
01348 I1 = LYH + L*NYH
01349 I2 = LYH + (MAXORD + 1)*NYH - 1
01350 IF (I1 .GT. I2) GOTO 200
01351 DO 95 I = I1,I2
01352 95     RWORK(I) = 0.0D0
01353 GOTO 200
01354 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
01355 ! Block C.
01356 ! The next block is for the initial call only (ISTATE = 1).
01357 ! It contains all remaining initializations, the initial call to F,
01358 ! and the calculation of the initial step size.
01359 ! The error weights in EWT are inverted after being loaded.
01360 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
01361 100  UROUND = DUMACH()
01362 TN = T
01363 IF (ITASK .NE. 4 .AND. ITASK .NE. 5) GOTO 110
01364 TCRIT = RWORK(1)
01365 IF ((TCRIT - TOUT)*(TOUT - T) .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 625
01366 IF (H0 .NE. 0.0D0 .AND. (T + H0 - TCRIT)*H0 .GT. 0.0D0) H0 = TCRIT - T
01367 110  JSTART = 0
01368 IF (MITER .GT. 0) RWORK(LWM) = SQRT(UROUND)
01369 NHNIL = 0
01370 NST = 0
01371 NJE = 0
01372 NSLAST = 0
01373 HU = 0.0D0
01374 NQU = 0
01375 CCMAX = 0.3D0
01376 MAXCOR = 3
01377 MSBP = 20
01378 MXNCF = 10
01379 ! Initial call to F.  (LF0 points to YH(*,2).) -------------------------
01380 LF0 = LYH + NYH
01381 CALL F (NEQ, T, Y, RWORK(LF0))
01382 NFE = 1
01383 ! Load the initial value vector in YH. ---------------------------------
01384 DO 115 I = 1,N
01385 115    RWORK(I+LYH-1) = Y(I)
01386 ! Load and invert the EWT array.  (H is temporarily set to 1.0.) -------
01387 NQ = 1
01388 H = 1.0D0
01389 CALL DEWSET (N, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LEWT))
01390 DO 120 I = 1,N
01391 IF (RWORK(I+LEWT-1) .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 621
01392 120    RWORK(I+LEWT-1) = 1.0D0/RWORK(I+LEWT-1)
01393 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
01394 ! The coding below computes the step size, H0, to be attempted on the
01395 ! first step, unless the user has supplied a value for this.
01396 ! First check that TOUT - T differs significantly from zero.
01397 ! A scalar tolerance quantity TOL is computed, as MAX(RTOL(I))
01398 ! if this is positive, or MAX(ATOL(I)/ABS(Y(I))) otherwise, adjusted
01399 ! so as to be between 100*UROUND and 1.0E-3.
01400 ! Then the computed value H0 is given by..
01401 !                                      NEQ
01402 !   H0**2 = TOL / ( w0**-2 + (1/NEQ) * SUM ( f(i)/ywt(i) )**2  )
01403 !                                       1
01404 ! where   w0     = MAX ( ABS(T), ABS(TOUT) ),
01405 !         f(i)   = i-th component of initial value of f,
01406 !         ywt(i) = EWT(i)/TOL  (a weight for y(i)).
01407 ! The sign of H0 is inferred from the initial values of TOUT and T.
01408 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
01409 IF (H0 .NE. 0.0D0) GOTO 180
01410 TDIST = ABS(TOUT - T)
01411 W0 = MAX(ABS(T),ABS(TOUT))
01412 IF (TDIST .LT. 2.0D0*UROUND*W0) GOTO 622
01413 TOL = RTOL(1)
01414 IF (ITOL .LE. 2) GOTO 140
01415 DO 130 I = 1,N
01416 130    TOL = MAX(TOL,RTOL(I))
01417 140  IF (TOL .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 160
01418 ATOLI = ATOL(1)
01419 DO 150 I = 1,N
01420 IF (ITOL .EQ. 2 .OR. ITOL .EQ. 4) ATOLI = ATOL(I)
01421 AYI = ABS(Y(I))
01422 IF (AYI .NE. 0.0D0) TOL = MAX(TOL,ATOLI/AYI)
01423 150    CONTINUE
01424 160  TOL = MAX(TOL,100.0D0*UROUND)
01425 TOL = MIN(TOL,0.001D0)
01426 SUM = DVNORM (N, RWORK(LF0), RWORK(LEWT))
01427 SUM = 1.0D0/(TOL*W0*W0) + TOL*SUM**2
01428 H0 = 1.0D0/SQRT(SUM)
01429 H0 = MIN(H0,TDIST)
01430 H0 = SIGN(H0,TOUT-T)
01431 ! Adjust H0 if necessary to meet HMAX bound. ---------------------------
01432 180  RH = ABS(H0)*HMXI
01433 IF (RH .GT. 1.0D0) H0 = H0/RH
01434 ! Load H with H0 and scale YH(*,2) by H0. ------------------------------
01435 H = H0
01436 DO 190 I = 1,N
01437 190    RWORK(I+LF0-1) = H0*RWORK(I+LF0-1)
01438 GOTO 270
01439 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
01440 ! Block D.
01441 ! The next code block is for continuation calls only (ISTATE = 2 or 3)
01442 ! and is to check stop conditions before taking a step.
01443 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
01444 200  NSLAST = NST
01445 GOTO (210, 250, 220, 230, 240), ITASK
01446 210  IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
01447 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
01448 IF (IFLAG .NE. 0) GOTO 627
01449 T = TOUT
01450 GOTO 420
01451 220  TP = TN - HU*(1.0D0 + 100.0D0*UROUND)
01452 IF ((TP - TOUT)*H .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 623
01453 IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
01454 GOTO 400
01455 230  TCRIT = RWORK(1)
01456 IF ((TN - TCRIT)*H .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 624
01457 IF ((TCRIT - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 625
01458 IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 245
01459 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
01460 IF (IFLAG .NE. 0) GOTO 627
01461 T = TOUT
01462 GOTO 420
01463 240  TCRIT = RWORK(1)
01464 IF ((TN - TCRIT)*H .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 624
01465 245  HMX = ABS(TN) + ABS(H)
01466 IHIT = ABS(TN - TCRIT) .LE. 100.0D0*UROUND*HMX
01467 IF (IHIT) GOTO 400
01468 TNEXT = TN + H*(1.0D0 + 4.0D0*UROUND)
01469 IF ((TNEXT - TCRIT)*H .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
01470 H = (TCRIT - TN)*(1.0D0 - 4.0D0*UROUND)
01471 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 2) JSTART = -2
01472 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
01473 ! Block E.
01474 ! The next block is normally executed for all calls and contains
01475 ! the call to the one-step core integrator DSTODE.
01476 !
01477 ! This is a looping point for the integration steps.
01478 !
01479 ! First check for too many steps being taken, update EWT (if not at
01480 ! start of problem), check for too much accuracy being requested, and
