07535 !              1     scalar     scalar     RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL
07536 !              2     scalar     array      RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i)
07537 !              3     array      scalar     RTOL(i)*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL
07538 !              4     array      array      RTOL(i)*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i)
07539 !
07540 !          When either of these parameters is a scalar, it need not
07541 !          be dimensioned in the user's calling program.
07542 !
07543 !          If none of the above choices (with ITOL, RTOL, and ATOL
07544 !          fixed throughout the problem) is suitable, more general
07545 !          error controls can be obtained by substituting
07546 !          user-supplied routines for the setting of EWT and/or for
07547 !          the norm calculation.  See Part 4 below.
07548 !
07549 !          If global errors are to be estimated by making a repeated
07550 !          run on the same problem with smaller tolerances, then all
07551 !          components of RTOL and ATOL (i.e. of EWT) should be scaled
07552 !          down uniformly.
07553 !
07554 ! ITASK  = an index specifying the task to be performed.
07555 !          Input only.  ITASK has the following values and meanings.
07556 !          1  means normal computation of output values of y(t) at
07557 !             t = TOUT (by overshooting and interpolating).
07558 !          2  means take one step only and return.
07559 !          3  means stop at the first internal mesh point at or
07560 !             beyond t = TOUT and return.
07561 !          4  means normal computation of output values of y(t) at
07562 !             t = TOUT but without overshooting t = TCRIT.
07563 !             TCRIT must be input as RWORK(1).  TCRIT may be equal to
07564 !             or beyond TOUT, but not behind it in the direction of
07565 !             integration.  This option is useful if the problem
07566 !             has a singularity at or beyond t = TCRIT.
07567 !          5  means take one step, without passing TCRIT, and return.
07568 !             TCRIT must be input as RWORK(1).
07569 !
07570 !          Note:  If ITASK = 4 or 5 and the solver reaches TCRIT
07571 !          (within roundoff), it will return T = TCRIT (exactly) to
07572 !          indicate this (unless ITASK = 4 and TOUT comes before TCRIT,
07573 !          in which case answers at t = TOUT are returned first).
07574 !
07575 ! ISTATE = an index used for input and output to specify the
07576 !          the state of the calculation.
07577 !
07578 !          On input, the values of ISTATE are as follows.
07579 !          1  means this is the first call for the problem
07580 !             (initializations will be done).  See note below.
07581 !          2  means this is not the first call, and the calculation
07582 !             is to continue normally, with no change in any input
07583 !             parameters except possibly TOUT and ITASK.
07584 !             (If ITOL, RTOL, and/or ATOL are changed between calls
07585 !             with ISTATE = 2, the new values will be used but not
07586 !             tested for legality.)
07587 !          3  means this is not the first call, and the
07588 !             calculation is to continue normally, but with
07589 !             a change in input parameters other than
07590 !             TOUT and ITASK.  Changes are allowed in
07591 !             NEQ, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, IOPT, LRW, LIW, MF,
07592 !             and any of the optional inputs except H0.
07593 !          Note:  A preliminary call with TOUT = T is not counted
07594 !          as a first call here, as no initialization or checking of
07595 !          input is done.  (Such a call is sometimes useful for the
07596 !          purpose of outputting the initial conditions.)
07597 !          Thus the first call for which TOUT .ne. T requires
07598 !          ISTATE = 1 on input.
07599 !
07600 !          On output, ISTATE has the following values and meanings.
07601 !           1  means nothing was done; TOUT = T and ISTATE = 1 on input.
07602 !           2  means the integration was performed successfully.
07603 !          -1  means an excessive amount of work (more than MXSTEP
07604 !              steps) was done on this call, before completing the
07605 !              requested task, but the integration was otherwise
07606 !              successful as far as T.  (MXSTEP is an optional input
07607 !              and is normally 500.)  To continue, the user may
07608 !              simply reset ISTATE to a value .gt. 1 and call again
07609 !              (the excess work step counter will be reset to 0).
07610 !              In addition, the user may increase MXSTEP to avoid
07611 !              this error return (see below on optional inputs).
07612 !          -2  means too much accuracy was requested for the precision
07613 !              of the machine being used.  This was detected before
07614 !              completing the requested task, but the integration
07615 !              was successful as far as T.  To continue, the tolerance
07616 !              parameters must be reset, and ISTATE must be set
07617 !              to 3.  The optional output TOLSF may be used for this
07618 !              purpose.  (Note: If this condition is detected before
07619 !              taking any steps, then an illegal input return
07620 !              (ISTATE = -3) occurs instead.)
07621 !          -3  means illegal input was detected, before taking any
07622 !              integration steps.  See written message for details.
07623 !              Note:  If the solver detects an infinite loop of calls
07624 !              to the solver with illegal input, it will cause
07625 !              the run to stop.
07626 !          -4  means there were repeated error test failures on
07627 !              one attempted step, before completing the requested
07628 !              task, but the integration was successful as far as T.
07629 !              The problem may have a singularity, or the input
07630 !              may be inappropriate.
07631 !          -5  means there were repeated convergence test failures on
07632 !              one attempted step, before completing the requested
07633 !              task, but the integration was successful as far as T.
07634 !          -6  means EWT(i) became zero for some i during the
07635 !              integration.  Pure relative error control (ATOL(i)=0.0)
07636 !              was requested on a variable which has now vanished.
07637 !              The integration was successful as far as T.
07638 !          -7  means the PSOL routine returned an unrecoverable error
07639 !              flag (IER .lt. 0).  The integration was successful as
07640 !              far as T.
07641 !
07642 !          Note:  since the normal output value of ISTATE is 2,
07643 !          it does not need to be reset for normal continuation.
07644 !          Also, since a negative input value of ISTATE will be
07645 !          regarded as illegal, a negative output value requires the
07646 !          user to change it, and possibly other inputs, before
07647 !          calling the solver again.
07648 !
07649 ! IOPT   = an integer flag to specify whether or not any optional
07650 !          inputs are being used on this call.  Input only.
07651 !          The optional inputs are listed separately below.
07652 !          IOPT = 0 means no optional inputs are being used.
07653 !                   Default values will be used in all cases.
07654 !          IOPT = 1 means one or more optional inputs are being used.
07655 !
07656 ! RWORK  = a real working array (double precision).
07657 !          The length of RWORK must be at least
07658 !             20 + NYH*(MAXORD + 1) + 3*NEQ + LENLS + LWP    where
07659 !          NYH    = the initial value of NEQ,
07660 !          MAXORD = 12 (if METH = 1) or 5 (if METH = 2) (unless a
07661 !                   smaller value is given as an optional input),
07662 !          LENLS = length of work space for linear system (Krylov)
07663 !                  method, excluding preconditioning:
07664 !            LENLS = 0                               if MITER = 0,
07665 !            LENLS = NEQ*(MAXL+3) + MAXL**2          if MITER = 1,
07666 !            LENLS = NEQ*(MAXL+3+MIN(1,MAXL-KMP))
07667 !                 + (MAXL+3)*MAXL + 1                if MITER = 2,
07668 !            LENLS = 6*NEQ                           if MITER = 3 or 4,
07669 !            LENLS = 3*NEQ                           if MITER = 9.
07670 !          (See the MF description for METH and MITER, and the
07671 !          list of optional inputs for MAXL and KMP.)
07672 !          LWP = length of real user work space for preconditioning
07673 !          (see JAC/PSOL).
07674 !          Thus if default values are used and NEQ is constant,
07675 !          this length is:
07676 !             20 + 16*NEQ           for MF = 10,
07677 !             45 + 24*NEQ + LWP     FOR MF = 11,
07678 !             61 + 24*NEQ + LWP     FOR MF = 12,
07679 !             20 + 22*NEQ + LWP     FOR MF = 13 OR 14,
07680 !             20 + 19*NEQ + LWP     FOR MF = 19,
07681 !             20 + 9*NEQ            FOR MF = 20,
07682 !             45 + 17*NEQ + LWP     FOR MF = 21,
07683 !             61 + 17*NEQ + LWP     FOR MF = 22,
07684 !             20 + 15*NEQ + LWP     FOR MF = 23 OR 24,
07685 !             20 + 12*NEQ + LWP     for MF = 29.
07686 !          The first 20 words of RWORK are reserved for conditional
07687 !          and optional inputs and optional outputs.
07688 !
07689 !          The following word in RWORK is a conditional input:
07690 !            RWORK(1) = TCRIT = critical value of t which the solver
07691 !                       is not to overshoot.  Required if ITASK is
07692 !                       4 or 5, and ignored otherwise.  (See ITASK.)
07693 !
07694 ! LRW    = the length of the array RWORK, as declared by the user.
07695 !          (This will be checked by the solver.)
07696 !
07697 ! IWORK  = an integer work array.  The length of IWORK must be at least
07698 !             30                 if MITER = 0 (MF = 10 or 20),
07699 !             30 + MAXL + LIWP   if MITER = 1 (MF = 11, 21),
07700 !             30 + LIWP          if MITER = 2, 3, 4, or 9.
07701 !          MAXL = 5 unless a different optional input value is given.
07702 !          LIWP = length of integer user work space for preconditioning
07703 !          (see conditional input list following).
07704 !          The first few words of IWORK are used for conditional and
07705 !          optional inputs and optional outputs.
07706 !
07707 !          The following 4 words in IWORK are conditional inputs,
07708 !          required if MITER .ge. 1:
07709 !          IWORK(1) = LWP  = length of real array WP for use in
07710 !                     preconditioning (part of RWORK array).
07711 !          IWORK(2) = LIWP = length of integer array IWP for use in
07712 !                     preconditioning (part of IWORK array).
07713 !                     The arrays WP and IWP are work arrays under the
07714 !                     user's control, for use in the routines that
07715 !                     perform preconditioning operations (JAC and PSOL).
07716 !          IWORK(3) = JPRE = preconditioner type flag:
07717 !                   = 0 for no preconditioning (P1 = P2 = P = identity)
07718 !                   = 1 for left-only preconditioning (P2 = identity)
07719 !                   = 2 for right-only preconditioning (P1 = identity)
07720 !                   = 3 for two-sided preconditioning (and PCG or PCGS)
07721 !          IWORK(4) = JACFLG = flag for whether JAC is called.
07722 !                   = 0 if JAC is not to be called,
07723 !                   = 1 if JAC is to be called.
07724 !                     Use JACFLG = 1 if JAC computes any nonconstant
07725 !                     data needed in preconditioning operations,
07726 !                     such as some of the Jacobian elements.
07727 !
07728 ! LIW    = the length of the array IWORK, as declared by the user.
07729 !          (This will be checked by the solver.)
07730 !
07731 ! Note:  The work arrays must not be altered between calls to DLSODPK
07732 ! for the same problem, except possibly for the conditional and
07733 ! optional inputs, and except for the last 3*NEQ words of RWORK.
07734 ! The latter space is used for internal scratch space, and so is
07735 ! available for use by the user outside DLSODPK between calls, if
07736 ! desired (but not for use by any of the user-supplied subroutines).
07737 !
07738 ! JAC    = the name of the user-supplied routine to compute any
07739 !          Jacobian elements (or approximations) involved in the
07740 !          matrix preconditioning operations (MITER .ge. 1).
07741 !          It is to have the form
07742 !            SUBROUTINE JAC (F, NEQ, T, Y, YSV, REWT, FTY, V,
07743 !           1                HL0, WP, IWP, IER)
07744 !            DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*),YSV(*), REWT(*), FTY(*), V(*),
07745 !           1                 HL0, WP(*)
07746 !            INTEGER IWP(*)
07747 !          This routine must evaluate and preprocess any parts of the
07748 !          Jacobian matrix df/dy used in the preconditioners P1, P2, P.
07749 !          the Y and FTY arrays contain the current values of y and
07750 !          f(t,y), respectively, and YSV also contains the current
07751 !          value of y.  The array V is work space of length
07752 !          NEQ for use by JAC.  REWT is the array of reciprocal error
07753 !          weights (1/EWT).  JAC must multiply all computed Jacobian
07754 !          elements by the scalar -HL0, add the identity matrix, and do
07755 !          any factorization operations called for, in preparation
07756 !          for solving linear systems with a coefficient matrix of
07757 !          P1, P2, or P.  The matrix P1*P2 or P should be an
07758 !          approximation to  identity - HL0 * (df/dy).  JAC should
07759 !          return IER = 0 if successful, and IER .ne. 0 if not.
07760 !          (If IER .ne. 0, a smaller time step will be tried.)
07761 !          The arrays WP (of length LWP) and IWP (of length LIWP)
07762 !          are for use by JAC and PSOL for work space and for storage
07763 !          of data needed for the solution of the preconditioner
07764 !          linear systems.  Their lengths and contents are under the
07765 !          user's control.
07766 !          The JAC routine may save relevant Jacobian elements (or
07767 !          approximations) used in the preconditioners, along with the
07768 !          value of HL0, and use these to reconstruct preconditioner
07769 !          matrices later without reevaluationg those elements.
07770 !          This may be cost-effective if JAC is called with HL0
07771 !          considerably different from its earlier value, indicating
07772 !          that a corrector convergence failure has occurred because
07773 !          of the change in HL0, not because of changes in the
07774 !          value of the Jacobian.  In doing this, use the saved and
07775 !          current values of HL0 to decide whether to use saved
07776 !          or reevaluated elements.
07777 !          JAC may alter V, but may not alter Y, YSV, REWT, FTY, or HL0.
07778 !          JAC must be declared External in the calling program.
07779 !               Subroutine JAC may access user-defined quantities in
07780 !          NEQ(2),... and/or in Y(NEQ(1)+1),... if NEQ is an array
07781 !          (dimensioned in JAC) and/or Y has length exceeding NEQ(1).
07782 !          See the descriptions of NEQ and Y above.
07783 !
07784 ! PSOL   = the name of the user-supplied routine for the
07785 !          solution of preconditioner linear systems.
07786 !          It is to have the form
07787 !            SUBROUTINE PSOL (NEQ, T, Y, FTY, WK,HL0, WP,IWP, B, LR,IER)
07788 !            DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), FTY(*), WK(*), HL0, WP(*), B(*)
07789 !            INTEGER IWP(*)
07790 !          This routine must solve a linear system with B as right-hand
07791 !          side and one of the preconditioning matrices, P1, P2, or P,
07792 !          as coefficient matrix, and return the solution vector in B.
07793 !          LR is a flag concerning left vs right preconditioning, input
07794 !          to PSOL.  PSOL is to use P1 if LR = 1 and P2 if LR = 2.
07795 !          In the case of the PCG or PCGS method, LR will be 3, and PSOL
07796 !          should solve the system P*x = B with the preconditioner P.
07797 !          In the case MITER = 9 (no Krylov iteration), LR will be 0,
07798 !          and PSOL is to return in B the desired approximate solution
07799 !          to A * x = B, where A = identity - HL0 * (df/dy).
07800 !          PSOL can use data generated in the JAC routine and stored in
07801 !          WP and IWP.
07802 !          The Y and FTY arrays contain the current values of y and
07803 !          f(t,y), respectively.  The array WK is work space of length
07804 !          NEQ for use by PSOL.
07805 !          The argument HL0 is the current value of the scalar appearing
07806 !          in the linear system.  If the old value, as of the last
07807 !          JAC call, is needed, it must have been saved by JAC in WP.
07808 !          On return, PSOL should set the error flag IER as follows:
07809 !            IER = 0 if PSOL was successful,
07810 !            IER .gt. 0 on a recoverable error, meaning that the
07811 !                   time step will be retried,
07812 !            IER .lt. 0 on an unrecoverable error, meaning that the
07813 !                   solver is to stop immediately.
07814 !          PSOL may not alter Y, FTY, or HL0.
07815 !          PSOL must be declared External in the calling program.
07816 !               Subroutine PSOL may access user-defined quantities in
07817 !          NEQ(2),... and Y(NEQ(1)+1),... if NEQ is an array
07818 !          (dimensioned in PSOL) and/or Y has length exceeding NEQ(1).
07819 !          See the descriptions of NEQ and Y above.
07820 !
07821 ! MF     = the method flag.  Used only for input.  The legal values of
07822 !          MF are 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, and 29.
07823 !          MF has decimal digits METH and MITER: MF = 10*METH + MITER.
07824 !          METH indicates the basic linear multistep method:
07825 !            METH = 1 means the implicit Adams method.
07826 !            METH = 2 means the method based on Backward
07827 !                     Differentiation Formulas (BDFs).
07828 !          MITER indicates the corrector iteration method:
07829 !            MITER = 0 means functional iteration (no linear system
07830 !                      is involved).
07831 !            MITER = 1 means Newton iteration with Scaled Preconditioned
07832 !                      Incomplete Orthogonalization Method (SPIOM)
07833 !                      for the linear systems.
07834 !            MITER = 2 means Newton iteration with Scaled Preconditioned
07835 !                      Generalized Minimal Residual method (SPIGMR)
07836 !                      for the linear systems.
07837 !            MITER = 3 means Newton iteration with Preconditioned
07838 !                      Conjugate Gradient method (PCG)
07839 !                      for the linear systems.
07840 !            MITER = 4 means Newton iteration with scaled Preconditioned
07841 !                      Conjugate Gradient method (PCGS)
07842 !                      for the linear systems.
07843 !            MITER = 9 means Newton iteration with only the
07844 !                      user-supplied PSOL routine called (no Krylov
07845 !                      iteration) for the linear systems.
07846 !                      JPRE is ignored, and PSOL is called with LR = 0.
07847 !          See comments in the introduction about the choice of MITER.
07848 !          If MITER .ge. 1, the user must supply routines JAC and PSOL
07849 !          (the names are arbitrary) as described above.
07850 !          For MITER = 0, dummy arguments can be used.
07851 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
07852 ! Optional Inputs.
07853 !
07854 ! The following is a list of the optional inputs provided for in the
07855 ! call sequence.  (See also Part 2.)  For each such input variable,
07856 ! this table lists its name as used in this documentation, its
07857 ! location in the call sequence, its meaning, and the default value.
07858 ! The use of any of these inputs requires IOPT = 1, and in that
07859 ! case all of these inputs are examined.  A value of zero for any
07860 ! of these optional inputs will cause the default value to be used.
07861 ! Thus to use a subset of the optional inputs, simply preload
07862 ! locations 5 to 10 in RWORK and IWORK to 0.0 and 0 respectively, and
07863 ! then set those of interest to nonzero values.
07864 !
07865 ! Name    Location      Meaning and Default Value
07866 !
07867 ! H0      RWORK(5)  the step size to be attempted on the first step.
07868 !                   The default value is determined by the solver.
07869 !
07870 ! HMAX    RWORK(6)  the maximum absolute step size allowed.
07871 !                   The default value is infinite.
07872 !
07873 ! HMIN    RWORK(7)  the minimum absolute step size allowed.
07874 !                   The default value is 0.  (This lower bound is not
07875 !                   enforced on the final step before reaching TCRIT
07876 !                   when ITASK = 4 or 5.)
07877 !
07878 ! DELT    RWORK(8)  convergence test constant in Krylov iteration
07879 !                   algorithm.  The default is .05.
07880 !
07881 ! MAXORD  IWORK(5)  the maximum order to be allowed.  The default
07882 !                   value is 12 if METH = 1, and 5 if METH = 2.
07883 !                   If MAXORD exceeds the default value, it will
07884 !                   be reduced to the default value.
07885 !                   If MAXORD is changed during the problem, it may
07886 !                   cause the current order to be reduced.
07887 !
07888 ! MXSTEP  IWORK(6)  maximum number of (internally defined) steps
07889 !                   allowed during one call to the solver.
07890 !                   The default value is 500.
07891 !
07892 ! MXHNIL  IWORK(7)  maximum number of messages printed (per problem)
07893 !                   warning that T + H = T on a step (H = step size).
07894 !                   This must be positive to result in a non-default
07895 !                   value.  The default value is 10.
07896 !
07897 ! MAXL    IWORK(8)  maximum number of iterations in the SPIOM, SPIGMR,
07898 !                   PCG, or PCGS algorithm (.le. NEQ).
07899 !                   The default is MAXL = MIN(5,NEQ).
07900 !
07901 ! KMP     IWORK(9)  number of vectors on which orthogonalization
07902 !                   is done in SPIOM or SPIGMR algorithm (.le. MAXL).
07903 !                   The default is KMP = MAXL.
07904 !                   Note:  When KMP .lt. MAXL and MF = 22, the length
07905 !                          of RWORK must be defined accordingly.  See
07906 !                          the definition of RWORK above.
07907 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
07908 ! Optional Outputs.
07909 !
07910 ! As optional additional output from DLSODPK, the variables listed
07911 ! below are quantities related to the performance of DLSODPK
07912 ! which are available to the user.  These are communicated by way of
07913 ! the work arrays, but also have internal mnemonic names as shown.
07914 ! Except where stated otherwise, all of these outputs are defined
07915 ! on any successful return from DLSODPK, and on any return with
07916 ! ISTATE = -1, -2, -4, -5, -6, or -7.  On an illegal input return
07917 ! (ISTATE = -3), they will be unchanged from their existing values
07918 ! (if any), except possibly for TOLSF, LENRW, and LENIW.
07919 ! On any error return, outputs relevant to the error will be defined,
07920 ! as noted below.
07921 !
07922 ! Name    Location      Meaning
07923 !
07924 ! HU      RWORK(11) the step size in t last used (successfully).
07925 !
07926 ! HCUR    RWORK(12) the step size to be attempted on the next step.
07927 !
07928 ! TCUR    RWORK(13) the current value of the independent variable
07929 !                   which the solver has actually reached, i.e. the
07930 !                   current internal mesh point in t.  On output, TCUR
07931 !                   will always be at least as far as the argument
07932 !                   T, but may be farther (if interpolation was done).
07933 !
07934 ! TOLSF   RWORK(14) a tolerance scale factor, greater than 1.0,
07935 !                   computed when a request for too much accuracy was
07936 !                   detected (ISTATE = -3 if detected at the start of
07937 !                   the problem, ISTATE = -2 otherwise).  If ITOL is
07938 !                   left unaltered but RTOL and ATOL are uniformly
07939 !                   scaled up by a factor of TOLSF for the next call,
07940 !                   then the solver is deemed likely to succeed.
07941 !                   (The user may also ignore TOLSF and alter the
07942 !                   tolerance parameters in any other way appropriate.)
07943 !
07944 ! NST     IWORK(11) the number of steps taken for the problem so far.
07945 !
07946 ! NFE     IWORK(12) the number of f evaluations for the problem so far.
07947 !
07948 ! NPE     IWORK(13) the number of calls to JAC so far (for Jacobian
07949 !                   evaluation associated with preconditioning).
07950 !
07951 ! NQU     IWORK(14) the method order last used (successfully).
07952 !
07953 ! NQCUR   IWORK(15) the order to be attempted on the next step.
07954 !
07955 ! IMXER   IWORK(16) the index of the component of largest magnitude in
07956 !                   the weighted local error vector ( E(i)/EWT(i) ),
07957 !                   on an error return with ISTATE = -4 or -5.
07958 !
07959 ! LENRW   IWORK(17) the length of RWORK actually required.
07960 !                   This is defined on normal returns and on an illegal
07961 !                   input return for insufficient storage.
07962 !
07963 ! LENIW   IWORK(18) the length of IWORK actually required.
07964 !                   This is defined on normal returns and on an illegal
07965 !                   input return for insufficient storage.
07966 !
07967 ! NNI     IWORK(19) number of nonlinear iterations so far (each of
07968 !                   which calls an iterative linear solver).
07969 !
07970 ! NLI     IWORK(20) number of linear iterations so far.
07971 !                   Note: A measure of the success of algorithm is
07972 !                   the average number of linear iterations per
07973 !                   nonlinear iteration, given by NLI/NNI.
07974 !                   If this is close to MAXL, MAXL may be too small.
07975 !
07976 ! NPS     IWORK(21) number of preconditioning solve operations
07977 !                   (PSOL calls) so far.
07978 !
07979 ! NCFN    IWORK(22) number of convergence failures of the nonlinear
07980 !                   (Newton) iteration so far.
07981 !                   Note: A measure of success is the overall
07982 !                   rate of nonlinear convergence failures, NCFN/NST.
07983 !
07984 ! NCFL    IWORK(23) number of convergence failures of the linear
07985 !                   iteration so far.
07986 !                   Note: A measure of success is the overall
07987 !                   rate of linear convergence failures, NCFL/NNI.
07988 !
07989 ! The following two arrays are segments of the RWORK array which
07990 ! may also be of interest to the user as optional outputs.
07991 ! For each array, the table below gives its internal name,
07992 ! its base address in RWORK, and its description.
07993 !
07994 ! Name    Base Address      Description
07995 !
07996 ! YH      21             the Nordsieck history array, of size NYH by
07997 !                        (NQCUR + 1), where NYH is the initial value
07998 !                        of NEQ.  For j = 0,1,...,NQCUR, column j+1
07999 !                        of YH contains HCUR**j/factorial(j) times
08000 !                        the j-th derivative of the interpolating
08001 !                        polynomial currently representing the solution,
08002 !                        evaluated at t = TCUR.
08003 !
08004 ! ACOR     LENRW-NEQ+1   array of size NEQ used for the accumulated
08005 !                        corrections on each step, scaled on output
08006 !                        to represent the estimated local error in y
08007 !                        on the last step.  This is the vector E in
08008 !                        the description of the error control.  It is
08009 !                        defined only on a successful return from
08010 !                        DLSODPK.
08011 !
08012 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08013 ! Part 2.  Other Routines Callable.
08014 !
08015 ! The following are optional calls which the user may make to
08016 ! gain additional capabilities in conjunction with DLSODPK.
08017 ! (The routines XSETUN and XSETF are designed to conform to the
08018 ! SLATEC error handling package.)
08019 !
08020 !     Form of Call                  Function
08021 !   CALL XSETUN(LUN)          Set the logical unit number, LUN, for
08022 !                             output of messages from DLSODPK, if
08023 !                             the default is not desired.
08024 !                             The default value of lun is 6.
08025 !
08026 !   CALL XSETF(MFLAG)         Set a flag to control the printing of
08027 !                             messages by DLSODPK.
08028 !                             MFLAG = 0 means do not print. (Danger:
08029 !                             This risks losing valuable information.)
08030 !                             MFLAG = 1 means print (the default).
08031 !
08032 !                             Either of the above calls may be made at
08033 !                             any time and will take effect immediately.
08034 !
08035 !   CALL DSRCPK(RSAV,ISAV,JOB) saves and restores the contents of
08036 !                             the internal Common blocks used by
08037 !                             DLSODPK (see Part 3 below).
08038 !                             RSAV must be a real array of length 222
08039 !                             or more, and ISAV must be an integer
08040 !                             array of length 50 or more.
08041 !                             JOB=1 means save Common into RSAV/ISAV.
08042 !                             JOB=2 means restore Common from RSAV/ISAV.
08043 !                                DSRCPK is useful if one is
08044 !                             interrupting a run and restarting
08045 !                             later, or alternating between two or
08046 !                             more problems solved with DLSODPK.
08047 !
08048 !   CALL DINTDY(,,,,,)        Provide derivatives of y, of various
08049 !        (See below)          orders, at a specified point t, if
08050 !                             desired.  It may be called only after
08051 !                             a successful return from DLSODPK.
08052 !
08053 ! The detailed instructions for using DINTDY are as follows.
08054 ! The form of the call is:
08055 !
08056 !   CALL DINTDY (T, K, RWORK(21), NYH, DKY, IFLAG)
08057 !
08058 ! The input parameters are:
08059 !
08060 ! T         = value of independent variable where answers are desired
08061 !             (normally the same as the T last returned by DLSODPK).
08062 !             for valid results, T must lie between TCUR - HU and TCUR.
08063 !             (See optional outputs for TCUR and HU.)
08064 ! K         = integer order of the derivative desired.  K must satisfy
08065 !             0 .le. K .le. NQCUR, where NQCUR is the current order
08066 !             (see optional outputs).  The capability corresponding
08067 !             to K = 0, i.e. computing y(T), is already provided
08068 !             by DLSODPK directly.  Since NQCUR .ge. 1, the first
08069 !             derivative dy/dt is always available with DINTDY.
08070 ! RWORK(21) = the base address of the history array YH.
08071 ! NYH       = column length of YH, equal to the initial value of NEQ.
08072 !
08073 ! The output parameters are:
08074 !
08075 ! DKY       = a real array of length NEQ containing the computed value
08076 !             of the K-th derivative of y(t).
08077 ! IFLAG     = integer flag, returned as 0 if K and T were legal,
08078 !             -1 if K was illegal, and -2 if T was illegal.
08079 !             On an error return, a message is also written.
08080 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08081 ! Part 3.  Common Blocks.
08082 !
08083 ! If DLSODPK is to be used in an overlay situation, the user
08084 ! must declare, in the primary overlay, the variables in:
08085 !   (1) the call sequence to DLSODPK, and
08086 !   (2) the two internal Common blocks
08087 !         /DLS001/  of length  255  (218 double precision words
08088 !                      followed by 37 integer words),
08089 !         /DLPK01/  of length  17  (4 double precision words
08090 !                      followed by 13 integer words).
08091 !
08092 ! If DLSODPK is used on a system in which the contents of internal
08093 ! Common blocks are not preserved between calls, the user should
08094 ! declare the above Common blocks in the calling program to insure
08095 ! that their contents are preserved.
08096 !
08097 ! If the solution of a given problem by DLSODPK is to be interrupted
08098 ! and then later continued, such as when restarting an interrupted run
08099 ! or alternating between two or more problems, the user should save,
08100 ! following the return from the last DLSODPK call prior to the
08101 ! interruption, the contents of the call sequence variables and the
08102 ! internal Common blocks, and later restore these values before the
08103 ! next DLSODPK call for that problem.  To save and restore the Common
08104 ! blocks, use Subroutine DSRCPK (see Part 2 above).
08105 !
08106 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08107 ! Part 4.  Optionally Replaceable Solver Routines.
08108 !
08109 ! below are descriptions of two routines in the DLSODPK package which
08110 ! relate to the measurement of errors.  Either routine can be
08111 ! replaced by a user-supplied version, if desired.  However, since such
08112 ! a replacement may have a major impact on performance, it should be
08113 ! done only when absolutely necessary, and only with great caution.
08114 ! (Note: The means by which the package version of a routine is
08115 ! superseded by the user's version may be system-dependent.)
08116 !
08117 ! (a) DEWSET.
08118 ! The following subroutine is called just before each internal
08119 ! integration step, and sets the array of error weights, EWT, as
08120 ! described under ITOL/RTOL/ATOL above:
08121 !     SUBROUTINE DEWSET (NEQ, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, YCUR, EWT)
08122 ! where NEQ, ITOL, RTOL, and ATOL are as in the DLSODPK call sequence,
08123 ! YCUR contains the current dependent variable vector, and
08124 ! EWT is the array of weights set by DEWSET.
08125 !
08126 ! If the user supplies this subroutine, it must return in EWT(i)
08127 ! (i = 1,...,NEQ) a positive quantity suitable for comparing errors
08128 ! in y(i) to.  The EWT array returned by DEWSET is passed to the DVNORM
08129 ! routine (see below), and also used by DLSODPK in the computation
08130 ! of the optional output IMXER, the diagonal Jacobian approximation,
08131 ! and the increments for difference quotient Jacobians.
08132 !
08133 ! In the user-supplied version of DEWSET, it may be desirable to use
08134 ! the current values of derivatives of y.  Derivatives up to order NQ
08135 ! are available from the history array YH, described above under
08136 ! optional outputs.  In DEWSET, YH is identical to the YCUR array,
08137 ! extended to NQ + 1 columns with a column length of NYH and scale
08138 ! factors of H**j/factorial(j).  On the first call for the problem,
08139 ! given by NST = 0, NQ is 1 and H is temporarily set to 1.0.
08140 ! NYH is the initial value of NEQ.  The quantities NQ, H, and NST
08141 ! can be obtained by including in DEWSET the statements:
08142 !     DOUBLE PRECISION RLS
08143 !     COMMON /DLS001/ RLS(218),ILS(37)
08144 !     NQ = ILS(33)
08145 !     NST = ILS(34)
08146 !     H = RLS(212)
08147 ! Thus, for example, the current value of dy/dt can be obtained as
08148 ! YCUR(NYH+i)/H  (i=1,...,NEQ)  (and the division by H is
08149 ! unnecessary when NST = 0).
08150 !
08151 ! (b) DVNORM.
08152 ! The following is a real function routine which computes the weighted
08153 ! root-mean-square norm of a vector v:
08154 !     D = DVNORM (N, V, W)
08155 ! where:
08156 !   N = the length of the vector,
08157 !   V = real array of length N containing the vector,
08158 !   W = real array of length N containing weights,
08159 !   D = SQRT( (1/N) * sum(V(i)*W(i))**2 ).
08160 ! DVNORM is called with N = NEQ and with W(i) = 1.0/EWT(i), where
08161 ! EWT is as set by Subroutine DEWSET.
08162 !
08163 ! If the user supplies this function, it should return a non-negative
08164 ! value of DVNORM suitable for use in the error control in DLSODPK.
08165 ! None of the arguments should be altered by DVNORM.
08166 ! For example, a user-supplied DVNORM routine might:
08167 !   -substitute a max-norm of (V(i)*W(i)) for the RMS-norm, or
08168 !   -ignore some components of V in the norm, with the effect of
08169 !    suppressing the error control on those components of y.
08170 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08171 !
08172 !***REVISION HISTORY  (YYYYMMDD)
08173 ! 19860901  DATE WRITTEN
08174 ! 19861010  Numerous minor revisions to SPIOM and SPGMR routines;
08175 !           minor corrections to prologues and comments.
08176 ! 19870114  Changed name SPGMR to SPIGMR; revised residual norm
08177 !           calculation in SPIGMR (for incomplete case);
08178 !           revised error return logic in SPIGMR;
08179 ! 19870330  Major update: corrected comments throughout;
08180 !           removed TRET from Common; rewrote EWSET with 4 loops;
08181 !           fixed t test in INTDY; added Cray directives in STODPK;
08182 !           in STODPK, fixed DELP init. and logic around PJAC call;
08183 !           combined routines to save/restore Common;
08184 !           passed LEVEL = 0 in error message calls (except run abort).
08185 ! 19871130  Added option MITER = 9; shortened WM array by 2;
08186 !           revised early return from SPIOM and SPIGMR;
08187 !           replaced copy loops with SCOPY/DCOPY calls;
08188 !           minor corrections/revisions to SOLPK, SPIGMR, ATV, ATP;
08189 !           corrections to main prologue and internal comments.
08190 ! 19880304  Corrections to type declarations in SOLPK, SPIOM, USOL.
08191 ! 19891025  Added ISTATE = -7 return; minor revisions to USOL;
08192 !           added initialization of JACFLG in main driver;
08193 !           removed YH and NYH from PKSET call list;
08194 !           minor revisions to SPIOM and SPIGMR;
08195 !           corrections to main prologue and internal comments.
08196 ! 19900803  Added YSV to JAC call list; minor comment corrections.
08197 ! 20010425  Major update: convert source lines to upper case;
08198 !           added *DECK lines; changed from 1 to * in dummy dimensions;
08199 !           changed names R1MACH/D1MACH to RUMACH/DUMACH;
08200 !           renamed routines for uniqueness across single/double prec.;
08201 !           converted intrinsic names to generic form;
08202 !           removed ILLIN and NTREP (data loaded) from Common;
08203 !           removed all 'own' variables from Common;
08204 !           changed error messages to quoted strings;
08205 !           replaced XERRWV/XERRWD with 1993 revised version;
08206 !           converted prologues, comments, error messages to mixed case;
08207 !           numerous corrections to prologues and internal comments.
08208 ! 20010507  Converted single precision source to double precision.
08209 ! 20020502  Corrected declarations in descriptions of user routines.
08210 ! 20030603  Corrected duplicate type declaration for DUMACH.
08211 ! 20031105  Restored 'own' variables to Common blocks, to enable
08212 !           interrupt/restart feature.
08213 ! 20031112  Added SAVE statements for data-loaded constants.
08214 ! 20031117  Changed internal name NPE to NJE.
08215 !
08216 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08217 ! Other routines in the DLSODPK package.
08218 !
08219 ! In addition to Subroutine DLSODPK, the DLSODPK package includes the
08220 ! following subroutines and function routines:
08221 !  DINTDY   computes an interpolated value of the y vector at t = TOUT.
08222 !  DEWSET   sets the error weight vector EWT before each step.
08223 !  DVNORM   computes the weighted RMS-norm of a vector.
08224 !  DSTODPK  is the core integrator, which does one step of the
08225 !           integration and the associated error control.
08226 !  DCFODE   sets all method coefficients and test constants.
08227 !  DPKSET   interfaces between DSTODPK and the JAC routine.
08228 !  DSOLPK   manages solution of linear system in Newton iteration.
08229 !  DSPIOM   performs the SPIOM algorithm.
08230 !  DATV     computes a scaled, preconditioned product (I-hl0*J)*v.
08231 !  DORTHOG  orthogonalizes a vector against previous basis vectors.
08232 !  DHEFA    generates an LU factorization of a Hessenberg matrix.
08233 !  DHESL    solves a Hessenberg square linear system.
08234 !  DSPIGMR  performs the SPIGMR algorithm.
08235 !  DHEQR    generates a QR factorization of a Hessenberg matrix.
08236 !  DHELS    finds the least squares solution of a Hessenberg system.
08237 !  DPCG     performs Preconditioned Conjugate Gradient algorithm (PCG).
08238 !  DPCGS    performs the PCGS algorithm.
08239 !  DATP     computes the product A*p, where A = I - hl0*df/dy.
08240 !  DUSOL    interfaces to the user's PSOL routine (MITER = 9).
08241 !  DSRCPK   is a user-callable routine to save and restore
08242 !           the contents of the internal Common blocks.
08243 !  DAXPY, DCOPY, DDOT, DNRM2, and DSCAL   are basic linear
08244 !           algebra modules (from the BLAS collection).
08245 !  DUMACH   computes the unit roundoff in a machine-independent manner.
08246 !  XERRWD, XSETUN, XSETF, IXSAV, and IUMACH  handle the printing of all
08247 !           error messages and warnings.  XERRWD is machine-dependent.
08248 ! Note:  DVNORM, DDOT, DNRM2, DUMACH, IXSAV, and IUMACH are function
08249 ! routines.  All the others are subroutines.
08250 !
08251 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08252 DOUBLE PRECISION DUMACH, DVNORM
08253 INTEGER INIT, MXSTEP, MXHNIL, NHNIL, NSLAST, NYH, IOWNS, ICF, IERPJ, IERSL, JCUR, JSTART, KFLAG, L, LYH, LEWT
08254 INTEGER LACOR, LSAVF, LWM, LIWM, METH, MITER, MAXORD, MAXCOR, MSBP, MXNCF, N, NQ, NST, NFE, NJE, NQU
08255 INTEGER JPRE, JACFLG, LOCWP, LOCIWP, LSAVX, KMP, MAXL, MNEWT, NNI, NLI, NPS, NCFN, NCFL
08256 INTEGER I, I1, I2, IFLAG, IMXER, KGO, LF0, LENIW, LENIWK, LENRW, LENWM, LENWK, LIWP, LWP, MORD, MXHNL0, MXSTP0
08257 INTEGER NCFN0, NCFL0, NLI0, NNI0, NNID, NSTD, NWARN
08258 DOUBLE PRECISION ROWNS, CCMAX, EL0, H, HMIN, HMXI, HU, RC, TN, UROUND
08259 DOUBLE PRECISION DELT, EPCON, SQRTN, RSQRTN
08260 DOUBLE PRECISION ATOLI, AVDIM, AYI, BIG, EWTI, H0, HMAX, HMX, RCFL, RCFN, RH, RTOLI, TCRIT, TDIST, TNEXT
08261 DOUBLE PRECISION TOL, TOLSF, TP, SIZE, SUM, W0
08262 DIMENSION MORD(2)
08263 LOGICAL IHIT, LAVD, LCFN, LCFL, LWARN
08264 character(len=60) MSG
08265 SAVE MORD, MXSTP0, MXHNL0
08266 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08267 ! The following two internal Common blocks contain
08268 ! (a) variables which are local to any subroutine but whose values must
08269 !     be preserved between calls to the routine ("own" variables), and
08270 ! (b) variables which are communicated between subroutines.
08271 ! The block DLS001 is declared in subroutines DLSODPK, DINTDY, DSTODPK,
08272 ! DSOLPK, and DATV.
08273 ! The block DLPK01 is declared in subroutines DLSODPK, DSTODPK, DPKSET,
08274 ! and DSOLPK.
08275 ! Groups of variables are replaced by dummy arrays in the Common
08276 ! declarations in routines where those variables are not used.
08277 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08278 COMMON /DLS001/ ROWNS(209), CCMAX, EL0, H, HMIN, HMXI, HU, RC, TN, UROUND, INIT, MXSTEP, MXHNIL, NHNIL, NSLAST, NYH, & 
08279 IOWNS( 6), ICF, IERPJ, IERSL, JCUR, JSTART, KFLAG, L, LYH, LEWT, LACOR, LSAVF, LWM, LIWM, METH, MITER, MAXORD, MAXCOR, & 
08280 MSBP , MXNCF , N, NQ, NST, NFE, NJE, NQU
08281 !
08282 COMMON /DLPK01/ DELT, EPCON, SQRTN, RSQRTN, JPRE, JACFLG, LOCWP, LOCIWP, LSAVX, KMP, MAXL, MNEWT, NNI, NLI, NPS, NCFN, NCFL
08283 !
08284 DATA MORD(1),MORD(2)/12,5/, MXSTP0/500/, MXHNL0/10/
08285 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08286 ! Block A.
08287 ! This code block is executed on every call.
08288 ! It tests ISTATE and ITASK for legality and branches appropriately.
08289 ! If ISTATE .gt. 1 but the flag INIT shows that initialization has
08290 ! not yet been done, an error return occurs.
08291 ! If ISTATE = 1 and TOUT = T, return immediately.
08292 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08293 IF (ISTATE .LT. 1 .OR. ISTATE .GT. 3) GOTO 601
08294 IF (ITASK .LT. 1 .OR. ITASK .GT. 5) GOTO 602
08295 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) GOTO 10
08296 IF (INIT .EQ. 0) GOTO 603
08297 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 2) GOTO 200
08298 GOTO 20
08299 10   INIT = 0
08300 IF (TOUT .EQ. T) RETURN
08301 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08302 ! Block B.
08303 ! The next code block is executed for the initial call (ISTATE = 1),
08304 ! or for a continuation call with parameter changes (ISTATE = 3).
08305 ! It contains checking of all inputs and various initializations.
08306 !
08307 ! First check legality of the non-optional inputs NEQ, ITOL, IOPT, MF.
08308 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08309 20   IF (NEQ(1) .LE. 0) GOTO 604
08310 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) GOTO 25
08311 IF (NEQ(1) .GT. N) GOTO 605
08312 25   N = NEQ(1)
08313 IF (ITOL .LT. 1 .OR. ITOL .GT. 4) GOTO 606
08314 IF (IOPT .LT. 0 .OR. IOPT .GT. 1) GOTO 607
08315 METH = MF/10
08316 MITER = MF - 10*METH
08317 IF (METH .LT. 1 .OR. METH .GT. 2) GOTO 608
08318 IF (MITER .LT. 0) GOTO 608
08319 IF (MITER .GT. 4 .AND. MITER .LT. 9) GOTO 608
08320 IF (MITER .GE. 1) JPRE = IWORK(3)
08321 JACFLG = 0
08322 IF (MITER .GE. 1) JACFLG = IWORK(4)
08323 ! Next process and check the optional inputs. --------------------------
08324 IF (IOPT .EQ. 1) GOTO 40
08325 MAXORD = MORD(METH)
08326 MXSTEP = MXSTP0
08327 MXHNIL = MXHNL0
08328 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) H0 = 0.0D0
08329 HMXI = 0.0D0
08330 HMIN = 0.0D0
08331 MAXL = MIN(5,N)
08332 KMP = MAXL
08333 DELT = 0.05D0
08334 GOTO 60
08335 40   MAXORD = IWORK(5)
08336 IF (MAXORD .LT. 0) GOTO 611
08337 IF (MAXORD .EQ. 0) MAXORD = 100
08338 MAXORD = MIN(MAXORD,MORD(METH))
08339 MXSTEP = IWORK(6)
08340 IF (MXSTEP .LT. 0) GOTO 612
08341 IF (MXSTEP .EQ. 0) MXSTEP = MXSTP0
08342 MXHNIL = IWORK(7)
08343 IF (MXHNIL .LT. 0) GOTO 613
08344 IF (MXHNIL .EQ. 0) MXHNIL = MXHNL0
08345 IF (ISTATE .NE. 1) GOTO 50
08346 H0 = RWORK(5)
08347 IF ((TOUT - T)*H0 .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 614
08348 50   HMAX = RWORK(6)
08349 IF (HMAX .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 615
08350 HMXI = 0.0D0
08351 IF (HMAX .GT. 0.0D0) HMXI = 1.0D0/HMAX
08352 HMIN = RWORK(7)
08353 IF (HMIN .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 616
08354 MAXL = IWORK(8)
08355 IF (MAXL .EQ. 0) MAXL = 5
08356 MAXL = MIN(MAXL,N)
08357 KMP = IWORK(9)
08358 IF (KMP .EQ. 0 .OR. KMP .GT. MAXL) KMP = MAXL
08359 DELT = RWORK(8)
08360 IF (DELT .EQ. 0.0D0) DELT = 0.05D0
08361 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08362 ! Set work array pointers and check lengths LRW and LIW.
08363 ! Pointers to segments of RWORK and IWORK are named by prefixing L to
08364 ! the name of the segment.  E.g., the segment YH starts at RWORK(LYH).
08365 ! RWORK segments (in order) are denoted  YH, WM, EWT, SAVF, SAVX, ACOR.
08366 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08367 60   LYH = 21
08368 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) NYH = N
08369 LWM = LYH + (MAXORD + 1)*NYH
08370 IF (MITER .EQ. 0) LENWK = 0
08371 IF (MITER .EQ. 1) LENWK = N*(MAXL+2) + MAXL*MAXL
08372 IF (MITER .EQ. 2) LENWK = N*(MAXL+2+MIN(1,MAXL-KMP)) + (MAXL+3)*MAXL + 1
08373 IF (MITER .EQ. 3 .OR. MITER .EQ. 4) LENWK = 5*N
08374 IF (MITER .EQ. 9) LENWK = 2*N
08375 LWP = 0
08376 IF (MITER .GE. 1) LWP = IWORK(1)
08377 LENWM = LENWK + LWP
08378 LOCWP = LENWK + 1
08379 LEWT = LWM + LENWM
08380 LSAVF = LEWT + N
08381 LSAVX = LSAVF + N
08382 LACOR = LSAVX + N
08383 IF (MITER .EQ. 0) LACOR = LSAVF + N
08384 LENRW = LACOR + N - 1
08385 IWORK(17) = LENRW
08386 LIWM = 31
08387 LENIWK = 0
08388 IF (MITER .EQ. 1) LENIWK = MAXL
08389 LIWP = 0
08390 IF (MITER .GE. 1) LIWP = IWORK(2)
08391 LENIW = 30 + LENIWK + LIWP
08392 LOCIWP = LENIWK + 1
08393 IWORK(18) = LENIW
08394 IF (LENRW .GT. LRW) GOTO 617
08395 IF (LENIW .GT. LIW) GOTO 618
08396 ! Check RTOL and ATOL for legality. ------------------------------------
08397 RTOLI = RTOL(1)
08398 ATOLI = ATOL(1)
08399 DO 70 I = 1,N
08400 IF (ITOL .GE. 3) RTOLI = RTOL(I)
08401 IF (ITOL .EQ. 2 .OR. ITOL .EQ. 4) ATOLI = ATOL(I)
08402 IF (RTOLI .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 619
08403 IF (ATOLI .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 620
08404 70     CONTINUE
08405 ! Load SQRT(N) and its reciprocal in Common. ---------------------------
08406 SQRTN = SQRT(REAL(N))
08407 RSQRTN = 1.0D0/SQRTN
08408 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) GOTO 100
08409 ! If ISTATE = 3, set flag to signal parameter changes to DSTODPK. ------
08410 JSTART = -1
08411 IF (NQ .LE. MAXORD) GOTO 90
08412 ! MAXORD was reduced below NQ.  Copy YH(*,MAXORD+2) into SAVF. ---------
08413 DO 80 I = 1,N
08414 80     RWORK(I+LSAVF-1) = RWORK(I+LWM-1)
08415 90   CONTINUE
08416 IF (N .EQ. NYH) GOTO 200
08417 ! NEQ was reduced.  Zero part of YH to avoid undefined references. -----
08418 I1 = LYH + L*NYH
08419 I2 = LYH + (MAXORD + 1)*NYH - 1
08420 IF (I1 .GT. I2) GOTO 200
08421 DO 95 I = I1,I2
08422 95     RWORK(I) = 0.0D0
08423 GOTO 200
08424 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08425 ! Block C.
08426 ! The next block is for the initial call only (ISTATE = 1).
08427 ! It contains all remaining initializations, the initial call to F,
08428 ! and the calculation of the initial step size.
08429 ! The error weights in EWT are inverted after being loaded.
08430 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08431 100  UROUND = DUMACH()
08432 TN = T
08433 IF (ITASK .NE. 4 .AND. ITASK .NE. 5) GOTO 110
08434 TCRIT = RWORK(1)
08435 IF ((TCRIT - TOUT)*(TOUT - T) .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 625
08436 IF (H0 .NE. 0.0D0 .AND. (T + H0 - TCRIT)*H0 .GT. 0.0D0) H0 = TCRIT - T
08437 110  JSTART = 0
08438 NHNIL = 0
08439 NST = 0
08440 NJE = 0
08441 NSLAST = 0
08442 NLI0 = 0
08443 NNI0 = 0
08444 NCFN0 = 0
08445 NCFL0 = 0
08446 NWARN = 0
08447 HU = 0.0D0
08448 NQU = 0
08449 CCMAX = 0.3D0
08450 MAXCOR = 3
08451 MSBP = 20
08452 MXNCF = 10
08453 NNI = 0
08454 NLI = 0
08455 NPS = 0
08456 NCFN = 0
08457 NCFL = 0
08458 ! Initial call to F.  (LF0 points to YH(*,2).) -------------------------
08459 LF0 = LYH + NYH
08460 CALL F (NEQ, T, Y, RWORK(LF0))
08461 NFE = 1
08462 ! Load the initial value vector in YH. ---------------------------------
08463 DO 115 I = 1,N
08464 115    RWORK(I+LYH-1) = Y(I)
08465 ! Load and invert the EWT array.  (H is temporarily set to 1.0.) -------
08466 NQ = 1
08467 H = 1.0D0
08468 CALL DEWSET (N, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LEWT))
08469 DO 120 I = 1,N
08470 IF (RWORK(I+LEWT-1) .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 621
08471 120    RWORK(I+LEWT-1) = 1.0D0/RWORK(I+LEWT-1)
08472 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08473 ! The coding below computes the step size, H0, to be attempted on the
08474 ! first step, unless the user has supplied a value for this.
08475 ! First check that TOUT - T differs significantly from zero.
08476 ! A scalar tolerance quantity TOL is computed, as MAX(RTOL(i))
08477 ! if this is positive, or MAX(ATOL(i)/ABS(Y(i))) otherwise, adjusted
08478 ! so as to be between 100*UROUND and 1.0E-3.
08479 ! Then the computed value H0 is given by..
08480 !                                      NEQ
08481 !   H0**2 = TOL / ( w0**-2 + (1/NEQ) * Sum ( f(i)/ywt(i) )**2  )
08482 !                                       1
08483 ! where   w0     = MAX ( ABS(T), ABS(TOUT) ),
08484 !         f(i)   = i-th component of initial value of f,
08485 !         ywt(i) = EWT(i)/TOL  (a weight for y(i)).
08486 ! The sign of H0 is inferred from the initial values of TOUT and T.
08487 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08488 IF (H0 .NE. 0.0D0) GOTO 180
08489 TDIST = ABS(TOUT - T)
08490 W0 = MAX(ABS(T),ABS(TOUT))
08491 IF (TDIST .LT. 2.0D0*UROUND*W0) GOTO 622
08492 TOL = RTOL(1)
08493 IF (ITOL .LE. 2) GOTO 140
08494 DO 130 I = 1,N
08495 130    TOL = MAX(TOL,RTOL(I))
08496 140  IF (TOL .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 160
08497 ATOLI = ATOL(1)
08498 DO 150 I = 1,N
08499 IF (ITOL .EQ. 2 .OR. ITOL .EQ. 4) ATOLI = ATOL(I)
08500 AYI = ABS(Y(I))
08501 IF (AYI .NE. 0.0D0) TOL = MAX(TOL,ATOLI/AYI)
08502 150    CONTINUE
08503 160  TOL = MAX(TOL,100.0D0*UROUND)
08504 TOL = MIN(TOL,0.001D0)
08505 SUM = DVNORM (N, RWORK(LF0), RWORK(LEWT))
08506 SUM = 1.0D0/(TOL*W0*W0) + TOL*SUM**2
08507 H0 = 1.0D0/SQRT(SUM)
08508 H0 = MIN(H0,TDIST)
08509 H0 = SIGN(H0,TOUT-T)
08510 ! Adjust H0 if necessary to meet HMAX bound. ---------------------------
08511 180  RH = ABS(H0)*HMXI
08512 IF (RH .GT. 1.0D0) H0 = H0/RH
08513 ! Load H with H0 and scale YH(*,2) by H0. ------------------------------
08514 H = H0
08515 DO 190 I = 1,N
08516 190    RWORK(I+LF0-1) = H0*RWORK(I+LF0-1)
08517 GOTO 270
08518 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08519 ! Block D.
08520 ! The next code block is for continuation calls only (ISTATE = 2 or 3)
08521 ! and is to check stop conditions before taking a step.
08522 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08523 200  NSLAST = NST
08524 NLI0 = NLI
08525 NNI0 = NNI
08526 NCFN0 = NCFN
08527 NCFL0 = NCFL
08528 NWARN = 0
08529 GOTO (210, 250, 220, 230, 240), ITASK
08530 210  IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
08531 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
08532 IF (IFLAG .NE. 0) GOTO 627
08533 T = TOUT
08534 GOTO 420
08535 220  TP = TN - HU*(1.0D0 + 100.0D0*UROUND)
08536 IF ((TP - TOUT)*H .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 623
08537 IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
08538 GOTO 400
08539 230  TCRIT = RWORK(1)
08540 IF ((TN - TCRIT)*H .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 624
08541 IF ((TCRIT - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 625
08542 IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 245
08543 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
08544 IF (IFLAG .NE. 0) GOTO 627
08545 T = TOUT
08546 GOTO 420
08547 240  TCRIT = RWORK(1)
08548 IF ((TN - TCRIT)*H .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 624
08549 245  HMX = ABS(TN) + ABS(H)
08550 IHIT = ABS(TN - TCRIT) .LE. 100.0D0*UROUND*HMX
08551 IF (IHIT) GOTO 400
08552 TNEXT = TN + H*(1.0D0 + 4.0D0*UROUND)
08553 IF ((TNEXT - TCRIT)*H .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
08554 H = (TCRIT - TN)*(1.0D0 - 4.0D0*UROUND)
08555 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 2) JSTART = -2
08556 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08557 ! Block E.
08558 ! The next block is normally executed for all calls and contains
08559 ! the call to the one-step core integrator DSTODPK.
08560 !
08561 ! This is a looping point for the integration steps.
08562 !
08563 ! First check for too many steps being taken,
08564 ! Check for poor Newton/Krylov method performance, update EWT (if not
08565 ! at start of problem), check for too much accuracy being requested,
08566 ! and check for H below the roundoff level in T.
08567 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08568 250  CONTINUE
08569 IF ((NST-NSLAST) .GE. MXSTEP) GOTO 500
08570 NSTD = NST - NSLAST
08571 NNID = NNI - NNI0
08572 IF (NSTD .LT. 10 .OR. NNID .EQ. 0) GOTO 255
08573 AVDIM = REAL(NLI - NLI0)/REAL(NNID)
08574 RCFN = REAL(NCFN - NCFN0)/REAL(NSTD)
08575 RCFL = REAL(NCFL - NCFL0)/REAL(NNID)
08576 LAVD = AVDIM .GT. (MAXL - 0.05D0)
08577 LCFN = RCFN .GT. 0.9D0
08578 LCFL = RCFL .GT. 0.9D0
08579 LWARN = LAVD .OR. LCFN .OR. LCFL
08580 IF (.NOT.LWARN) GOTO 255
08581 NWARN = NWARN + 1
08582 IF (NWARN .GT. 10) GOTO 255
08583 IF (LAVD) THEN
08584 MSG='DLSODPK- Warning. Poor iterative algorithm performance seen '
08585 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 111, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08586 ENDIF
08587 IF (LAVD) THEN
08588 MSG='      at T = R1 by average no. of linear iterations = R2    '
08589 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 111, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, AVDIM)
08590 ENDIF
08591 IF (LCFN) THEN
08592 MSG='DLSODPK- Warning. Poor iterative algorithm performance seen '
08593 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 112, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08594 ENDIF
08595 IF (LCFN) THEN
08596 MSG='      at T = R1 by nonlinear convergence failure rate = R2  '
08597 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 112, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, RCFN)
08598 ENDIF
08599 IF (LCFL) THEN
08600 MSG='DLSODPK- Warning. Poor iterative algorithm performance seen '
08601 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 113, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08602 ENDIF
08603 IF (LCFL) THEN
08604 MSG='      at T = R1 by linear convergence failure rate = R2     '
08605 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 113, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, RCFL)
08606 ENDIF
08607 255  CONTINUE
08608 CALL DEWSET (N, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LEWT))
08609 DO 260 I = 1,N
08610 IF (RWORK(I+LEWT-1) .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 510
08611 260    RWORK(I+LEWT-1) = 1.0D0/RWORK(I+LEWT-1)
08612 270  TOLSF = UROUND*DVNORM (N, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LEWT))
08613 IF (TOLSF .LE. 1.0D0) GOTO 280
08614 TOLSF = TOLSF*2.0D0
08615 IF (NST .EQ. 0) GOTO 626
08616 GOTO 520
08617 280  IF ((TN + H) .NE. TN) GOTO 290
08618 NHNIL = NHNIL + 1
08619 IF (NHNIL .GT. MXHNIL) GOTO 290
08620 MSG = 'DLSODPK-  Warning..Internal T(=R1) and H(=R2) are '
08621 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 101, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08622 MSG='      such that in the machine, T + H = T on the next step  '
08623 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 101, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08624 MSG = '     (H = step size). Solver will continue anyway.'
08625 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 101, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, H)
08626 IF (NHNIL .LT. MXHNIL) GOTO 290
08627 MSG = 'DLSODPK-  Above warning has been issued I1 times. '
08628 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 102, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08629 MSG = '     It will not be issued again for this problem.'
08630 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 102, 0, 1, MXHNIL, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08631 290  CONTINUE
08632 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08633 !     CALL DSTODPK(NEQ,Y,YH,NYH,YH,EWT,SAVF,SAVX,ACOR,WM,IWM,F,JAC,PSOL)
08634 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08635 CALL DSTODPK(NEQ, Y, RWORK(LYH), NYH, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LEWT), RWORK(LSAVF), RWORK(LSAVX), RWORK(LACOR), &
08636 RWORK(LWM), IWORK(LIWM), F, JAC, PSOL)
08637 KGO = 1 - KFLAG
08638 GOTO (300, 530, 540, 550), KGO
08639 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08640 ! Block F.
08641 ! The following block handles the case of a successful return from the
08642 ! core integrator (KFLAG = 0).  Test for stop conditions.
08643 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08644 300  INIT = 1
08645 GOTO (310, 400, 330, 340, 350), ITASK
08646 ! ITASK = 1.  If TOUT has been reached, interpolate. -------------------
08647 310  IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
08648 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
08649 T = TOUT
08650 GOTO 420
08651 ! ITASK = 3.  Jump to exit if TOUT was reached. ------------------------
08652 330  IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .GE. 0.0D0) GOTO 400
08653 GOTO 250
08654 ! ITASK = 4.  See if TOUT or TCRIT was reached.  Adjust H if necessary.
08655 340  IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 345
08656 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
08657 T = TOUT
08658 GOTO 420
08659 345  HMX = ABS(TN) + ABS(H)
08660 IHIT = ABS(TN - TCRIT) .LE. 100.0D0*UROUND*HMX
08661 IF (IHIT) GOTO 400
08662 TNEXT = TN + H*(1.0D0 + 4.0D0*UROUND)
08663 IF ((TNEXT - TCRIT)*H .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
08664 H = (TCRIT - TN)*(1.0D0 - 4.0D0*UROUND)
08665 JSTART = -2
08666 GOTO 250
08667 ! ITASK = 5.  see if TCRIT was reached and jump to exit. ---------------
08668 350  HMX = ABS(TN) + ABS(H)
08669 IHIT = ABS(TN - TCRIT) .LE. 100.0D0*UROUND*HMX
08670 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08671 ! Block G.
08672 ! The following block handles all successful returns from DLSODPK.
08673 ! If ITASK .ne. 1, Y is loaded from YH and T is set accordingly.
08674 ! ISTATE is set to 2, and the optional outputs are loaded into the
08675 ! work arrays before returning.
08676 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08677 400  DO 410 I = 1,N
08678 410    Y(I) = RWORK(I+LYH-1)
08679 T = TN
08680 IF (ITASK .NE. 4 .AND. ITASK .NE. 5) GOTO 420
08681 IF (IHIT) T = TCRIT
08682 420  ISTATE = 2
08683 RWORK(11) = HU
08684 RWORK(12) = H
08685 RWORK(13) = TN
08686 IWORK(11) = NST
08687 IWORK(12) = NFE
08688 IWORK(13) = NJE
08689 IWORK(14) = NQU
08690 IWORK(15) = NQ
08691 IWORK(19) = NNI
08692 IWORK(20) = NLI
08693 IWORK(21) = NPS
08694 IWORK(22) = NCFN
08695 IWORK(23) = NCFL
08696 RETURN
08697 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08698 ! Block H.
08699 ! The following block handles all unsuccessful returns other than
08700 ! those for illegal input.  First the error message routine is called.
08701 ! If there was an error test or convergence test failure, IMXER is set.
08702 ! Then Y is loaded from YH and T is set to TN.
08703 ! The optional outputs are loaded into the work arrays before returning.
08704 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08705 ! The maximum number of steps was taken before reaching TOUT. ----------
08706 500  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  At current T (=R1), MXSTEP (=I1) steps  '
08707 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 201, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08708 MSG = '      taken on this call before reaching TOUT     '
08709 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 201, 0, 1, MXSTEP, 0, 1, TN, 0.0D0)
08710 ISTATE = -1
08711 GOTO 580
08712 ! EWT(i) .le. 0.0 for some i (not at start of problem). ----------------
08713 510  EWTI = RWORK(LEWT+I-1)
08714 MSG = 'DLSODPK-  At T (=R1), EWT(I1) has become R2.le.0. '
08715 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 202, 0, 1, I, 0, 2, TN, EWTI)
08716 ISTATE = -6
08717 GOTO 580
08718 ! Too much accuracy requested for machine precision. -------------------
08719 520  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  At T (=R1), too much accuracy requested '
08720 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 203, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08721 MSG = '      for precision of machine..  See TOLSF (=R2) '
08722 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 203, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, TOLSF)
08723 RWORK(14) = TOLSF
08724 ISTATE = -2
08725 GOTO 580
08726 ! KFLAG = -1.  Error test failed repeatedly or with ABS(H) = HMIN. -----
08727 530  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  At T(=R1), step size H(=R2), the error  '
08728 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 204, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08729 MSG = '      test failed repeatedly or with ABS(H) = HMIN'
08730 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 204, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, H)
08731 ISTATE = -4
08732 GOTO 560
08733 ! KFLAG = -2.  Convergence failed repeatedly or with ABS(H) = HMIN. ----
08734 540  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  At T (=R1) and step size H (=R2), the   '
08735 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 205, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08736 MSG = '      corrector convergence failed repeatedly     '
08737 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 205, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08738 MSG = '      or with ABS(H) = HMIN   '
08739 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 205, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, H)
08740 ISTATE = -5
08741 GOTO 560
08742 ! KFLAG = -3.  Unrecoverable error from PSOL. --------------------------
08743 550  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  At T (=R1) an unrecoverable error return'
08744 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 205, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08745 MSG = '      was made from Subroutine PSOL     '
08746 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 205, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, TN, 0.0D0)
08747 ISTATE = -7
08748 GOTO 580
08749 ! Compute IMXER if relevant. -------------------------------------------
08750 560  BIG = 0.0D0
08751 IMXER = 1
08752 DO 570 I = 1,N
08753 SIZE = ABS(RWORK(I+LACOR-1)*RWORK(I+LEWT-1))
08754 IF (BIG .GE. SIZE) GOTO 570
08755 BIG = SIZE
08756 IMXER = I
08757 570    CONTINUE
08758 IWORK(16) = IMXER
08759 ! Set Y vector, T, and optional outputs. -------------------------------
08760 580  DO 590 I = 1,N
08761 590    Y(I) = RWORK(I+LYH-1)
08762 T = TN
08763 RWORK(11) = HU
08764 RWORK(12) = H
08765 RWORK(13) = TN
08766 IWORK(11) = NST
08767 IWORK(12) = NFE
08768 IWORK(13) = NJE
08769 IWORK(14) = NQU
08770 IWORK(15) = NQ
08771 IWORK(19) = NNI
08772 IWORK(20) = NLI
08773 IWORK(21) = NPS
08774 IWORK(22) = NCFN
08775 IWORK(23) = NCFL
08776 RETURN
08777 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08778 ! Block I.
08779 ! The following block handles all error returns due to illegal input
08780 ! (ISTATE = -3), as detected before calling the core integrator.
08781 ! First the error message routine is called.  If the illegal input
08782 ! is a negative ISTATE, the run is aborted (apparent infinite loop).
08783 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08784 601  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  ISTATE(=I1) illegal.'
08785 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 1, 0, 1, ISTATE, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08786 IF (ISTATE .LT. 0) GOTO 800
08787 GOTO 700
08788 602  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  ITASK (=I1) illegal.'
08789 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 2, 0, 1, ITASK, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08790 GOTO 700
08791 603  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  ISTATE.gt.1 but DLSODPK not initialized.'
08792 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 3, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08793 GOTO 700
08794 604  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  NEQ (=I1) .lt. 1    '
08795 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 4, 0, 1, NEQ(1), 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08796 GOTO 700
08797 605  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  ISTATE = 3 and NEQ increased (I1 to I2).'
08798 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 5, 0, 2, N, NEQ(1), 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08799 GOTO 700
08800 606  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  ITOL (=I1) illegal. '
08801 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 6, 0, 1, ITOL, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08802 GOTO 700
08803 607  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  IOPT (=I1) illegal. '
08804 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 7, 0, 1, IOPT, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08805 GOTO 700
08806 608  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  MF (=I1) illegal.   '
08807 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 8, 0, 1, MF, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08808 GOTO 700
08809 611  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  MAXORD (=I1) .lt. 0 '
08810 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 11, 0, 1, MAXORD, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08811 GOTO 700
08812 612  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  MXSTEP (=I1) .lt. 0 '
08813 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 12, 0, 1, MXSTEP, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08814 GOTO 700
08815 613  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  MXHNIL (=I1) .lt. 0 '
08816 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 13, 0, 1, MXHNIL, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08817 GOTO 700
08818 614  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  TOUT (=R1) behind T (=R2)     '
08819 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 14, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TOUT, T)
08820 MSG = '      Integration direction is given by H0 (=R1)  '
08821 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 14, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, H0, 0.0D0)
08822 GOTO 700
08823 615  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  HMAX (=R1) .lt. 0.0 '
08824 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 15, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, HMAX, 0.0D0)
08825 GOTO 700
08826 616  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  HMIN (=R1) .lt. 0.0 '
08827 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 16, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, HMIN, 0.0D0)
08828 GOTO 700
08829 617  MSG='DLSODPK-  RWORK length needed, LENRW(=I1), exceeds LRW(=I2) '
08830 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 17, 0, 2, LENRW, LRW, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08831 GOTO 700
08832 618  MSG='DLSODPK-  IWORK length needed, LENIW(=I1), exceeds LIW(=I2) '
08833 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 18, 0, 2, LENIW, LIW, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08834 GOTO 700
08835 619  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  RTOL(I1) is R1 .lt. 0.0       '
08836 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 19, 0, 1, I, 0, 1, RTOLI, 0.0D0)
08837 GOTO 700
08838 620  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  ATOL(I1) is R1 .lt. 0.0       '
08839 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 20, 0, 1, I, 0, 1, ATOLI, 0.0D0)
08840 GOTO 700
08841 621  EWTI = RWORK(LEWT+I-1)
08842 MSG = 'DLSODPK-  EWT(I1) is R1 .le. 0.0        '
08843 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 21, 0, 1, I, 0, 1, EWTI, 0.0D0)
08844 GOTO 700
08845 622  MSG='DLSODPK- TOUT(=R1) too close to T(=R2) to start integration.'
08846 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 22, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TOUT, T)
08847 GOTO 700
08848 623  MSG='DLSODPK-  ITASK = I1 and TOUT (=R1) behind TCUR - HU (= R2) '
08849 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 23, 0, 1, ITASK, 0, 2, TOUT, TP)
08850 GOTO 700
08851 624  MSG='DLSODPK-  ITASK = 4 or 5 and TCRIT (=R1) behind TCUR (=R2)  '
08852 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 24, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TCRIT, TN)
08853 GOTO 700
08854 625  MSG='DLSODPK-  ITASK = 4 or 5 and TCRIT (=R1) behind TOUT (=R2)  '
08855 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 25, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TCRIT, TOUT)
08856 GOTO 700
08857 626  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  At start of problem, too much accuracy  '
08858 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 26, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08859 MSG='      requested for precision of machine..  See TOLSF (=R1) '
08860 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 26, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, TOLSF, 0.0D0)
08861 RWORK(14) = TOLSF
08862 GOTO 700
08863 627  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  Trouble in DINTDY. ITASK = I1, TOUT = R1'
08864 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 27, 0, 1, ITASK, 0, 1, TOUT, 0.0D0)
08865 !
08866 700  ISTATE = -3
08867 RETURN
08868 !
08869 800  MSG = 'DLSODPK-  Run aborted.. apparent infinite loop.   '
08870 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 303, 2, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
08871 RETURN
08872 !----------------------- End of Subroutine DLSODPK ---------------------
08873 END
08874 
08875 SUBROUTINE DLSODKR(F, NEQ, Y, T, TOUT, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, ITASK, ISTATE, IOPT, RWORK, LRW, IWORK, LIW, &
08876 JAC, PSOL, MF, G, NG, JROOT)
08877 EXTERNAL F, JAC, PSOL, G
08878 INTEGER NEQ, ITOL, ITASK, ISTATE, IOPT, LRW, IWORK, LIW, MF, NG, JROOT
08879 DOUBLE PRECISION Y, T, TOUT, RTOL, ATOL, RWORK
08880 DIMENSION NEQ(*), Y(*), RTOL(*), ATOL(*), RWORK(LRW), IWORK(LIW), JROOT(*)
08881 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08882 ! This is the 18 November 2003 version of
08883 ! DLSODKR: Livermore Solver for Ordinary Differential equations,
08884 !          with preconditioned Krylov iteration methods for the
08885 !          Newton correction linear systems, and with Rootfinding.
08886 !
08887 ! This version is in double precision.
08888 !
08889 ! DLSODKR solves the initial value problem for stiff or nonstiff
08890 ! systems of first order ODEs,
08891 !     dy/dt = f(t,y) ,  or, in component form,
08892 !     dy(i)/dt = f(i) = f(i,t,y(1),y(2),...,y(NEQ)) (i = 1,...,NEQ).
08893 ! At the same time, it locates the roots of any of a set of functions
08894 !     g(i) = g(i,t,y(1),...,y(NEQ))  (i = 1,...,ng).
08895 !
08896 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08897 ! Introduction.
08898 !
08899 ! This is a modification of the DLSODE package, and differs from it
08900 ! in five ways:
08901 ! (a) It uses various preconditioned Krylov subspace iteration methods
08902 ! for the linear algebraic systems that arise in the case of stiff
08903 ! systems.  See the introductory notes below.
08904 ! (b) It does automatic switching between functional (fixpoint)
08905 ! iteration and Newton iteration in the corrector iteration.
08906 ! (c) It finds the root of at least one of a set of constraint
08907 ! functions g(i) of the independent and dependent variables.
08908 ! It finds only those roots for which some g(i), as a function
08909 ! of t, changes sign in the interval of integration.
08910 ! It then returns the solution at the root, if that occurs
08911 ! sooner than the specified stop condition, and otherwise returns
08912 ! the solution according the specified stop condition.
08913 ! (d) It supplies to JAC an input flag, JOK, which indicates whether
08914 ! JAC may (optionally) bypass the evaluation of Jacobian matrix data
08915 ! and instead process saved data (with the current value of scalar hl0).
08916 ! (e) It contains a new subroutine that calculates the initial step
08917 ! size to be attempted.
08918 !
08919 !
08920 ! Introduction to the Krylov methods in DLSODKR:
08921 !
08922 ! The linear systems that must be solved have the form
08923 !   A * x  = b ,  where  A = identity - hl0 * (df/dy) .
08924 ! Here hl0 is a scalar, and df/dy is the Jacobian matrix of partial
08925 ! derivatives of f (NEQ by NEQ).
08926 !
08927 ! The particular Krylov method is chosen by setting the second digit,
08928 ! MITER, in the method flag MF.
08929 ! Currently, the values of MITER have the following meanings:
08930 !
08931 !  MITER = 1 means the Scaled Preconditioned Incomplete
08932 !            Orthogonalization Method (SPIOM).
08933 !
08934 !          2 means an incomplete version of the preconditioned scaled
08935 !            Generalized Minimal Residual method (SPIGMR).
08936 !            This is the best choice in general.
08937 !
08938 !          3 means the Preconditioned Conjugate Gradient method (PCG).
08939 !            Recommended only when df/dy is symmetric or nearly so.
08940 !
08941 !          4 means the scaled Preconditioned Conjugate Gradient method
08942 !            (PCGS).  Recommended only when D-inverse * df/dy * D is
08943 !            symmetric or nearly so, where D is the diagonal scaling
08944 !            matrix with elements 1/EWT(i) (see RTOL/ATOL description).
08945 !
08946 !          9 means that only a user-supplied matrix P (approximating A)
08947 !            will be used, with no Krylov iteration done.  This option
08948 !            allows the user to provide the complete linear system
08949 !            solution algorithm, if desired.
08950 !
08951 ! The user can apply preconditioning to the linear system A*x = b,
08952 ! by means of arbitrary matrices (the preconditioners).
08953 !     In the case of SPIOM and SPIGMR, one can apply left and right
08954 ! preconditioners P1 and P2, and the basic iterative method is then
08955 ! applied to the matrix (P1-inverse)*A*(P2-inverse) instead of to the
08956 ! matrix A.  The product P1*P2 should be an approximation to matrix A
08957 ! such that linear systems with P1 or P2 are easier to solve than with
08958 ! A.  Preconditioning from the left only or right only means using
08959 ! P2 = identity or P1 = identity, respectively.
08960 !     In the case of the PCG and PCGS methods, there is only one
08961 ! preconditioner matrix P (but it can be the product of more than one).
08962 ! It should approximate the matrix A but allow for relatively
08963 ! easy solution of linear systems with coefficient matrix P.
08964 ! For PCG, P should be positive definite symmetric, or nearly so,
08965 ! and for PCGS, the scaled preconditioner D-inverse * P * D
08966 ! should be symmetric or nearly so.
08967 !     If the Jacobian J = df/dy splits in a natural way into a sum
08968 ! J = J1 + J2, then one possible choice of preconditioners is
08969 !     P1 = identity - hl0 * J1  and  P2 = identity - hl0 * J2
08970 ! provided each of these is easy to solve (or approximately solve).
08971 !
08972 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08973 ! References:
08974 ! 1.  Peter N. Brown and Alan C. Hindmarsh, Reduced Storage Matrix
08975 !     Methods in Stiff ODE Systems, J. Appl. Math. & Comp., 31 (1989),
08976 !     pp. 40-91; also  L.L.N.L. Report UCRL-95088, Rev. 1, June 1987.
08977 ! 2.  Alan C. Hindmarsh,  ODEPACK, A Systematized Collection of ODE
08978 !     Solvers, in Scientific Computing, R. S. Stepleman et al. (Eds.),
08979 !     North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1983, pp. 55-64.
08980 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08981 ! Authors:       Alan C. Hindmarsh and Peter N. Brown
08982 !                Center for Applied Scientific Computing, L-561
08983 !                Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
08984 !                Livermore, CA 94551
08985 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
08986 ! Summary of Usage.
08987 !
08988 ! Communication between the user and the DLSODKR package, for normal
08989 ! situations, is summarized here.  This summary describes only a subset
08990 ! of the full set of options available.  See the full description for
08991 ! details, including optional communication, nonstandard options,
08992 ! and instructions for special situations.  See also the demonstration
08993 ! program distributed with this solver.
08994 !
08995 ! A. First provide a subroutine of the form:
08996 !               SUBROUTINE F (NEQ, T, Y, YDOT)
08997 !               DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), YDOT(*)
08998 ! which supplies the vector function f by loading YDOT(i) with f(i).
08999 !
09000 ! B. Provide a subroutine of the form:
09001 !               SUBROUTINE G (NEQ, T, Y, NG, GOUT)
09002 !               DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), GOUT(NG)
09003 ! which supplies the vector function g by loading GOUT(i) with
09004 ! g(i), the i-th constraint function whose root is sought.
09005 !
09006 ! C. Next determine (or guess) whether or not the problem is stiff.
09007 ! Stiffness occurs when the Jacobian matrix df/dy has an eigenvalue
09008 ! whose real part is negative and large in magnitude, compared to the
09009 ! reciprocal of the t span of interest.  If the problem is nonstiff,
09010 ! use a method flag MF = 10.  If it is stiff, MF should be between 21
09011 ! and 24, or possibly 29.  MF = 22 is generally the best choice.
09012 ! Use 23 or 24 only if symmetry is present.  Use MF = 29 if the
09013 ! complete linear system solution is to be provided by the user.
09014 ! The following four parameters must also be set.
09015 !  IWORK(1) = LWP  = length of real array WP for preconditioning.
09016 !  IWORK(2) = LIWP = length of integer array IWP for preconditioning.
09017 !  IWORK(3) = JPRE = preconditioner type flag:
09018 !                  = 0 for no preconditioning (P1 = P2 = P = identity)
09019 !                  = 1 for left-only preconditioning (P2 = identity)
09020 !                  = 2 for right-only preconditioning (P1 = identity)
09021 !                  = 3 for two-sided preconditioning (and PCG or PCGS)
09022 !  IWORK(4) = JACFLG = flag for whether JAC is called.
09023 !                    = 0 if JAC is not to be called,
09024 !                    = 1 if JAC is to be called.
09025 !  Use JACFLG = 1 if JAC computes any nonconstant data for use in
09026 !  preconditioning, such as Jacobian elements.
09027 !  The arrays WP and IWP are work arrays under the user's control,
09028 !  for use in the routines that perform preconditioning operations.
09029 !
09030 ! D. If the problem is stiff, you must supply two routines that deal
09031 ! with the preconditioning of the linear systems to be solved.
09032 ! These are as follows:
09033 !
09034 !     SUBROUTINE JAC (F, NEQ, T, Y, YSV, REWT, FTY,V,HL0,JOK,WP,IWP,IER)
09035 !     DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), YSV(*), REWT(*), FTY(*), V(*), HL0,WP(*)
09036 !     INTEGER IWP(*)
09037 !        This routine must evaluate and preprocess any parts of the
09038 !     Jacobian matrix df/dy involved in the preconditioners P1, P2, P.
09039 !     The Y and FTY arrays contain the current values of y and f(t,y),
09040 !     respectively, and YSV also contains the current value of y.
09041 !     The array V is work space of length NEQ.
09042 !     JAC must multiply all computed Jacobian elements by the scalar
09043 !     -HL0, add the identity matrix, and do any factorization
09044 !     operations called for, in preparation for solving linear systems
09045 !     with a coefficient matrix of P1, P2, or P.  The matrix P1*P2 or P
