09046 !     should be an approximation to  identity - hl0 * (df/dy).
09047 !     JAC should return IER = 0 if successful, and IER .ne. 0 if not.
09048 !     (If IER .ne. 0, a smaller time step will be tried.)
09049 !     JAC may alter Y and V, but not YSV, REWT, FTY, or HL0.
09050 !     The JOK argument can be ignored (or see full description below).
09051 !
09052 !     SUBROUTINE PSOL (NEQ, T, Y, FTY, WK, HL0, WP, IWP, B, LR, IER)
09053 !     DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), FTY(*), WK(*), HL0, WP(*), B(*)
09054 !     INTEGER IWP(*)
09055 !        This routine must solve a linear system with B as right-hand
09056 !     side and one of the preconditioning matrices, P1, P2, or P, as
09057 !     coefficient matrix, and return the solution vector in B.
09058 !     LR is a flag concerning left vs right preconditioning, input
09059 !     to PSOL.  PSOL is to use P1 if LR = 1 and P2 if LR = 2.
09060 !     In the case of the PCG or PCGS method, LR will be 3, and PSOL
09061 !     should solve the system P*x = B with the preconditioner matrix P.
09062 !     In the case MF = 29 (no Krylov iteration), LR will be 0,
09063 !     and PSOL is to return in B the desired approximate solution
09064 !     to A * x = B, where A = identity - hl0 * (df/dy).
09065 !     PSOL can use data generated in the JAC routine and stored in
09066 !     WP and IWP.  WK is a work array of length NEQ.
09067 !     The argument HL0 is the current value of the scalar appearing
09068 !     in the linear system.  If the old value, at the time of the last
09069 !     JAC call, is needed, it must have been saved by JAC in WP.
09070 !     on return, PSOL should set the error flag IER as follows:
09071 !       IER = 0 if PSOL was successful,
09072 !       IER .gt. 0 if a recoverable error occurred, meaning that the
09073 !              time step will be retried,
09074 !       IER .lt. 0 if an unrecoverable error occurred, meaning that the
09075 !              solver is to stop immediately.
09076 !
09077 ! E. Write a main program which calls Subroutine DLSODKR once for
09078 ! each point at which answers are desired.  This should also provide
09079 ! for possible use of logical unit 6 for output of error messages
09080 ! by DLSODKR.  On the first call to DLSODKR, supply arguments as
09081 ! follows:
09082 ! F      = name of subroutine for right-hand side vector f.
09083 !          This name must be declared External in calling program.
09084 ! NEQ    = number of first order ODEs.
09085 ! Y      = array of initial values, of length NEQ.
09086 ! T      = the initial value of the independent variable.
09087 ! TOUT   = first point where output is desired (.ne. T).
09088 ! ITOL   = 1 or 2 according as ATOL (below) is a scalar or array.
09089 ! RTOL   = relative tolerance parameter (scalar).
09090 ! ATOL   = absolute tolerance parameter (scalar or array).
09091 !          The estimated local error in y(i) will be controlled so as
09092 !          to be roughly less (in magnitude) than
09093 !             EWT(i) = RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL     if ITOL = 1, or
09094 !             EWT(i) = RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i)  if ITOL = 2.
09095 !          Thus the local error test passes if, in each component,
09096 !          either the absolute error is less than ATOL (or ATOL(i)),
09097 !          or the relative error is less than RTOL.
09098 !          Use RTOL = 0.0 for pure absolute error control, and
09099 !          use ATOL = 0.0 (or ATOL(i) = 0.0) for pure relative error
09100 !          control.  Caution: Actual (global) errors may exceed these
09101 !          local tolerances, so choose them conservatively.
09102 ! ITASK  = 1 for normal computation of output values of y at t = TOUT.
09103 ! ISTATE = integer flag (input and output).  Set ISTATE = 1.
09104 ! IOPT   = 0 to indicate no optional inputs used.
09105 ! RWORK  = real work array of length at least:
09106 !             20 + 16*NEQ + 3*NG           for MF = 10,
09107 !             45 + 17*NEQ + 3*NG + LWP     for MF = 21,
09108 !             61 + 17*NEQ + 3*NG + LWP     for MF = 22,
09109 !             20 + 15*NEQ + 3*NG + LWP     for MF = 23 or 24,
09110 !             20 + 12*NEQ + 3*NG + LWP     for MF = 29.
09111 ! LRW    = declared length of RWORK (in user's dimension).
09112 ! IWORK  = integer work array of length at least:
09113 !             30            for MF = 10,
09114 !             35 + LIWP     for MF = 21,
09115 !             30 + LIWP     for MF = 22, 23, 24, or 29.
09116 ! LIW    = declared length of IWORK (in user's dimension).
09117 ! JAC,PSOL = names of subroutines for preconditioning.
09118 !          These names must be declared External in the calling program.
09119 ! MF     = method flag.  Standard values are:
09120 !          10 for nonstiff (Adams) method.
09121 !          21 for stiff (BDF) method, with preconditioned SIOM.
09122 !          22 for stiff method, with preconditioned GMRES method.
09123 !          23 for stiff method, with preconditioned CG method.
09124 !          24 for stiff method, with scaled preconditioned CG method.
09125 !          29 for stiff method, with user's PSOL routine only.
09126 ! G      = name of subroutine for constraint functions, whose
09127 !          roots are desired during the integration.
09128 !          This name must be declared External in calling program.
09129 ! NG     = number of constraint functions g(i).  If there are none,
09130 !          set NG = 0, and pass a dummy name for G.
09131 ! JROOT  = integer array of length NG for output of root information.
09132 !          See next paragraph.
09133 ! Note that the main program must declare arrays Y, RWORK, IWORK,
09134 ! JROOT, and possibly ATOL.
09135 !
09136 ! F. The output from the first call (or any call) is:
09137 !      Y = array of computed values of y(t) vector.
09138 !      T = corresponding value of independent variable (normally TOUT).
09139 ! ISTATE = 2 or 3  if DLSODKR was successful, negative otherwise.
09140 !           2 means no root was found, and TOUT was reached as desired.
09141 !           3 means a root was found prior to reaching TOUT.
09142 !          -1 means excess work done on this call (perhaps wrong MF).
09143 !          -2 means excess accuracy requested (tolerances too small).
09144 !          -3 means illegal input detected (see printed message).
09145 !          -4 means repeated error test failures (check all inputs).
09146 !          -5 means repeated convergence failures (perhaps bad JAC
09147 !             or PSOL routine supplied or wrong choice of MF or
09148 !             tolerances, or this solver is inappropriate).
09149 !          -6 means error weight became zero during problem. (Solution
09150 !             component i vanished, and ATOL or ATOL(i) = 0.)
09151 !          -7 means an unrecoverable error occurred in PSOL.
09152 ! JROOT  = array showing roots found if ISTATE = 3 on return.
09153 !          JROOT(i) = 1 if g(i) has a root at T, or 0 otherwise.
09154 !
09155 ! G. To continue the integration after a successful return, proceed
09156 ! as follows:
09157 ! (a) If ISTATE = 2 on return, reset TOUT and call DLSODKR again.
09158 ! (b) If ISTATE = 3 on return, reset ISTATE to 2 and call DLSODKR again.
09159 ! In either case, no other parameters need be reset.
09160 !
09161 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
09162 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
09163 ! Full Description of User Interface to DLSODKR.
09164 !
09165 ! The user interface to DLSODKR consists of the following parts.
09166 !
09167 ! 1.   The call sequence to Subroutine DLSODKR, which is a driver
09168 !      routine for the solver.  This includes descriptions of both
09169 !      the call sequence arguments and of user-supplied routines.
09170 !      Following these descriptions is a description of
09171 !      optional inputs available through the call sequence, and then
09172 !      a description of optional outputs (in the work arrays).
09173 !
09174 ! 2.   Descriptions of other routines in the DLSODKR package that may be
09175 !      (optionally) called by the user.  These provide the ability to
09176 !      alter error message handling, save and restore the internal
09177 !      Common, and obtain specified derivatives of the solution y(t).
09178 !
09179 ! 3.   Descriptions of Common blocks to be declared in overlay
09180 !      or similar environments, or to be saved when doing an interrupt
09181 !      of the problem and continued solution later.
09182 !
09183 ! 4.   Description of two routines in the DLSODKR package, either of
09184 !      which the user may replace with his/her own version, if desired.
09185 !      These relate to the measurement of errors.
09186 !
09187 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
09188 ! Part 1.  Call Sequence.
09189 !
09190 ! The call sequence parameters used for input only are
09191 !  F, NEQ, TOUT, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, ITASK, IOPT, LRW, LIW, JAC, PSOL, MF,
09192 !  G, and NG,
09193 ! that used only for output is  JROOT,
09194 ! and those used for both input and output are
09195 !  Y, T, ISTATE.
09196 ! The work arrays RWORK and IWORK are also used for conditional and
09197 ! optional inputs and optional outputs.  (The term output here refers
09198 ! to the return from Subroutine DLSODKR to the user's calling program.)
09199 !
09200 ! The legality of input parameters will be thoroughly checked on the
09201 ! initial call for the problem, but not checked thereafter unless a
09202 ! change in input parameters is flagged by ISTATE = 3 on input.
09203 !
09204 ! The descriptions of the call arguments are as follows.
09205 !
09206 ! F      = the name of the user-supplied subroutine defining the
09207 !          ODE system.  The system must be put in the first-order
09208 !          form dy/dt = f(t,y), where f is a vector-valued function
09209 !          of the scalar t and the vector y.  Subroutine F is to
09210 !          compute the function f.  It is to have the form
09211 !               SUBROUTINE F (NEQ, T, Y, YDOT)
09212 !               DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), YDOT(*)
09213 !          where NEQ, T, and Y are input, and the array YDOT = f(t,y)
09214 !          is output.  Y and YDOT are arrays of length NEQ.
09215 !          Subroutine F should not alter Y(1),...,Y(NEQ).
09216 !          F must be declared External in the calling program.
09217 !
09218 !          Subroutine F may access user-defined quantities in
09219 !          NEQ(2),... and/or in Y(NEQ(1)+1),... if NEQ is an array
09220 !          (dimensioned in F) and/or Y has length exceeding NEQ(1).
09221 !          See the descriptions of NEQ and Y below.
09222 !
09223 !          If quantities computed in the F routine are needed
09224 !          externally to DLSODKR, an extra call to F should be made
09225 !          for this purpose, for consistent and accurate results.
09226 !          If only the derivative dy/dt is needed, use DINTDY instead.
09227 !
09228 ! NEQ    = the size of the ODE system (number of first order
09229 !          ordinary differential equations).  Used only for input.
09230 !          NEQ may be decreased, but not increased, during the problem.
09231 !          If NEQ is decreased (with ISTATE = 3 on input), the
09232 !          remaining components of Y should be left undisturbed, if
09233 !          these are to be accessed in the user-supplied routines.
09234 !
09235 !          Normally, NEQ is a scalar, and it is generally referred to
09236 !          as a scalar in this user interface description.  However,
09237 !          NEQ may be an array, with NEQ(1) set to the system size.
09238 !          (The DLSODKR package accesses only NEQ(1).)  In either case,
09239 !          this parameter is passed as the NEQ argument in all calls
09240 !          to the user-supplied routines.  Hence, if it is an array,
09241 !          locations NEQ(2),... may be used to store other integer data
09242 !          and pass it to the user-supplied routines. Each such routine
09243 !          must include NEQ in a Dimension statement in that case.
09244 !
09245 ! Y      = a real array for the vector of dependent variables, of
09246 !          length NEQ or more.  Used for both input and output on the
09247 !          first call (ISTATE = 1), and only for output on other calls.
09248 !          On the first call, Y must contain the vector of initial
09249 !          values.  On output, Y contains the computed solution vector,
09250 !          evaluated at T.  If desired, the Y array may be used
09251 !          for other purposes between calls to the solver.
09252 !
09253 !          This array is passed as the Y argument in all calls to F, G,
09254 !          JAC, and PSOL.  Hence its length may exceed NEQ, and
09255 !          locations Y(NEQ+1),... may be used to store other real data
09256 !          and pass it to the user-supplied routines.
09257 !          (The DLSODKR package accesses only Y(1),...,Y(NEQ).)
09258 !
09259 ! T      = the independent variable.  On input, T is used only on the
09260 !          first call, as the initial point of the integration.
09261 !          On output, after each call, T is the value at which a
09262 !          computed solution y is evaluated (usually the same as TOUT).
09263 !          If a root was found, T is the computed location of the
09264 !          root reached first, on output.
09265 !          On an error return, T is the farthest point reached.
09266 !
09267 ! TOUT   = the next value of t at which a computed solution is desired.
09268 !          Used only for input.
09269 !
09270 !          When starting the problem (ISTATE = 1), TOUT may be equal
09271 !          to T for one call, then should .ne. T for the next call.
09272 !          For the initial T, an input value of TOUT .ne. T is used
09273 !          in order to determine the direction of the integration
09274 !          (i.e. the algebraic sign of the step sizes) and the rough
09275 !          scale of the problem.  Integration in either direction
09276 !          (forward or backward in t) is permitted.
09277 !
09278 !          If ITASK = 2 or 5 (one-step modes), TOUT is ignored after
09279 !          the first call (i.e. the first call with TOUT .ne. T).
09280 !          Otherwise, TOUT is required on every call.
09281 !
09282 !          If ITASK = 1, 3, or 4, the values of TOUT need not be
09283 !          monotone, but a value of TOUT which backs up is limited
09284 !          to the current internal T interval, whose endpoints are
09285 !          TCUR - HU and TCUR (see optional outputs, below, for
09286 !          TCUR and HU).
09287 !
09288 ! ITOL   = an indicator for the type of error control.  See
09289 !          description below under ATOL.  Used only for input.
09290 !
09291 ! RTOL   = a relative error tolerance parameter, either a scalar or
09292 !          an array of length NEQ.  See description below under ATOL.
09293 !          Input only.
09294 !
09295 ! ATOL   = an absolute error tolerance parameter, either a scalar or
09296 !          an array of length NEQ.  Input only.
09297 !
09298 !             The input parameters ITOL, RTOL, and ATOL determine
09299 !          the error control performed by the solver.  The solver will
09300 !          control the vector E = (E(i)) of estimated local errors
09301 !          in y, according to an inequality of the form
09302 !                      RMS-norm of ( E(i)/EWT(i) )   .le.   1,
09303 !          where       EWT(i) = RTOL(i)*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i),
09304 !          and the RMS-norm (root-mean-square norm) here is
09305 !          RMS-norm(v) = SQRT(sum v(i)**2 / NEQ).  Here EWT = (EWT(i))
09306 !          is a vector of weights which must always be positive, and
09307 !          the values of RTOL and ATOL should all be non-negative.
09308 !          The following table gives the types (scalar/array) of
09309 !          RTOL and ATOL, and the corresponding form of EWT(i).
09310 !
09311 !             ITOL    RTOL       ATOL          EWT(i)
09312 !              1     scalar     scalar     RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL
09313 !              2     scalar     array      RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i)
09314 !              3     array      scalar     RTOL(i)*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL
09315 !              4     array      array      RTOL(i)*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i)
09316 !
09317 !          When either of these parameters is a scalar, it need not
09318 !          be dimensioned in the user's calling program.
09319 !
09320 !          If none of the above choices (with ITOL, RTOL, and ATOL
09321 !          fixed throughout the problem) is suitable, more general
09322 !          error controls can be obtained by substituting
09323 !          user-supplied routines for the setting of EWT and/or for
09324 !          the norm calculation.  See Part 4 below.
09325 !
09326 !          If global errors are to be estimated by making a repeated
09327 !          run on the same problem with smaller tolerances, then all
09328 !          components of RTOL and ATOL (i.e. of EWT) should be scaled
09329 !          down uniformly.
09330 !
09331 ! ITASK  = an index specifying the task to be performed.
09332 !          Input only.  ITASK has the following values and meanings.
09333 !          1  means normal computation of output values of y(t) at
09334 !             t = TOUT (by overshooting and interpolating).
09335 !          2  means take one step only and return.
09336 !          3  means stop at the first internal mesh point at or
09337 !             beyond t = TOUT and return.
09338 !          4  means normal computation of output values of y(t) at
09339 !             t = TOUT but without overshooting t = TCRIT.
09340 !             TCRIT must be input as RWORK(1).  TCRIT may be equal to
09341 !             or beyond TOUT, but not behind it in the direction of
09342 !             integration.  This option is useful if the problem
09343 !             has a singularity at or beyond t = TCRIT.
09344 !          5  means take one step, without passing TCRIT, and return.
09345 !             TCRIT must be input as RWORK(1).
09346 !
09347 !          Note:  If ITASK = 4 or 5 and the solver reaches TCRIT
09348 !          (within roundoff), it will return T = TCRIT (exactly) to
09349 !          indicate this (unless ITASK = 4 and TOUT comes before TCRIT,
09350 !          in which case answers at T = TOUT are returned first).
09351 !
09352 ! ISTATE = an index used for input and output to specify the
09353 !          the state of the calculation.
09354 !
09355 !          On input, the values of ISTATE are as follows.
09356 !          1  means this is the first call for the problem
09357 !             (initializations will be done).  See note below.
09358 !          2  means this is not the first call, and the calculation
09359 !             is to continue normally, with no change in any input
09360 !             parameters except possibly TOUT and ITASK.
09361 !             (If ITOL, RTOL, and/or ATOL are changed between calls
09362 !             with ISTATE = 2, the new values will be used but not
09363 !             tested for legality.)
09364 !          3  means this is not the first call, and the
09365 !             calculation is to continue normally, but with
09366 !             a change in input parameters other than
09367 !             TOUT and ITASK.  Changes are allowed in
09368 !             NEQ, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, IOPT, LRW, LIW, MF,
09369 !             and any of the optional inputs except H0.
09370 !             In addition, immediately following a return with
09371 !             ISTATE = 3 (root found), NG and G may be changed.
09372 !             (But changing NG from 0 to .gt. 0 is not allowed.)
09373 !          Note:  A preliminary call with TOUT = T is not counted
09374 !          as a first call here, as no initialization or checking of
09375 !          input is done.  (Such a call is sometimes useful for the
09376 !          purpose of outputting the initial conditions.)
09377 !          Thus the first call for which TOUT .ne. T requires
09378 !          ISTATE = 1 on input.
09379 !
09380 !          On output, ISTATE has the following values and meanings.
09381 !           1  means nothing was done; TOUT = T and ISTATE = 1 on input.
09382 !           2  means the integration was performed successfully.
09383 !           3  means the integration was successful, and one or more
09384 !              roots were found before satisfying the stop condition
09385 !              specified by ITASK.  See JROOT.
09386 !          -1  means an excessive amount of work (more than MXSTEP
09387 !              steps) was done on this call, before completing the
09388 !              requested task, but the integration was otherwise
09389 !              successful as far as T.  (MXSTEP is an optional input
09390 !              and is normally 500.)  To continue, the user may
09391 !              simply reset ISTATE to a value .gt. 1 and call again
09392 !              (the excess work step counter will be reset to 0).
09393 !              In addition, the user may increase MXSTEP to avoid
09394 !              this error return (see below on optional inputs).
09395 !          -2  means too much accuracy was requested for the precision
09396 !              of the machine being used.  This was detected before
09397 !              completing the requested task, but the integration
09398 !              was successful as far as T.  To continue, the tolerance
09399 !              parameters must be reset, and ISTATE must be set
09400 !              to 3.  The optional output TOLSF may be used for this
09401 !              purpose.  (Note: If this condition is detected before
09402 !              taking any steps, then an illegal input return
09403 !              (ISTATE = -3) occurs instead.)
09404 !          -3  means illegal input was detected, before taking any
09405 !              integration steps.  See written message for details.
09406 !              Note:  If the solver detects an infinite loop of calls
09407 !              to the solver with illegal input, it will cause
09408 !              the run to stop.
09409 !          -4  means there were repeated error test failures on
09410 !              one attempted step, before completing the requested
09411 !              task, but the integration was successful as far as T.
09412 !              The problem may have a singularity, or the input
09413 !              may be inappropriate.
09414 !          -5  means there were repeated convergence test failures on
09415 !              one attempted step, before completing the requested
09416 !              task, but the integration was successful as far as T.
09417 !          -6  means EWT(i) became zero for some i during the
09418 !              integration.  Pure relative error control (ATOL(i)=0.0)
09419 !              was requested on a variable which has now vanished.
09420 !              The integration was successful as far as T.
09421 !          -7  means the PSOL routine returned an unrecoverable error
09422 !              flag (IER .lt. 0).  The integration was successful as
09423 !              far as T.
09424 !
09425 !          Note:  Since the normal output value of ISTATE is 2,
09426 !          it does not need to be reset for normal continuation.
09427 !          Also, since a negative input value of ISTATE will be
09428 !          regarded as illegal, a negative output value requires the
09429 !          user to change it, and possibly other inputs, before
09430 !          calling the solver again.
09431 !
09432 ! IOPT   = an integer flag to specify whether or not any optional
09433 !          inputs are being used on this call.  Input only.
09434 !          The optional inputs are listed separately below.
09435 !          IOPT = 0 means no optional inputs are being used.
09436 !                   Default values will be used in all cases.
09437 !          IOPT = 1 means one or more optional inputs are being used.
09438 !
09439 ! RWORK  = a real working array (double precision).
09440 !          The length of RWORK must be at least
09441 !             20 + NYH*(MAXORD+1) + 3*NEQ + 3*NG + LENLS + LWP    where
09442 !          NYH    = the initial value of NEQ,
09443 !          MAXORD = 12 (if METH = 1) or 5 (if METH = 2) (unless a
09444 !                   smaller value is given as an optional input),
09445 !          LENLS = length of work space for linear system (Krylov)
09446 !                  method, excluding preconditioning:
09447 !            LENLS = 0                               if MITER = 0,
09448 !            LENLS = NEQ*(MAXL+3) + MAXL**2          if MITER = 1,
09449 !            LENLS = NEQ*(MAXL+3+MIN(1,MAXL-KMP))
09450 !                 + (MAXL+3)*MAXL + 1                if MITER = 2,
09451 !            LENLS = 6*NEQ                           if MITER = 3 or 4,
09452 !            LENLS = 3*NEQ                           if MITER = 9.
09453 !          (See the MF description for METH and MITER, and the
09454 !          list of optional inputs for MAXL and KMP.)
09455 !          LWP = length of real user work space for preconditioning
09456 !          (see JAC/PSOL).
09457 !          Thus if default values are used and NEQ is constant,
09458 !          this length is:
09459 !             20 + 16*NEQ + 3*NG           for MF = 10,
09460 !             45 + 24*NEQ + 3*NG + LWP     for MF = 11,
09461 !             61 + 24*NEQ + 3*NG + LWP     for MF = 12,
09462 !             20 + 22*NEQ + 3*NG + LWP     for MF = 13 or 14,
09463 !             20 + 19*NEQ + 3*NG + LWP     for MF = 19,
09464 !             20 + 9*NEQ + 3*NG            for MF = 20,
09465 !             45 + 17*NEQ + 3*NG + LWP     for MF = 21,
09466 !             61 + 17*NEQ + 3*NG + LWP     for MF = 22,
09467 !             20 + 15*NEQ + 3*NG + LWP     for MF = 23 or 24,
09468 !             20 + 12*NEQ + 3*NG + LWP     for MF = 29.
09469 !          The first 20 words of RWORK are reserved for conditional
09470 !          and optional inputs and optional outputs.
09471 !
09472 !          The following word in RWORK is a conditional input:
09473 !            RWORK(1) = TCRIT = critical value of t which the solver
09474 !                       is not to overshoot.  Required if ITASK is
09475 !                       4 or 5, and ignored otherwise.  (See ITASK.)
09476 !
09477 ! LRW    = the length of the array RWORK, as declared by the user.
09478 !          (This will be checked by the solver.)
09479 !
09480 ! IWORK  = an integer work array.  The length of IWORK must be at least
09481 !             30                 if MITER = 0 (MF = 10 or 20),
09482 !             30 + MAXL + LIWP   if MITER = 1 (MF = 11, 21),
09483 !             30 + LIWP          if MITER = 2, 3, 4, or 9.
09484 !          MAXL = 5 unless a different optional input value is given.
09485 !          LIWP = length of integer user work space for preconditioning
09486 !          (see conditional input list following).
09487 !          The first few words of IWORK are used for conditional and
09488 !          optional inputs and optional outputs.
09489 !
09490 !          The following 4 words in IWORK are conditional inputs,
09491 !          required if MITER .ge. 1:
09492 !          IWORK(1) = LWP  = length of real array WP for use in
09493 !                     preconditioning (part of RWORK array).
09494 !          IWORK(2) = LIWP = length of integer array IWP for use in
09495 !                     preconditioning (part of IWORK array).
09496 !                     The arrays WP and IWP are work arrays under the
09497 !                     user's control, for use in the routines that
09498 !                     perform preconditioning operations (JAC and PSOL).
09499 !          IWORK(3) = JPRE = preconditioner type flag:
09500 !                   = 0 for no preconditioning (P1 = P2 = P = identity)
09501 !                   = 1 for left-only preconditioning (P2 = identity)
09502 !                   = 2 for right-only preconditioning (P1 = identity)
09503 !                   = 3 for two-sided preconditioning (and PCG or PCGS)
09504 !          IWORK(4) = JACFLG = flag for whether JAC is called.
09505 !                   = 0 if JAC is not to be called,
09506 !                   = 1 if JAC is to be called.
09507 !                     Use JACFLG = 1 if JAC computes any nonconstant
09508 !                     data needed in preconditioning operations,
09509 !                     such as some of the Jacobian elements.
09510 !
09511 ! LIW    = the length of the array IWORK, as declared by the user.
09512 !          (This will be checked by the solver.)
09513 !
09514 ! Note:  The work arrays must not be altered between calls to DLSODKR
09515 ! for the same problem, except possibly for the conditional and
09516 ! optional inputs, and except for the last 3*NEQ words of RWORK.
09517 ! The latter space is used for internal scratch space, and so is
09518 ! available for use by the user outside DLSODKR between calls, if
09519 ! desired (but not for use by any of the user-supplied routines).
09520 !
09521 ! JAC    = the name of the user-supplied routine to compute any
09522 !          Jacobian elements (or approximations) involved in the
09523 !          matrix preconditioning operations (MITER .ge. 1).
09524 !          It is to have the form
09525 !            SUBROUTINE JAC (F, NEQ, T, Y, YSV, REWT, FTY, V,
09526 !           1                HL0, JOK, WP, IWP, IER)
09527 !            DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), YSV(*), REWT(*), FTY(*), V(*),
09528 !           1                 HL0, WP(*)
09529 !            INTEGER IWP(*)
09530 !          This routine must evaluate and preprocess any parts of the
09531 !          Jacobian matrix df/dy used in the preconditioners P1, P2, P.
09532 !          The Y and FTY arrays contain the current values of y and
09533 !          f(t,y), respectively, and the YSV array also contains
09534 !          the current y vector.  The array V is work space of length
09535 !          NEQ for use by JAC.  REWT is the array of reciprocal error
09536 !          weights (1/EWT).  JAC must multiply all computed Jacobian
09537 !          elements by the scalar -HL0, add the identity matrix, and do
09538 !          any factorization operations called for, in preparation
09539 !          for solving linear systems with a coefficient matrix of
09540 !          P1, P2, or P.  The matrix P1*P2 or P should be an
09541 !          approximation to  identity - hl0 * (df/dy).  JAC should
09542 !          return IER = 0 if successful, and IER .ne. 0 if not.
09543 !          (If IER .ne. 0, a smaller time step will be tried.)
09544 !          The arrays WP (of length LWP) and IWP (of length LIWP)
09545 !          are for use by JAC and PSOL for work space and for storage
09546 !          of data needed for the solution of the preconditioner
09547 !          linear systems.  Their lengths and contents are under the
09548 !          user's control.
09549 !               The argument JOK is an input flag for optional use
09550 !          by JAC in deciding whether to recompute Jacobian elements
09551 !          or use saved values.  If JOK = -1, then JAC must compute
09552 !          any relevant Jacobian elements (or approximations) used in
09553 !          the preconditioners.  Optionally, JAC may also save these
09554 !          elements for later reuse.  If JOK = 1, the integrator has
09555 !          made a judgement (based on the convergence history and the
09556 !          value of HL0) that JAC need not recompute Jacobian elements,
09557 !          but instead use saved values, and the current value of HL0,
09558 !          to reconstruct the preconditioner matrices, followed by
09559 !          any required factorizations.  This may be cost-effective if
09560 !          Jacobian elements are costly and storage is available.
09561 !               JAC may alter Y and V, but not YSV, REWT, FTY, or HL0.
09562 !          JAC must be declared External in the calling program.
09563 !               Subroutine JAC may access user-defined quantities in
09564 !          NEQ(2),... and/or in Y(NEQ(1)+1),... if NEQ is an array
09565 !          (dimensioned in JAC) and/or Y has length exceeding NEQ(1).
09566 !          See the descriptions of NEQ and Y above.
09567 !
09568 ! PSOL   = the name of the user-supplied routine for the
09569 !          solution of preconditioner linear systems.
09570 !          It is to have the form
09571 !            SUBROUTINE PSOL (NEQ, T, Y, FTY, WK,HL0, WP,IWP, B, LR,IER)
09572 !            DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), FTY(*), WK(*), HL0, WP(*), B(*)
09573 !            INTEGER IWP(*)
09574 !          This routine must solve a linear system with B as right-hand
09575 !          side and one of the preconditioning matrices, P1, P2, or P,
09576 !          as coefficient matrix, and return the solution vector in B.
09577 !          LR is a flag concerning left vs right preconditioning, input
09578 !          to PSOL.  PSOL is to use P1 if LR = 1 and P2 if LR = 2.
09579 !          In the case of the PCG or PCGS method, LR will be 3, and PSOL
09580 !          should solve the system P*x = B with the preconditioner P.
09581 !          In the case MITER = 9 (no Krylov iteration), LR will be 0,
09582 !          and PSOL is to return in B the desired approximate solution
09583 !          to A * x = B, where A = identity - hl0 * (df/dy).
09584 !          PSOL can use data generated in the JAC routine and stored in
09585 !          WP and IWP.
09586 !          The Y and FTY arrays contain the current values of y and
09587 !          f(t,y), respectively.  The array WK is work space of length
09588 !          NEQ for use by PSOL.
09589 !          The argument HL0 is the current value of the scalar appearing
09590 !          in the linear system.  If the old value, as of the last
09591 !          JAC call, is needed, it must have been saved by JAC in WP.
09592 !          On return, PSOL should set the error flag IER as follows:
09593 !            IER = 0 if PSOL was successful,
09594 !            IER .gt. 0 on a recoverable error, meaning that the
09595 !                   time step will be retried,
09596 !            IER .lt. 0 on an unrecoverable error, meaning that the
09597 !                   solver is to stop immediately.
09598 !          PSOL may not alter Y, FTY, or HL0.
09599 !          PSOL must be declared External in the calling program.
09600 !               Subroutine PSOL may access user-defined quantities in
09601 !          NEQ(2),... and Y(NEQ(1)+1),... if NEQ is an array
09602 !          (dimensioned in PSOL) and/or Y has length exceeding NEQ(1).
09603 !          See the descriptions of NEQ and Y above.
09604 !
09605 ! MF     = the method flag.  Used only for input.  The legal values of
09606 !          MF are 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, and 29.
09607 !          MF has decimal digits METH and MITER: MF = 10*METH + MITER.
09608 !          METH indicates the basic linear multistep method:
09609 !            METH = 1 means the implicit Adams method.
09610 !            METH = 2 means the method based on Backward
09611 !                     Differentiation Formulas (BDFs).
09612 !          MITER indicates the corrector iteration method:
09613 !            MITER = 0 means functional iteration (no linear system
09614 !                      is involved).
09615 !            MITER = 1 means Newton iteration with Scaled Preconditioned
09616 !                      Incomplete Orthogonalization Method (SPIOM)
09617 !                      for the linear systems.
09618 !            MITER = 2 means Newton iteration with Scaled Preconditioned
09619 !                      Incomplete Generalized Minimal Residual method
09620 !                      (SPIGMR) for the linear systems.
09621 !            MITER = 3 means Newton iteration with Preconditioned
09622 !                      Conjugate Gradient method (PCG)
09623 !                      for the linear systems.
09624 !            MITER = 4 means Newton iteration with scaled preconditioned
09625 !                      Conjugate Gradient method (PCGS)
09626 !                      for the linear systems.
09627 !            MITER = 9 means Newton iteration with only the
09628 !                      user-supplied PSOL routine called (no Krylov
09629 !                      iteration) for the linear systems.
09630 !                      JPRE is ignored, and PSOL is called with LR = 0.
09631 !          See comments in the introduction about the choice of MITER.
09632 !          If MITER .ge. 1, the user must supply routines JAC and PSOL
09633 !          (the names are arbitrary) as described above.
09634 !          For MITER = 0, a dummy argument can be used.
09635 !
09636 ! G      = the name of subroutine for constraint functions, whose
09637 !          roots are desired during the integration.  It is to have
09638 !          the form
09639 !               SUBROUTINE G (NEQ, T, Y, NG, GOUT)
09640 !               DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), GOUT(NG)
09641 !          where NEQ, T, Y, and NG are input, and the array GOUT
09642 !          is output.  NEQ, T, and Y have the same meaning as in
09643 !          the F routine, and GOUT is an array of length NG.
09644 !          For i = 1,...,NG, this routine is to load into GOUT(i)
09645 !          the value at (t,y) of the i-th constraint function g(i).
09646 !          DLSODKR will find roots of the g(i) of odd multiplicity
09647 !          (i.e. sign changes) as they occur during the integration.
09648 !          G must be declared External in the calling program.
09649 !
09650 !          Caution: Because of numerical errors in the functions
09651 !          g(i) due to roundoff and integration error, DLSODKR may
09652 !          return false roots, or return the same root at two or more
09653 !          nearly equal values of t.  If such false roots are
09654 !          suspected, the user should consider smaller error tolerances
09655 !          and/or higher precision in the evaluation of the g(i).
09656 !
09657 !          If a root of some g(i) defines the end of the problem,
09658 !          the input to DLSODKR should nevertheless allow integration
09659 !          to a point slightly past that root, so that DLSODKR can
09660 !          locate the root by interpolation.
09661 !
09662 !          Subroutine G may access user-defined quantities in
09663 !          NEQ(2),... and Y(NEQ(1)+1),... if NEQ is an array
09664 !          (dimensioned in G) and/or Y has length exceeding NEQ(1).
09665 !          See the descriptions of NEQ and Y above.
09666 !
09667 ! NG     = number of constraint functions g(i).  If there are none,
09668 !          set NG = 0, and pass a dummy name for G.
09669 !
09670 ! JROOT  = integer array of length NG.  Used only for output.
09671 !          On a return with ISTATE = 3 (one or more roots found),
09672 !          JROOT(i) = 1 if g(i) has a root at t, or JROOT(i) = 0 if not.
09673 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
09674 ! Optional Inputs.
09675 !
09676 ! The following is a list of the optional inputs provided for in the
09677 ! call sequence.  (See also Part 2.)  For each such input variable,
09678 ! this table lists its name as used in this documentation, its
09679 ! location in the call sequence, its meaning, and the default value.
09680 ! The use of any of these inputs requires IOPT = 1, and in that
09681 ! case all of these inputs are examined.  A value of zero for any
09682 ! of these optional inputs will cause the default value to be used.
09683 ! Thus to use a subset of the optional inputs, simply preload
09684 ! locations 5 to 10 in RWORK and IWORK to 0.0 and 0 respectively, and
09685 ! then set those of interest to nonzero values.
09686 !
09687 ! Name    Location      Meaning and Default Value
09688 !
09689 ! H0      RWORK(5)  the step size to be attempted on the first step.
09690 !                   The default value is determined by the solver.
09691 !
09692 ! HMAX    RWORK(6)  the maximum absolute step size allowed.
09693 !                   The default value is infinite.
09694 !
09695 ! HMIN    RWORK(7)  the minimum absolute step size allowed.
09696 !                   The default value is 0.  (This lower bound is not
09697 !                   enforced on the final step before reaching TCRIT
09698 !                   when ITASK = 4 or 5.)
09699 !
09700 ! DELT    RWORK(8)  convergence test constant in Krylov iteration
09701 !                   algorithm.  The default is .05.
09702 !
09703 ! MAXORD  IWORK(5)  the maximum order to be allowed.  The default
09704 !                   value is 12 if METH = 1, and 5 if METH = 2.
09705 !                   If MAXORD exceeds the default value, it will
09706 !                   be reduced to the default value.
09707 !                   If MAXORD is changed during the problem, it may
09708 !                   cause the current order to be reduced.
09709 !
09710 ! MXSTEP  IWORK(6)  maximum number of (internally defined) steps
09711 !                   allowed during one call to the solver.
09712 !                   The default value is 500.
09713 !
09714 ! MXHNIL  IWORK(7)  maximum number of messages printed (per problem)
09715 !                   warning that T + H = T on a step (H = step size).
09716 !                   This must be positive to result in a non-default
09717 !                   value.  The default value is 10.
09718 !
09719 ! MAXL    IWORK(8)  maximum number of iterations in the SPIOM, SPIGMR,
09720 !                   PCG, or PCGS algorithm (.le. NEQ).
09721 !                   The default is MAXL = MIN(5,NEQ).
09722 !
09723 ! KMP     IWORK(9)  number of vectors on which orthogonalization
09724 !                   is done in SPIOM or SPIGMR algorithm (.le. MAXL).
09725 !                   The default is KMP = MAXL.
09726 !                   Note:  When KMP .lt. MAXL and MF = 22, the length
09727 !                          of RWORK must be defined accordingly.  See
09728 !                          the definition of RWORK above.
09729 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
09730 ! Optional Outputs.
09731 !
09732 ! As optional additional output from DLSODKR, the variables listed
09733 ! below are quantities related to the performance of DLSODKR
09734 ! which are available to the user.  These are communicated by way of
09735 ! the work arrays, but also have internal mnemonic names as shown.
09736 ! Except where stated otherwise, all of these outputs are defined
09737 ! on any successful return from DLSODKR, and on any return with
09738 ! ISTATE = -1, -2, -4, -5, -6, or -7.  On an illegal input return
09739 ! (ISTATE = -3), they will be unchanged from their existing values
09740 ! (if any), except possibly for TOLSF, LENRW, and LENIW.
09741 ! On any error return, outputs relevant to the error will be defined,
09742 ! as noted below.
09743 !
09744 ! Name    Location      Meaning
09745 !
09746 ! HU      RWORK(11) the step size in t last used (successfully).
09747 !
09748 ! HCUR    RWORK(12) the step size to be attempted on the next step.
09749 !
09750 ! TCUR    RWORK(13) the current value of the independent variable
09751 !                   which the solver has actually reached, i.e. the
09752 !                   current internal mesh point in t.  On output, TCUR
09753 !                   will always be at least as far as the argument
09754 !                   T, but may be farther (if interpolation was done).
09755 !
09756 ! TOLSF   RWORK(14) a tolerance scale factor, greater than 1.0,
09757 !                   computed when a request for too much accuracy was
09758 !                   detected (ISTATE = -3 if detected at the start of
09759 !                   the problem, ISTATE = -2 otherwise).  If ITOL is
09760 !                   left unaltered but RTOL and ATOL are uniformly
09761 !                   scaled up by a factor of TOLSF for the next call,
09762 !                   then the solver is deemed likely to succeed.
09763 !                   (The user may also ignore TOLSF and alter the
09764 !                   tolerance parameters in any other way appropriate.)
09765 !
09766 ! NGE     IWORK(10) the number of g evaluations for the problem so far.
09767 !
09768 ! NST     IWORK(11) the number of steps taken for the problem so far.
09769 !
09770 ! NFE     IWORK(12) the number of f evaluations for the problem so far.
09771 !
09772 ! NPE     IWORK(13) the number of calls to JAC so far (for evaluation
09773 !                   of preconditioners).
09774 !
09775 ! NQU     IWORK(14) the method order last used (successfully).
09776 !
09777 ! NQCUR   IWORK(15) the order to be attempted on the next step.
09778 !
09779 ! IMXER   IWORK(16) the index of the component of largest magnitude in
09780 !                   the weighted local error vector ( E(i)/EWT(i) ),
09781 !                   on an error return with ISTATE = -4 or -5.
09782 !
09783 ! LENRW   IWORK(17) the length of RWORK actually required.
09784 !                   This is defined on normal returns and on an illegal
09785 !                   input return for insufficient storage.
09786 !
09787 ! LENIW   IWORK(18) the length of IWORK actually required.
09788 !                   This is defined on normal returns and on an illegal
09789 !                   input return for insufficient storage.
09790 !
09791 ! NNI     IWORK(19) number of nonlinear iterations so far (each of
09792 !                   which calls an iterative linear solver).
09793 !
09794 ! NLI     IWORK(20) number of linear iterations so far.
09795 !                   Note: A measure of the success of algorithm is
09796 !                   the average number of linear iterations per
09797 !                   nonlinear iteration, given by NLI/NNI.
09798 !                   If this is close to MAXL, MAXL may be too small.
09799 !
09800 ! NPS     IWORK(21) number of preconditioning solve operations
09801 !                   (PSOL calls) so far.
09802 !
09803 ! NCFN    IWORK(22) number of convergence failures of the nonlinear
09804 !                   (Newton) iteration so far.
09805 !                   Note: A measure of success is the overall
09806 !                   rate of nonlinear convergence failures, NCFN/NST.
09807 !
09808 ! NCFL    IWORK(23) number of convergence failures of the linear
09809 !                   iteration so far.
09810 !                   Note: A measure of success is the overall
09811 !                   rate of linear convergence failures, NCFL/NNI.
09812 !
09813 ! NSFI    IWORK(24) number of functional iteration steps so far.
09814 !                   Note: A measure of the extent to which the
09815 !                   problem is nonstiff is the ratio NSFI/NST.
09816 !
09817 ! NJEV    IWORK(25) number of JAC calls with JOK = -1 so far
09818 !                   (number of evaluations of Jacobian data).
09819 !
09820 ! The following two arrays are segments of the RWORK array which
09821 ! may also be of interest to the user as optional outputs.
09822 ! For each array, the table below gives its internal name,
09823 ! its base address in RWORK, and its description.
09824 !
09825 ! Name    Base Address      Description
09826 !
09827 ! YH      21 + 3*NG      the Nordsieck history array, of size NYH by
09828 !                        (NQCUR + 1), where NYH is the initial value
09829 !                        of NEQ.  For j = 0,1,...,NQCUR, column j+1
09830 !                        of YH contains HCUR**j/factorial(j) times
09831 !                        the j-th derivative of the interpolating
09832 !                        polynomial currently representing the solution,
09833 !                        evaluated at t = TCUR.
09834 !
09835 ! ACOR     LENRW-NEQ+1   array of size NEQ used for the accumulated
09836 !                        corrections on each step, scaled on output
09837 !                        to represent the estimated local error in y
09838 !                        on the last step.  This is the vector E in
09839 !                        the description of the error control.  It is
09840 !                        defined only on a successful return from
09841 !                        DLSODKR.
09842 !
09843 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
09844 ! Part 2.  Other Routines Callable.
09845 !
09846 ! The following are optional calls which the user may make to
09847 ! gain additional capabilities in conjunction with DLSODKR.
09848 ! (The routines XSETUN and XSETF are designed to conform to the
09849 ! SLATEC error handling package.)
09850 !
09851 !     Form of Call                  Function
09852 !   CALL XSETUN(LUN)          Set the logical unit number, LUN, for
09853 !                             output of messages from DLSODKR, if
09854 !                             the default is not desired.
09855 !                             The default value of LUN is 6.
09856 !
09857 !   CALL XSETF(MFLAG)         Set a flag to control the printing of
09858 !                             messages by DLSODKR.
09859 !                             MFLAG = 0 means do not print. (Danger:
09860 !                             This risks losing valuable information.)
09861 !                             MFLAG = 1 means print (the default).
09862 !
09863 !                             Either of the above calls may be made at
09864 !                             any time and will take effect immediately.
09865 !
09866 !   CALL DSRCKR(RSAV,ISAV,JOB) saves and restores the contents of
09867 !                             the internal Common blocks used by
09868 !                             DLSODKR (see Part 3 below).
09869 !                             RSAV must be a real array of length 228
09870 !                             or more, and ISAV must be an integer
09871 !                             array of length 63 or more.
09872 !                             JOB=1 means save Common into RSAV/ISAV.
09873 !                             JOB=2 means restore Common from RSAV/ISAV.
09874 !                                DSRCKR is useful if one is
09875 !                             interrupting a run and restarting
09876 !                             later, or alternating between two or
09877 !                             more problems solved with DLSODKR.
09878 !
09879 !   CALL DINTDY(,,,,,)        Provide derivatives of y, of various
09880 !        (see below)          orders, at a specified point t, if
09881 !                             desired.  It may be called only after
09882 !                             a successful return from DLSODKR.
09883 !
09884 ! The detailed instructions for using DINTDY are as follows.
09885 ! The form of the call is:
09886 !
09887 !   LYH = 21 + 3*NG
09888 !   CALL DINTDY (T, K, RWORK(LYH), NYH, DKY, IFLAG)
09889 !
09890 ! The input parameters are:
09891 !
09892 ! T         = value of independent variable where answers are desired
09893 !             (normally the same as the T last returned by DLSODKR).
09894 !             For valid results, T must lie between TCUR - HU and TCUR.
09895 !             (See optional outputs for TCUR and HU.)
09896 ! K         = integer order of the derivative desired.  K must satisfy
09897 !             0 .le. K .le. NQCUR, where NQCUR is the current order
09898 !             (see optional outputs).  The capability corresponding
09899 !             to K = 0, i.e. computing y(T), is already provided
09900 !             by DLSODKR directly.  Since NQCUR .ge. 1, the first
09901 !             derivative dy/dt is always available with DINTDY.
09902 ! LYH       = 21 + 3*NG = base address in RWORK of the history array YH.
09903 ! NYH       = column length of YH, equal to the initial value of NEQ.
09904 !
09905 ! The output parameters are:
09906 !
09907 ! DKY       = a real array of length NEQ containing the computed value
09908 !             of the K-th derivative of y(t).
09909 ! IFLAG     = integer flag, returned as 0 if K and T were legal,
09910 !             -1 if K was illegal, and -2 if T was illegal.
09911 !             On an error return, a message is also written.
09912 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
09913 ! Part 3.  Common Blocks.
09914 !
09915 ! If DLSODKR is to be used in an overlay situation, the user
09916 ! must declare, in the primary overlay, the variables in:
09917 !   (1) the call sequence to DLSODKR, and
09918 !   (2) the four internal Common blocks
09919 !         /DLS001/  of length  255  (218 double precision words
09920 !                      followed by 37 integer words),
09921 !         /DLS002/  of length   5  (1 double precision word
09922 !                      followed by  4 integer words),
09923 !         /DLPK01/  of length  17  (4 double precision words
09924 !                      followed by 13 integer words),
09925 !         /DLSR01/  of length  14     (5 double precision words
09926 !                      followed by  9 integer words).
09927 !
09928 ! If DLSODKR is used on a system in which the contents of internal
09929 ! Common blocks are not preserved between calls, the user should
09930 ! declare the above Common blocks in the calling program to insure
09931 ! that their contents are preserved.
09932 !
09933 ! If the solution of a given problem by DLSODKR is to be interrupted
09934 ! and then later continued, such as when restarting an interrupted run
09935 ! or alternating between two or more problems, the user should save,
09936 ! following the return from the last DLSODKR call prior to the
09937 ! interruption, the contents of the call sequence variables and the
09938 ! internal Common blocks, and later restore these values before the
09939 ! next DLSODKR call for that problem.  To save and restore the Common
09940 ! blocks, use Subroutine DSRCKR (see Part 2 above).
09941 !
09942 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
09943 ! Part 4.  Optionally Replaceable Solver Routines.
09944 !
09945 ! Below are descriptions of two routines in the DLSODKR package which
09946 ! relate to the measurement of errors.  Either routine can be
09947 ! replaced by a user-supplied version, if desired.  However, since such
09948 ! a replacement may have a major impact on performance, it should be
09949 ! done only when absolutely necessary, and only with great caution.
09950 ! (Note: The means by which the package version of a routine is
09951 ! superseded by the user's version may be system-dependent.)
09952 !
09953 ! (a) DEWSET.
09954 ! The following subroutine is called just before each internal
09955 ! integration step, and sets the array of error weights, EWT, as
09956 ! described under ITOL/RTOL/ATOL above:
09957 !     SUBROUTINE DEWSET (NEQ, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, YCUR, EWT)
09958 ! where NEQ, ITOL, RTOL, and ATOL are as in the DLSODKR call sequence,
09959 ! YCUR contains the current dependent variable vector, and
09960 ! EWT is the array of weights set by DEWSET.
09961 !
09962 ! If the user supplies this subroutine, it must return in EWT(i)
09963 ! (i = 1,...,NEQ) a positive quantity suitable for comparing errors
09964 ! in y(i) to.  The EWT array returned by DEWSET is passed to the DVNORM
09965 ! routine (see below), and also used by DLSODKR in the computation
09966 ! of the optional output IMXER, the diagonal Jacobian approximation,
09967 ! and the increments for difference quotient Jacobians.
09968 !
09969 ! In the user-supplied version of DEWSET, it may be desirable to use
09970 ! the current values of derivatives of y.  Derivatives up to order NQ
09971 ! are available from the history array YH, described above under
09972 ! optional outputs.  In DEWSET, YH is identical to the YCUR array,
09973 ! extended to NQ + 1 columns with a column length of NYH and scale
09974 ! factors of H**j/factorial(j).  On the first call for the problem,
09975 ! given by NST = 0, NQ is 1 and H is temporarily set to 1.0.
09976 ! NYH is the initial value of NEQ.  The quantities NQ, H, and NST
09977 ! can be obtained by including in DEWSET the statements:
09978 !     DOUBLE PRECISION RLS
09979 !     COMMON /DLS001/ RLS(218),ILS(37)
09980 !     NQ = ILS(33)
09981 !     NST = ILS(34)
09982 !     H = RLS(212)
09983 ! Thus, for example, the current value of dy/dt can be obtained as
09984 ! YCUR(NYH+i)/H  (i=1,...,NEQ)  (and the division by H is
09985 ! unnecessary when NST = 0).
09986 !
09987 ! (b) DVNORM.
09988 ! The following is a real function routine which computes the weighted
09989 ! root-mean-square norm of a vector v:
09990 !     D = DVNORM (N, V, W)
09991 ! where:
09992 !   N = the length of the vector,
09993 !   V = real array of length N containing the vector,
09994 !   W = real array of length N containing weights,
09995 !   D = SQRT( (1/N) * sum(V(i)*W(i))**2 ).
09996 ! DVNORM is called with N = NEQ and with W(i) = 1.0/EWT(i), where
09997 ! EWT is as set by Subroutine DEWSET.
09998 !
09999 ! If the user supplies this function, it should return a non-negative
10000 ! value of DVNORM suitable for use in the error control in DLSODKR.
10001 ! None of the arguments should be altered by DVNORM.
10002 ! For example, a user-supplied DVNORM routine might:
10003 !   -substitute a max-norm of (V(i)*W(i)) for the RMS-norm, or
10004 !   -ignore some components of V in the norm, with the effect of
10005 !    suppressing the error control on those components of y.
10006 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10007 !
10008 !***REVISION HISTORY  (YYYYMMDD)
10009 ! 19900117  DATE WRITTEN
10010 ! 19900503  Added iteration switching (functional/Newton).
10011 ! 19900802  Added flag for Jacobian-saving in user preconditioner.
10012 ! 19900910  Added new initial stepsize routine LHIN.
10013 ! 19901019  Corrected LHIN - y array restored.
10014 ! 19910909  Changed names STOPK to STOKA, PKSET to SETPK;
10015 !           removed unused variables in driver declarations;
10016 !           minor corrections to main prologue.
10017 ! 20010425  Major update: convert source lines to upper case;
10018 !           added *DECK lines; changed from 1 to * in dummy dimensions;
10019 !           changed names R1MACH/D1MACH to RUMACH/DUMACH;
10020 !           renamed routines for uniqueness across single/double prec.;
10021 !           converted intrinsic names to generic form;
10022 !           removed ILLIN and NTREP (data loaded) from Common;
10023 !           removed all 'own' variables from Common;
10024 !           changed error messages to quoted strings;
10025 !           replaced XERRWV/XERRWD with 1993 revised version;
10026 !           converted prologues, comments, error messages to mixed case;
10027 !           numerous corrections to prologues and internal comments.
10028 ! 20010507  Converted single precision source to double precision.
10029 ! 20020502  Corrected declarations in descriptions of user routines.
10030 ! 20030603  Corrected duplicate type declaration for DUMACH.
10031 ! 20031105  Restored 'own' variables to Common blocks, to enable
10032 !           interrupt/restart feature.
10033 ! 20031112  Added SAVE statements for data-loaded constants.
10034 ! 20031117  Changed internal name NPE to NJE.
10035 !
10036 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10037 ! Other routines in the DLSODKR package.
10038 !
10039 ! In addition to Subroutine DLSODKR, the DLSODKR package includes the
10040 ! following subroutines and function routines:
10041 !  DLHIN    calculates a step size to be attempted initially.
10042 !  DRCHEK   does preliminary checking for roots, and serves as an
10043 !           interface between Subroutine DLSODKR and Subroutine DROOTS.
10044 !  DROOTS   finds the leftmost root of a set of functions.
10045 !  DINTDY   computes an interpolated value of the y vector at t = TOUT.
10046 !  DEWSET   sets the error weight vector EWT before each step.
10047 !  DVNORM   computes the weighted RMS-norm of a vector.
10048 !  DSTOKA   is the core integrator, which does one step of the
10049 !           integration and the associated error control.
10050 !  DCFODE   sets all method coefficients and test constants.
10051 !  DSETPK   interfaces between DSTOKA and the JAC routine.
10052 !  DSOLPK   manages solution of linear system in Newton iteration.
10053 !  DSPIOM   performs the SPIOM algorithm.
10054 !  DATV     computes a scaled, preconditioned product (I-hl0*J)*v.
10055 !  DORTHOG  orthogonalizes a vector against previous basis vectors.
10056 !  DHEFA    generates an LU factorization of a Hessenberg matrix.
10057 !  DHESL    solves a Hessenberg square linear system.
10058 !  DSPIGMR  performs the SPIGMR algorithm.
10059 !  DHEQR    generates a QR factorization of a Hessenberg matrix.
10060 !  DHELS    finds the least squares solution of a Hessenberg system.
10061 !  DPCG     performs preconditioned conjugate gradient algorithm (PCG).
10062 !  DPCGS    performs the PCGS algorithm.
10063 !  DATP     computes the product A*p, where A = I - hl0*df/dy.
10064 !  DUSOL    interfaces to the user's PSOL routine (MITER = 9).
10065 !  DSRCKR   is a user-callable routine to save and restore
10066 !           the contents of the internal Common blocks.
10067 !  DAXPY, DCOPY, DDOT, DNRM2, and DSCAL   are basic linear
10068 !           algebra modules (from the BLAS collection).
10069 !  DUMACH   computes the unit roundoff in a machine-independent manner.
10070 !  XERRWD, XSETUN, XSETF, IXSAV, and IUMACH  handle the printing of all
10071 !           error messages and warnings.  XERRWD is machine-dependent.
10072 ! Note:  DVNORM, DDOT, DNRM2, DUMACH, IXSAV, and IUMACH are function
10073 ! routines.  All the others are subroutines.
10074 !
10075 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10076 DOUBLE PRECISION DUMACH, DVNORM
10077 INTEGER INIT, MXSTEP, MXHNIL, NHNIL, NSLAST, NYH, IOWNS, ICF, IERPJ, IERSL, JCUR, JSTART, KFLAG, L, LYH
10078 INTEGER LEWT, LACOR, LSAVF, LWM, LIWM, METH, MITER, MAXORD, MAXCOR, MSBP, MXNCF, N, NQ, NST, NFE, NJE, NQU
10079 INTEGER NEWT, NSFI, NSLJ, NJEV
10080 INTEGER LG0, LG1, LGX, IOWNR3, IRFND, ITASKC, NGC, NGE
10081 INTEGER JPRE, JACFLG, LOCWP, LOCIWP, LSAVX, KMP, MAXL, MNEWT, NNI, NLI, NPS, NCFN, NCFL
10082 INTEGER I, I1, I2, IER, IFLAG, IMXER, KGO, LF0, LENIW, LENIWK, LENRW, LENWM, LENWK, LIWP, LWP, MORD, MXHNL0
10083 INTEGER MXSTP0, NCFN0, NCFL0, NITER, NLI0, NNI0, NNID, NSTD, NWARN
10084 INTEGER IRFP, IRT, LENYH, LYHNEW
10085 DOUBLE PRECISION ROWNS, CCMAX, EL0, H, HMIN, HMXI, HU, RC, TN, UROUND
10086 DOUBLE PRECISION STIFR
10087 DOUBLE PRECISION ROWNR3, T0, TLAST, TOUTC
10088 DOUBLE PRECISION DELT, EPCON, SQRTN, RSQRTN
10089 DOUBLE PRECISION ATOLI, AVDIM, BIG, EWTI, H0, HMAX, HMX, RCFL, RCFN, RH, RTOLI, TCRIT, TNEXT, TOLSF, TP, SIZE
10090 DIMENSION MORD(2)
10091 LOGICAL IHIT, LAVD, LCFN, LCFL, LWARN
10092 character(len=60) MSG
10093 SAVE MORD, MXSTP0, MXHNL0
10094 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10095 ! The following four internal Common blocks contain
10096 ! (a) variables which are local to any subroutine but whose values must
10097 !     be preserved between calls to the routine ("own" variables), and
10098 ! (b) variables which are communicated between subroutines.
10099 ! The block DLS001 is declared in subroutines DLSODKR, DINTDY,
10100 ! DSTOKA, DSOLPK, and DATV.
10101 ! The block DLS002 is declared in subroutines DLSODKR and DSTOKA.
10102 ! The block DLSR01 is declared in subroutines DLSODKR, DRCHEK, DROOTS.
10103 ! The block DLPK01 is declared in subroutines DLSODKR, DSTOKA, DSETPK,
10104 ! and DSOLPK.
10105 ! Groups of variables are replaced by dummy arrays in the Common
10106 ! declarations in routines where those variables are not used.
10107 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10108 COMMON /DLS001/ ROWNS(209), CCMAX, EL0, H, HMIN, HMXI, HU, RC, TN, UROUND, INIT, MXSTEP, MXHNIL, NHNIL, NSLAST, NYH, & 
10109 IOWNS( 6), ICF, IERPJ, IERSL, JCUR, JSTART, KFLAG, L, LYH, LEWT, LACOR, LSAVF, LWM, LIWM, METH, MITER, MAXORD, MAXCOR, &
10110 MSBP, MXNCF, N, NQ, NST, NFE, NJE, NQU
10111 !
10112 COMMON /DLS002/ STIFR, NEWT, NSFI, NSLJ, NJEV
10113 !
10114 COMMON /DLSR01/ ROWNR3(2), T0, TLAST, TOUTC, LG0, LG1, LGX, IOWNR3(2), IRFND, ITASKC, NGC, NGE
10115 !
10116 COMMON /DLPK01/ DELT, EPCON, SQRTN, RSQRTN, JPRE, JACFLG, LOCWP, LOCIWP, LSAVX, KMP, MAXL, MNEWT, NNI, NLI, NPS, NCFN, NCFL
10117 !
10118 DATA MORD(1),MORD(2)/12,5/, MXSTP0/500/, MXHNL0/10/
10119 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10120 ! Block A.
10121 ! This code block is executed on every call.
10122 ! It tests ISTATE and ITASK for legality and branches appropriately.
10123 ! If ISTATE .gt. 1 but the flag INIT shows that initialization has
10124 ! not yet been done, an error return occurs.
10125 ! If ISTATE = 1 and TOUT = T, return immediately.
10126 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10127 IF (ISTATE .LT. 1 .OR. ISTATE .GT. 3) GOTO 601
10128 IF (ITASK .LT. 1 .OR. ITASK .GT. 5) GOTO 602
10129 ITASKC = ITASK
10130 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) GOTO 10
10131 IF (INIT .EQ. 0) GOTO 603
10132 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 2) GOTO 200
10133 GOTO 20
10134 10   INIT = 0
10135 IF (TOUT .EQ. T) RETURN
10136 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10137 ! Block B.
10138 ! The next code block is executed for the initial call (ISTATE = 1),
10139 ! or for a continuation call with parameter changes (ISTATE = 3).
10140 ! It contains checking of all inputs and various initializations.
10141 !
10142 ! First check legality of the non-optional inputs NEQ, ITOL, IOPT, MF,
10143 ! and NG.
10144 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10145 20   IF (NEQ(1) .LE. 0) GOTO 604
10146 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) GOTO 25
10147 IF (NEQ(1) .GT. N) GOTO 605
10148 25   N = NEQ(1)
10149 IF (ITOL .LT. 1 .OR. ITOL .GT. 4) GOTO 606
10150 IF (IOPT .LT. 0 .OR. IOPT .GT. 1) GOTO 607
10151 METH = MF/10
10152 MITER = MF - 10*METH
10153 IF (METH .LT. 1 .OR. METH .GT. 2) GOTO 608
10154 IF (MITER .LT. 0) GOTO 608
10155 IF (MITER .GT. 4 .AND. MITER .LT. 9) GOTO 608
10156 IF (MITER .GE. 1) JPRE = IWORK(3)
10157 JACFLG = 0
10158 IF (MITER .GE. 1) JACFLG = IWORK(4)
10159 IF (NG .LT. 0) GOTO 630
10160 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) GOTO 35
10161 IF (IRFND .EQ. 0 .AND. NG .NE. NGC) GOTO 631
10162 35   NGC = NG
10163 ! Next process and check the optional inputs. --------------------------
10164 IF (IOPT .EQ. 1) GOTO 40
10165 MAXORD = MORD(METH)
10166 MXSTEP = MXSTP0
10167 MXHNIL = MXHNL0
10168 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) H0 = 0.0D0
10169 HMXI = 0.0D0
10170 HMIN = 0.0D0
10171 MAXL = MIN(5,N)
10172 KMP = MAXL
10173 DELT = 0.05D0
10174 GOTO 60
10175 40   MAXORD = IWORK(5)
10176 IF (MAXORD .LT. 0) GOTO 611
10177 IF (MAXORD .EQ. 0) MAXORD = 100
10178 MAXORD = MIN(MAXORD,MORD(METH))
10179 MXSTEP = IWORK(6)
10180 IF (MXSTEP .LT. 0) GOTO 612
10181 IF (MXSTEP .EQ. 0) MXSTEP = MXSTP0
10182 MXHNIL = IWORK(7)
10183 IF (MXHNIL .LT. 0) GOTO 613
10184 IF (MXHNIL .EQ. 0) MXHNIL = MXHNL0
10185 IF (ISTATE .NE. 1) GOTO 50
10186 H0 = RWORK(5)
10187 IF ((TOUT - T)*H0 .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 614
10188 50   HMAX = RWORK(6)
10189 IF (HMAX .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 615
10190 HMXI = 0.0D0
10191 IF (HMAX .GT. 0.0D0) HMXI = 1.0D0/HMAX
10192 HMIN = RWORK(7)
10193 IF (HMIN .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 616
10194 MAXL = IWORK(8)
10195 IF (MAXL .EQ. 0) MAXL = 5
10196 MAXL = MIN(MAXL,N)
10197 KMP = IWORK(9)
10198 IF (KMP .EQ. 0 .OR. KMP .GT. MAXL) KMP = MAXL
10199 DELT = RWORK(8)
10200 IF (DELT .EQ. 0.0D0) DELT = 0.05D0
10201 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10202 ! Set work array pointers and check lengths LRW and LIW.
10203 ! Pointers to segments of RWORK and IWORK are named by prefixing L to
10204 ! the name of the segment.  E.g., the segment YH starts at RWORK(LYH).
10205 ! RWORK segments (in order) are denoted  G0, G1, GX, YH, WM,
10206 ! EWT, SAVF, SAVX, ACOR.
10207 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10208 60   IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) NYH = N
10209 LG0 = 21
10210 LG1 = LG0 + NG
10211 LGX = LG1 + NG
10212 LYHNEW = LGX + NG
10213 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) LYH = LYHNEW
10214 IF (LYHNEW .EQ. LYH) GOTO 62
10215 ! If ISTATE = 3 and NG was changed, shift YH to its new location. ------
10216 LENYH = L*NYH
10217 IF (LRW .LT. LYHNEW-1+LENYH) GOTO 62
10218 I1 = 1
10219 IF (LYHNEW .GT. LYH) I1 = -1
10220 CALL DCOPY (LENYH, RWORK(LYH), I1, RWORK(LYHNEW), I1)
10221 LYH = LYHNEW
10222 62   CONTINUE
10223 LWM = LYH + (MAXORD + 1)*NYH
10224 IF (MITER .EQ. 0) LENWK = 0
10225 IF (MITER .EQ. 1) LENWK = N*(MAXL+2) + MAXL*MAXL
10226 IF (MITER .EQ. 2) LENWK = N*(MAXL+2+MIN(1,MAXL-KMP)) + (MAXL+3)*MAXL + 1
10227 IF (MITER .EQ. 3 .OR. MITER .EQ. 4) LENWK = 5*N
10228 IF (MITER .EQ. 9) LENWK = 2*N
10229 LWP = 0
10230 IF (MITER .GE. 1) LWP = IWORK(1)
10231 LENWM = LENWK + LWP
10232 LOCWP = LENWK + 1
10233 LEWT = LWM + LENWM
10234 LSAVF = LEWT + N
10235 LSAVX = LSAVF + N
10236 LACOR = LSAVX + N
10237 IF (MITER .EQ. 0) LACOR = LSAVF + N
10238 LENRW = LACOR + N - 1
10239 IWORK(17) = LENRW
10240 LIWM = 31
10241 LENIWK = 0
10242 IF (MITER .EQ. 1) LENIWK = MAXL
10243 LIWP = 0
10244 IF (MITER .GE. 1) LIWP = IWORK(2)
10245 LENIW = 30 + LENIWK + LIWP
10246 LOCIWP = LENIWK + 1
10247 IWORK(18) = LENIW
10248 IF (LENRW .GT. LRW) GOTO 617
10249 IF (LENIW .GT. LIW) GOTO 618
10250 ! Check RTOL and ATOL for legality. ------------------------------------
10251 RTOLI = RTOL(1)
10252 ATOLI = ATOL(1)
10253 DO 70 I = 1,N
10254 IF (ITOL .GE. 3) RTOLI = RTOL(I)
10255 IF (ITOL .EQ. 2 .OR. ITOL .EQ. 4) ATOLI = ATOL(I)
10256 IF (RTOLI .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 619
10257 IF (ATOLI .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 620
10258 70     CONTINUE
10259 ! Load SQRT(N) and its reciprocal in Common. ---------------------------
10260 SQRTN = SQRT(REAL(N))
10261 RSQRTN = 1.0D0/SQRTN
10262 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) GOTO 100
10263 ! If ISTATE = 3, set flag to signal parameter changes to DSTOKA.--------
10264 JSTART = -1
10265 IF (NQ .LE. MAXORD) GOTO 90
10266 ! MAXORD was reduced below NQ.  Copy YH(*,MAXORD+2) into SAVF. ---------
10267 DO 80 I = 1,N
10268 80     RWORK(I+LSAVF-1) = RWORK(I+LWM-1)
10269 90   CONTINUE
10270 IF (N .EQ. NYH) GOTO 200
10271 ! NEQ was reduced.  Zero part of YH to avoid undefined references. -----
10272 I1 = LYH + L*NYH
10273 I2 = LYH + (MAXORD + 1)*NYH - 1
10274 IF (I1 .GT. I2) GOTO 200
10275 DO 95 I = I1,I2
10276 95     RWORK(I) = 0.0D0
10277 GOTO 200
10278 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10279 ! Block C.
10280 ! The next block is for the initial call only (ISTATE = 1).
10281 ! It contains all remaining initializations, the initial call to F,
10282 ! and the calculation of the initial step size.
10283 ! The error weights in EWT are inverted after being loaded.
10284 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10285 100  UROUND = DUMACH()
10286 TN = T
10287 IF (ITASK .NE. 4 .AND. ITASK .NE. 5) GOTO 110
10288 TCRIT = RWORK(1)
10289 IF ((TCRIT - TOUT)*(TOUT - T) .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 625
10290 IF (H0 .NE. 0.0D0 .AND. (T + H0 - TCRIT)*H0 .GT. 0.0D0) H0 = TCRIT - T
10291 110  JSTART = 0
10292 NHNIL = 0
10293 NST = 0
10294 NJE = 0
10295 NSLAST = 0
10296 NLI0 = 0
10297 NNI0 = 0
10298 NCFN0 = 0
10299 NCFL0 = 0
10300 NWARN = 0
10301 HU = 0.0D0
10302 NQU = 0
10303 CCMAX = 0.3D0
10304 MAXCOR = 3
10305 MSBP = 20
10306 MXNCF = 10
10307 NNI = 0
10308 NLI = 0
10309 NPS = 0
10310 NCFN = 0
10311 NCFL = 0
10312 NSFI = 0
10313 NJEV = 0
10314 ! Initial call to F.  (LF0 points to YH(*,2).) -------------------------
10315 LF0 = LYH + NYH
10316 CALL F (NEQ, T, Y, RWORK(LF0))
10317 NFE = 1
10318 ! Load the initial value vector in YH. ---------------------------------
10319 DO 115 I = 1,N
10320 115    RWORK(I+LYH-1) = Y(I)
10321 ! Load and invert the EWT array.  (H is temporarily set to 1.0.) -------
10322 NQ = 1
10323 H = 1.0D0
10324 CALL DEWSET (N, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LEWT))
10325 DO 120 I = 1,N
10326 IF (RWORK(I+LEWT-1) .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 621
10327 120    RWORK(I+LEWT-1) = 1.0D0/RWORK(I+LEWT-1)
10328 IF (H0 .NE. 0.0D0) GOTO 180
10329 ! Call DLHIN to set initial step size H0 to be attempted. --------------
10330 CALL DLHIN (NEQ, N, T, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LF0), F, TOUT, UROUND, RWORK(LEWT), ITOL, ATOL, Y, RWORK(LACOR), H0, NITER, IER)
10331 NFE = NFE + NITER
10332 IF (IER .NE. 0) GOTO 622
10333 ! Adjust H0 if necessary to meet HMAX bound. ---------------------------
10334 180  RH = ABS(H0)*HMXI
10335 IF (RH .GT. 1.0D0) H0 = H0/RH
10336 ! Load H with H0 and scale YH(*,2) by H0. ------------------------------
10337 H = H0
10338 DO 190 I = 1,N
10339 190    RWORK(I+LF0-1) = H0*RWORK(I+LF0-1)
10340 ! Check for a zero of g at T. ------------------------------------------
10341 IRFND = 0
10342 TOUTC = TOUT
10343 IF (NGC .EQ. 0) GOTO 270
10344 CALL DRCHEK (1, G, NEQ, Y, RWORK(LYH), NYH, RWORK(LG0), RWORK(LG1), RWORK(LGX), JROOT, IRT)
10345 IF (IRT .EQ. 0) GOTO 270
10346 GOTO 632
10347 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10348 ! Block D.
10349 ! The next code block is for continuation calls only (ISTATE = 2 or 3)
10350 ! and is to check stop conditions before taking a step.
10351 ! First, DRCHEK is called to check for a root within the last step
10352 ! taken, other than the last root found there, if any.
10353 ! If ITASK = 2 or 5, and y(TN) has not yet been returned to the user
10354 ! because of an intervening root, return through Block G.
10355 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10356 200  NSLAST = NST
10357 !
10358 IRFP = IRFND
10359 IF (NGC .EQ. 0) GOTO 205
10360 IF (ITASK .EQ. 1 .OR. ITASK .EQ. 4) TOUTC = TOUT
10361 CALL DRCHEK (2, G, NEQ, Y, RWORK(LYH), NYH, RWORK(LG0), RWORK(LG1), RWORK(LGX), JROOT, IRT)
10362 IF (IRT .NE. 1) GOTO 205
10363 IRFND = 1
10364 ISTATE = 3
10365 T = T0
10366 GOTO 425
10367 205  CONTINUE
10368 IRFND = 0
10369 IF (IRFP .EQ. 1 .AND. TLAST .NE. TN .AND. ITASK .EQ. 2) GOTO 400
10370 !
10371 NLI0 = NLI
10372 NNI0 = NNI
10373 NCFN0 = NCFN
10374 NCFL0 = NCFL
10375 NWARN = 0
10376 GOTO (210, 250, 220, 230, 240), ITASK
10377 210  IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
10378 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
10379 IF (IFLAG .NE. 0) GOTO 627
10380 T = TOUT
10381 GOTO 420
10382 220  TP = TN - HU*(1.0D0 + 100.0D0*UROUND)
10383 IF ((TP - TOUT)*H .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 623
10384 IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
10385 GOTO 400
10386 230  TCRIT = RWORK(1)
10387 IF ((TN - TCRIT)*H .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 624
10388 IF ((TCRIT - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 625
10389 IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 245
10390 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
10391 IF (IFLAG .NE. 0) GOTO 627
10392 T = TOUT
10393 GOTO 420
10394 240  TCRIT = RWORK(1)
10395 IF ((TN - TCRIT)*H .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 624
10396 245  HMX = ABS(TN) + ABS(H)
10397 IHIT = ABS(TN - TCRIT) .LE. 100.0D0*UROUND*HMX
10398 IF (IHIT) T = TCRIT
10399 IF (IRFP .EQ. 1 .AND. TLAST .NE. TN .AND. ITASK .EQ. 5) GOTO 400
10400 IF (IHIT) GOTO 400
10401 TNEXT = TN + H*(1.0D0 + 4.0D0*UROUND)
10402 IF ((TNEXT - TCRIT)*H .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
10403 H = (TCRIT - TN)*(1.0D0 - 4.0D0*UROUND)
10404 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 2) JSTART = -2
10405 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10406 ! Block E.
10407 ! The next block is normally executed for all calls and contains
10408 ! the call to the one-step core integrator DSTOKA.
10409 !
10410 ! This is a looping point for the integration steps.
10411 !
10412 ! First check for too many steps being taken,
10413 ! check for poor Newton/Krylov method performance, update EWT (if not
10414 ! at start of problem), check for too much accuracy being requested,
10415 ! and check for H below the roundoff level in T.
10416 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10417 250  CONTINUE
10418 IF ((NST-NSLAST) .GE. MXSTEP) GOTO 500
10419 NSTD = NST - NSLAST
10420 NNID = NNI - NNI0
10421 IF (NSTD .LT. 10 .OR. NNID .EQ. 0) GOTO 255
10422 AVDIM = REAL(NLI - NLI0)/REAL(NNID)
10423 RCFN = REAL(NCFN - NCFN0)/REAL(NSTD)
10424 RCFL = REAL(NCFL - NCFL0)/REAL(NNID)
10425 LAVD = AVDIM .GT. (MAXL - 0.05D0)
10426 LCFN = RCFN .GT. 0.9D0
10427 LCFL = RCFL .GT. 0.9D0
10428 LWARN = LAVD .OR. LCFN .OR. LCFL
10429 IF (.NOT.LWARN) GOTO 255
10430 NWARN = NWARN + 1
10431 IF (NWARN .GT. 10) GOTO 255
10432 IF (LAVD) THEN
10433 MSG='DLSODKR- Warning. Poor iterative algorithm performance seen '
10434 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 111, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10435 ENDIF
10436 IF (LAVD) THEN
10437 MSG='      at T = R1 by average no. of linear iterations = R2    '
10438 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 111, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, AVDIM)
10439 ENDIF
10440 IF (LCFN) THEN
10441 MSG='DLSODKR- Warning. Poor iterative algorithm performance seen '
10442 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 112, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10443 ENDIF
10444 IF (LCFN) THEN
10445 MSG='      at T = R1 by nonlinear convergence failure rate = R2  '
10446 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 112, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, RCFN)
10447 ENDIF
10448 IF (LCFL) THEN
10449 MSG='DLSODKR- Warning. Poor iterative algorithm performance seen '
10450 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 113, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10451 ENDIF
10452 IF (LCFL) THEN
10453 MSG='      at T = R1 by linear convergence failure rate = R2     '
10454 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 113, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, RCFL)
10455 ENDIF
10456 255  CONTINUE
10457 CALL DEWSET (N, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LEWT))
10458 DO 260 I = 1,N
10459 IF (RWORK(I+LEWT-1) .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 510
10460 260    RWORK(I+LEWT-1) = 1.0D0/RWORK(I+LEWT-1)
10461 270  TOLSF = UROUND*DVNORM (N, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LEWT))
10462 IF (TOLSF .LE. 1.0D0) GOTO 280
10463 TOLSF = TOLSF*2.0D0
10464 IF (NST .EQ. 0) GOTO 626
10465 GOTO 520
10466 280  IF ((TN + H) .NE. TN) GOTO 290
10467 NHNIL = NHNIL + 1
10468 IF (NHNIL .GT. MXHNIL) GOTO 290
10469 MSG = 'DLSODKR-  Warning.. Internal T(=R1) and H(=R2) are'
10470 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 101, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10471 MSG='      such that in the machine, T + H = T on the next step  '
10472 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 101, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10473 MSG = '     (H = step size). Solver will continue anyway.'
10474 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 101, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, H)
10475 IF (NHNIL .LT. MXHNIL) GOTO 290
10476 MSG = 'DLSODKR-  Above warning has been issued I1 times. '
10477 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 102, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10478 MSG = '     It will not be issued again for this problem.'
10479 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 102, 0, 1, MXHNIL, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10480 290  CONTINUE
10481 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10482 !     CALL DSTOKA(NEQ,Y,YH,NYH,YH,EWT,SAVF,SAVX,ACOR,WM,IWM,F,JAC,PSOL)
10483 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10484 CALL DSTOKA (NEQ, Y, RWORK(LYH), NYH, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LEWT), RWORK(LSAVF), RWORK(LSAVX), RWORK(LACOR), RWORK(LWM), &
10485 IWORK(LIWM), F, JAC, PSOL)
10486 KGO = 1 - KFLAG
10487 GOTO (300, 530, 540, 550), KGO
10488 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10489 ! Block F.
10490 ! The following block handles the case of a successful return from the
10491 ! core integrator (KFLAG = 0).
10492 ! Call DRCHEK to check for a root within the last step.
10493 ! Then, if no root was found, check for stop conditions.
10494 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10495 300  INIT = 1
10496 !
10497 IF (NGC .EQ. 0) GOTO 315
10498 CALL DRCHEK (3, G, NEQ, Y, RWORK(LYH), NYH, RWORK(LG0), RWORK(LG1), RWORK(LGX), JROOT, IRT)
10499 IF (IRT .NE. 1) GOTO 315
10500 IRFND = 1
10501 ISTATE = 3
10502 T = T0
10503 GOTO 425
10504 315  CONTINUE
10505 !
10506 GOTO (310, 400, 330, 340, 350), ITASK
10507 ! ITASK = 1.  If TOUT has been reached, interpolate. -------------------
10508 310  IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
