10509 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
10510 T = TOUT
10511 GOTO 420
10512 ! ITASK = 3.  Jump to exit if TOUT was reached. ------------------------
10513 330  IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .GE. 0.0D0) GOTO 400
10514 GOTO 250
10515 ! ITASK = 4.  See if TOUT or TCRIT was reached.  Adjust H if necessary.
10516 340  IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 345
10517 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
10518 T = TOUT
10519 GOTO 420
10520 345  HMX = ABS(TN) + ABS(H)
10521 IHIT = ABS(TN - TCRIT) .LE. 100.0D0*UROUND*HMX
10522 IF (IHIT) GOTO 400
10523 TNEXT = TN + H*(1.0D0 + 4.0D0*UROUND)
10524 IF ((TNEXT - TCRIT)*H .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
10525 H = (TCRIT - TN)*(1.0D0 - 4.0D0*UROUND)
10526 JSTART = -2
10527 GOTO 250
10528 ! ITASK = 5.  See if TCRIT was reached and jump to exit. ---------------
10529 350  HMX = ABS(TN) + ABS(H)
10530 IHIT = ABS(TN - TCRIT) .LE. 100.0D0*UROUND*HMX
10531 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10532 ! Block G.
10533 ! The following block handles all successful returns from DLSODKR.
10534 ! If ITASK .ne. 1, Y is loaded from YH and T is set accordingly.
10535 ! ISTATE is set to 2, and the optional outputs are loaded into the
10536 ! work arrays before returning.
10537 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10538 400  DO 410 I = 1,N
10539 410    Y(I) = RWORK(I+LYH-1)
10540 T = TN
10541 IF (ITASK .NE. 4 .AND. ITASK .NE. 5) GOTO 420
10542 IF (IHIT) T = TCRIT
10543 420  ISTATE = 2
10544 425  CONTINUE
10545 RWORK(11) = HU
10546 RWORK(12) = H
10547 RWORK(13) = TN
10548 IWORK(11) = NST
10549 IWORK(12) = NFE
10550 IWORK(13) = NJE
10551 IWORK(14) = NQU
10552 IWORK(15) = NQ
10553 IWORK(19) = NNI
10554 IWORK(20) = NLI
10555 IWORK(21) = NPS
10556 IWORK(22) = NCFN
10557 IWORK(23) = NCFL
10558 IWORK(24) = NSFI
10559 IWORK(25) = NJEV
10560 IWORK(10) = NGE
10561 TLAST = T
10562 RETURN
10563 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10564 ! Block H.
10565 ! The following block handles all unsuccessful returns other than
10566 ! those for illegal input.  First the error message routine is called.
10567 ! If there was an error test or convergence test failure, IMXER is set.
10568 ! Then Y is loaded from YH and T is set to TN.
10569 ! The optional outputs are loaded into the work arrays before returning.
10570 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10571 ! The maximum number of steps was taken before reaching TOUT. ----------
10572 500  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  At current T (=R1), MXSTEP (=I1) steps  '
10573 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 201, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10574 MSG = '      taken on this call before reaching TOUT     '
10575 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 201, 0, 1, MXSTEP, 0, 1, TN, 0.0D0)
10576 ISTATE = -1
10577 GOTO 580
10578 ! EWT(i) .le. 0.0 for some i (not at start of problem). ----------------
10579 510  EWTI = RWORK(LEWT+I-1)
10580 MSG = 'DLSODKR-  At T(=R1), EWT(I1) has become R2 .le. 0.'
10581 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 202, 0, 1, I, 0, 2, TN, EWTI)
10582 ISTATE = -6
10583 GOTO 580
10584 ! Too much accuracy requested for machine precision. -------------------
10585 520  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  At T (=R1), too much accuracy requested '
10586 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 203, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10587 MSG = '      for precision of machine..  See TOLSF (=R2) '
10588 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 203, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, TOLSF)
10589 RWORK(14) = TOLSF
10590 ISTATE = -2
10591 GOTO 580
10592 ! KFLAG = -1.  Error test failed repeatedly or with ABS(H) = HMIN. -----
10593 530  MSG = 'DLSODKR- At T(=R1) and step size H(=R2), the error'
10594 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 204, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10595 MSG = '      test failed repeatedly or with ABS(H) = HMIN'
10596 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 204, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, H)
10597 ISTATE = -4
10598 GOTO 560
10599 ! KFLAG = -2.  Convergence failed repeatedly or with ABS(H) = HMIN. ----
10600 540  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  At T (=R1) and step size H (=R2), the   '
10601 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 205, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10602 MSG = '      corrector convergence failed repeatedly     '
10603 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 205, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10604 MSG = '      or with ABS(H) = HMIN   '
10605 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 205, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, H)
10606 ISTATE = -5
10607 GOTO 580
10608 ! KFLAG = -3.  Unrecoverable error from PSOL. --------------------------
10609 550  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  At T (=R1) an unrecoverable error return'
10610 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 206, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10611 MSG = '      was made from Subroutine PSOL     '
10612 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 206, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, TN, 0.0D0)
10613 ISTATE = -7
10614 GOTO 580
10615 ! Compute IMXER if relevant. -------------------------------------------
10616 560  BIG = 0.0D0
10617 IMXER = 1
10618 DO 570 I = 1,N
10619 SIZE = ABS(RWORK(I+LACOR-1)*RWORK(I+LEWT-1))
10620 IF (BIG .GE. SIZE) GOTO 570
10621 BIG = SIZE
10622 IMXER = I
10623 570    CONTINUE
10624 IWORK(16) = IMXER
10625 ! Set Y vector, T, and optional outputs. -------------------------------
10626 580  DO 590 I = 1,N
10627 590    Y(I) = RWORK(I+LYH-1)
10628 T = TN
10629 RWORK(11) = HU
10630 RWORK(12) = H
10631 RWORK(13) = TN
10632 IWORK(11) = NST
10633 IWORK(12) = NFE
10634 IWORK(13) = NJE
10635 IWORK(14) = NQU
10636 IWORK(15) = NQ
10637 IWORK(19) = NNI
10638 IWORK(20) = NLI
10639 IWORK(21) = NPS
10640 IWORK(22) = NCFN
10641 IWORK(23) = NCFL
10642 IWORK(24) = NSFI
10643 IWORK(25) = NJEV
10644 IWORK(10) = NGE
10645 TLAST = T
10646 RETURN
10647 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10648 ! Block I.
10649 ! The following block handles all error returns due to illegal input
10650 ! (ISTATE = -3), as detected before calling the core integrator.
10651 ! First the error message routine is called.  If the illegal input
10652 ! is a negative ISTATE, the run is aborted (apparent infinite loop).
10653 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10654 601  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  ISTATE(=I1) illegal.'
10655 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 1, 0, 1, ISTATE, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10656 IF (ISTATE .LT. 0) GOTO 800
10657 GOTO 700
10658 602  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  ITASK (=I1) illegal.'
10659 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 2, 0, 1, ITASK, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10660 GOTO 700
10661 603  MSG = 'DLSODKR- ISTATE.gt.1 but DLSODKR not initialized. '
10662 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 3, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10663 GOTO 700
10664 604  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  NEQ (=I1) .lt. 1    '
10665 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 4, 0, 1, NEQ(1), 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10666 GOTO 700
10667 605  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  ISTATE = 3 and NEQ increased (I1 to I2).'
10668 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 5, 0, 2, N, NEQ(1), 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10669 GOTO 700
10670 606  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  ITOL (=I1) illegal. '
10671 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 6, 0, 1, ITOL, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10672 GOTO 700
10673 607  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  IOPT (=I1) illegal. '
10674 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 7, 0, 1, IOPT, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10675 GOTO 700
10676 608  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  MF (=I1) illegal.   '
10677 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 8, 0, 1, MF, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10678 GOTO 700
10679 611  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  MAXORD (=I1) .lt. 0 '
10680 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 11, 0, 1, MAXORD, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10681 GOTO 700
10682 612  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  MXSTEP (=I1) .lt. 0 '
10683 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 12, 0, 1, MXSTEP, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10684 GOTO 700
10685 613  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  MXHNIL (=I1) .lt. 0 '
10686 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 13, 0, 1, MXHNIL, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10687 GOTO 700
10688 614  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  TOUT (=R1) behind T (=R2)     '
10689 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 14, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TOUT, T)
10690 MSG = '      Integration direction is given by H0 (=R1)  '
10691 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 14, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, H0, 0.0D0)
10692 GOTO 700
10693 615  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  HMAX (=R1) .lt. 0.0 '
10694 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 15, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, HMAX, 0.0D0)
10695 GOTO 700
10696 616  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  HMIN (=R1) .lt. 0.0 '
10697 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 16, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, HMIN, 0.0D0)
10698 GOTO 700
10699 617  MSG='DLSODKR-  RWORK length needed, LENRW(=I1), exceeds LRW(=I2) '
10700 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 17, 0, 2, LENRW, LRW, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10701 GOTO 700
10702 618  MSG='DLSODKR-  IWORK length needed, LENIW(=I1), exceeds LIW(=I2) '
10703 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 18, 0, 2, LENIW, LIW, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10704 GOTO 700
10705 619  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  RTOL(I1) is R1 .lt. 0.0       '
10706 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 19, 0, 1, I, 0, 1, RTOLI, 0.0D0)
10707 GOTO 700
10708 620  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  ATOL(I1) is R1 .lt. 0.0       '
10709 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 20, 0, 1, I, 0, 1, ATOLI, 0.0D0)
10710 GOTO 700
10711 621  EWTI = RWORK(LEWT+I-1)
10712 MSG = 'DLSODKR-  EWT(I1) is R1 .le. 0.0        '
10713 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 21, 0, 1, I, 0, 1, EWTI, 0.0D0)
10714 GOTO 700
10715 622  MSG='DLSODKR- TOUT(=R1) too close to T(=R2) to start integration.'
10716 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 22, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TOUT, T)
10717 GOTO 700
10718 623  MSG='DLSODKR-  ITASK = I1 and TOUT (=R1) behind TCUR - HU (= R2) '
10719 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 23, 0, 1, ITASK, 0, 2, TOUT, TP)
10720 GOTO 700
10721 624  MSG='DLSODKR-  ITASK = 4 or 5 and TCRIT (=R1) behind TCUR (=R2)  '
10722 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 24, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TCRIT, TN)
10723 GOTO 700
10724 625  MSG='DLSODKR-  ITASK = 4 or 5 and TCRIT (=R1) behind TOUT (=R2)  '
10725 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 25, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TCRIT, TOUT)
10726 GOTO 700
10727 626  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  At start of problem, too much accuracy  '
10728 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 26, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10729 MSG='      requested for precision of machine..  See TOLSF (=R1) '
10730 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 26, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, TOLSF, 0.0D0)
10731 RWORK(14) = TOLSF
10732 GOTO 700
10733 627  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  Trouble in DINTDY. ITASK = I1, TOUT = R1'
10734 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 27, 0, 1, ITASK, 0, 1, TOUT, 0.0D0)
10735 GOTO 700
10736 630  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  NG (=I1) .lt. 0     '
10737 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 30, 0, 1, NG, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10738 GOTO 700
10739 631  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  NG changed (from I1 to I2) illegally,   '
10740 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 31, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10741 MSG = '      i.e. not immediately after a root was found.'
10742 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 31, 0, 2, NGC, NG, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10743 GOTO 700
10744 632  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  One or more components of g has a root  '
10745 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 32, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10746 MSG = '      too near to the initial point.    '
10747 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 32, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10748 !
10749 700  ISTATE = -3
10750 RETURN
10751 !
10752 800  MSG = 'DLSODKR-  Run aborted.. apparent infinite loop.   '
10753 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 303, 2, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
10754 RETURN
10755 !----------------------- End of Subroutine DLSODKR ---------------------
10756 END
10757 
10758 SUBROUTINE DLSODI(RES, ADDA, JAC, NEQ, Y, YDOTI, T, TOUT, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, ITASK, ISTATE, IOPT, RWORK, LRW, IWORK, LIW, MF)
10759 EXTERNAL RES, ADDA, JAC
10760 INTEGER NEQ, ITOL, ITASK, ISTATE, IOPT, LRW, IWORK, LIW, MF
10761 DOUBLE PRECISION Y, YDOTI, T, TOUT, RTOL, ATOL, RWORK
10762 DIMENSION NEQ(*), Y(*), YDOTI(*), RTOL(*), ATOL(*), RWORK(LRW), IWORK(LIW)
10763 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10764 ! This is the 18 November 2003 version of
10765 ! DLSODI: Livermore Solver for Ordinary Differential Equations
10766 !         (Implicit form).
10767 !
10768 ! This version is in double precision.
10769 !
10770 ! DLSODI solves the initial value problem for linearly implicit
10771 ! systems of first order ODEs,
10772 !     A(t,y) * dy/dt = g(t,y) ,  where A(t,y) is a square matrix,
10773 ! or, in component form,
10774 !     ( a   * ( dy / dt ))  + ... +  ( a     * ( dy   / dt ))  =
10775 !        i,1      1                     i,NEQ      NEQ
10776 !
10777 !      =   g ( t, y , y ,..., y    )   ( i = 1,...,NEQ )
10778 !           i      1   2       NEQ
10779 !
10780 ! If A is singular, this is a differential-algebraic system.
10781 !
10782 ! DLSODI is a variant version of the DLSODE package.
10783 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10784 ! Reference:
10785 !     Alan C. Hindmarsh,  ODEPACK, A Systematized Collection of ODE
10786 !     Solvers, in Scientific Computing, R. S. Stepleman et al. (Eds.),
10787 !     North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1983, pp. 55-64.
10788 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10789 ! Authors:       Alan C. Hindmarsh and Jeffrey F. Painter
10790 !                Center for Applied Scientific Computing, L-561
10791 !                Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
10792 !                Livermore, CA 94551
10793 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10794 ! Summary of Usage.
10795 !
10796 ! Communication between the user and the DLSODI package, for normal
10797 ! situations, is summarized here.  This summary describes only a subset
10798 ! of the full set of options available.  See the full description for
10799 ! details, including optional communication, nonstandard options,
10800 ! and instructions for special situations.  See also the example
10801 ! problem (with program and output) following this summary.
10802 !
10803 ! A. First, provide a subroutine of the form:
10804 !               SUBROUTINE RES (NEQ, T, Y, S, R, IRES)
10805 !               DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), S(*), R(*)
10806 ! which computes the residual function
10807 !     r = g(t,y)  -  A(t,y) * s ,
10808 ! as a function of t and the vectors y and s.  (s is an internally
10809 ! generated approximation to dy/dt.)  The arrays Y and S are inputs
10810 ! to the RES routine and should not be altered.  The residual
10811 ! vector is to be stored in the array R.  The argument IRES should be
10812 ! ignored for casual use of DLSODI.  (For uses of IRES, see the
10813 ! paragraph on RES in the full description below.)
10814 !
10815 ! B. Next, decide whether full or banded form is more economical
10816 ! for the storage of matrices.  DLSODI must deal internally with the
10817 ! matrices A and dr/dy, where r is the residual function defined above.
10818 ! DLSODI generates a linear combination of these two matrices, and
10819 ! this is treated in either full or banded form.
10820 !     The matrix structure is communicated by a method flag MF,
10821 ! which is 21 or 22 for the full case, and 24 or 25 in the band case.
10822 !     In the banded case, DLSODI requires two half-bandwidth
10823 ! parameters ML and MU.  These are, respectively, the widths of the
10824 ! lower and upper parts of the band, excluding the main diagonal.
10825 ! Thus the band consists of the locations (i,j) with
10826 ! i-ML .le. j .le. i+MU, and the full bandwidth is ML+MU+1.
10827 ! Note that the band must accommodate the nonzero elements of
10828 ! A(t,y), dg/dy, and d(A*s)/dy (s fixed).  Alternatively, one
10829 ! can define a band that encloses only the elements that are relatively
10830 ! large in magnitude, and gain some economy in storage and possibly
10831 ! also efficiency, although the appropriate threshhold for
10832 ! retaining matrix elements is highly problem-dependent.
10833 !
10834 ! C. You must also provide a subroutine of the form:
10835 !               SUBROUTINE ADDA (NEQ, T, Y, ML, MU, P, NROWP)
10836 !               DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), P(NROWP,*)
10837 ! which adds the matrix A = A(t,y) to the contents of the array P.
10838 ! T and the Y array are input and should not be altered.
10839 !     In the full matrix case, this routine should add elements of
10840 ! to P in the usual order.  I.e., add A(i,j) to P(i,j).  (Ignore the
10841 ! ML and MU arguments in this case.)
10842 !     In the band matrix case, this routine should add element A(i,j)
10843 ! to P(i-j+MU+1,j).  I.e., add the diagonal lines of A to the rows of
10844 ! P from the top down (the top line of A added to the first row of P).
10845 !
10846 ! D. For the sake of efficiency, you are encouraged to supply the
10847 ! Jacobian matrix dr/dy in closed form, where r = g(t,y) - A(t,y)*s
10848 ! (s = a fixed vector) as above.  If dr/dy is being supplied,
10849 ! use MF = 21 or 24, and provide a subroutine of the form:
10850 !               SUBROUTINE JAC (NEQ, T, Y, S, ML, MU, P, NROWP)
10851 !               DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), S(*), P(NROWP,*)
10852 ! which computes dr/dy as a function of t, y, and s.  Here T, Y, and
10853 ! S are inputs, and the routine is to load dr/dy into P as follows:
10854 !     In the full matrix case (MF = 21), load P(i,j) with dr(i)/dy(j),
10855 ! the partial derivative of r(i) with respect to y(j).  (Ignore the
10856 ! ML and MU arguments in this case.)
10857 !     In the band matrix case (MF = 24), load P(i-j+mu+1,j) with
10858 ! dr(i)/dy(j), i.e. load the diagonal lines of dr/dy into the rows of
10859 ! P from the top down.
10860 !     In either case, only nonzero elements need be loaded, and the
10861 ! indexing of P is the same as in the ADDA routine.
10862 !     Note that if A is independent of y (or this dependence
10863 ! is weak enough to be ignored) then JAC is to compute dg/dy.
10864 !     If it is not feasible to provide a JAC routine, use
10865 ! MF = 22 or 25, and DLSODI will compute an approximate Jacobian
10866 ! internally by difference quotients.
10867 !
10868 ! E. Next decide whether or not to provide the initial value of the
10869 ! derivative vector dy/dt.  If the initial value of A(t,y) is
10870 ! nonsingular (and not too ill-conditioned), you may let DLSODI compute
10871 ! this vector (ISTATE = 0).  (DLSODI will solve the system A*s = g for
10872 ! s, with initial values of A and g.)  If A(t,y) is initially
10873 ! singular, then the system is a differential-algebraic system, and
10874 ! you must make use of the particular form of the system to compute the
10875 ! initial values of y and dy/dt.  In that case, use ISTATE = 1 and
10876 ! load the initial value of dy/dt into the array YDOTI.
10877 ! The input array YDOTI and the initial Y array must be consistent with
10878 ! the equations A*dy/dt = g.  This implies that the initial residual
10879 ! r = g(t,y) - A(t,y)*YDOTI  must be approximately zero.
10880 !
10881 ! F. Write a main program which calls Subroutine DLSODI once for
10882 ! each point at which answers are desired.  This should also provide
10883 ! for possible use of logical unit 6 for output of error messages
10884 ! by DLSODI.  On the first call to DLSODI, supply arguments as follows:
10885 ! RES    = name of user subroutine for residual function r.
10886 ! ADDA   = name of user subroutine for computing and adding A(t,y).
10887 ! JAC    = name of user subroutine for Jacobian matrix dr/dy
10888 !          (MF = 21 or 24).  If not used, pass a dummy name.
10889 ! Note: the names for the RES and ADDA routines and (if used) the
10890 !        JAC routine must be declared External in the calling program.
10891 ! NEQ    = number of scalar equations in the system.
10892 ! Y      = array of initial values, of length NEQ.
10893 ! YDOTI  = array of length NEQ (containing initial dy/dt if ISTATE = 1).
10894 ! T      = the initial value of the independent variable.
10895 ! TOUT   = first point where output is desired (.ne. T).
10896 ! ITOL   = 1 or 2 according as ATOL (below) is a scalar or array.
10897 ! RTOL   = relative tolerance parameter (scalar).
10898 ! ATOL   = absolute tolerance parameter (scalar or array).
10899 !          the estimated local error in y(i) will be controlled so as
10900 !          to be roughly less (in magnitude) than
10901 !             EWT(i) = RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL     if ITOL = 1, or
10902 !             EWT(i) = RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i)  if ITOL = 2.
10903 !          Thus the local error test passes if, in each component,
10904 !          either the absolute error is less than ATOL (or ATOL(i)),
10905 !          or the relative error is less than RTOL.
10906 !          Use RTOL = 0.0 for pure absolute error control, and
10907 !          use ATOL = 0.0 (or ATOL(i) = 0.0) for pure relative error
10908 !          control.  Caution: Actual (global) errors may exceed these
10909 !          local tolerances, so choose them conservatively.
10910 ! ITASK  = 1 for normal computation of output values of y at t = TOUT.
10911 ! ISTATE = integer flag (input and output).  Set ISTATE = 1 if the
10912 !          initial dy/dt is supplied, and 0 otherwise.
10913 ! IOPT   = 0 to indicate no optional inputs used.
10914 ! RWORK  = real work array of length at least:
10915 !             22 +  9*NEQ + NEQ**2           for MF = 21 or 22,
10916 !             22 + 10*NEQ + (2*ML + MU)*NEQ  for MF = 24 or 25.
10917 ! LRW    = declared length of RWORK (in user's dimension).
10918 ! IWORK  = integer work array of length at least 20 + NEQ.
10919 !          If MF = 24 or 25, input in IWORK(1),IWORK(2) the lower
10920 !          and upper half-bandwidths ML,MU.
10921 ! LIW    = declared length of IWORK (in user's dimension).
10922 ! MF     = method flag.  Standard values are:
10923 !          21 for a user-supplied full Jacobian.
10924 !          22 for an internally generated full Jacobian.
10925 !          24 for a user-supplied banded Jacobian.
10926 !          25 for an internally generated banded Jacobian.
10927 !          for other choices of MF, see the paragraph on MF in
10928 !          the full description below.
10929 ! Note that the main program must declare arrays Y, YDOTI, RWORK, IWORK,
10930 ! and possibly ATOL.
10931 !
10932 ! G. The output from the first call (or any call) is:
10933 !      Y = array of computed values of y(t) vector.
10934 !      T = corresponding value of independent variable (normally TOUT).
10935 ! ISTATE = 2  if DLSODI was successful, negative otherwise.
10936 !          -1 means excess work done on this call (check all inputs).
10937 !          -2 means excess accuracy requested (tolerances too small).
10938 !          -3 means illegal input detected (see printed message).
10939 !          -4 means repeated error test failures (check all inputs).
10940 !          -5 means repeated convergence failures (perhaps bad Jacobian
10941 !             supplied or wrong choice of tolerances).
10942 !          -6 means error weight became zero during problem. (Solution
10943 !             component i vanished, and ATOL or ATOL(i) = 0.)
10944 !          -7 cannot occur in casual use.
10945 !          -8 means DLSODI was unable to compute the initial dy/dt.
10946 !             In casual use, this means A(t,y) is initially singular.
10947 !             Supply YDOTI and use ISTATE = 1 on the first call.
10948 !
10949 !  If DLSODI returns ISTATE = -1, -4, or -5, then the output of
10950 !  DLSODI also includes YDOTI = array containing residual vector
10951 !  r = g - A * dy/dt  evaluated at the current t, y, and dy/dt.
10952 !
10953 ! H. To continue the integration after a successful return, simply
10954 ! reset TOUT and call DLSODI again.  No other parameters need be reset.
10955 !
10956 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
10957 ! Example Problem.
10958 !
10959 ! The following is a simple example problem, with the coding
10960 ! needed for its solution by DLSODI.  The problem is from chemical
10961 ! kinetics, and consists of the following three equations:
10962 !     dy1/dt = -.04*y1 + 1.e4*y2*y3
10963 !     dy2/dt = .04*y1 - 1.e4*y2*y3 - 3.e7*y2**2
10964 !       0.   = y1 + y2 + y3 - 1.
10965 ! on the interval from t = 0.0 to t = 4.e10, with initial conditions
10966 ! y1 = 1.0, y2 = y3 = 0.
10967 !
10968 ! The following coding solves this problem with DLSODI, using MF = 21
10969 ! and printing results at t = .4, 4., ..., 4.e10.  It uses
10970 ! ITOL = 2 and ATOL much smaller for y2 than y1 or y3 because
10971 ! y2 has much smaller values.  dy/dt is supplied in YDOTI. We had
10972 ! obtained the initial value of dy3/dt by differentiating the
10973 ! third equation and evaluating the first two at t = 0.
10974 ! At the end of the run, statistical quantities of interest are
10975 ! printed (see optional outputs in the full description below).
10976 !
10977 !     EXTERNAL RESID, APLUSP, DGBYDY
10978 !     DOUBLE PRECISION ATOL, RTOL, RWORK, T, TOUT, Y, YDOTI
10979 !     DIMENSION Y(3), YDOTI(3), ATOL(3), RWORK(58), IWORK(23)
10980 !     NEQ = 3
10981 !     Y(1) = 1.
10982 !     Y(2) = 0.
10983 !     Y(3) = 0.
10984 !     YDOTI(1) = -.04
10985 !     YDOTI(2) =  .04
10986 !     YDOTI(3) =  0.
10987 !     T = 0.
10988 !     TOUT = .4
10989 !     ITOL = 2
10990 !     RTOL = 1.D-4
10991 !     ATOL(1) = 1.D-6
10992 !     ATOL(2) = 1.D-10
10993 !     ATOL(3) = 1.D-6
10994 !     ITASK = 1
10995 !     ISTATE = 1
10996 !     IOPT = 0
10997 !     LRW = 58
10998 !     LIW = 23
10999 !     MF = 21
11000 !     DO 40  IOUT = 1,12
11001 !       CALL DLSODI(RESID, APLUSP, DGBYDY, NEQ, Y, YDOTI, T, TOUT, ITOL,
11002 !    1     RTOL, ATOL, ITASK, ISTATE, IOPT, RWORK, LRW, IWORK, LIW, MF)
11003 !       WRITE (6,20)  T, Y(1), Y(2), Y(3)
11004 !  20   FORMAT(' At t =',D12.4,'   Y =',3D14.6)
11005 !       IF (ISTATE .LT. 0 )  GOTO 80
11006 !  40   TOUT = TOUT*10.
11007 !     WRITE (6,60)  IWORK(11), IWORK(12), IWORK(13)
11008 !  60 FORMAT(/' No. steps =',I4,'  No. r-s =',I4,'  No. J-s =',I4)
11009 !     STOP
11010 !  80 WRITE (6,90)  ISTATE
11011 !  90 FORMAT(///' Error halt.. ISTATE =',I3)
11012 !     STOP
11013 !     END
11014 !
11015 !     SUBROUTINE RESID(NEQ, T, Y, S, R, IRES)
11016 !     DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y, S, R
11017 !     DIMENSION Y(3), S(3), R(3)
11018 !     R(1) = -.04*Y(1) + 1.D4*Y(2)*Y(3) - S(1)
11019 !     R(2) = .04*Y(1) - 1.D4*Y(2)*Y(3) - 3.D7*Y(2)*Y(2) - S(2)
11020 !     R(3) = Y(1) + Y(2) + Y(3) - 1.
11021 !     RETURN
11022 !     END
11023 !
11024 !     SUBROUTINE APLUSP(NEQ, T, Y, ML, MU, P, NROWP)
11025 !     DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y, P
11026 !     DIMENSION Y(3), P(NROWP,3)
11027 !     P(1,1) = P(1,1) + 1.
11028 !     P(2,2) = P(2,2) + 1.
11029 !     RETURN
11030 !     END
11031 !
11032 !     SUBROUTINE DGBYDY(NEQ, T, Y, S, ML, MU, P, NROWP)
11033 !     DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y, S, P
11034 !     DIMENSION Y(3), S(3), P(NROWP,3)
11035 !     P(1,1) = -.04
11036 !     P(1,2) = 1.D4*Y(3)
11037 !     P(1,3) = 1.D4*Y(2)
11038 !     P(2,1) = .04
11039 !     P(2,2) = -1.D4*Y(3) - 6.D7*Y(2)
11040 !     P(2,3) = -1.D4*Y(2)
11041 !     P(3,1) = 1.
11042 !     P(3,2) = 1.
11043 !     P(3,3) = 1.
11044 !     RETURN
11045 !     END
11046 !
11047 ! The output of this program (on a CDC-7600 in single precision)
11048 ! is as follows:
11049 !
11050 !   At t =  4.0000e-01   Y =  9.851726e-01  3.386406e-05  1.479357e-02
11051 !   At t =  4.0000e+00   Y =  9.055142e-01  2.240418e-05  9.446344e-02
11052 !   At t =  4.0000e+01   Y =  7.158050e-01  9.184616e-06  2.841858e-01
11053 !   At t =  4.0000e+02   Y =  4.504846e-01  3.222434e-06  5.495122e-01
11054 !   At t =  4.0000e+03   Y =  1.831701e-01  8.940379e-07  8.168290e-01
11055 !   At t =  4.0000e+04   Y =  3.897016e-02  1.621193e-07  9.610297e-01
11056 !   At t =  4.0000e+05   Y =  4.935213e-03  1.983756e-08  9.950648e-01
11057 !   At t =  4.0000e+06   Y =  5.159269e-04  2.064759e-09  9.994841e-01
11058 !   At t =  4.0000e+07   Y =  5.306413e-05  2.122677e-10  9.999469e-01
11059 !   At t =  4.0000e+08   Y =  5.494532e-06  2.197826e-11  9.999945e-01
11060 !   At t =  4.0000e+09   Y =  5.129457e-07  2.051784e-12  9.999995e-01
11061 !   At t =  4.0000e+10   Y = -7.170472e-08 -2.868188e-13  1.000000e+00
11062 !
11063 !   No. steps = 330  No. r-s = 404  No. J-s =  69
11064 !
11065 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
11066 ! Full Description of User Interface to DLSODI.
11067 !
11068 ! The user interface to DLSODI consists of the following parts.
11069 !
11070 ! 1.   The call sequence to Subroutine DLSODI, which is a driver
11071 !      routine for the solver.  This includes descriptions of both
11072 !      the call sequence arguments and of user-supplied routines.
11073 !      Following these descriptions is a description of
11074 !      optional inputs available through the call sequence, and then
11075 !      a description of optional outputs (in the work arrays).
11076 !
11077 ! 2.   Descriptions of other routines in the DLSODI package that may be
11078 !      (optionally) called by the user.  These provide the ability to
11079 !      alter error message handling, save and restore the internal
11080 !      Common, and obtain specified derivatives of the solution y(t).
11081 !
11082 ! 3.   Descriptions of Common blocks to be declared in overlay
11083 !      or similar environments, or to be saved when doing an interrupt
11084 !      of the problem and continued solution later.
11085 !
11086 ! 4.   Description of two routines in the DLSODI package, either of
11087 !      which the user may replace with his/her own version, if desired.
11088 !      These relate to the measurement of errors.
11089 !
11090 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
11091 ! Part 1.  Call Sequence.
11092 !
11093 ! The call sequence parameters used for input only are
11094 !     RES, ADDA, JAC, NEQ, TOUT, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, ITASK,
11095 !     IOPT, LRW, LIW, MF,
11096 ! and those used for both input and output are
11097 !     Y, T, ISTATE, YDOTI.
11098 ! The work arrays RWORK and IWORK are also used for conditional and
11099 ! optional inputs and optional outputs.  (The term output here refers
11100 ! to the return from Subroutine DLSODI to the user's calling program.)
11101 !
11102 ! The legality of input parameters will be thoroughly checked on the
11103 ! initial call for the problem, but not checked thereafter unless a
11104 ! change in input parameters is flagged by ISTATE = 3 on input.
11105 !
11106 ! The descriptions of the call arguments are as follows.
11107 !
11108 ! RES    = the name of the user-supplied subroutine which supplies
11109 !          the residual vector for the ODE system, defined by
11110 !            r = g(t,y) - A(t,y) * s
11111 !          as a function of the scalar t and the vectors
11112 !          s and y (s approximates dy/dt).  This subroutine
11113 !          is to have the form
11114 !               SUBROUTINE RES (NEQ, T, Y, S, R, IRES)
11115 !               DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), S(*), R(*)
11116 !          where NEQ, T, Y, S, and IRES are input, and R and
11117 !          IRES are output.  Y, S, and R are arrays of length NEQ.
11118 !             On input, IRES indicates how DLSODI will use the
11119 !          returned array R, as follows:
11120 !             IRES = 1  means that DLSODI needs the full residual,
11121 !                       r = g - A*s, exactly.
11122 !             IRES = -1 means that DLSODI is using R only to compute
11123 !                       the Jacobian dr/dy by difference quotients.
11124 !          The RES routine can ignore IRES, or it can omit some terms
11125 !          if IRES = -1.  If A does not depend on y, then RES can
11126 !          just return R = g when IRES = -1.  If g - A*s contains other
11127 !          additive terms that are independent of y, these can also be
11128 !          dropped, if done consistently, when IRES = -1.
11129 !             The subroutine should set the flag IRES if it
11130 !          encounters a halt condition or illegal input.
11131 !          Otherwise, it should not reset IRES.  On output,
11132 !             IRES = 1 or -1 represents a normal return, and
11133 !          DLSODI continues integrating the ODE.  Leave IRES
11134 !          unchanged from its input value.
11135 !             IRES = 2 tells DLSODI to immediately return control
11136 !          to the calling program, with ISTATE = 3.  This lets
11137 !          the calling program change parameters of the problem,
11138 !          if necessary.
11139 !             IRES = 3 represents an error condition (for example, an
11140 !          illegal value of y).  DLSODI tries to integrate the system
11141 !          without getting IRES = 3 from RES.  If it cannot, DLSODI
11142 !          returns with ISTATE = -7 or -1.
11143 !             On an DLSODI return with ISTATE = 3, -1, or -7, the values
11144 !          of T and Y returned correspond to the last point reached
11145 !          successfully without getting the flag IRES = 2 or 3.
11146 !             The flag values IRES = 2 and 3 should not be used to
11147 !          handle switches or root-stop conditions.  This is better
11148 !          done by calling DLSODI in a one-step mode and checking the
11149 !          stopping function for a sign change at each step.
11150 !             If quantities computed in the RES routine are needed
11151 !          externally to DLSODI, an extra call to RES should be made
11152 !          for this purpose, for consistent and accurate results.
11153 !          To get the current dy/dt for the S argument, use DINTDY.
11154 !             RES must be declared External in the calling
11155 !          program.  See note below for more about RES.
11156 !
11157 ! ADDA   = the name of the user-supplied subroutine which adds the
11158 !          matrix A = A(t,y) to another matrix stored in the same form
11159 !          as A.  The storage form is determined by MITER (see MF).
11160 !          This subroutine is to have the form
11161 !               SUBROUTINE ADDA (NEQ, T, Y, ML, MU, P, NROWP)
11162 !               DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), P(NROWP,*)
11163 !          where NEQ, T, Y, ML, MU, and NROWP are input and P is
11164 !          output.  Y is an array of length NEQ, and the matrix P is
11165 !          stored in an NROWP by NEQ array.
11166 !             In the full matrix case ( MITER = 1 or 2) ADDA should
11167 !          add  A    to P(i,j).  ML and MU are ignored.
11168 !                i,j
11169 !             In the band matrix case ( MITER = 4 or 5) ADDA should
11170 !          add  A    to  P(i-j+MU+1,j).
11171 !                i,j
11172 !          See JAC for details on this band storage form.
11173 !             ADDA must be declared External in the calling program.
11174 !          See note below for more information about ADDA.
11175 !
11176 ! JAC    = the name of the user-supplied subroutine which supplies the
11177 !          Jacobian matrix, dr/dy, where r = g - A*s.  The form of the
11178 !          Jacobian matrix is determined by MITER.  JAC is required
11179 !          if MITER = 1 or 4 -- otherwise a dummy name can be
11180 !          passed.  This subroutine is to have the form
11181 !               SUBROUTINE JAC ( NEQ, T, Y, S, ML, MU, P, NROWP )
11182 !               DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), S(*), P(NROWP,*)
11183 !          where NEQ, T, Y, S, ML, MU, and NROWP are input and P
11184 !          is output.  Y and S are arrays of length NEQ, and the
11185 !          matrix P is stored in an NROWP by NEQ array.
11186 !          P is to be loaded with partial derivatives (elements
11187 !          of the Jacobian matrix) on output.
11188 !             In the full matrix case (MITER = 1), ML and MU
11189 !          are ignored and the Jacobian is to be loaded into P
11190 !          by columns-- i.e., dr(i)/dy(j) is loaded into P(i,j).
11191 !             In the band matrix case (MITER = 4), the elements
11192 !          within the band are to be loaded into P by columns,
11193 !          with diagonal lines of dr/dy loaded into the
11194 !          rows of P.  Thus dr(i)/dy(j) is to be loaded
11195 !          into P(i-j+MU+1,j).  The locations in P in the two
11196 !          triangular areas which correspond to nonexistent matrix
11197 !          elements can be ignored or loaded arbitrarily, as they
11198 !          they are overwritten by DLSODI.  ML and MU are the
11199 !          half-bandwidth parameters (see IWORK).
11200 !               In either case, P is preset to zero by the solver,
11201 !          so that only the nonzero elements need be loaded by JAC.
11202 !          Each call to JAC is preceded by a call to RES with the same
11203 !          arguments NEQ, T, Y, and S.  Thus to gain some efficiency,
11204 !          intermediate quantities shared by both calculations may be
11205 !          saved in a user Common block by RES and not recomputed by JAC
11206 !          if desired.  Also, JAC may alter the Y array, if desired.
11207 !               JAC need not provide dr/dy exactly.  A crude
11208 !          approximation (possibly with a smaller bandwidth) will do.
11209 !               JAC must be declared External in the calling program.
11210 !               See note below for more about JAC.
11211 !
11212 !    Note on RES, ADDA, and JAC:
11213 !          These subroutines may access user-defined quantities in
11214 !          NEQ(2),... and/or in Y(NEQ(1)+1),... if NEQ is an array
11215 !          (dimensioned in the subroutines) and/or Y has length
11216 !          exceeding NEQ(1).  However, these routines should not alter
11217 !          NEQ(1), Y(1),...,Y(NEQ) or any other input variables.
11218 !          See the descriptions of NEQ and Y below.
11219 !
11220 ! NEQ    = the size of the system (number of first order ordinary
11221 !          differential equations or scalar algebraic equations).
11222 !          Used only for input.
11223 !          NEQ may be decreased, but not increased, during the problem.
11224 !          If NEQ is decreased (with ISTATE = 3 on input), the
11225 !          remaining components of Y should be left undisturbed, if
11226 !          these are to be accessed in RES, ADDA, or JAC.
11227 !
11228 !          Normally, NEQ is a scalar, and it is generally referred to
11229 !          as a scalar in this user interface description.  However,
11230 !          NEQ may be an array, with NEQ(1) set to the system size.
11231 !          (The DLSODI package accesses only NEQ(1).)  In either case,
11232 !          this parameter is passed as the NEQ argument in all calls
11233 !          to RES, ADDA, and JAC.  Hence, if it is an array,
11234 !          locations NEQ(2),... may be used to store other integer data
11235 !          and pass it to RES, ADDA, or JAC.  Each such subroutine
11236 !          must include NEQ in a Dimension statement in that case.
11237 !
11238 ! Y      = a real array for the vector of dependent variables, of
11239 !          length NEQ or more.  Used for both input and output on the
11240 !          first call (ISTATE = 0 or 1), and only for output on other
11241 !          calls.  On the first call, Y must contain the vector of
11242 !          initial values.  On output, Y contains the computed solution
11243 !          vector, evaluated at T.  If desired, the Y array may be used
11244 !          for other purposes between calls to the solver.
11245 !
11246 !          This array is passed as the Y argument in all calls to RES,
11247 !          ADDA, and JAC.  Hence its length may exceed NEQ,
11248 !          and locations Y(NEQ+1),... may be used to store other real
11249 !          data and pass it to RES, ADDA, or JAC.  (The DLSODI
11250 !          package accesses only Y(1),...,Y(NEQ). )
11251 !
11252 ! YDOTI  = a real array for the initial value of the vector
11253 !          dy/dt and for work space, of dimension at least NEQ.
11254 !
11255 !          On input:
11256 !            If ISTATE = 0, then DLSODI will compute the initial value
11257 !          of dy/dt, if A is nonsingular.  Thus YDOTI will
11258 !          serve only as work space and may have any value.
11259 !            If ISTATE = 1, then YDOTI must contain the initial value
11260 !          of dy/dt.
11261 !            If ISTATE = 2 or 3 (continuation calls), then YDOTI
11262 !          may have any value.
11263 !            Note: If the initial value of A is singular, then
11264 !          DLSODI cannot compute the initial value of dy/dt, so
11265 !          it must be provided in YDOTI, with ISTATE = 1.
11266 !
11267 !          On output, when DLSODI terminates abnormally with ISTATE =
11268 !          -1, -4, or -5, YDOTI will contain the residual
11269 !          r = g(t,y) - A(t,y)*(dy/dt).  If r is large, t is near
11270 !          its initial value, and YDOTI is supplied with ISTATE = 1,
11271 !          then there may have been an incorrect input value of
11272 !          YDOTI = dy/dt, or the problem (as given to DLSODI)
11273 !          may not have a solution.
11274 !
11275 !          If desired, the YDOTI array may be used for other
11276 !          purposes between calls to the solver.
11277 !
11278 ! T      = the independent variable.  On input, T is used only on the
11279 !          first call, as the initial point of the integration.
11280 !          On output, after each call, T is the value at which a
11281 !          computed solution Y is evaluated (usually the same as TOUT).
11282 !          on an error return, T is the farthest point reached.
11283 !
11284 ! TOUT   = the next value of t at which a computed solution is desired.
11285 !          Used only for input.
11286 !
11287 !          When starting the problem (ISTATE = 0 or 1), TOUT may be
11288 !          equal to T for one call, then should .ne. T for the next
11289 !          call.  For the initial T, an input value of TOUT .ne. T is
11290 !          used in order to determine the direction of the integration
11291 !          (i.e. the algebraic sign of the step sizes) and the rough
11292 !          scale of the problem.  Integration in either direction
11293 !          (forward or backward in t) is permitted.
11294 !
11295 !          If ITASK = 2 or 5 (one-step modes), TOUT is ignored after
11296 !          the first call (i.e. the first call with TOUT .ne. T).
11297 !          Otherwise, TOUT is required on every call.
11298 !
11299 !          If ITASK = 1, 3, or 4, the values of TOUT need not be
11300 !          monotone, but a value of TOUT which backs up is limited
11301 !          to the current internal T interval, whose endpoints are
11302 !          TCUR - HU and TCUR (see optional outputs, below, for
11303 !          TCUR and HU).
11304 !
11305 ! ITOL   = an indicator for the type of error control.  See
11306 !          description below under ATOL.  Used only for input.
11307 !
11308 ! RTOL   = a relative error tolerance parameter, either a scalar or
11309 !          an array of length NEQ.  See description below under ATOL.
11310 !          Input only.
11311 !
11312 ! ATOL   = an absolute error tolerance parameter, either a scalar or
11313 !          an array of length NEQ.  Input only.
11314 !
11315 !             The input parameters ITOL, RTOL, and ATOL determine
11316 !          the error control performed by the solver.  The solver will
11317 !          control the vector E = (E(i)) of estimated local errors
11318 !          in y, according to an inequality of the form
11319 !                      RMS-norm of ( E(i)/EWT(i) )   .le.   1,
11320 !          where       EWT(i) = RTOL(i)*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i),
11321 !          and the RMS-norm (root-mean-square norm) here is
11322 !          RMS-norm(v) = SQRT(sum v(i)**2 / NEQ).  Here EWT = (EWT(i))
11323 !          is a vector of weights which must always be positive, and
11324 !          the values of RTOL and ATOL should all be non-negative.
11325 !          The following table gives the types (scalar/array) of
11326 !          RTOL and ATOL, and the corresponding form of EWT(i).
11327 !
11328 !             ITOL    RTOL       ATOL          EWT(i)
11329 !              1     scalar     scalar     RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL
11330 !              2     scalar     array      RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i)
11331 !              3     array      scalar     RTOL(i)*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL
11332 !              4     array      scalar     RTOL(i)*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i)
11333 !
11334 !          When either of these parameters is a scalar, it need not
11335 !          be dimensioned in the user's calling program.
11336 !
11337 !          If none of the above choices (with ITOL, RTOL, and ATOL
11338 !          fixed throughout the problem) is suitable, more general
11339 !          error controls can be obtained by substituting
11340 !          user-supplied routines for the setting of EWT and/or for
11341 !          the norm calculation.  See Part 4 below.
11342 !
11343 !          If global errors are to be estimated by making a repeated
11344 !          run on the same problem with smaller tolerances, then all
11345 !          components of RTOL and ATOL (i.e. of EWT) should be scaled
11346 !          down uniformly.
11347 !
11348 ! ITASK  = an index specifying the task to be performed.
11349 !          Input only.  ITASK has the following values and meanings.
11350 !          1  means normal computation of output values of y(t) at
11351 !             t = TOUT (by overshooting and interpolating).
11352 !          2  means take one step only and return.
11353 !          3  means stop at the first internal mesh point at or
11354 !             beyond t = TOUT and return.
11355 !          4  means normal computation of output values of y(t) at
11356 !             t = TOUT but without overshooting t = TCRIT.
11357 !             TCRIT must be input as RWORK(1).  TCRIT may be equal to
11358 !             or beyond TOUT, but not behind it in the direction of
11359 !             integration.  This option is useful if the problem
11360 !             has a singularity at or beyond t = TCRIT.
11361 !          5  means take one step, without passing TCRIT, and return.
11362 !             TCRIT must be input as RWORK(1).
11363 !
11364 !          Note:  If ITASK = 4 or 5 and the solver reaches TCRIT
11365 !          (within roundoff), it will return T = TCRIT (exactly) to
11366 !          indicate this (unless ITASK = 4 and TOUT comes before TCRIT,
11367 !          in which case answers at t = TOUT are returned first).
11368 !
11369 ! ISTATE = an index used for input and output to specify the
11370 !          state of the calculation.
11371 !
11372 !          On input, the values of ISTATE are as follows.
11373 !          0  means this is the first call for the problem, and
11374 !             DLSODI is to compute the initial value of dy/dt
11375 !             (while doing other initializations).  See note below.
11376 !          1  means this is the first call for the problem, and
11377 !             the initial value of dy/dt has been supplied in
11378 !             YDOTI (DLSODI will do other initializations).  See note
11379 !             below.
11380 !          2  means this is not the first call, and the calculation
11381 !             is to continue normally, with no change in any input
11382 !             parameters except possibly TOUT and ITASK.
11383 !             (If ITOL, RTOL, and/or ATOL are changed between calls
11384 !             with ISTATE = 2, the new values will be used but not
11385 !             tested for legality.)
11386 !          3  means this is not the first call, and the
11387 !             calculation is to continue normally, but with
11388 !             a change in input parameters other than
11389 !             TOUT and ITASK.  Changes are allowed in
11390 !             NEQ, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, IOPT, LRW, LIW, MF, ML, MU,
11391 !             and any of the optional inputs except H0.
11392 !             (See IWORK description for ML and MU.)
11393 !          Note:  A preliminary call with TOUT = T is not counted
11394 !          as a first call here, as no initialization or checking of
11395 !          input is done.  (Such a call is sometimes useful for the
11396 !          purpose of outputting the initial conditions.)
11397 !          Thus the first call for which TOUT .ne. T requires
11398 !          ISTATE = 0 or 1 on input.
11399 !
11400 !          On output, ISTATE has the following values and meanings.
11401 !           0 or 1  means nothing was done; TOUT = t and
11402 !              ISTATE = 0 or 1 on input.
11403 !           2  means that the integration was performed successfully.
11404 !           3  means that the user-supplied Subroutine RES signalled
11405 !              DLSODI to halt the integration and return (IRES = 2).
11406 !              Integration as far as T was achieved with no occurrence
11407 !              of IRES = 2, but this flag was set on attempting the
11408 !              next step.
11409 !          -1  means an excessive amount of work (more than MXSTEP
11410 !              steps) was done on this call, before completing the
11411 !              requested task, but the integration was otherwise
11412 !              successful as far as T.  (MXSTEP is an optional input
11413 !              and is normally 500.)  To continue, the user may
11414 !              simply reset ISTATE to a value .gt. 1 and call again
11415 !              (the excess work step counter will be reset to 0).
11416 !              In addition, the user may increase MXSTEP to avoid
11417 !              this error return (see below on optional inputs).
11418 !          -2  means too much accuracy was requested for the precision
11419 !              of the machine being used.  This was detected before
11420 !              completing the requested task, but the integration
11421 !              was successful as far as T.  To continue, the tolerance
11422 !              parameters must be reset, and ISTATE must be set
11423 !              to 3.  The optional output TOLSF may be used for this
11424 !              purpose.  (Note: If this condition is detected before
11425 !              taking any steps, then an illegal input return
11426 !              (ISTATE = -3) occurs instead.)
11427 !          -3  means illegal input was detected, before taking any
11428 !              integration steps.  See written message for details.
11429 !              Note:  If the solver detects an infinite loop of calls
11430 !              to the solver with illegal input, it will cause
11431 !              the run to stop.
11432 !          -4  means there were repeated error test failures on
11433 !              one attempted step, before completing the requested
11434 !              task, but the integration was successful as far as T.
11435 !              The problem may have a singularity, or the input
11436 !              may be inappropriate.
11437 !          -5  means there were repeated convergence test failures on
11438 !              one attempted step, before completing the requested
11439 !              task, but the integration was successful as far as T.
11440 !              This may be caused by an inaccurate Jacobian matrix.
11441 !          -6  means EWT(i) became zero for some i during the
11442 !              integration.  pure relative error control (ATOL(i)=0.0)
11443 !              was requested on a variable which has now vanished.
11444 !              the integration was successful as far as T.
11445 !          -7  means that the user-supplied Subroutine RES set
11446 !              its error flag (IRES = 3) despite repeated tries by
11447 !              DLSODI to avoid that condition.
11448 !          -8  means that ISTATE was 0 on input but DLSODI was unable
11449 !              to compute the initial value of dy/dt.  See the
11450 !              printed message for details.
11451 !
11452 !          Note:  Since the normal output value of ISTATE is 2,
11453 !          it does not need to be reset for normal continuation.
11454 !          Similarly, ISTATE (= 3) need not be reset if RES told
11455 !          DLSODI to return because the calling program must change
11456 !          the parameters of the problem.
11457 !          Also, since a negative input value of ISTATE will be
11458 !          regarded as illegal, a negative output value requires the
11459 !          user to change it, and possibly other inputs, before
11460 !          calling the solver again.
11461 !
11462 ! IOPT   = an integer flag to specify whether or not any optional
11463 !          inputs are being used on this call.  Input only.
11464 !          The optional inputs are listed separately below.
11465 !          IOPT = 0 means no optional inputs are being used.
11466 !                   Default values will be used in all cases.
11467 !          IOPT = 1 means one or more optional inputs are being used.
11468 !
11469 ! RWORK  = a real working array (double precision).
11470 !          The length of RWORK must be at least
11471 !             20 + NYH*(MAXORD + 1) + 3*NEQ + LENWM    where
11472 !          NYH    = the initial value of NEQ,
11473 !          MAXORD = 12 (if METH = 1) or 5 (if METH = 2) (unless a
11474 !                   smaller value is given as an optional input),
11475 !          LENWM   = NEQ**2 + 2    if MITER is 1 or 2, and
11476 !          LENWM   = (2*ML+MU+1)*NEQ + 2 if MITER is 4 or 5.
11477 !          (See MF description for the definition of METH and MITER.)
11478 !          Thus if MAXORD has its default value and NEQ is constant,
11479 !          this length is
11480 !             22 + 16*NEQ + NEQ**2         for MF = 11 or 12,
11481 !             22 + 17*NEQ + (2*ML+MU)*NEQ  for MF = 14 or 15,
11482 !             22 +  9*NEQ + NEQ**2         for MF = 21 or 22,
11483 !             22 + 10*NEQ + (2*ML+MU)*NEQ  for MF = 24 or 25.
11484 !          The first 20 words of RWORK are reserved for conditional
11485 !          and optional inputs and optional outputs.
11486 !
11487 !          The following word in RWORK is a conditional input:
11488 !            RWORK(1) = TCRIT = critical value of t which the solver
11489 !                       is not to overshoot.  Required if ITASK is
11490 !                       4 or 5, and ignored otherwise.  (See ITASK.)
11491 !
11492 ! LRW    = the length of the array RWORK, as declared by the user.
11493 !          (This will be checked by the solver.)
11494 !
11495 ! IWORK  = an integer work array.  The length of IWORK must be at least
11496 !          20 + NEQ .  The first few words of IWORK are used for
11497 !          conditional and optional inputs and optional outputs.
11498 !
11499 !          The following 2 words in IWORK are conditional inputs:
11500 !            IWORK(1) = ML     These are the lower and upper
11501 !            IWORK(2) = MU     half-bandwidths, respectively, of the
11502 !                       matrices in the problem-- the Jacobian dr/dy
11503 !                       and the left-hand side matrix A. These
11504 !                       half-bandwidths exclude the main diagonal,
11505 !                       so the total bandwidth is ML + MU + 1 .
11506 !                       The band is defined by the matrix locations
11507 !                       (i,j) with i-ML .le. j .le. i+MU.  ML and MU
11508 !                       must satisfy  0 .le.  ML,MU  .le. NEQ-1.
11509 !                       These are required if MITER is 4 or 5, and
11510 !                       ignored otherwise.
11511 !                       ML and MU may in fact be the band parameters
11512 !                       for matrices to which dr/dy and A are only
11513 !                       approximately equal.
11514 !
11515 ! LIW    = the length of the array IWORK, as declared by the user.
11516 !          (This will be checked by the solver.)
11517 !
11518 ! Note:  The work arrays must not be altered between calls to DLSODI
11519 ! for the same problem, except possibly for the conditional and
11520 ! optional inputs, and except for the last 3*NEQ words of RWORK.
11521 ! The latter space is used for internal scratch space, and so is
11522 ! available for use by the user outside DLSODI between calls, if
11523 ! desired (but not for use by RES, ADDA, or JAC).
11524 !
11525 ! MF     = the method flag.  Used only for input.  The legal values of
11526 !          MF are 11, 12, 14, 15, 21, 22, 24, and 25.
11527 !          MF has decimal digits METH and MITER: MF = 10*METH + MITER.
11528 !            METH indicates the basic linear multistep method:
11529 !              METH = 1 means the implicit Adams method.
11530 !              METH = 2 means the method based on Backward
11531 !                       Differentiation Formulas (BDFs).
11532 !                The BDF method is strongly preferred for stiff
11533 !              problems, while the Adams method is preferred when
11534 !              the problem is not stiff.  If the matrix A(t,y) is
11535 !              nonsingular, stiffness here can be taken to mean that of
11536 !              the explicit ODE system dy/dt = A-inverse * g.  If A is
11537 !              singular, the concept of stiffness is not well defined.
11538 !                If you do not know whether the problem is stiff, we
11539 !              recommend using METH = 2.  If it is stiff, the advantage
11540 !              of METH = 2 over METH = 1 will be great, while if it is
11541 !              not stiff, the advantage of METH = 1 will be slight.
11542 !              If maximum efficiency is important, some experimentation
11543 !              with METH may be necessary.
11544 !            MITER indicates the corrector iteration method:
11545 !              MITER = 1 means chord iteration with a user-supplied
11546 !                        full (NEQ by NEQ) Jacobian.
11547 !              MITER = 2 means chord iteration with an internally
11548 !                        generated (difference quotient) full Jacobian.
11549 !                        This uses NEQ+1 extra calls to RES per dr/dy
11550 !                        evaluation.
11551 !              MITER = 4 means chord iteration with a user-supplied
11552 !                        banded Jacobian.
11553 !              MITER = 5 means chord iteration with an internally
11554 !                        generated banded Jacobian (using ML+MU+2
11555 !                        extra calls to RES per dr/dy evaluation).
11556 !              If MITER = 1 or 4, the user must supply a Subroutine JAC
11557 !              (the name is arbitrary) as described above under JAC.
11558 !              For other values of MITER, a dummy argument can be used.
11559 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
11560 ! Optional Inputs.
11561 !
11562 ! The following is a list of the optional inputs provided for in the
11563 ! call sequence.  (See also Part 2.)  For each such input variable,
11564 ! this table lists its name as used in this documentation, its
11565 ! location in the call sequence, its meaning, and the default value.
11566 ! the use of any of these inputs requires IOPT = 1, and in that
11567 ! case all of these inputs are examined.  A value of zero for any
11568 ! of these optional inputs will cause the default value to be used.
11569 ! Thus to use a subset of the optional inputs, simply preload
11570 ! locations 5 to 10 in RWORK and IWORK to 0.0 and 0 respectively, and
11571 ! then set those of interest to nonzero values.
11572 !
11573 ! Name    Location      Meaning and Default Value
11574 !
11575 ! H0      RWORK(5)  the step size to be attempted on the first step.
11576 !                   The default value is determined by the solver.
11577 !
11578 ! HMAX    RWORK(6)  the maximum absolute step size allowed.
11579 !                   The default value is infinite.
11580 !
11581 ! HMIN    RWORK(7)  the minimum absolute step size allowed.
11582 !                   The default value is 0.  (This lower bound is not
11583 !                   enforced on the final step before reaching TCRIT
11584 !                   when ITASK = 4 or 5.)
11585 !
11586 ! MAXORD  IWORK(5)  the maximum order to be allowed.  The default
11587 !                   value is 12 if METH = 1, and 5 if METH = 2.
11588 !                   If MAXORD exceeds the default value, it will
11589 !                   be reduced to the default value.
11590 !                   If MAXORD is changed during the problem, it may
11591 !                   cause the current order to be reduced.
11592 !
11593 ! MXSTEP  IWORK(6)  maximum number of (internally defined) steps
11594 !                   allowed during one call to the solver.
11595 !                   The default value is 500.
11596 !
11597 ! MXHNIL  IWORK(7)  maximum number of messages printed (per problem)
11598 !                   warning that T + H = T on a step (H = step size).
11599 !                   This must be positive to result in a non-default
11600 !                   value.  The default value is 10.
11601 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
11602 ! Optional Outputs.
11603 !
11604 ! As optional additional output from DLSODI, the variables listed
11605 ! below are quantities related to the performance of DLSODI
11606 ! which are available to the user.  These are communicated by way of
11607 ! the work arrays, but also have internal mnemonic names as shown.
11608 ! Except where stated otherwise, all of these outputs are defined
11609 ! on any successful return from DLSODI, and on any return with
11610 ! ISTATE = -1, -2, -4, -5, -6, or -7.  On a return with -3 (illegal
11611 ! input) or -8, they will be unchanged from their existing values
11612 ! (if any), except possibly for TOLSF, LENRW, and LENIW.
11613 ! On any error return, outputs relevant to the error will be defined,
11614 ! as noted below.
11615 !
11616 ! Name    Location      Meaning
11617 !
11618 ! HU      RWORK(11) the step size in t last used (successfully).
11619 !
11620 ! HCUR    RWORK(12) the step size to be attempted on the next step.
11621 !
11622 ! TCUR    RWORK(13) the current value of the independent variable
11623 !                   which the solver has actually reached, i.e. the
11624 !                   current internal mesh point in t.  On output, TCUR
11625 !                   will always be at least as far as the argument
11626 !                   T, but may be farther (if interpolation was done).
11627 !
11628 ! TOLSF   RWORK(14) a tolerance scale factor, greater than 1.0,
11629 !                   computed when a request for too much accuracy was
11630 !                   detected (ISTATE = -3 if detected at the start of
11631 !                   the problem, ISTATE = -2 otherwise).  If ITOL is
11632 !                   left unaltered but RTOL and ATOL are uniformly
11633 !                   scaled up by a factor of TOLSF for the next call,
11634 !                   then the solver is deemed likely to succeed.
11635 !                   (The user may also ignore TOLSF and alter the
11636 !                   tolerance parameters in any other way appropriate.)
11637 !
11638 ! NST     IWORK(11) the number of steps taken for the problem so far.
11639 !
11640 ! NRE     IWORK(12) the number of residual evaluations (RES calls)
11641 !                   for the problem so far.
11642 !
11643 ! NJE     IWORK(13) the number of Jacobian evaluations (each involving
11644 !                   an evaluation of A and dr/dy) for the problem so
11645 !                   far.  This equals the number of calls to ADDA and
11646 !                   (if MITER = 1 or 4) JAC, and the number of matrix
11647 !                   LU decompositions.
11648 !
11649 ! NQU     IWORK(14) the method order last used (successfully).
11650 !
11651 ! NQCUR   IWORK(15) the order to be attempted on the next step.
11652 !
11653 ! IMXER   IWORK(16) the index of the component of largest magnitude in
11654 !                   the weighted local error vector ( E(i)/EWT(i) ),
11655 !                   on an error return with ISTATE = -4 or -5.
11656 !
11657 ! LENRW   IWORK(17) the length of RWORK actually required.
11658 !                   This is defined on normal returns and on an illegal
11659 !                   input return for insufficient storage.
11660 !
11661 ! LENIW   IWORK(18) the length of IWORK actually required.
11662 !                   This is defined on normal returns and on an illegal
11663 !                   input return for insufficient storage.
11664 !
11665 !
11666 ! The following two arrays are segments of the RWORK array which
11667 ! may also be of interest to the user as optional outputs.
11668 ! For each array, the table below gives its internal name,
11669 ! its base address in RWORK, and its description.
11670 !
11671 ! Name    Base Address      Description
11672 !
11673 ! YH      21             the Nordsieck history array, of size NYH by
11674 !                        (NQCUR + 1), where NYH is the initial value
11675 !                        of NEQ.  For j = 0,1,...,NQCUR, column j+1
11676 !                        of YH contains HCUR**j/factorial(j) times
11677 !                        the j-th derivative of the interpolating
11678 !                        polynomial currently representing the solution,
11679 !                        evaluated at t = TCUR.
11680 !
11681 ! ACOR     LENRW-NEQ+1   array of size NEQ used for the accumulated
11682 !                        corrections on each step, scaled on output to
11683 !                        represent the estimated local error in y on the
11684 !                        last step. This is the vector E in the descrip-
11685 !                        tion of the error control.  It is defined only
11686 !                        on a return from DLSODI with ISTATE = 2.
11687 !
11688 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
11689 ! Part 2.  Other Routines Callable.
11690 !
11691 ! The following are optional calls which the user may make to
11692 ! gain additional capabilities in conjunction with DLSODI.
11693 ! (The routines XSETUN and XSETF are designed to conform to the
11694 ! SLATEC error handling package.)
11695 !
11696 !     Form of Call                  Function
11697 !   CALL XSETUN(LUN)          Set the logical unit number, LUN, for
11698 !                             output of messages from DLSODI, if
11699 !                             the default is not desired.
11700 !                             The default value of LUN is 6.
11701 !
11702 !   CALL XSETF(MFLAG)         Set a flag to control the printing of
11703 !                             messages by DLSODI.
11704 !                             MFLAG = 0 means do not print. (Danger:
11705 !                             This risks losing valuable information.)
11706 !                             MFLAG = 1 means print (the default).
11707 !
11708 !                             Either of the above calls may be made at
11709 !                             any time and will take effect immediately.
11710 !
11711 !   CALL DSRCOM(RSAV,ISAV,JOB) saves and restores the contents of
11712 !                             the internal Common blocks used by
11713 !                             DLSODI (see Part 3 below).
11714 !                             RSAV must be a real array of length 218
11715 !                             or more, and ISAV must be an integer
11716 !                             array of length 37 or more.
11717 !                             JOB=1 means save Common into RSAV/ISAV.
11718 !                             JOB=2 means restore Common from RSAV/ISAV.
11719 !                                DSRCOM is useful if one is
11720 !                             interrupting a run and restarting
11721 !                             later, or alternating between two or
11722 !                             more problems solved with DLSODI.
11723 !
11724 !   CALL DINTDY(,,,,,)        Provide derivatives of y, of various
11725 !        (see below)          orders, at a specified point t, if
11726 !                             desired.  It may be called only after
11727 !                             a successful return from DLSODI.
11728 !
11729 ! The detailed instructions for using DINTDY are as follows.
11730 ! The form of the call is:
11731 !
11732 !   CALL DINTDY (T, K, RWORK(21), NYH, DKY, IFLAG)
11733 !
11734 ! The input parameters are:
11735 !
11736 ! T         = value of independent variable where answers are desired
11737 !             (normally the same as the T last returned by DLSODI).
11738 !             For valid results, T must lie between TCUR - HU and TCUR.
11739 !             (See optional outputs for TCUR and HU.)
11740 ! K         = integer order of the derivative desired.  K must satisfy
11741 !             0 .le. K .le. NQCUR, where NQCUR is the current order
11742 !             (see optional outputs).  The capability corresponding
11743 !             to K = 0, i.e. computing y(T), is already provided
11744 !             by DLSODI directly.  Since NQCUR .ge. 1, the first
11745 !             derivative dy/dt is always available with DINTDY.
11746 ! RWORK(21) = the base address of the history array YH.
11747 ! NYH       = column length of YH, equal to the initial value of NEQ.
11748 !
11749 ! The output parameters are:
11750 !
11751 ! DKY       = a real array of length NEQ containing the computed value
11752 !             of the K-th derivative of y(t).
11753 ! IFLAG     = integer flag, returned as 0 if K and T were legal,
11754 !             -1 if K was illegal, and -2 if T was illegal.
11755 !             On an error return, a message is also written.
11756 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
11757 ! Part 3.  Common Blocks.
11758 !
11759 ! If DLSODI is to be used in an overlay situation, the user
11760 ! must declare, in the primary overlay, the variables in:
11761 !   (1) the call sequence to DLSODI, and
11762 !   (2) the internal Common block
11763 !         /DLS001/  of length  255  (218 double precision words
11764 !                      followed by 37 integer words),
11765 !
11766 ! If DLSODI is used on a system in which the contents of internal
11767 ! Common blocks are not preserved between calls, the user should
11768 ! declare the above Common block in the calling program to insure
11769 ! that their contents are preserved.
11770 !
11771 ! If the solution of a given problem by DLSODI is to be interrupted
11772 ! and then later continued, such as when restarting an interrupted run
11773 ! or alternating between two or more problems, the user should save,
11774 ! following the return from the last DLSODI call prior to the
11775 ! interruption, the contents of the call sequence variables and the
11776 ! internal Common blocks, and later restore these values before the
11777 ! next DLSODI call for that problem.  To save and restore the Common
11778 ! blocks, use Subroutine DSRCOM (see Part 2 above).
11779 !
11780 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
11781 ! Part 4.  Optionally Replaceable Solver Routines.
11782 !
11783 ! Below are descriptions of two routines in the DLSODI package which
11784 ! relate to the measurement of errors.  Either routine can be
11785 ! replaced by a user-supplied version, if desired.  However, since such
11786 ! a replacement may have a major impact on performance, it should be
11787 ! done only when absolutely necessary, and only with great caution.
11788 ! (Note: The means by which the package version of a routine is
11789 ! superseded by the user's version may be system-dependent.)
11790 !
11791 ! (a) DEWSET.
11792 ! The following subroutine is called just before each internal
11793 ! integration step, and sets the array of error weights, EWT, as
11794 ! described under ITOL/RTOL/ATOL above:
11795 !     SUBROUTINE DEWSET (NEQ, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, YCUR, EWT)
11796 ! where NEQ, ITOL, RTOL, and ATOL are as in the DLSODI call sequence,
11797 ! YCUR contains the current dependent variable vector, and
11798 ! EWT is the array of weights set by DEWSET.
11799 !
11800 ! If the user supplies this subroutine, it must return in EWT(i)
11801 ! (i = 1,...,NEQ) a positive quantity suitable for comparing errors
11802 ! in y(i) to.  The EWT array returned by DEWSET is passed to the DVNORM
11803 ! routine (see below), and also used by DLSODI in the computation
11804 ! of the optional output IMXER, the diagonal Jacobian approximation,
11805 ! and the increments for difference quotient Jacobians.
11806 !
11807 ! In the user-supplied version of DEWSET, it may be desirable to use
11808 ! the current values of derivatives of y.  Derivatives up to order NQ
11809 ! are available from the history array YH, described above under
11810 ! optional outputs.  In DEWSET, YH is identical to the YCUR array,
11811 ! extended to NQ + 1 columns with a column length of NYH and scale
11812 ! factors of H**j/factorial(j).  On the first call for the problem,
11813 ! given by NST = 0, NQ is 1 and H is temporarily set to 1.0.
11814 ! NYH is the initial value of NEQ.  The quantities NQ, H, and NST
11815 ! can be obtained by including in DEWSET the statements:
11816 !     DOUBLE PRECISION RLS
11817 !     COMMON /DLS001/ RLS(218),ILS(37)
11818 !     NQ = ILS(33)
11819 !     NST = ILS(34)
11820 !     H = RLS(212)
11821 ! Thus, for example, the current value of dy/dt can be obtained as
11822 ! YCUR(NYH+i)/H  (i=1,...,NEQ)  (and the division by H is
11823 ! unnecessary when NST = 0).
11824 !
11825 ! (b) DVNORM.
11826 ! The following is a real function routine which computes the weighted
11827 ! root-mean-square norm of a vector v:
11828 !     D = DVNORM (N, V, W)
11829 ! where:
11830 !   N = the length of the vector,
11831 !   V = real array of length N containing the vector,
11832 !   W = real array of length N containing weights,
11833 !   D = SQRT( (1/N) * sum(V(i)*W(i))**2 ).
11834 ! DVNORM is called with N = NEQ and with W(i) = 1.0/EWT(i), where
11835 ! EWT is as set by Subroutine DEWSET.
11836 !
11837 ! If the user supplies this function, it should return a non-negative
11838 ! value of DVNORM suitable for use in the error control in DLSODI.
11839 ! None of the arguments should be altered by DVNORM.
11840 ! For example, a user-supplied DVNORM routine might:
11841 !   -substitute a max-norm of (V(i)*W(i)) for the RMS-norm, or
11842 !   -ignore some components of V in the norm, with the effect of
11843 !    suppressing the error control on those components of y.
11844 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
11845 !
11846 !***REVISION HISTORY  (YYYYMMDD)
11847 ! 19800424  DATE WRITTEN
11848 ! 19800519  Corrected access of YH on forced order reduction;
11849 !           numerous corrections to prologues and other comments.
11850 ! 19800617  In main driver, added loading of SQRT(UROUND) in RWORK;
11851 !           minor corrections to main prologue.
11852 ! 19800903  Corrected ISTATE logic; minor changes in prologue.
11853 ! 19800923  Added zero initialization of HU and NQU.
11854 ! 19801028  Reorganized RES calls in AINVG, STODI, and PREPJI;
11855 !           in LSODI, corrected NRE increment and reset LDY0 at 580;
11856 !           numerous corrections to main prologue.
11857 ! 19801218  Revised XERRWD routine; minor corrections to main prologue.
11858 ! 19810330  Added Common block /LSI001/; use LSODE's INTDY and SOLSY;
11859 !           minor corrections to XERRWD and error message at 604;
11860 !           minor corrections to declarations; corrections to prologues.
11861 ! 19810818  Numerous revisions: replaced EWT by 1/EWT; used flags
11862 !           JCUR, ICF, IERPJ, IERSL between STODI and subordinates;
11863 !           added tuning parameters CCMAX, MAXCOR, MSBP, MXNCF;
11864 !           reorganized returns from STODI; reorganized type decls.;
11865 !           fixed message length in XERRWD; changed default LUNIT to 6;
11866 !           changed Common lengths; changed comments throughout.
11867 ! 19820906  Corrected use of ABS(H) in STODI; minor comment fixes.
11868 ! 19830510  Numerous revisions: revised diff. quotient increment;
11869 !           eliminated block /LSI001/, using IERPJ flag;
11870 !           revised STODI logic after PJAC return;
11871 !           revised tuning of H change and step attempts in STODI;
11872 !           corrections to main prologue and internal comments.
11873 ! 19870330  Major update: corrected comments throughout;
11874 !           removed TRET from Common; rewrote EWSET with 4 loops;
11875 !           fixed t test in INTDY; added Cray directives in STODI;
11876 !           in STODI, fixed DELP init. and logic around PJAC call;
11877 !           combined routines to save/restore Common;
11878 !           passed LEVEL = 0 in error message calls (except run abort).
11879 ! 20010425  Major update: convert source lines to upper case;
11880 !           added *DECK lines; changed from 1 to * in dummy dimensions;
11881 !           changed names R1MACH/D1MACH to RUMACH/DUMACH;
11882 !           renamed routines for uniqueness across single/double prec.;
11883 !           converted intrinsic names to generic form;
11884 !           removed ILLIN and NTREP (data loaded) from Common;
11885 !           removed all 'own' variables from Common;
11886 !           changed error messages to quoted strings;
11887 !           replaced XERRWV/XERRWD with 1993 revised version;
11888 !           converted prologues, comments, error messages to mixed case;
11889 !           converted arithmetic IF statements to logical IF statements;
11890 !           numerous corrections to prologues and internal comments.
11891 ! 20010507  Converted single precision source to double precision.
11892 ! 20020502  Corrected declarations in descriptions of user routines.
11893 ! 20031105  Restored 'own' variables to Common block, to enable
11894 !           interrupt/restart feature.
11895 ! 20031112  Added SAVE statements for data-loaded constants.
11896 ! 20031117  Changed internal names NRE, LSAVR to NFE, LSAVF resp.
11897 !
11898 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
11899 ! Other routines in the DLSODI package.
11900 !
11901 ! In addition to Subroutine DLSODI, the DLSODI package includes the
11902 ! following subroutines and function routines:
11903 !  DAINVG   computes the initial value of the vector
11904 !             dy/dt = A-inverse * g
11905 !  DINTDY   computes an interpolated value of the y vector at t = TOUT.
11906 !  DSTODI   is the core integrator, which does one step of the
11907 !           integration and the associated error control.
11908 !  DCFODE   sets all method coefficients and test constants.
11909 !  DPREPJI  computes and preprocesses the Jacobian matrix
11910 !           and the Newton iteration matrix P.
11911 !  DSOLSY   manages solution of linear system in chord iteration.
11912 !  DEWSET   sets the error weight vector EWT before each step.
11913 !  DVNORM   computes the weighted RMS-norm of a vector.
11914 !  DSRCOM   is a user-callable routine to save and restore
11915 !           the contents of the internal Common blocks.
11916 !  DGEFA and DGESL   are routines from LINPACK for solving full
11917 !           systems of linear algebraic equations.
11918 !  DGBFA and DGBSL   are routines from LINPACK for solving banded
11919 !           linear systems.
11920 !  DUMACH   computes the unit roundoff in a machine-independent manner.
11921 !  XERRWD, XSETUN, XSETF, IXSAV, and IUMACH  handle the printing of all
11922 !           error messages and warnings.  XERRWD is machine-dependent.
11923 ! Note:  DVNORM, DUMACH, IXSAV, and IUMACH are function routines.
11924 ! All the others are subroutines.
11925 !
11926 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
11927 EXTERNAL DPREPJI, DSOLSY
11928 DOUBLE PRECISION DUMACH, DVNORM
11929 INTEGER INIT, MXSTEP, MXHNIL, NHNIL, NSLAST, NYH, IOWNS, ICF, IERPJ, IERSL, JCUR, JSTART, KFLAG, L, LYH
11930 INTEGER LEWT, LACOR, LSAVF, LWM, LIWM, METH, MITER, MAXORD, MAXCOR, MSBP, MXNCF, N, NQ, NST, NFE, NJE, NQU
11931 INTEGER I, I1, I2, IER, IFLAG, IMXER, IRES, KGO, LENIW, LENRW, LENWM, LP, LYD0, ML, MORD, MU, MXHNL0, MXSTP0
11932 DOUBLE PRECISION ROWNS, CCMAX, EL0, H, HMIN, HMXI, HU, RC, TN, UROUND
11933 DOUBLE PRECISION ATOLI, AYI, BIG, EWTI, H0, HMAX, HMX, RH, RTOLI, TCRIT, TDIST, TNEXT, TOL, TOLSF, TP, SIZE, SUM, W0
11934 DIMENSION MORD(2)
11935 LOGICAL IHIT
11936 character(len=60) MSG
11937 SAVE MORD, MXSTP0, MXHNL0
11938 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
11939 ! The following internal Common block contains
