11940 ! (a) variables which are local to any subroutine but whose values must
11941 !     be preserved between calls to the routine ("own" variables), and
11942 ! (b) variables which are communicated between subroutines.
11943 ! The block DLS001 is declared in subroutines DLSODI, DINTDY, DSTODI,
11944 ! DPREPJI, and DSOLSY.
11945 ! Groups of variables are replaced by dummy arrays in the Common
11946 ! declarations in routines where those variables are not used.
11947 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
11948 COMMON /DLS001/ ROWNS(209), CCMAX, EL0, H, HMIN, HMXI, HU, RC, TN, UROUND, INIT, MXSTEP, MXHNIL, NHNIL, NSLAST, NYH, &
11949 IOWNS(6), ICF, IERPJ, IERSL, JCUR, JSTART, KFLAG, L, LYH, LEWT, LACOR, LSAVF, LWM, LIWM, METH, MITER, MAXORD, MAXCOR, &
11950 MSBP, MXNCF, N, NQ, NST, NFE, NJE, NQU
11951 !
11952 DATA MORD(1),MORD(2)/12,5/, MXSTP0/500/, MXHNL0/10/
11953 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
11954 ! Block A.
11955 ! This code block is executed on every call.
11956 ! It tests ISTATE and ITASK for legality and branches appropriately.
11957 ! If ISTATE .gt. 1 but the flag INIT shows that initialization has
11958 ! not yet been done, an error return occurs.
11959 ! If ISTATE = 0 or 1 and TOUT = T, return immediately.
11960 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
11961 IF (ISTATE .LT. 0 .OR. ISTATE .GT. 3) GOTO 601
11962 IF (ITASK .LT. 1 .OR. ITASK .GT. 5) GOTO 602
11963 IF (ISTATE .LE. 1) GOTO 10
11964 IF (INIT .EQ. 0) GOTO 603
11965 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 2) GOTO 200
11966 GOTO 20
11967 10   INIT = 0
11968 IF (TOUT .EQ. T) RETURN
11969 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
11970 ! Block B.
11971 ! The next code block is executed for the initial call (ISTATE = 0 or 1)
11972 ! or for a continuation call with parameter changes (ISTATE = 3).
11973 ! It contains checking of all inputs and various initializations.
11974 !
11975 ! First check legality of the non-optional inputs NEQ, ITOL, IOPT,
11976 ! MF, ML, and MU.
11977 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
11978 20   IF (NEQ(1) .LE. 0) GOTO 604
11979 IF (ISTATE .LE. 1) GOTO 25
11980 IF (NEQ(1) .GT. N) GOTO 605
11981 25   N = NEQ(1)
11982 IF (ITOL .LT. 1 .OR. ITOL .GT. 4) GOTO 606
11983 IF (IOPT .LT. 0 .OR. IOPT .GT. 1) GOTO 607
11984 METH = MF/10
11985 MITER = MF - 10*METH
11986 IF (METH .LT. 1 .OR. METH .GT. 2) GOTO 608
11987 IF (MITER .LE. 0 .OR. MITER .GT. 5) GOTO 608
11988 IF (MITER .EQ. 3)  GOTO 608
11989 IF (MITER .LT. 3) GOTO 30
11990 ML = IWORK(1)
11991 MU = IWORK(2)
11992 IF (ML .LT. 0 .OR. ML .GE. N) GOTO 609
11993 IF (MU .LT. 0 .OR. MU .GE. N) GOTO 610
11994 30   CONTINUE
11995 ! Next process and check the optional inputs. --------------------------
11996 IF (IOPT .EQ. 1) GOTO 40
11997 MAXORD = MORD(METH)
11998 MXSTEP = MXSTP0
11999 MXHNIL = MXHNL0
12000 IF (ISTATE .LE. 1) H0 = 0.0D0
12001 HMXI = 0.0D0
12002 HMIN = 0.0D0
12003 GOTO 60
12004 40   MAXORD = IWORK(5)
12005 IF (MAXORD .LT. 0) GOTO 611
12006 IF (MAXORD .EQ. 0) MAXORD = 100
12007 MAXORD = MIN(MAXORD,MORD(METH))
12008 MXSTEP = IWORK(6)
12009 IF (MXSTEP .LT. 0) GOTO 612
12010 IF (MXSTEP .EQ. 0) MXSTEP = MXSTP0
12011 MXHNIL = IWORK(7)
12012 IF (MXHNIL .LT. 0) GOTO 613
12013 IF (MXHNIL .EQ. 0) MXHNIL = MXHNL0
12014 IF (ISTATE .GT. 1) GOTO 50
12015 H0 = RWORK(5)
12016 IF ((TOUT - T)*H0 .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 614
12017 50   HMAX = RWORK(6)
12018 IF (HMAX .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 615
12019 HMXI = 0.0D0
12020 IF (HMAX .GT. 0.0D0) HMXI = 1.0D0/HMAX
12021 HMIN = RWORK(7)
12022 IF (HMIN .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 616
12023 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12024 ! Set work array pointers and check lengths LRW and LIW.
12025 ! Pointers to segments of RWORK and IWORK are named by prefixing L to
12026 ! the name of the segment.  E.g., the segment YH starts at RWORK(LYH).
12027 ! Segments of RWORK (in order) are denoted YH, WM, EWT, SAVR, ACOR.
12028 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12029 60   LYH = 21
12030 IF (ISTATE .LE. 1) NYH = N
12031 LWM = LYH + (MAXORD + 1)*NYH
12032 IF (MITER .LE. 2) LENWM = N*N + 2
12033 IF (MITER .GE. 4) LENWM = (2*ML + MU + 1)*N + 2
12034 LEWT = LWM + LENWM
12035 LSAVF = LEWT + N
12036 LACOR = LSAVF + N
12037 LENRW = LACOR + N - 1
12038 IWORK(17) = LENRW
12039 LIWM = 1
12040 LENIW = 20 + N
12041 IWORK(18) = LENIW
12042 IF (LENRW .GT. LRW) GOTO 617
12043 IF (LENIW .GT. LIW) GOTO 618
12044 ! Check RTOL and ATOL for legality. ------------------------------------
12045 RTOLI = RTOL(1)
12046 ATOLI = ATOL(1)
12047 DO 70 I = 1,N
12048 IF (ITOL .GE. 3) RTOLI = RTOL(I)
12049 IF (ITOL .EQ. 2 .OR. ITOL .EQ. 4) ATOLI = ATOL(I)
12050 IF (RTOLI .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 619
12051 IF (ATOLI .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 620
12052 70     CONTINUE
12053 IF (ISTATE .LE. 1) GOTO 100
12054 ! If ISTATE = 3, set flag to signal parameter changes to DSTODI. -------
12055 JSTART = -1
12056 IF (NQ .LE. MAXORD) GOTO 90
12057 ! MAXORD was reduced below NQ.  Copy YH(*,MAXORD+2) into YDOTI.---------
12058 DO 80 I = 1,N
12059 80     YDOTI(I) = RWORK(I+LWM-1)
12060 ! Reload WM(1) = RWORK(lWM), since lWM may have changed. ---------------
12061 90   RWORK(LWM) = SQRT(UROUND)
12062 IF (N .EQ. NYH) GOTO 200
12063 ! NEQ was reduced.  Zero part of YH to avoid undefined references. -----
12064 I1 = LYH + L*NYH
12065 I2 = LYH + (MAXORD + 1)*NYH - 1
12066 IF (I1 .GT. I2) GOTO 200
12067 DO 95 I = I1,I2
12068 95     RWORK(I) = 0.0D0
12069 GOTO 200
12070 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12071 ! Block C.
12072 ! The next block is for the initial call only (ISTATE = 0 or 1).
12073 ! It contains all remaining initializations, the call to DAINVG
12074 ! (if ISTATE = 1), and the calculation of the initial step size.
12075 ! The error weights in EWT are inverted after being loaded.
12076 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12077 100  UROUND = DUMACH()
12078 TN = T
12079 IF (ITASK .NE. 4 .AND. ITASK .NE. 5) GOTO 105
12080 TCRIT = RWORK(1)
12081 IF ((TCRIT - TOUT)*(TOUT - T) .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 625
12082 IF (H0 .NE. 0.0D0 .AND. (T + H0 - TCRIT)*H0 .GT. 0.0D0) H0 = TCRIT - T
12083 105  JSTART = 0
12084 RWORK(LWM) = SQRT(UROUND)
12085 NHNIL = 0
12086 NST = 0
12087 NFE = 0
12088 NJE = 0
12089 NSLAST = 0
12090 HU = 0.0D0
12091 NQU = 0
12092 CCMAX = 0.3D0
12093 MAXCOR = 3
12094 MSBP = 20
12095 MXNCF = 10
12096 ! Compute initial dy/dt, if necessary, and load it and initial Y into YH
12097 LYD0 = LYH + NYH
12098 LP = LWM + 1
12099 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 1) GOTO 120
12100 ! DLSODI must compute initial dy/dt (LYD0 points to YH(*,2)). ----------
12101 CALL DAINVG( RES, ADDA, NEQ, T, Y, RWORK(LYD0), MITER, ML, MU, RWORK(LP), IWORK(21), IER )
12102 NFE = NFE + 1
12103 IF (IER .LT. 0) GOTO 560
12104 IF (IER .GT. 0) GOTO 565
12105 DO 115 I = 1,N
12106 115        RWORK(I+LYH-1) = Y(I)
12107 GOTO 130
12108 ! Initial dy/dt was supplied.  Load into YH (LYD0 points to YH(*,2).). -
12109 120     DO 125 I = 1,N
12110 RWORK(I+LYH-1) = Y(I)
12111 125        RWORK(I+LYD0-1) = YDOTI(I)
12112 ! Load and invert the EWT array.  (H is temporarily set to 1.0.) -------
12113 130  CONTINUE
12114 NQ = 1
12115 H = 1.0D0
12116 CALL DEWSET (N, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LEWT))
12117 DO 135 I = 1,N
12118 IF (RWORK(I+LEWT-1) .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 621
12119 135    RWORK(I+LEWT-1) = 1.0D0/RWORK(I+LEWT-1)
12120 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12121 ! The coding below computes the step size, H0, to be attempted on the
12122 ! first step, unless the user has supplied a value for this.
12123 ! First check that TOUT - T differs significantly from zero.
12124 ! A scalar tolerance quantity TOL is computed, as MAX(RTOL(i))
12125 ! if this is positive, or MAX(ATOL(i)/ABS(Y(i))) otherwise, adjusted
12126 ! so as to be between 100*UROUND and 1.0E-3.
12127 ! Then the computed value H0 is given by..
12128 !                                      NEQ
12129 !   H0**2 = TOL / ( w0**-2 + (1/NEQ) * Sum ( YDOT(i)/ywt(i) )**2  )
12130 !                                       1
12131 ! where   w0      = MAX ( ABS(T), ABS(TOUT) ),
12132 !         YDOT(i) = i-th component of initial value of dy/dt,
12133 !         ywt(i)  = EWT(i)/TOL  (a weight for y(i)).
12134 ! The sign of H0 is inferred from the initial values of TOUT and T.
12135 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12136 IF (H0 .NE. 0.0D0) GOTO 180
12137 TDIST = ABS(TOUT - T)
12138 W0 = MAX(ABS(T),ABS(TOUT))
12139 IF (TDIST .LT. 2.0D0*UROUND*W0) GOTO 622
12140 TOL = RTOL(1)
12141 IF (ITOL .LE. 2) GOTO 145
12142 DO 140 I = 1,N
12143 140    TOL = MAX(TOL,RTOL(I))
12144 145  IF (TOL .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 160
12145 ATOLI = ATOL(1)
12146 DO 150 I = 1,N
12147 IF (ITOL .EQ. 2 .OR. ITOL .EQ. 4) ATOLI = ATOL(I)
12148 AYI = ABS(Y(I))
12149 IF (AYI .NE. 0.0D0) TOL = MAX(TOL,ATOLI/AYI)
12150 150    CONTINUE
12151 160  TOL = MAX(TOL,100.0D0*UROUND)
12152 TOL = MIN(TOL,0.001D0)
12153 SUM = DVNORM (N, RWORK(LYD0), RWORK(LEWT))
12154 SUM = 1.0D0/(TOL*W0*W0) + TOL*SUM**2
12155 H0 = 1.0D0/SQRT(SUM)
12156 H0 = MIN(H0,TDIST)
12157 H0 = SIGN(H0,TOUT-T)
12158 ! Adjust H0 if necessary to meet HMAX bound. ---------------------------
12159 180  RH = ABS(H0)*HMXI
12160 IF (RH .GT. 1.0D0) H0 = H0/RH
12161 ! Load H with H0 and scale YH(*,2) by H0. ------------------------------
12162 H = H0
12163 DO 190 I = 1,N
12164 190    RWORK(I+LYD0-1) = H0*RWORK(I+LYD0-1)
12165 GOTO 270
12166 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12167 ! Block D.
12168 ! The next code block is for continuation calls only (ISTATE = 2 or 3)
12169 ! and is to check stop conditions before taking a step.
12170 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12171 200  NSLAST = NST
12172 GOTO (210, 250, 220, 230, 240), ITASK
12173 210  IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
12174 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
12175 IF (IFLAG .NE. 0) GOTO 627
12176 T = TOUT
12177 GOTO 420
12178 220  TP = TN - HU*(1.0D0 + 100.0D0*UROUND)
12179 IF ((TP - TOUT)*H .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 623
12180 IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
12181 GOTO 400
12182 230  TCRIT = RWORK(1)
12183 IF ((TN - TCRIT)*H .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 624
12184 IF ((TCRIT - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 625
12185 IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 245
12186 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
12187 IF (IFLAG .NE. 0) GOTO 627
12188 T = TOUT
12189 GOTO 420
12190 240  TCRIT = RWORK(1)
12191 IF ((TN - TCRIT)*H .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 624
12192 245  HMX = ABS(TN) + ABS(H)
12193 IHIT = ABS(TN - TCRIT) .LE. 100.0D0*UROUND*HMX
12194 IF (IHIT) GOTO 400
12195 TNEXT = TN + H*(1.0D0 + 4.0D0*UROUND)
12196 IF ((TNEXT - TCRIT)*H .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
12197 H = (TCRIT - TN)*(1.0D0 - 4.0D0*UROUND)
12198 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 2) JSTART = -2
12199 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12200 ! Block E.
12201 ! The next block is normally executed for all calls and contains
12202 ! the call to the one-step core integrator DSTODI.
12203 !
12204 ! This is a looping point for the integration steps.
12205 !
12206 ! First check for too many steps being taken, update EWT (if not at
12207 ! start of problem), check for too much accuracy being requested, and
12208 ! check for H below the roundoff level in T.
12209 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12210 250  CONTINUE
12211 IF ((NST-NSLAST) .GE. MXSTEP) GOTO 500
12212 CALL DEWSET (N, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LEWT))
12213 DO 260 I = 1,N
12214 IF (RWORK(I+LEWT-1) .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 510
12215 260    RWORK(I+LEWT-1) = 1.0D0/RWORK(I+LEWT-1)
12216 270  TOLSF = UROUND*DVNORM (N, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LEWT))
12217 IF (TOLSF .LE. 1.0D0) GOTO 280
12218 TOLSF = TOLSF*2.0D0
12219 IF (NST .EQ. 0) GOTO 626
12220 GOTO 520
12221 280  IF ((TN + H) .NE. TN) GOTO 290
12222 NHNIL = NHNIL + 1
12223 IF (NHNIL .GT. MXHNIL) GOTO 290
12224 MSG = 'DLSODI-  Warning..Internal T (=R1) and H (=R2) are'
12225 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 101, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12226 MSG='      such that in the machine, T + H = T on the next step  '
12227 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 101, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12228 MSG = '     (H = step size). Solver will continue anyway.'
12229 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 101, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, H)
12230 IF (NHNIL .LT. MXHNIL) GOTO 290
12231 MSG = 'DLSODI-  Above warning has been issued I1 times.  '
12232 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 102, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12233 MSG = '     It will not be issued again for this problem.'
12234 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 102, 0, 1, MXHNIL, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12235 290  CONTINUE
12236 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12237 !     CALL DSTODI(NEQ,Y,YH,NYH,YH1,EWT,SAVF,SAVR,ACOR,WM,IWM,RES,
12238 !                 ADDA,JAC,DPREPJI,DSOLSY)
12239 ! Note: SAVF in DSTODI occupies the same space as YDOTI in DLSODI.
12240 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12241 CALL DSTODI(NEQ, Y, RWORK(LYH), NYH, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LEWT), YDOTI, RWORK(LSAVF), RWORK(LACOR), &
12242 RWORK(LWM), IWORK(LIWM), RES, ADDA, JAC, DPREPJI, DSOLSY)
12243 KGO = 1 - KFLAG
12244 GOTO (300, 530, 540, 400, 550), KGO
12245 !
12246 ! KGO = 1:success; 2:error test failure; 3:convergence failure;
12247 !       4:RES ordered return. 5:RES returned error.
12248 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12249 ! Block F.
12250 ! The following block handles the case of a successful return from the
12251 ! core integrator (KFLAG = 0).  Test for stop conditions.
12252 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12253 300  INIT = 1
12254 GOTO (310, 400, 330, 340, 350), ITASK
12255 ! ITASK = 1.  If TOUT has been reached, interpolate. -------------------
12256 310  IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
12257 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
12258 T = TOUT
12259 GOTO 420
12260 ! ITASK = 3.  Jump to exit if TOUT was reached. ------------------------
12261 330  IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .GE. 0.0D0) GOTO 400
12262 GOTO 250
12263 ! ITASK = 4.  see if TOUT or TCRIT was reached.  adjust h if necessary.
12264 340  IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 345
12265 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
12266 T = TOUT
12267 GOTO 420
12268 345  HMX = ABS(TN) + ABS(H)
12269 IHIT = ABS(TN - TCRIT) .LE. 100.0D0*UROUND*HMX
12270 IF (IHIT) GOTO 400
12271 TNEXT = TN + H*(1.0D0 + 4.0D0*UROUND)
12272 IF ((TNEXT - TCRIT)*H .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
12273 H = (TCRIT - TN)*(1.0D0 - 4.0D0*UROUND)
12274 JSTART = -2
12275 GOTO 250
12276 ! ITASK = 5.  See if TCRIT was reached and jump to exit. ---------------
12277 350  HMX = ABS(TN) + ABS(H)
12278 IHIT = ABS(TN - TCRIT) .LE. 100.0D0*UROUND*HMX
12279 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12280 ! Block G.
12281 ! The following block handles all successful returns from DLSODI.
12282 ! if ITASK .ne. 1, Y is loaded from YH and T is set accordingly.
12283 ! ISTATE is set to 2, and the optional outputs are loaded into the
12284 ! work arrays before returning.
12285 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12286 400  DO 410 I = 1,N
12287 410    Y(I) = RWORK(I+LYH-1)
12288 T = TN
12289 IF (ITASK .NE. 4 .AND. ITASK .NE. 5) GOTO 420
12290 IF (IHIT) T = TCRIT
12291 420  ISTATE = 2
12292 IF (KFLAG .EQ. -3) ISTATE = 3
12293 RWORK(11) = HU
12294 RWORK(12) = H
12295 RWORK(13) = TN
12296 IWORK(11) = NST
12297 IWORK(12) = NFE
12298 IWORK(13) = NJE
12299 IWORK(14) = NQU
12300 IWORK(15) = NQ
12301 RETURN
12302 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12303 ! Block H.
12304 ! The following block handles all unsuccessful returns other than
12305 ! those for illegal input.  First the error message routine is called.
12306 ! If there was an error test or convergence test failure, IMXER is set.
12307 ! Then Y is loaded from YH and T is set to TN.
12308 ! The optional outputs are loaded into the work arrays before returning.
12309 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12310 ! The maximum number of steps was taken before reaching TOUT. ----------
12311 500  MSG = 'DLSODI-  At current T (=R1), MXSTEP (=I1) steps   '
12312 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 201, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12313 MSG = '      taken on this call before reaching TOUT     '
12314 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 201, 0, 1, MXSTEP, 0, 1, TN, 0.0D0)
12315 ISTATE = -1
12316 GOTO 580
12317 ! EWT(i) .le. 0.0 for some i (not at start of problem). ----------------
12318 510  EWTI = RWORK(LEWT+I-1)
12319 MSG = 'DLSODI-  At T (=R1), EWT(I1) has become R2 .le. 0.'
12320 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 202, 0, 1, I, 0, 2, TN, EWTI)
12321 ISTATE = -6
12322 GOTO 590
12323 ! Too much accuracy requested for machine precision. -------------------
12324 520  MSG = 'DLSODI-  At T (=R1), too much accuracy requested  '
12325 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 203, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12326 MSG = '      for precision of machine..  See TOLSF (=R2) '
12327 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 203, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, TOLSF)
12328 RWORK(14) = TOLSF
12329 ISTATE = -2
12330 GOTO 590
12331 ! KFLAG = -1.  Error test failed repeatedly or with ABS(H) = HMIN. -----
12332 530  MSG = 'DLSODI-  At T(=R1) and step size H(=R2), the error'
12333 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 204, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12334 MSG = '      test failed repeatedly or with ABS(H) = HMIN'
12335 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 204, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, H)
12336 ISTATE = -4
12337 GOTO 570
12338 ! KFLAG = -2.  Convergence failed repeatedly or with ABS(H) = HMIN. ----
12339 540  MSG = 'DLSODI-  At T (=R1) and step size H (=R2), the    '
12340 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 205, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12341 MSG = '      corrector convergence failed repeatedly     '
12342 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 205, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12343 MSG = '      or with ABS(H) = HMIN   '
12344 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 205, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, H)
12345 ISTATE = -5
12346 GOTO 570
12347 ! IRES = 3 returned by RES, despite retries by DSTODI. -----------------
12348 550  MSG = 'DLSODI-  At T (=R1) residual routine returned     '
12349 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 206, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12350 MSG = '      error IRES = 3 repeatedly.        '
12351 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 206, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, TN, 0.0D0)
12352 ISTATE = -7
12353 GOTO 590
12354 ! DAINVG failed because matrix A was singular. -------------------------
12355 560  IER = -IER
12356 MSG='DLSODI- Attempt to initialize dy/dt failed:  Matrix A is    '
12357 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 207, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12358 MSG = '      singular.  DGEFA or DGBFA returned INFO = I1'
12359 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 207, 0, 1, IER, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12360 ISTATE = -8
12361 RETURN
12362 ! DAINVG failed because RES set IRES to 2 or 3. ------------------------
12363 565  MSG = 'DLSODI-  Attempt to initialize dy/dt failed       '
12364 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 208, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12365 MSG = '      because residual routine set its error flag '
12366 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 208, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12367 MSG = '      to IRES = (I1)'
12368 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 20, 208, 0, 1, IER, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12369 ISTATE = -8
12370 RETURN
12371 ! Compute IMXER if relevant. -------------------------------------------
12372 570  BIG = 0.0D0
12373 IMXER = 1
12374 DO 575 I = 1,N
12375 SIZE = ABS(RWORK(I+LACOR-1)*RWORK(I+LEWT-1))
12376 IF (BIG .GE. SIZE) GOTO 575
12377 BIG = SIZE
12378 IMXER = I
12379 575    CONTINUE
12380 IWORK(16) = IMXER
12381 ! Compute residual if relevant. ----------------------------------------
12382 580  LYD0 = LYH + NYH
12383 DO 585  I = 1,N
12384 RWORK(I+LSAVF-1) = RWORK(I+LYD0-1)/H
12385 585     Y(I) = RWORK(I+LYH-1)
12386 IRES = 1
12387 CALL RES (NEQ, TN, Y, RWORK(LSAVF), YDOTI, IRES )
12388 NFE = NFE + 1
12389 IF (IRES .LE. 1) GOTO 595
12390 MSG = 'DLSODI-  Residual routine set its flag IRES       '
12391 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 210, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12392 MSG = '      to (I1) when called for final output.       '
12393 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 210, 0, 1, IRES, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12394 GOTO 595
12395 ! Set Y vector, T, and optional outputs. -------------------------------
12396 590  DO 592 I = 1,N
12397 592    Y(I) = RWORK(I+LYH-1)
12398 595  T = TN
12399 RWORK(11) = HU
12400 RWORK(12) = H
12401 RWORK(13) = TN
12402 IWORK(11) = NST
12403 IWORK(12) = NFE
12404 IWORK(13) = NJE
12405 IWORK(14) = NQU
12406 IWORK(15) = NQ
12407 RETURN
12408 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12409 ! Block I.
12410 ! The following block handles all error returns due to illegal input
12411 ! (ISTATE = -3), as detected before calling the core integrator.
12412 ! First the error message routine is called.  If the illegal input
12413 ! is a negative ISTATE, the run is aborted (apparent infinite loop).
12414 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12415 601  MSG = 'DLSODI-  ISTATE (=I1) illegal.'
12416 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 1, 0, 1, ISTATE, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12417 IF (ISTATE .LT. 0) GOTO 800
12418 GOTO 700
12419 602  MSG = 'DLSODI-  ITASK (=I1) illegal. '
12420 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 2, 0, 1, ITASK, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12421 GOTO 700
12422 603  MSG = 'DLSODI-  ISTATE .gt. 1 but DLSODI not initialized.'
12423 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 3, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12424 GOTO 700
12425 604  MSG = 'DLSODI-  NEQ (=I1) .lt. 1     '
12426 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 4, 0, 1, NEQ(1), 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12427 GOTO 700
12428 605  MSG = 'DLSODI-  ISTATE = 3 and NEQ increased (I1 to I2). '
12429 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 5, 0, 2, N, NEQ(1), 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12430 GOTO 700
12431 606  MSG = 'DLSODI-  ITOL (=I1) illegal.  '
12432 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 6, 0, 1, ITOL, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12433 GOTO 700
12434 607  MSG = 'DLSODI-  IOPT (=I1) illegal.  '
12435 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 7, 0, 1, IOPT, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12436 GOTO 700
12437 608  MSG = 'DLSODI-  MF (=I1) illegal.    '
12438 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 8, 0, 1, MF, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12439 GOTO 700
12440 609  MSG = 'DLSODI-  ML(=I1) illegal: .lt. 0 or .ge. NEQ(=I2) '
12441 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 9, 0, 2, ML, NEQ(1), 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12442 GOTO 700
12443 610  MSG = 'DLSODI-  MU(=I1) illegal: .lt. 0 or .ge. NEQ(=I2) '
12444 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 10, 0, 2, MU, NEQ(1), 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12445 GOTO 700
12446 611  MSG = 'DLSODI-  MAXORD (=I1) .lt. 0  '
12447 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 11, 0, 1, MAXORD, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12448 GOTO 700
12449 612  MSG = 'DLSODI-  MXSTEP (=I1) .lt. 0  '
12450 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 12, 0, 1, MXSTEP, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12451 GOTO 700
12452 613  MSG = 'DLSODI-  MXHNIL (=I1) .lt. 0  '
12453 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 13, 0, 1, MXHNIL, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12454 GOTO 700
12455 614  MSG = 'DLSODI-  TOUT (=R1) behind T (=R2)      '
12456 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 14, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TOUT, T)
12457 MSG = '      Integration direction is given by H0 (=R1)  '
12458 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 14, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, H0, 0.0D0)
12459 GOTO 700
12460 615  MSG = 'DLSODI-  HMAX (=R1) .lt. 0.0  '
12461 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 15, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, HMAX, 0.0D0)
12462 GOTO 700
12463 616  MSG = 'DLSODI-  HMIN (=R1) .lt. 0.0  '
12464 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 16, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, HMIN, 0.0D0)
12465 GOTO 700
12466 617  MSG='DLSODI-  RWORK length needed, LENRW (=I1), exceeds LRW (=I2)'
12467 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 17, 0, 2, LENRW, LRW, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12468 GOTO 700
12469 618  MSG='DLSODI-  IWORK length needed, LENIW (=I1), exceeds LIW (=I2)'
12470 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 18, 0, 2, LENIW, LIW, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12471 GOTO 700
12472 619  MSG = 'DLSODI-  RTOL(=I1) is R1 .lt. 0.0       '
12473 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 19, 0, 1, I, 0, 1, RTOLI, 0.0D0)
12474 GOTO 700
12475 620  MSG = 'DLSODI-  ATOL(=I1) is R1 .lt. 0.0       '
12476 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 20, 0, 1, I, 0, 1, ATOLI, 0.0D0)
12477 GOTO 700
12478 621  EWTI = RWORK(LEWT+I-1)
12479 MSG = 'DLSODI-  EWT(I1) is R1 .le. 0.0         '
12480 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 21, 0, 1, I, 0, 1, EWTI, 0.0D0)
12481 GOTO 700
12482 622  MSG='DLSODI-  TOUT(=R1) too close to T(=R2) to start integration.'
12483 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 22, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TOUT, T)
12484 GOTO 700
12485 623  MSG='DLSODI-  ITASK = I1 and TOUT (=R1) behind TCUR - HU (= R2)  '
12486 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 23, 0, 1, ITASK, 0, 2, TOUT, TP)
12487 GOTO 700
12488 624  MSG='DLSODI-  ITASK = 4 or 5 and TCRIT (=R1) behind TCUR (=R2)   '
12489 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 24, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TCRIT, TN)
12490 GOTO 700
12491 625  MSG='DLSODI-  ITASK = 4 or 5 and TCRIT (=R1) behind TOUT (=R2)   '
12492 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 25, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TCRIT, TOUT)
12493 GOTO 700
12494 626  MSG = 'DLSODI-  At start of problem, too much accuracy   '
12495 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 26, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12496 MSG='      requested for precision of machine..  See TOLSF (=R1) '
12497 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 26, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, TOLSF, 0.0D0)
12498 RWORK(14) = TOLSF
12499 GOTO 700
12500 627  MSG = 'DLSODI-  Trouble in DINTDY.  ITASK = I1, TOUT = R1'
12501 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 27, 0, 1, ITASK, 0, 1, TOUT, 0.0D0)
12502 !
12503 700  ISTATE = -3
12504 RETURN
12505 !
12506 800  MSG = 'DLSODI-  Run aborted.. apparent infinite loop.    '
12507 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 303, 2, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
12508 RETURN
12509 !----------------------- End of Subroutine DLSODI ----------------------
12510 END
12511 
12512 SUBROUTINE DLSOIBT(RES, ADDA, JAC, NEQ, Y, YDOTI, T, TOUT, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, ITASK, ISTATE, IOPT, RWORK, LRW, IWORK, LIW, MF)
12513 EXTERNAL RES, ADDA, JAC
12514 INTEGER NEQ, ITOL, ITASK, ISTATE, IOPT, LRW, IWORK, LIW, MF
12515 DOUBLE PRECISION Y, YDOTI, T, TOUT, RTOL, ATOL, RWORK
12516 DIMENSION NEQ(*), Y(*), YDOTI(*), RTOL(*), ATOL(*), RWORK(LRW), IWORK(LIW)
12517 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12518 ! This is the 18 November 2003 version of
12519 ! DLSOIBT: Livermore Solver for Ordinary differential equations given
12520 !          in Implicit form, with Block-Tridiagonal Jacobian treatment.
12521 !
12522 ! This version is in double precision.
12523 !
12524 ! DLSOIBT solves the initial value problem for linearly implicit
12525 ! systems of first order ODEs,
12526 !     A(t,y) * dy/dt = g(t,y) ,  where A(t,y) is a square matrix,
12527 ! or, in component form,
12528 !     ( a   * ( dy / dt ))  + ... +  ( a     * ( dy   / dt ))  =
12529 !        i,1      1                     i,NEQ      NEQ
12530 !
12531 !      =   g ( t, y , y ,..., y    )   ( i = 1,...,NEQ )
12532 !           i      1   2       NEQ
12533 !
12534 ! If A is singular, this is a differential-algebraic system.
12535 !
12536 ! DLSOIBT is a variant version of the DLSODI package, for the case where
12537 ! the matrices A, dg/dy, and d(A*s)/dy are all block-tridiagonal.
12538 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12539 ! Reference:
12540 !     Alan C. Hindmarsh,  ODEPACK, A Systematized Collection of ODE
12541 !     Solvers, in Scientific Computing,  R. S. Stepleman et al. (Eds.),
12542 !     North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1983, pp. 55-64.
12543 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12544 ! Authors:       Alan C. Hindmarsh and Jeffrey F. Painter
12545 !                Center for Applied Scientific Computing, L-561
12546 !                Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
12547 !                Livermore, CA 94551
12548 ! and
12549 !                Charles S. Kenney
12550 ! formerly at:   Naval Weapons Center
12551 !                China Lake, CA 93555
12552 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12553 ! Summary of Usage.
12554 !
12555 ! Communication between the user and the DLSOIBT package, for normal
12556 ! situations, is summarized here.  This summary describes only a subset
12557 ! of the full set of options available.  See the full description for
12558 ! details, including optional communication, nonstandard options,
12559 ! and instructions for special situations.  See also the example
12560 ! problem (with program and output) following this summary.
12561 !
12562 ! A. First, provide a subroutine of the form:
12563 !               SUBROUTINE RES (NEQ, T, Y, S, R, IRES)
12564 !               DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), S(*), R(*)
12565 ! which computes the residual function
12566 !     r = g(t,y)  -  A(t,y) * s ,
12567 ! as a function of t and the vectors y and s.  (s is an internally
12568 ! generated approximation to dy/dt.)  The arrays Y and S are inputs
12569 ! to the RES routine and should not be altered.  The residual
12570 ! vector is to be stored in the array R.  The argument IRES should be
12571 ! ignored for casual use of DLSOIBT.  (For uses of IRES, see the
12572 ! paragraph on RES in the full description below.)
12573 !
12574 ! B. Next, identify the block structure of the matrices A = A(t,y) and
12575 ! dr/dy.  DLSOIBT must deal internally with a linear combination, P, of
12576 ! these two matrices.  The matrix P (hence both A and dr/dy) must have
12577 ! a block-tridiagonal form with fixed structure parameters
12578 !     MB = block size, MB .ge. 1, and
12579 !     NB = number of blocks in each direction, NB .ge. 4,
12580 ! with MB*NB = NEQ.  In each of the NB block-rows of the matrix P
12581 ! (each consisting of MB consecutive rows), the nonzero elements are
12582 ! to lie in three consecutive MB by MB blocks.  In block-rows
12583 ! 2 through NB - 1, these are centered about the main diagonal.
12584 ! in block-rows 1 and NB, they are the diagonal blocks and the two
12585 ! blocks adjacent to the diagonal block.  (Thus block positions (1,3)
12586 ! and (NB,NB-2) can be nonzero.)
12587 ! Alternatively, P (hence A and dr/dy) may be only approximately
12588 ! equal to matrices with this form, and DLSOIBT should still succeed.
12589 ! The block-tridiagonal matrix P is described by three arrays,
12590 ! each of size MB by MB by NB:
12591 !     PA = array of diagonal blocks,
12592 !     PB = array of superdiagonal (and one subdiagonal) blocks, and
12593 !     PC = array of subdiagonal (and one superdiagonal) blocks.
12594 ! Specifically, the three MB by MB blocks in the k-th block-row of P
12595 ! are stored in (reading across):
12596 !     PC(*,*,k) = block to the left of the diagonal block,
12597 !     PA(*,*,k) = diagonal block, and
12598 !     PB(*,*,k) = block to the right of the diagonal block,
12599 ! except for k = 1, where the three blocks (reading across) are
12600 !     PA(*,*,1) (= diagonal block), PB(*,*,1), and PC(*,*,1),
12601 ! and k = NB, where they are
12602 !     PB(*,*,NB), PC(*,*,NB), and PA(*,*,NB) (= diagonal block).
12603 ! (Each asterisk * stands for an index that ranges from 1 to MB.)
12604 !
12605 ! C. You must also provide a subroutine of the form:
12606 !     SUBROUTINE ADDA (NEQ, T, Y, MB, NB, PA, PB, PC)
12607 !     DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), PA(MB,MB,NB), PB(MB,MB,NB), PC(MB,MB,NB)
12608 ! which adds the nonzero blocks of the matrix A = A(t,y) to the
12609 ! contents of the arrays PA, PB, and PC, following the structure
12610 ! description in Paragraph B above.
12611 ! T and the Y array are input and should not be altered.
12612 ! Thus the affect of ADDA should be the following:
12613 !     DO 30 K = 1,NB
12614 !       DO 20 J = 1,MB
12615 !         DO 10 I = 1,MB
12616 !           PA(I,J,K) = PA(I,J,K) +
12617 !             ( (I,J) element of K-th diagonal block of A)
12618 !           PB(I,J,K) = PB(I,J,K) +
12619 !             ( (I,J) element of block in block position (K,K+1) of A,
12620 !             or in block position (NB,NB-2) if K = NB)
12621 !           PC(I,J,K) = PC(I,J,K) +
12622 !             ( (I,J) element of block in block position (K,K-1) of A,
12623 !             or in block position (1,3) if K = 1)
12624 ! 10        CONTINUE
12625 ! 20      CONTINUE
12626 ! 30    CONTINUE
12627 !
12628 ! D. For the sake of efficiency, you are encouraged to supply the
12629 ! Jacobian matrix dr/dy in closed form, where r = g(t,y) - A(t,y)*s
12630 ! (s = a fixed vector) as above.  If dr/dy is being supplied,
12631 ! use MF = 21, and provide a subroutine of the form:
12632 !     SUBROUTINE JAC (NEQ, T, Y, S, MB, NB, PA, PB, PC)
12633 !     DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), S(*), PA(MB,MB,NB), PB(MB,MB,NB),
12634 !    1                 PC(MB,MB,NB)
12635 ! which computes dr/dy as a function of t, y, and s.  Here T, Y, and
12636 ! S are inputs, and the routine is to load dr/dy into PA, PB, PC,
12637 ! according to the structure description in Paragraph B above.
12638 ! That is, load the diagonal blocks into PA, the superdiagonal blocks
12639 ! (and block (NB,NB-2) ) into PB, and the subdiagonal blocks (and
12640 ! block (1,3) ) into PC.  The blocks in block-row k of dr/dy are to
12641 ! be loaded into PA(*,*,k), PB(*,*,k), and PC(*,*,k).
12642 !     Only nonzero elements need be loaded, and the indexing
12643 ! of PA, PB, and PC is the same as in the ADDA routine.
12644 !     Note that if A is independent of Y (or this dependence
12645 ! is weak enough to be ignored) then JAC is to compute dg/dy.
12646 !     If it is not feasible to provide a JAC routine, use
12647 ! MF = 22, and DLSOIBT will compute an approximate Jacobian
12648 ! internally by difference quotients.
12649 !
12650 ! E. Next decide whether or not to provide the initial value of the
12651 ! derivative vector dy/dt.  If the initial value of A(t,y) is
12652 ! nonsingular (and not too ill-conditioned), you may let DLSOIBT compute
12653 ! this vector (ISTATE = 0).  (DLSOIBT will solve the system A*s = g for
12654 ! s, with initial values of A and g.)  If A(t,y) is initially
12655 ! singular, then the system is a differential-algebraic system, and
12656 ! you must make use of the particular form of the system to compute the
12657 ! initial values of y and dy/dt.  In that case, use ISTATE = 1 and
12658 ! load the initial value of dy/dt into the array YDOTI.
12659 ! The input array YDOTI and the initial Y array must be consistent with
12660 ! the equations A*dy/dt = g.  This implies that the initial residual
12661 ! r = g(t,y) - A(t,y)*YDOTI  must be approximately zero.
12662 !
12663 ! F. Write a main program which calls Subroutine DLSOIBT once for
12664 ! each point at which answers are desired.  This should also provide
12665 ! for possible use of logical unit 6 for output of error messages by
12666 ! DLSOIBT.  on the first call to DLSOIBT, supply arguments as follows:
12667 ! RES    = name of user subroutine for residual function r.
12668 ! ADDA   = name of user subroutine for computing and adding A(t,y).
12669 ! JAC    = name of user subroutine for Jacobian matrix dr/dy
12670 !          (MF = 21).  If not used, pass a dummy name.
12671 ! Note: the names for the RES and ADDA routines and (if used) the
12672 !        JAC routine must be declared External in the calling program.
12673 ! NEQ    = number of scalar equations in the system.
12674 ! Y      = array of initial values, of length NEQ.
12675 ! YDOTI  = array of length NEQ (containing initial dy/dt if ISTATE = 1).
12676 ! T      = the initial value of the independent variable.
12677 ! TOUT   = first point where output is desired (.ne. T).
12678 ! ITOL   = 1 or 2 according as ATOL (below) is a scalar or array.
12679 ! RTOL   = relative tolerance parameter (scalar).
12680 ! ATOL   = absolute tolerance parameter (scalar or array).
12681 !          the estimated local error in y(i) will be controlled so as
12682 !          to be roughly less (in magnitude) than
12683 !             EWT(i) = RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL     if ITOL = 1, or
12684 !             EWT(i) = RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i)  if ITOL = 2.
12685 !          Thus the local error test passes if, in each component,
12686 !          either the absolute error is less than ATOL (or ATOL(i)),
12687 !          or the relative error is less than RTOL.
12688 !          Use RTOL = 0.0 for pure absolute error control, and
12689 !          use ATOL = 0.0 (or ATOL(i) = 0.0) for pure relative error
12690 !          control.  Caution: Actual (global) errors may exceed these
12691 !          local tolerances, so choose them conservatively.
12692 ! ITASK  = 1 for normal computation of output values of y at t = TOUT.
12693 ! ISTATE = integer flag (input and output).  Set ISTATE = 1 if the
12694 !          initial dy/dt is supplied, and 0 otherwise.
12695 ! IOPT   = 0 to indicate no optional inputs used.
12696 ! RWORK  = real work array of length at least:
12697 !             22 + 9*NEQ + 3*MB*MB*NB        for MF = 21 or 22.
12698 ! LRW    = declared length of RWORK (in user's dimension).
12699 ! IWORK  = integer work array of length at least 20 + NEQ.
12700 !          Input in IWORK(1) the block size MB and in IWORK(2) the
12701 !          number NB of blocks in each direction along the matrix A.
12702 !          These must satisfy  MB .ge. 1, NB .ge. 4, and MB*NB = NEQ.
12703 ! LIW    = declared length of IWORK (in user's dimension).
12704 ! MF     = method flag.  Standard values are:
12705 !          21 for a user-supplied Jacobian.
12706 !          22 for an internally generated Jacobian.
12707 !          For other choices of MF, see the paragraph on MF in
12708 !          the full description below.
12709 ! Note that the main program must declare arrays Y, YDOTI, RWORK, IWORK,
12710 ! and possibly ATOL.
12711 !
12712 ! G. The output from the first call (or any call) is:
12713 !      Y = array of computed values of y(t) vector.
12714 !      T = corresponding value of independent variable (normally TOUT).
12715 ! ISTATE = 2  if DLSOIBT was successful, negative otherwise.
12716 !          -1 means excess work done on this call (check all inputs).
12717 !          -2 means excess accuracy requested (tolerances too small).
12718 !          -3 means illegal input detected (see printed message).
12719 !          -4 means repeated error test failures (check all inputs).
12720 !          -5 means repeated convergence failures (perhaps bad Jacobian
12721 !             supplied or wrong choice of tolerances).
12722 !          -6 means error weight became zero during problem. (Solution
12723 !             component i vanished, and ATOL or ATOL(i) = 0.)
12724 !          -7 cannot occur in casual use.
12725 !          -8 means DLSOIBT was unable to compute the initial dy/dt.
12726 !             In casual use, this means A(t,y) is initially singular.
12727 !             Supply YDOTI and use ISTATE = 1 on the first call.
12728 !
12729 !  If DLSOIBT returns ISTATE = -1, -4, or -5, then the output of
12730 !  DLSOIBT also includes YDOTI = array containing residual vector
12731 !  r = g - A * dy/dt  evaluated at the current t, y, and dy/dt.
12732 !
12733 ! H. To continue the integration after a successful return, simply
12734 ! reset TOUT and call DLSOIBT again.  No other parameters need be reset.
12735 !
12736 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12737 ! Example Problem.
12738 !
12739 ! The following is an example problem, with the coding needed
12740 ! for its solution by DLSOIBT.  The problem comes from the partial
12741 ! differential equation (the Burgers equation)
12742 !   du/dt  =  - u * du/dx  +  eta * d**2 u/dx**2,   eta = .05,
12743 ! on -1 .le. x .le. 1.  The boundary conditions are
12744 !   du/dx = 0  at x = -1 and at x = 1.
12745 ! The initial profile is a square wave,
12746 !   u = 1 in ABS(x) .lt. .5,  u = .5 at ABS(x) = .5,  u = 0 elsewhere.
12747 ! The PDE is discretized in x by a simplified Galerkin method,
12748 ! using piecewise linear basis functions, on a grid of 40 intervals.
12749 ! The equations at x = -1 and 1 use a 3-point difference approximation
12750 ! for the right-hand side.  The result is a system A * dy/dt = g(y),
12751 ! of size NEQ = 41, where y(i) is the approximation to u at x = x(i),
12752 ! with x(i) = -1 + (i-1)*delx, delx = 2/(NEQ-1) = .05.  The individual
12753 ! equations in the system are
12754 !   dy(1)/dt = ( y(3) - 2*y(2) + y(1) ) * eta / delx**2,
12755 !   dy(NEQ)/dt = ( y(NEQ-2) - 2*y(NEQ-1) + y(NEQ) ) * eta / delx**2,
12756 ! and for i = 2, 3, ..., NEQ-1,
12757 !   (1/6) dy(i-1)/dt + (4/6) dy(i)/dt + (1/6) dy(i+1)/dt
12758 !       = ( y(i-1)**2 - y(i+1)**2 ) / (4*delx)
12759 !         + ( y(i+1) - 2*y(i) + y(i-1) ) * eta / delx**2.
12760 ! The following coding solves the problem with MF = 21, with output
12761 ! of solution statistics at t = .1, .2, .3, and .4, and of the
12762 ! solution vector at t = .4.  Here the block size is just MB = 1.
12763 !
12764 !     EXTERNAL RESID, ADDABT, JACBT
12765 !     DOUBLE PRECISION ATOL, RTOL, RWORK, T, TOUT, Y, YDOTI
12766 !     DIMENSION Y(41), YDOTI(41), RWORK(514), IWORK(61)
12767 !     NEQ = 41
12768 !     DO 10 I = 1,NEQ
12769 !  10   Y(I) = 0.0
12770 !     Y(11) = 0.5
12771 !     DO 20 I = 12,30
12772 !  20   Y(I) = 1.0
12773 !     Y(31) = 0.5
12774 !     T = 0.0
12775 !     TOUT = 0.1
12776 !     ITOL = 1
12777 !     RTOL = 1.0D-4
12778 !     ATOL = 1.0D-5
12779 !     ITASK = 1
12780 !     ISTATE = 0
12781 !     IOPT = 0
12782 !     LRW = 514
12783 !     LIW = 61
12784 !     IWORK(1) = 1
12785 !     IWORK(2) = NEQ
12786 !     MF = 21
12787 !     DO 40 IO = 1,4
12788 !       CALL DLSOIBT (RESID, ADDABT, JACBT, NEQ, Y, YDOTI, T, TOUT,
12789 !    1     ITOL,RTOL,ATOL, ITASK, ISTATE, IOPT, RWORK,LRW,IWORK,LIW, MF)
12790 !       WRITE (6,30) T, IWORK(11), IWORK(12), IWORK(13)
12791 !  30   FORMAT(' At t =',F5.2,'   No. steps =',I4,'  No. r-s =',I4,
12792 !    1         '  No. J-s =',I3)
12793 !       IF (ISTATE .NE. 2)  GOTO 90
12794 !       TOUT = TOUT + 0.1
12795 !  40   CONTINUE
12796 !     WRITE(6,50) (Y(I),I=1,NEQ)
12797 !  50 FORMAT(/' Final solution values..'/9(5D12.4/))
12798 !     STOP
12799 !  90 WRITE(6,95) ISTATE
12800 !  95 FORMAT(///' Error halt.. ISTATE =',I3)
12801 !     STOP
12802 !     END
12803 !
12804 !     SUBROUTINE RESID (N, T, Y, S, R, IRES)
12805 !     DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y, S, R, ETA, DELX, EODSQ
12806 !     DIMENSION Y(N), S(N), R(N)
12807 !     DATA ETA/0.05/, DELX/0.05/
12808 !     EODSQ = ETA/DELX**2
12809 !     R(1) = EODSQ*(Y(3) - 2.0*Y(2) + Y(1)) - S(1)
12810 !     NM1 = N - 1
12811 !     DO 10 I = 2,NM1
12812 !       R(I) = (Y(I-1)**2 - Y(I+1)**2)/(4.0*DELX)
12813 !    1        + EODSQ*(Y(I+1) - 2.0*Y(I) + Y(I-1))
12814 !    2        - (S(I-1) + 4.0*S(I) + S(I+1))/6.0
12815 !  10   CONTINUE
12816 !     R(N) = EODSQ*(Y(N-2) - 2.0*Y(NM1) + Y(N)) - S(N)
12817 !     RETURN
12818 !     END
12819 !
12820 !     SUBROUTINE ADDABT (N, T, Y, MB, NB, PA, PB, PC)
12821 !     DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y, PA, PB, PC
12822 !     DIMENSION Y(N), PA(MB,MB,NB), PB(MB,MB,NB), PC(MB,MB,NB)
12823 !     PA(1,1,1) = PA(1,1,1) + 1.0
12824 !     NM1 = N - 1
12825 !     DO 10 K = 2,NM1
12826 !       PA(1,1,K) = PA(1,1,K) + (4.0/6.0)
12827 !       PB(1,1,K) = PB(1,1,K) + (1.0/6.0)
12828 !       PC(1,1,K) = PC(1,1,K) + (1.0/6.0)
12829 !  10   CONTINUE
12830 !     PA(1,1,N) = PA(1,1,N) + 1.0
12831 !     RETURN
12832 !     END
12833 !
12834 !     SUBROUTINE JACBT (N, T, Y, S, MB, NB, PA, PB, PC)
12835 !     DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y, S, PA, PB, PC, ETA, DELX, EODSQ
12836 !     DIMENSION Y(N), S(N), PA(MB,MB,NB),PB(MB,MB,NB),PC(MB,MB,NB)
12837 !     DATA ETA/0.05/, DELX/0.05/
12838 !     EODSQ = ETA/DELX**2
12839 !     PA(1,1,1) = EODSQ
12840 !     PB(1,1,1) = -2.0*EODSQ
12841 !     PC(1,1,1) = EODSQ
12842 !     DO 10 K = 2,N
12843 !       PA(1,1,K) = -2.0*EODSQ
12844 !       PB(1,1,K) = -Y(K+1)*(0.5/DELX) + EODSQ
12845 !       PC(1,1,K) = Y(K-1)*(0.5/DELX) + EODSQ
12846 !  10   CONTINUE
12847 !     PB(1,1,N) = EODSQ
12848 !     PC(1,1,N) = -2.0*EODSQ
12849 !     PA(1,1,N) = EODSQ
12850 !     RETURN
12851 !     END
12852 !
12853 ! The output of this program (on a CDC-7600 in single precision)
12854 ! is as follows:
12855 !
12856 ! At t = 0.10   No. steps =  35  No. r-s =  45  No. J-s =  9
12857 ! At t = 0.20   No. steps =  43  No. r-s =  54  No. J-s = 10
12858 ! At t = 0.30   No. steps =  48  No. r-s =  60  No. J-s = 11
12859 ! At t = 0.40   No. steps =  51  No. r-s =  64  No. J-s = 12
12860 !
12861 ! Final solution values..
12862 !  1.2747e-02  1.1997e-02  1.5560e-02  2.3767e-02  3.7224e-02
12863 !  5.6646e-02  8.2645e-02  1.1557e-01  1.5541e-01  2.0177e-01
12864 !  2.5397e-01  3.1104e-01  3.7189e-01  4.3530e-01  5.0000e-01
12865 !  5.6472e-01  6.2816e-01  6.8903e-01  7.4612e-01  7.9829e-01
12866 !  8.4460e-01  8.8438e-01  9.1727e-01  9.4330e-01  9.6281e-01
12867 !  9.7632e-01  9.8426e-01  9.8648e-01  9.8162e-01  9.6617e-01
12868 !  9.3374e-01  8.7535e-01  7.8236e-01  6.5321e-01  5.0003e-01
12869 !  3.4709e-01  2.1876e-01  1.2771e-01  7.3671e-02  5.0642e-02
12870 !  5.4496e-02
12871 !
12872 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12873 ! Full Description of User Interface to DLSOIBT.
12874 !
12875 ! The user interface to DLSOIBT consists of the following parts.
12876 !
12877 ! 1.   The call sequence to Subroutine DLSOIBT, which is a driver
12878 !      routine for the solver.  This includes descriptions of both
12879 !      the call sequence arguments and of user-supplied routines.
12880 !      Following these descriptions is a description of
12881 !      optional inputs available through the call sequence, and then
12882 !      a description of optional outputs (in the work arrays).
12883 !
12884 ! 2.   Descriptions of other routines in the DLSOIBT package that may be
12885 !      (optionally) called by the user.  These provide the ability to
12886 !      alter error message handling, save and restore the internal
12887 !      Common, and obtain specified derivatives of the solution y(t).
12888 !
12889 ! 3.   Descriptions of Common blocks to be declared in overlay
12890 !      or similar environments, or to be saved when doing an interrupt
12891 !      of the problem and continued solution later.
12892 !
12893 ! 4.   Description of two routines in the DLSOIBT package, either of
12894 !      which the user may replace with his/her own version, if desired.
12895 !      These relate to the measurement of errors.
12896 !
12897 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
12898 ! Part 1.  Call Sequence.
12899 !
12900 ! The call sequence parameters used for input only are
12901 !     RES, ADDA, JAC, NEQ, TOUT, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, ITASK,
12902 !     IOPT, LRW, LIW, MF,
12903 ! and those used for both input and output are
12904 !     Y, T, ISTATE, YDOTI.
12905 ! The work arrays RWORK and IWORK are also used for additional and
12906 ! optional inputs and optional outputs.  (The term output here refers
12907 ! to the return from Subroutine DLSOIBT to the user's calling program.)
12908 !
12909 ! The legality of input parameters will be thoroughly checked on the
12910 ! initial call for the problem, but not checked thereafter unless a
12911 ! change in input parameters is flagged by ISTATE = 3 on input.
12912 !
12913 ! The descriptions of the call arguments are as follows.
12914 !
12915 ! RES    = the name of the user-supplied subroutine which supplies
12916 !          the residual vector for the ODE system, defined by
12917 !            r = g(t,y) - A(t,y) * s
12918 !          as a function of the scalar t and the vectors
12919 !          s and y (s approximates dy/dt).  This subroutine
12920 !          is to have the form
12921 !              SUBROUTINE RES (NEQ, T, Y, S, R, IRES)
12922 !              DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), S(*), R(*)
12923 !          where NEQ, T, Y, S, and IRES are input, and R and
12924 !          IRES are output. Y, S, and R are arrays of length NEQ.
12925 !             On input, IRES indicates how DLSOIBT will use the
12926 !          returned array R, as follows:
12927 !             IRES = 1  means that DLSOIBT needs the full residual,
12928 !                       r = g - A*s, exactly.
12929 !             IRES = -1 means that DLSOIBT is using R only to compute
12930 !                       the Jacobian dr/dy by difference quotients.
12931 !          The RES routine can ignore IRES, or it can omit some terms
12932 !          if IRES = -1.  If A does not depend on y, then RES can
12933 !          just return R = g when IRES = -1.  If g - A*s contains other
12934 !          additive terms that are independent of y, these can also be
12935 !          dropped, if done consistently, when IRES = -1.
12936 !             The subroutine should set the flag IRES if it
12937 !          encounters a halt condition or illegal input.
12938 !          Otherwise, it should not reset IRES.  On output,
12939 !             IRES = 1 or -1 represents a normal return, and
12940 !          DLSOIBT continues integrating the ODE.  Leave IRES
12941 !          unchanged from its input value.
12942 !             IRES = 2 tells DLSOIBT to immediately return control
12943 !          to the calling program, with ISTATE = 3.  This lets
12944 !          the calling program change parameters of the problem
12945 !          if necessary.
12946 !             IRES = 3 represents an error condition (for example, an
12947 !          illegal value of y).  DLSOIBT tries to integrate the system
12948 !          without getting IRES = 3 from RES.  If it cannot, DLSOIBT
12949 !          returns with ISTATE = -7 or -1.
12950 !             On an DLSOIBT return with ISTATE = 3, -1, or -7, the
12951 !          values of T and Y returned correspond to the last point
12952 !          reached successfully without getting the flag IRES = 2 or 3.
12953 !             The flag values IRES = 2 and 3 should not be used to
12954 !          handle switches or root-stop conditions.  This is better
12955 !          done by calling DLSOIBT in a one-step mode and checking the
12956 !          stopping function for a sign change at each step.
12957 !             If quantities computed in the RES routine are needed
12958 !          externally to DLSOIBT, an extra call to RES should be made
12959 !          for this purpose, for consistent and accurate results.
12960 !          To get the current dy/dt for the S argument, use DINTDY.
12961 !             RES must be declared External in the calling
12962 !          program. See note below for more about RES.
12963 !
12964 ! ADDA   = the name of the user-supplied subroutine which adds the
12965 !          matrix A = A(t,y) to another matrix, P, stored in
12966 !          block-tridiagonal form.  This routine is to have the form
12967 !               SUBROUTINE ADDA (NEQ, T, Y, MB, NB, PA, PB, PC)
12968 !               DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), PA(MB,MB,NB), PB(MB,MB,NB),
12969 !              1                 PC(MB,MB,NB)
12970 !          where NEQ, T, Y, MB, NB, and the arrays PA, PB, and PC
12971 !          are input, and the arrays PA, PB, and PC are output.
12972 !          Y is an array of length NEQ, and the arrays PA, PB, PC
12973 !          are all MB by MB by NB.
12974 !             Here a block-tridiagonal structure is assumed for A(t,y),
12975 !          and also for the matrix P to which A is added here,
12976 !          as described in Paragraph B of the Summary of Usage above.
12977 !          Thus the affect of ADDA should be the following:
12978 !               DO 30 K = 1,NB
12979 !                 DO 20 J = 1,MB
12980 !                   DO 10 I = 1,MB
12981 !                     PA(I,J,K) = PA(I,J,K) +
12982 !                       ( (I,J) element of K-th diagonal block of A)
12983 !                     PB(I,J,K) = PB(I,J,K) +
12984 !                       ( (I,J) element of block (K,K+1) of A,
12985 !                       or block (NB,NB-2) if K = NB)
12986 !                     PC(I,J,K) = PC(I,J,K) +
12987 !                       ( (I,J) element of block (K,K-1) of A,
12988 !                       or block (1,3) if K = 1)
12989 !           10        CONTINUE
12990 !           20      CONTINUE
12991 !           30    CONTINUE
12992 !             ADDA must be declared External in the calling program.
12993 !          See note below for more information about ADDA.
12994 !
12995 ! JAC    = the name of the user-supplied subroutine which supplies
12996 !          the Jacobian matrix, dr/dy, where r = g - A*s.  JAC is
12997 !          required if MITER = 1.  Otherwise a dummy name can be
12998 !          passed.  This subroutine is to have the form
12999 !               SUBROUTINE JAC (NEQ, T, Y, S, MB, NB, PA, PB, PC)
13000 !               DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), S(*), PA(MB,MB,NB),
13001 !              1                 PB(MB,MB,NB), PC(MB,MB,NB)
13002 !          where NEQ, T, Y, S, MB, NB, and the arrays PA, PB, and PC
13003 !          are input, and the arrays PA, PB, and PC are output.
13004 !          Y and S are arrays of length NEQ, and the arrays PA, PB, PC
13005 !          are all MB by MB by NB.
13006 !          PA, PB, and PC are to be loaded with partial derivatives
13007 !          (elements of the Jacobian matrix) on output, in terms of the
13008 !          block-tridiagonal structure assumed, as described
13009 !          in Paragraph B of the Summary of Usage above.
13010 !          That is, load the diagonal blocks into PA, the
13011 !          superdiagonal blocks (and block (NB,NB-2) ) into PB, and
13012 !          the subdiagonal blocks (and block (1,3) ) into PC.
13013 !          The blocks in block-row k of dr/dy are to be loaded into
13014 !          PA(*,*,k), PB(*,*,k), and PC(*,*,k).
13015 !          Thus the affect of JAC should be the following:
13016 !               DO 30 K = 1,NB
13017 !                 DO 20 J = 1,MB
13018 !                   DO 10 I = 1,MB
13019 !                     PA(I,J,K) = ( (I,J) element of
13020 !                       K-th diagonal block of dr/dy)
13021 !                     PB(I,J,K) = ( (I,J) element of block (K,K+1)
13022 !                       of dr/dy, or block (NB,NB-2) if K = NB)
13023 !                     PC(I,J,K) = ( (I,J) element of block (K,K-1)
13024 !                       of dr/dy, or block (1,3) if K = 1)
13025 !           10        CONTINUE
13026 !           20      CONTINUE
13027 !           30    CONTINUE
13028 !               PA, PB, and PC are preset to zero by the solver,
13029 !          so that only the nonzero elements need be loaded by JAC.
13030 !          Each call to JAC is preceded by a call to RES with the same
13031 !          arguments NEQ, T, Y, and S.  Thus to gain some efficiency,
13032 !          intermediate quantities shared by both calculations may be
13033 !          saved in a user Common block by RES and not recomputed by JAC
13034 !          if desired.  Also, JAC may alter the Y array, if desired.
13035 !               JAC need not provide dr/dy exactly.  A crude
13036 !          approximation will do, so that DLSOIBT may be used when
13037 !          A and dr/dy are not really block-tridiagonal, but are close
13038 !          to matrices that are.
13039 !               JAC must be declared External in the calling program.
13040 !               See note below for more about JAC.
13041 !
13042 !    Note on RES, ADDA, and JAC:
13043 !          These subroutines may access user-defined quantities in
13044 !          NEQ(2),... and/or in Y(NEQ(1)+1),... if NEQ is an array
13045 !          (dimensioned in the subroutines) and/or Y has length
13046 !          exceeding NEQ(1).  However, these routines should not alter
13047 !          NEQ(1), Y(1),...,Y(NEQ) or any other input variables.
13048 !          See the descriptions of NEQ and Y below.
13049 !
13050 ! NEQ    = the size of the system (number of first order ordinary
13051 !          differential equations or scalar algebraic equations).
13052 !          Used only for input.
13053 !          NEQ may be decreased, but not increased, during the problem.
13054 !          If NEQ is decreased (with ISTATE = 3 on input), the
13055 !          remaining components of Y should be left undisturbed, if
13056 !          these are to be accessed in RES, ADDA, or JAC.
13057 !
13058 !          Normally, NEQ is a scalar, and it is generally referred to
13059 !          as a scalar in this user interface description.  However,
13060 !          NEQ may be an array, with NEQ(1) set to the system size.
13061 !          (The DLSOIBT package accesses only NEQ(1).)  In either case,
13062 !          this parameter is passed as the NEQ argument in all calls
13063 !          to RES, ADDA, and JAC.  Hence, if it is an array,
13064 !          locations NEQ(2),... may be used to store other integer data
13065 !          and pass it to RES, ADDA, or JAC.  Each such subroutine
13066 !          must include NEQ in a Dimension statement in that case.
13067 !
13068 ! Y      = a real array for the vector of dependent variables, of
13069 !          length NEQ or more.  Used for both input and output on the
13070 !          first call (ISTATE = 0 or 1), and only for output on other
13071 !          calls.  On the first call, Y must contain the vector of
13072 !          initial values.  On output, Y contains the computed solution
13073 !          vector, evaluated at t.  If desired, the Y array may be used
13074 !          for other purposes between calls to the solver.
13075 !
13076 !          This array is passed as the Y argument in all calls to RES,
13077 !          ADDA, and JAC.  Hence its length may exceed NEQ,
13078 !          and locations Y(NEQ+1),... may be used to store other real
13079 !          data and pass it to RES, ADDA, or JAC.  (The DLSOIBT
13080 !          package accesses only Y(1),...,Y(NEQ). )
13081 !
13082 ! YDOTI  = a real array for the initial value of the vector
13083 !          dy/dt and for work space, of dimension at least NEQ.
13084 !
13085 !          On input:
13086 !            If ISTATE = 0 then DLSOIBT will compute the initial value
13087 !          of dy/dt, if A is nonsingular.  Thus YDOTI will
13088 !          serve only as work space and may have any value.
13089 !            If ISTATE = 1 then YDOTI must contain the initial value
13090 !          of dy/dt.
13091 !            If ISTATE = 2 or 3 (continuation calls) then YDOTI
13092 !          may have any value.
13093 !            Note: If the initial value of A is singular, then
13094 !          DLSOIBT cannot compute the initial value of dy/dt, so
13095 !          it must be provided in YDOTI, with ISTATE = 1.
13096 !
13097 !          On output, when DLSOIBT terminates abnormally with ISTATE =
13098 !          -1, -4, or -5, YDOTI will contain the residual
13099 !          r = g(t,y) - A(t,y)*(dy/dt).  If r is large, t is near
13100 !          its initial value, and YDOTI is supplied with ISTATE = 1,
13101 !          there may have been an incorrect input value of
13102 !          YDOTI = dy/dt, or the problem (as given to DLSOIBT)
13103 !          may not have a solution.
13104 !
13105 !          If desired, the YDOTI array may be used for other
13106 !          purposes between calls to the solver.
13107 !
13108 ! T      = the independent variable.  On input, T is used only on the
13109 !          first call, as the initial point of the integration.
13110 !          On output, after each call, T is the value at which a
13111 !          computed solution y is evaluated (usually the same as TOUT).
13112 !          On an error return, T is the farthest point reached.
13113 !
13114 ! TOUT   = the next value of t at which a computed solution is desired.
13115 !          Used only for input.
13116 !
13117 !          When starting the problem (ISTATE = 0 or 1), TOUT may be
13118 !          equal to T for one call, then should .ne. T for the next
13119 !          call.  For the initial T, an input value of TOUT .ne. T is
13120 !          used in order to determine the direction of the integration
13121 !          (i.e. the algebraic sign of the step sizes) and the rough
13122 !          scale of the problem.  Integration in either direction
13123 !          (forward or backward in t) is permitted.
13124 !
13125 !          If ITASK = 2 or 5 (one-step modes), TOUT is ignored after
13126 !          the first call (i.e. the first call with TOUT .ne. T).
13127 !          Otherwise, TOUT is required on every call.
13128 !
13129 !          If ITASK = 1, 3, or 4, the values of TOUT need not be
13130 !          monotone, but a value of TOUT which backs up is limited
13131 !          to the current internal T interval, whose endpoints are
13132 !          TCUR - HU and TCUR (see optional outputs, below, for
13133 !          TCUR and HU).
13134 !
13135 ! ITOL   = an indicator for the type of error control.  See
13136 !          description below under ATOL.  Used only for input.
13137 !
13138 ! RTOL   = a relative error tolerance parameter, either a scalar or
13139 !          an array of length NEQ.  See description below under ATOL.
13140 !          Input only.
13141 !
13142 ! ATOL   = an absolute error tolerance parameter, either a scalar or
13143 !          an array of length NEQ.  Input only.
13144 !
13145 !             The input parameters ITOL, RTOL, and ATOL determine
13146 !          the error control performed by the solver.  The solver will
13147 !          control the vector E = (E(i)) of estimated local errors
13148 !          in y, according to an inequality of the form
13149 !                      RMS-norm of ( E(i)/EWT(i) )   .le.   1,
13150 !          where       EWT(i) = RTOL(i)*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i),
13151 !          and the RMS-norm (root-mean-square norm) here is
13152 !          RMS-norm(v) = SQRT(sum v(i)**2 / NEQ).  Here EWT = (EWT(i))
13153 !          is a vector of weights which must always be positive, and
13154 !          the values of RTOL and ATOL should all be non-negative.
13155 !          The following table gives the types (scalar/array) of
13156 !          RTOL and ATOL, and the corresponding form of EWT(i).
13157 !
13158 !             ITOL    RTOL       ATOL          EWT(i)
13159 !              1     scalar     scalar     RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL
13160 !              2     scalar     array      RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i)
13161 !              3     array      scalar     RTOL(i)*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL
13162 !              4     array      scalar     RTOL(i)*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i)
13163 !
13164 !          When either of these parameters is a scalar, it need not
13165 !          be dimensioned in the user's calling program.
13166 !
13167 !          If none of the above choices (with ITOL, RTOL, and ATOL
13168 !          fixed throughout the problem) is suitable, more general
13169 !          error controls can be obtained by substituting
13170 !          user-supplied routines for the setting of EWT and/or for
13171 !          the norm calculation.  See Part 4 below.
13172 !
13173 !          If global errors are to be estimated by making a repeated
13174 !          run on the same problem with smaller tolerances, then all
13175 !          components of RTOL and ATOL (i.e. of EWT) should be scaled
13176 !          down uniformly.
13177 !
13178 ! ITASK  = an index specifying the task to be performed.
13179 !          Input only.  ITASK has the following values and meanings.
13180 !          1  means normal computation of output values of y(t) at
13181 !             t = TOUT (by overshooting and interpolating).
13182 !          2  means take one step only and return.
13183 !          3  means stop at the first internal mesh point at or
13184 !             beyond t = TOUT and return.
13185 !          4  means normal computation of output values of y(t) at
13186 !             t = TOUT but without overshooting t = TCRIT.
13187 !             TCRIT must be input as RWORK(1).  TCRIT may be equal to
13188 !             or beyond TOUT, but not behind it in the direction of
13189 !             integration.  This option is useful if the problem
13190 !             has a singularity at or beyond t = TCRIT.
13191 !          5  means take one step, without passing TCRIT, and return.
13192 !             TCRIT must be input as RWORK(1).
13193 !
13194 !          Note:  If ITASK = 4 or 5 and the solver reaches TCRIT
13195 !          (within roundoff), it will return T = TCRIT (exactly) to
13196 !          indicate this (unless ITASK = 4 and TOUT comes before TCRIT,
13197 !          in which case answers at t = TOUT are returned first).
13198 !
13199 ! ISTATE = an index used for input and output to specify the
13200 !          state of the calculation.
13201 !
13202 !          On input, the values of ISTATE are as follows.
13203 !          0  means this is the first call for the problem, and
13204 !             DLSOIBT is to compute the initial value of dy/dt
13205 !             (while doing other initializations).  See note below.
13206 !          1  means this is the first call for the problem, and
13207 !             the initial value of dy/dt has been supplied in
13208 !             YDOTI (DLSOIBT will do other initializations).
13209 !             See note below.
13210 !          2  means this is not the first call, and the calculation
13211 !             is to continue normally, with no change in any input
13212 !             parameters except possibly TOUT and ITASK.
13213 !             (If ITOL, RTOL, and/or ATOL are changed between calls
13214 !             with ISTATE = 2, the new values will be used but not
13215 !             tested for legality.)
13216 !          3  means this is not the first call, and the
13217 !             calculation is to continue normally, but with
13218 !             a change in input parameters other than
13219 !             TOUT and ITASK.  Changes are allowed in
13220 !             NEQ, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, IOPT, LRW, LIW, MF, MB, NB,
13221 !             and any of the optional inputs except H0.
13222 !             (See IWORK description for MB and NB.)
13223 !          Note:  A preliminary call with TOUT = T is not counted
13224 !          as a first call here, as no initialization or checking of
13225 !          input is done.  (Such a call is sometimes useful for the
13226 !          purpose of outputting the initial conditions.)
13227 !          Thus the first call for which TOUT .ne. T requires
13228 !          ISTATE = 0 or 1 on input.
13229 !
13230 !          On output, ISTATE has the following values and meanings.
13231 !           0 or 1  means nothing was done; TOUT = t and
13232 !              ISTATE = 0 or 1 on input.
13233 !           2  means that the integration was performed successfully.
13234 !           3  means that the user-supplied Subroutine RES signalled
13235 !              DLSOIBT to halt the integration and return (IRES = 2).
13236 !              Integration as far as T was achieved with no occurrence
13237 !              of IRES = 2, but this flag was set on attempting the
13238 !              next step.
13239 !          -1  means an excessive amount of work (more than MXSTEP
13240 !              steps) was done on this call, before completing the
13241 !              requested task, but the integration was otherwise
13242 !              successful as far as T.  (MXSTEP is an optional input
13243 !              and is normally 500.)  To continue, the user may
13244 !              simply reset ISTATE to a value .gt. 1 and call again
13245 !              (the excess work step counter will be reset to 0).
13246 !              In addition, the user may increase MXSTEP to avoid
13247 !              this error return (see below on optional inputs).
13248 !          -2  means too much accuracy was requested for the precision
13249 !              of the machine being used.  This was detected before
13250 !              completing the requested task, but the integration
13251 !              was successful as far as T.  To continue, the tolerance
13252 !              parameters must be reset, and ISTATE must be set
13253 !              to 3.  The optional output TOLSF may be used for this
13254 !              purpose.  (Note: If this condition is detected before
13255 !              taking any steps, then an illegal input return
13256 !              (ISTATE = -3) occurs instead.)
13257 !          -3  means illegal input was detected, before taking any
13258 !              integration steps.  See written message for details.
13259 !              Note:  If the solver detects an infinite loop of calls
13260 !              to the solver with illegal input, it will cause
13261 !              the run to stop.
13262 !          -4  means there were repeated error test failures on
13263 !              one attempted step, before completing the requested
13264 !              task, but the integration was successful as far as T.
13265 !              The problem may have a singularity, or the input
13266 !              may be inappropriate.
13267 !          -5  means there were repeated convergence test failures on
13268 !              one attempted step, before completing the requested
13269 !              task, but the integration was successful as far as T.
13270 !              This may be caused by an inaccurate Jacobian matrix.
13271 !          -6  means EWT(i) became zero for some i during the
13272 !              integration.  Pure relative error control (ATOL(i) = 0.0)
13273 !              was requested on a variable which has now vanished.
13274 !              The integration was successful as far as T.
13275 !          -7  means that the user-supplied Subroutine RES set
13276 !              its error flag (IRES = 3) despite repeated tries by
13277 !              DLSOIBT to avoid that condition.
13278 !          -8  means that ISTATE was 0 on input but DLSOIBT was unable
13279 !              to compute the initial value of dy/dt.  See the
13280 !              printed message for details.
13281 !
13282 !          Note:  Since the normal output value of ISTATE is 2,
13283 !          it does not need to be reset for normal continuation.
13284 !          Similarly, ISTATE (= 3) need not be reset if RES told
13285 !          DLSOIBT to return because the calling program must change
13286 !          the parameters of the problem.
13287 !          Also, since a negative input value of ISTATE will be
13288 !          regarded as illegal, a negative output value requires the
13289 !          user to change it, and possibly other inputs, before
13290 !          calling the solver again.
13291 !
13292 ! IOPT   = an integer flag to specify whether or not any optional
13293 !          inputs are being used on this call.  Input only.
13294 !          The optional inputs are listed separately below.
13295 !          IOPT = 0 means no optional inputs are being used.
13296 !                   Default values will be used in all cases.
13297 !          IOPT = 1 means one or more optional inputs are being used.
13298 !
13299 ! RWORK  = a real working array (double precision).
13300 !          The length of RWORK must be at least
13301 !             20 + NYH*(MAXORD + 1) + 3*NEQ + LENWM    where
13302 !          NYH    = the initial value of NEQ,
13303 !          MAXORD = 12 (if METH = 1) or 5 (if METH = 2) (unless a
13304 !                   smaller value is given as an optional input),
13305 !          LENWM  = 3*MB*MB*NB + 2.
13306 !          (See MF description for the definition of METH.)
13307 !          Thus if MAXORD has its default value and NEQ is constant,
13308 !          this length is
13309 !             22 + 16*NEQ + 3*MB*MB*NB     for MF = 11 or 12,
13310 !             22 + 9*NEQ + 3*MB*MB*NB      for MF = 21 or 22.
13311 !          The first 20 words of RWORK are reserved for conditional
13312 !          and optional inputs and optional outputs.
13313 !
13314 !          The following word in RWORK is a conditional input:
13315 !            RWORK(1) = TCRIT = critical value of t which the solver
13316 !                       is not to overshoot.  Required if ITASK is
13317 !                       4 or 5, and ignored otherwise.  (See ITASK.)
13318 !
13319 ! LRW    = the length of the array RWORK, as declared by the user.
13320 !          (This will be checked by the solver.)
13321 !
13322 ! IWORK  = an integer work array.  The length of IWORK must be at least
13323 !          20 + NEQ .  The first few words of IWORK are used for
13324 !          additional and optional inputs and optional outputs.
13325 !
13326 !          The following 2 words in IWORK are additional required
13327 !          inputs to DLSOIBT:
13328 !            IWORK(1) = MB = block size
13329 !            IWORK(2) = NB = number of blocks in the main diagonal
13330 !          These must satisfy  MB .ge. 1, NB .ge. 4, and MB*NB = NEQ.
13331 !
13332 ! LIW    = the length of the array IWORK, as declared by the user.
13333 !          (This will be checked by the solver.)
13334 !
13335 ! Note:  The work arrays must not be altered between calls to DLSOIBT
13336 ! for the same problem, except possibly for the additional and
13337 ! optional inputs, and except for the last 3*NEQ words of RWORK.
13338 ! The latter space is used for internal scratch space, and so is
13339 ! available for use by the user outside DLSOIBT between calls, if
13340 ! desired (but not for use by RES, ADDA, or JAC).
13341 !
13342 ! MF     = the method flag.  used only for input.  The legal values of
13343 !          MF are 11, 12, 21, and 22.
13344 !          MF has decimal digits METH and MITER: MF = 10*METH + MITER.
13345 !            METH indicates the basic linear multistep method:
13346 !              METH = 1 means the implicit Adams method.
13347 !              METH = 2 means the method based on Backward
13348 !                       Differentiation Formulas (BDFS).
13349 !                The BDF method is strongly preferred for stiff
13350 !              problems, while the Adams method is preferred when the
13351 !              problem is not stiff.  If the matrix A(t,y) is
13352 !              nonsingular, stiffness here can be taken to mean that of
13353 !              the explicit ODE system dy/dt = A-inverse * g.  If A is
13354 !              singular, the concept of stiffness is not well defined.
13355 !                If you do not know whether the problem is stiff, we
13356 !              recommend using METH = 2.  If it is stiff, the advantage
13357 !              of METH = 2 over METH = 1 will be great, while if it is
13358 !              not stiff, the advantage of METH = 1 will be slight.
13359 !              If maximum efficiency is important, some experimentation
13360 !              with METH may be necessary.
13361 !            MITER indicates the corrector iteration method:
13362 !              MITER = 1 means chord iteration with a user-supplied
13363 !                        block-tridiagonal Jacobian.
13364 !              MITER = 2 means chord iteration with an internally
13365 !                        generated (difference quotient) block-
13366 !                        tridiagonal Jacobian approximation, using
13367 !                        3*MB+1 extra calls to RES per dr/dy evaluation.
13368 !              If MITER = 1, the user must supply a Subroutine JAC
13369 !              (the name is arbitrary) as described above under JAC.
13370 !              For MITER = 2, a dummy argument can be used.
13371 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13372 ! Optional Inputs.
13373 !
13374 ! The following is a list of the optional inputs provided for in the
13375 ! call sequence.  (See also Part 2.)  For each such input variable,
13376 ! this table lists its name as used in this documentation, its
13377 ! location in the call sequence, its meaning, and the default value.
13378 ! The use of any of these inputs requires IOPT = 1, and in that
13379 ! case all of these inputs are examined.  A value of zero for any
13380 ! of these optional inputs will cause the default value to be used.
13381 ! Thus to use a subset of the optional inputs, simply preload
13382 ! locations 5 to 10 in RWORK and IWORK to 0.0 and 0 respectively, and
13383 ! then set those of interest to nonzero values.
13384 !
13385 ! Name    Location      Meaning and Default Value
13386 !
13387 ! H0      RWORK(5)  the step size to be attempted on the first step.
13388 !                   The default value is determined by the solver.
13389 !
13390 ! HMAX    RWORK(6)  the maximum absolute step size allowed.
13391 !                   The default value is infinite.
13392 !
13393 ! HMIN    RWORK(7)  the minimum absolute step size allowed.
13394 !                   The default value is 0.  (This lower bound is not
13395 !                   enforced on the final step before reaching TCRIT
13396 !                   when ITASK = 4 or 5.)
13397 !
13398 ! MAXORD  IWORK(5)  the maximum order to be allowed.  The default
13399 !                   value is 12 if METH = 1, and 5 if METH = 2.
13400 !                   If MAXORD exceeds the default value, it will
13401 !                   be reduced to the default value.
13402 !                   If MAXORD is changed during the problem, it may
13403 !                   cause the current order to be reduced.
13404 !
13405 ! MXSTEP  IWORK(6)  maximum number of (internally defined) steps
13406 !                   allowed during one call to the solver.
13407 !                   The default value is 500.
13408 !
13409 ! MXHNIL  IWORK(7)  maximum number of messages printed (per problem)
13410 !                   warning that T + H = T on a step (H = step size).
13411 !                   This must be positive to result in a non-default
13412 !                   value.  The default value is 10.
13413 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13414 ! Optional Outputs.
13415 !
13416 ! As optional additional output from DLSOIBT, the variables listed
13417 ! below are quantities related to the performance of DLSOIBT
13418 ! which are available to the user.  These are communicated by way of
13419 ! the work arrays, but also have internal mnemonic names as shown.
13420 ! Except where stated otherwise, all of these outputs are defined
13421 ! on any successful return from DLSOIBT, and on any return with
13422 ! ISTATE = -1, -2, -4, -5, -6, or -7.  On a return with -3 (illegal
13423 ! input) or -8, they will be unchanged from their existing values
13424 ! (if any), except possibly for TOLSF, LENRW, and LENIW.
13425 ! On any error return, outputs relevant to the error will be defined,
13426 ! as noted below.
13427 !
13428 ! Name    Location      Meaning
13429 !
13430 ! HU      RWORK(11) the step size in t last used (successfully).
13431 !
13432 ! HCUR    RWORK(12) the step size to be attempted on the next step.
13433 !
13434 ! TCUR    RWORK(13) the current value of the independent variable
13435 !                   which the solver has actually reached, i.e. the
13436 !                   current internal mesh point in t.  On output, TCUR
13437 !                   will always be at least as far as the argument
13438 !                   T, but may be farther (if interpolation was done).
13439 !
13440 ! TOLSF   RWORK(14) a tolerance scale factor, greater than 1.0,
13441 !                   computed when a request for too much accuracy was
13442 !                   detected (ISTATE = -3 if detected at the start of
13443 !                   the problem, ISTATE = -2 otherwise).  If ITOL is
13444 !                   left unaltered but RTOL and ATOL are uniformly
13445 !                   scaled up by a factor of TOLSF for the next call,
13446 !                   then the solver is deemed likely to succeed.
13447 !                   (The user may also ignore TOLSF and alter the
13448 !                   tolerance parameters in any other way appropriate.)
13449 !
13450 ! NST     IWORK(11) the number of steps taken for the problem so far.
13451 !
13452 ! NRE     IWORK(12) the number of residual evaluations (RES calls)
13453 !                   for the problem so far.
13454 !
13455 ! NJE     IWORK(13) the number of Jacobian evaluations (each involving
13456 !                   an evaluation of a and dr/dy) for the problem so
13457 !                   far.  This equals the number of calls to ADDA and
