13458 !                   (if MITER = 1) to JAC, and the number of matrix
13459 !                   LU decompositions.
13460 !
13461 ! NQU     IWORK(14) the method order last used (successfully).
13462 !
13463 ! NQCUR   IWORK(15) the order to be attempted on the next step.
13464 !
13465 ! IMXER   IWORK(16) the index of the component of largest magnitude in
13466 !                   the weighted local error vector ( E(i)/EWT(i) ),
13467 !                   on an error return with ISTATE = -4 or -5.
13468 !
13469 ! LENRW   IWORK(17) the length of RWORK actually required.
13470 !                   This is defined on normal returns and on an illegal
13471 !                   input return for insufficient storage.
13472 !
13473 ! LENIW   IWORK(18) the length of IWORK actually required.
13474 !                   This is defined on normal returns and on an illegal
13475 !                   input return for insufficient storage.
13476 !
13477 !
13478 ! The following two arrays are segments of the RWORK array which
13479 ! may also be of interest to the user as optional outputs.
13480 ! For each array, the table below gives its internal name,
13481 ! its base address in RWORK, and its description.
13482 !
13483 ! Name    Base Address      Description
13484 !
13485 ! YH      21             the Nordsieck history array, of size NYH by
13486 !                        (NQCUR + 1), where NYH is the initial value
13487 !                        of NEQ.  For j = 0,1,...,NQCUR, column j+1
13488 !                        of YH contains HCUR**j/factorial(j) times
13489 !                        the j-th derivative of the interpolating
13490 !                        polynomial currently representing the solution,
13491 !                        evaluated at t = TCUR.
13492 !
13493 ! ACOR     LENRW-NEQ+1   array of size NEQ used for the accumulated
13494 !                        corrections on each step, scaled on output to
13495 !                        represent the estimated local error in y on
13496 !                        the last step.  This is the vector E in the
13497 !                        description of the error control.  It is
13498 !                        defined only on a return from DLSOIBT with
13499 !                        ISTATE = 2.
13500 !
13501 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13502 ! Part 2.  Other Routines Callable.
13503 !
13504 ! The following are optional calls which the user may make to
13505 ! gain additional capabilities in conjunction with DLSOIBT.
13506 ! (The routines XSETUN and XSETF are designed to conform to the
13507 ! SLATEC error handling package.)
13508 !
13509 !     Form of Call                  Function
13510 !   CALL XSETUN(LUN)          Set the logical unit number, LUN, for
13511 !                             output of messages from DLSOIBT, if
13512 !                             the default is not desired.
13513 !                             The default value of LUN is 6.
13514 !
13515 !   CALL XSETF(MFLAG)         Set a flag to control the printing of
13516 !                             messages by DLSOIBT.
13517 !                             MFLAG = 0 means do not print. (Danger:
13518 !                             This risks losing valuable information.)
13519 !                             MFLAG = 1 means print (the default).
13520 !
13521 !                             Either of the above calls may be made at
13522 !                             any time and will take effect immediately.
13523 !
13524 !   CALL DSRCOM(RSAV,ISAV,JOB) saves and restores the contents of
13525 !                             the internal Common blocks used by
13526 !                             DLSOIBT (see Part 3 below).
13527 !                             RSAV must be a real array of length 218
13528 !                             or more, and ISAV must be an integer
13529 !                             array of length 37 or more.
13530 !                             JOB=1 means save Common into RSAV/ISAV.
13531 !                             JOB=2 means restore Common from RSAV/ISAV.
13532 !                                DSRCOM is useful if one is
13533 !                             interrupting a run and restarting
13534 !                             later, or alternating between two or
13535 !                             more problems solved with DLSOIBT.
13536 !
13537 !   CALL DINTDY(,,,,,)        Provide derivatives of y, of various
13538 !        (see below)          orders, at a specified point t, if
13539 !                             desired.  It may be called only after
13540 !                             a successful return from DLSOIBT.
13541 !
13542 ! The detailed instructions for using DINTDY are as follows.
13543 ! The form of the call is:
13544 !
13545 !   CALL DINTDY (T, K, RWORK(21), NYH, DKY, IFLAG)
13546 !
13547 ! The input parameters are:
13548 !
13549 ! T         = value of independent variable where answers are desired
13550 !             (normally the same as the t last returned by DLSOIBT).
13551 !             For valid results, T must lie between TCUR - HU and TCUR.
13552 !             (See optional outputs for TCUR and HU.)
13553 ! K         = integer order of the derivative desired.  K must satisfy
13554 !             0 .le. K .le. NQCUR, where NQCUR is the current order
13555 !             (see optional outputs).  The capability corresponding
13556 !             to K = 0, i.e. computing y(t), is already provided
13557 !             by DLSOIBT directly.  Since NQCUR .ge. 1, the first
13558 !             derivative dy/dt is always available with DINTDY.
13559 ! RWORK(21) = the base address of the history array YH.
13560 ! NYH       = column length of YH, equal to the initial value of NEQ.
13561 !
13562 ! The output parameters are:
13563 !
13564 ! DKY       = a real array of length NEQ containing the computed value
13565 !             of the K-th derivative of y(t).
13566 ! IFLAG     = integer flag, returned as 0 if K and T were legal,
13567 !             -1 if K was illegal, and -2 if T was illegal.
13568 !             On an error return, a message is also written.
13569 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13570 ! Part 3.  Common Blocks.
13571 !
13572 ! If DLSOIBT is to be used in an overlay situation, the user
13573 ! must declare, in the primary overlay, the variables in:
13574 !   (1) the call sequence to DLSOIBT, and
13575 !   (2) the internal Common block
13576 !         /DLS001/  of length  255  (218 double precision words
13577 !                      followed by 37 integer words),
13578 !
13579 ! If DLSOIBT is used on a system in which the contents of internal
13580 ! Common blocks are not preserved between calls, the user should
13581 ! declare the above Common block in the calling program to insure
13582 ! that their contents are preserved.
13583 !
13584 ! If the solution of a given problem by DLSOIBT is to be interrupted
13585 ! and then later continued, such as when restarting an interrupted run
13586 ! or alternating between two or more problems, the user should save,
13587 ! following the return from the last DLSOIBT call prior to the
13588 ! interruption, the contents of the call sequence variables and the
13589 ! internal Common blocks, and later restore these values before the
13590 ! next DLSOIBT call for that problem.  To save and restore the Common
13591 ! blocks, use Subroutine DSRCOM (see Part 2 above).
13592 !
13593 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13594 ! Part 4.  Optionally Replaceable Solver Routines.
13595 !
13596 ! Below are descriptions of two routines in the DLSOIBT package which
13597 ! relate to the measurement of errors.  Either routine can be
13598 ! replaced by a user-supplied version, if desired.  However, since such
13599 ! a replacement may have a major impact on performance, it should be
13600 ! done only when absolutely necessary, and only with great caution.
13601 ! (Note: The means by which the package version of a routine is
13602 ! superseded by the user's version may be system-dependent.)
13603 !
13604 ! (a) DEWSET.
13605 ! The following subroutine is called just before each internal
13606 ! integration step, and sets the array of error weights, EWT, as
13607 ! described under ITOL/RTOL/ATOL above:
13608 !     SUBROUTINE DEWSET (NEQ, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, YCUR, EWT)
13609 ! where NEQ, ITOL, RTOL, and ATOL are as in the DLSOIBT call sequence,
13610 ! YCUR contains the current dependent variable vector, and
13611 ! EWT is the array of weights set by DEWSET.
13612 !
13613 ! If the user supplies this subroutine, it must return in EWT(i)
13614 ! (i = 1,...,NEQ) a positive quantity suitable for comparing errors
13615 ! in y(i) to.  The EWT array returned by DEWSET is passed to the DVNORM
13616 ! routine (see below), and also used by DLSOIBT in the computation
13617 ! of the optional output IMXER, the diagonal Jacobian approximation,
13618 ! and the increments for difference quotient Jacobians.
13619 !
13620 ! In the user-supplied version of DEWSET, it may be desirable to use
13621 ! the current values of derivatives of y.  Derivatives up to order NQ
13622 ! are available from the history array YH, described above under
13623 ! optional outputs.  In DEWSET, YH is identical to the YCUR array,
13624 ! extended to NQ + 1 columns with a column length of NYH and scale
13625 ! factors of H**j/factorial(j).  On the first call for the problem,
13626 ! given by NST = 0, NQ is 1 and H is temporarily set to 1.0.
13627 ! NYH is the initial value of NEQ.  The quantities NQ, H, and NST
13628 ! can be obtained by including in DEWSET the statements:
13629 !     DOUBLE PRECISION RLS
13630 !     COMMON /DLS001/ RLS(218),ILS(37)
13631 !     NQ = ILS(33)
13632 !     NST = ILS(34)
13633 !     H = RLS(212)
13634 ! Thus, for example, the current value of dy/dt can be obtained as
13635 ! YCUR(NYH+i)/H  (i=1,...,NEQ)  (and the division by H is
13636 ! unnecessary when NST = 0).
13637 !
13638 ! (b) DVNORM.
13639 ! The following is a real function routine which computes the weighted
13640 ! root-mean-square norm of a vector v:
13641 !     D = DVNORM (N, V, W)
13642 ! where:
13643 !   N = the length of the vector,
13644 !   V = real array of length N containing the vector,
13645 !   W = real array of length N containing weights,
13646 !   D = SQRT( (1/N) * sum(V(i)*W(i))**2 ).
13647 ! DVNORM is called with N = NEQ and with W(i) = 1.0/EWT(i), where
13648 ! EWT is as set by Subroutine DEWSET.
13649 !
13650 ! If the user supplies this function, it should return a non-negative
13651 ! value of DVNORM suitable for use in the error control in DLSOIBT.
13652 ! None of the arguments should be altered by DVNORM.
13653 ! For example, a user-supplied DVNORM routine might:
13654 !   -substitute a max-norm of (V(i)*W(i)) for the RMS-norm, or
13655 !   -ignore some components of V in the norm, with the effect of
13656 !    suppressing the error control on those components of y.
13657 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13658 !
13659 !***REVISION HISTORY  (YYYYMMDD)
13660 ! 19840625  DATE WRITTEN
13661 ! 19870330  Major update: corrected comments throughout;
13662 !           removed TRET from Common; rewrote EWSET with 4 loops;
13663 !           fixed t test in INTDY; added Cray directives in STODI;
13664 !           in STODI, fixed DELP init. and logic around PJAC call;
13665 !           combined routines to save/restore Common;
13666 !           passed LEVEL = 0 in error message calls (except run abort).
13667 ! 20010425  Major update: convert source lines to upper case;
13668 !           added *DECK lines; changed from 1 to * in dummy dimensions;
13669 !           changed names R1MACH/D1MACH to RUMACH/DUMACH;
13670 !           renamed routines for uniqueness across single/double prec.;
13671 !           converted intrinsic names to generic form;
13672 !           removed ILLIN and NTREP (data loaded) from Common;
13673 !           removed all 'own' variables from Common;
13674 !           changed error messages to quoted strings;
13675 !           replaced XERRWV/XERRWD with 1993 revised version;
13676 !           converted prologues, comments, error messages to mixed case;
13677 !           converted arithmetic IF statements to logical IF statements;
13678 !           numerous corrections to prologues and internal comments.
13679 ! 20010507  Converted single precision source to double precision.
13680 ! 20020502  Corrected declarations in descriptions of user routines.
13681 ! 20031105  Restored 'own' variables to Common block, to enable
13682 !           interrupt/restart feature.
13683 ! 20031112  Added SAVE statements for data-loaded constants.
13684 ! 20031117  Changed internal names NRE, LSAVR to NFE, LSAVF resp.
13685 !
13686 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13687 ! Other routines in the DLSOIBT package.
13688 !
13689 ! In addition to Subroutine DLSOIBT, the DLSOIBT package includes the
13690 ! following subroutines and function routines:
13691 !  DAIGBT   computes the initial value of the vector
13692 !             dy/dt = A-inverse * g
13693 !  DINTDY   computes an interpolated value of the y vector at t = TOUT.
13694 !  DSTODI   is the core integrator, which does one step of the
13695 !           integration and the associated error control.
13696 !  DCFODE   sets all method coefficients and test constants.
13697 !  DEWSET   sets the error weight vector EWT before each step.
13698 !  DVNORM   computes the weighted RMS-norm of a vector.
13699 !  DSRCOM   is a user-callable routine to save and restore
13700 !           the contents of the internal Common blocks.
13701 !  DPJIBT   computes and preprocesses the Jacobian matrix
13702 !           and the Newton iteration matrix P.
13703 !  DSLSBT   manages solution of linear system in chord iteration.
13704 !  DDECBT and DSOLBT   are routines for solving block-tridiagonal
13705 !           systems of linear algebraic equations.
13706 !  DGEFA and DGESL   are routines from LINPACK for solving full
13707 !           systems of linear algebraic equations.
13708 !  DDOT     is one of the basic linear algebra modules (BLAS).
13709 !  DUMACH   computes the unit roundoff in a machine-independent manner.
13710 !  XERRWD, XSETUN, XSETF, IXSAV, and IUMACH  handle the printing of all
13711 !           error messages and warnings.  XERRWD is machine-dependent.
13712 ! Note:  DVNORM, DDOT, DUMACH, IXSAV, and IUMACH are function routines.
13713 ! All the others are subroutines.
13714 !
13715 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13716 EXTERNAL DPJIBT, DSLSBT
13717 DOUBLE PRECISION DUMACH, DVNORM
13718 INTEGER INIT, MXSTEP, MXHNIL, NHNIL, NSLAST, NYH, IOWNS, ICF, IERPJ, IERSL, JCUR, JSTART, KFLAG, L, LYH, LEWT, LACOR, LSAVF
13719 INTEGER LWM, LIWM, METH, MITER, MAXORD, MAXCOR, MSBP, MXNCF, N, NQ, NST, NFE, NJE, NQU
13720 INTEGER I, I1, I2, IER, IFLAG, IMXER, IRES, KGO, LENIW, LENRW, LENWM, LP, LYD0, MB, MORD, MXHNL0, MXSTP0, NB
13721 DOUBLE PRECISION ROWNS, CCMAX, EL0, H, HMIN, HMXI, HU, RC, TN, UROUND
13722 DOUBLE PRECISION ATOLI, AYI, BIG, EWTI, H0, HMAX, HMX, RH, RTOLI, TCRIT, TDIST, TNEXT, TOL, TOLSF, TP, SIZE, SUM, W0
13723 DIMENSION MORD(2)
13724 LOGICAL IHIT
13725 character(len=60) MSG
13726 SAVE MORD, MXSTP0, MXHNL0
13727 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13728 ! The following internal Common block contains
13729 ! (a) variables which are local to any subroutine but whose values must
13730 !     be preserved between calls to the routine ("own" variables), and
13731 ! (b) variables which are communicated between subroutines.
13732 ! The block DLS001 is declared in subroutines DLSOIBT, DINTDY, DSTODI,
13733 ! DPJIBT, and DSLSBT.
13734 ! Groups of variables are replaced by dummy arrays in the Common
13735 ! declarations in routines where those variables are not used.
13736 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13737 COMMON /DLS001/ ROWNS(209), CCMAX, EL0, H, HMIN, HMXI, HU, RC, TN, UROUND, INIT, MXSTEP, MXHNIL, NHNIL, NSLAST, NYH, &
13738 IOWNS(6), ICF, IERPJ, IERSL, JCUR, JSTART, KFLAG, L, LYH, LEWT, LACOR, LSAVF, LWM, LIWM, METH, MITER, MAXORD, MAXCOR, MSBP, &
13739 MXNCF, N, NQ, NST, NFE, NJE, NQU
13740 !
13741 DATA MORD(1),MORD(2)/12,5/, MXSTP0/500/, MXHNL0/10/
13742 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13743 ! Block A.
13744 ! This code block is executed on every call.
13745 ! It tests ISTATE and ITASK for legality and branches appropriately.
13746 ! If ISTATE .gt. 1 but the flag INIT shows that initialization has
13747 ! not yet been done, an error return occurs.
13748 ! If ISTATE = 0 or 1 and TOUT = T, return immediately.
13749 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13750 IF (ISTATE .LT. 0 .OR. ISTATE .GT. 3) GOTO 601
13751 IF (ITASK .LT. 1 .OR. ITASK .GT. 5) GOTO 602
13752 IF (ISTATE .LE. 1) GOTO 10
13753 IF (INIT .EQ. 0) GOTO 603
13754 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 2) GOTO 200
13755 GOTO 20
13756 10   INIT = 0
13757 IF (TOUT .EQ. T) RETURN
13758 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13759 ! Block B.
13760 ! The next code block is executed for the initial call (ISTATE = 0 or 1)
13761 ! or for a continuation call with parameter changes (ISTATE = 3).
13762 ! It contains checking of all inputs and various initializations.
13763 !
13764 ! First check legality of the non-optional inputs NEQ, ITOL, IOPT,
13765 ! MF, MB, and NB.
13766 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13767 20   IF (NEQ(1) .LE. 0) GOTO 604
13768 IF (ISTATE .LE. 1) GOTO 25
13769 IF (NEQ(1) .GT. N) GOTO 605
13770 25   N = NEQ(1)
13771 IF (ITOL .LT. 1 .OR. ITOL .GT. 4) GOTO 606
13772 IF (IOPT .LT. 0 .OR. IOPT .GT. 1) GOTO 607
13773 METH = MF/10
13774 MITER = MF - 10*METH
13775 IF (METH .LT. 1 .OR. METH .GT. 2) GOTO 608
13776 IF (MITER .LT. 1 .OR. MITER .GT. 2) GOTO 608
13777 MB = IWORK(1)
13778 NB = IWORK(2)
13779 IF (MB .LT. 1 .OR. MB .GT. N) GOTO 609
13780 IF (NB .LT. 4) GOTO 610
13781 IF (MB*NB .NE. N) GOTO 609
13782 ! Next process and check the optional inputs. --------------------------
13783 IF (IOPT .EQ. 1) GOTO 40
13784 MAXORD = MORD(METH)
13785 MXSTEP = MXSTP0
13786 MXHNIL = MXHNL0
13787 IF (ISTATE .LE. 1) H0 = 0.0D0
13788 HMXI = 0.0D0
13789 HMIN = 0.0D0
13790 GOTO 60
13791 40   MAXORD = IWORK(5)
13792 IF (MAXORD .LT. 0) GOTO 611
13793 IF (MAXORD .EQ. 0) MAXORD = 100
13794 MAXORD = MIN(MAXORD,MORD(METH))
13795 MXSTEP = IWORK(6)
13796 IF (MXSTEP .LT. 0) GOTO 612
13797 IF (MXSTEP .EQ. 0) MXSTEP = MXSTP0
13798 MXHNIL = IWORK(7)
13799 IF (MXHNIL .LT. 0) GOTO 613
13800 IF (MXHNIL .EQ. 0) MXHNIL = MXHNL0
13801 IF (ISTATE .GT. 1) GOTO 50
13802 H0 = RWORK(5)
13803 IF ((TOUT - T)*H0 .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 614
13804 50   HMAX = RWORK(6)
13805 IF (HMAX .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 615
13806 HMXI = 0.0D0
13807 IF (HMAX .GT. 0.0D0) HMXI = 1.0D0/HMAX
13808 HMIN = RWORK(7)
13809 IF (HMIN .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 616
13810 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13811 ! Set work array pointers and check lengths LRW and LIW.
13812 ! Pointers to segments of RWORK and IWORK are named by prefixing L to
13813 ! the name of the segment.  E.g., the segment YH starts at RWORK(LYH).
13814 ! Segments of RWORK (in order) are denoted YH, WM, EWT, SAVR, ACOR.
13815 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13816 60   LYH = 21
13817 IF (ISTATE .LE. 1) NYH = N
13818 LWM = LYH + (MAXORD + 1)*NYH
13819 LENWM = 3*MB*MB*NB + 2
13820 LEWT = LWM + LENWM
13821 LSAVF = LEWT + N
13822 LACOR = LSAVF + N
13823 LENRW = LACOR + N - 1
13824 IWORK(17) = LENRW
13825 LIWM = 1
13826 LENIW = 20 + N
13827 IWORK(18) = LENIW
13828 IF (LENRW .GT. LRW) GOTO 617
13829 IF (LENIW .GT. LIW) GOTO 618
13830 ! Check RTOL and ATOL for legality. ------------------------------------
13831 RTOLI = RTOL(1)
13832 ATOLI = ATOL(1)
13833 DO 70 I = 1,N
13834 IF (ITOL .GE. 3) RTOLI = RTOL(I)
13835 IF (ITOL .EQ. 2 .OR. ITOL .EQ. 4) ATOLI = ATOL(I)
13836 IF (RTOLI .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 619
13837 IF (ATOLI .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 620
13838 70     CONTINUE
13839 IF (ISTATE .LE. 1) GOTO 100
13840 ! If ISTATE = 3, set flag to signal parameter changes to DSTODI. -------
13841 JSTART = -1
13842 IF (NQ .LE. MAXORD) GOTO 90
13843 ! MAXORD was reduced below NQ.  Copy YH(*,MAXORD+2) into YDOTI.---------
13844 DO 80 I = 1,N
13845 80     YDOTI(I) = RWORK(I+LWM-1)
13846 ! Reload WM(1) = RWORK(lWM), since lWM may have changed. ---------------
13847 90   RWORK(LWM) = SQRT(UROUND)
13848 IF (N .EQ. NYH) GOTO 200
13849 ! NEQ was reduced.  Zero part of YH to avoid undefined references. -----
13850 I1 = LYH + L*NYH
13851 I2 = LYH + (MAXORD + 1)*NYH - 1
13852 IF (I1 .GT. I2) GOTO 200
13853 DO 95 I = I1,I2
13854 95     RWORK(I) = 0.0D0
13855 GOTO 200
13856 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13857 ! Block C.
13858 ! The next block is for the initial call only (ISTATE = 0 or 1).
13859 ! It contains all remaining initializations, the call to DAIGBT
13860 ! (if ISTATE = 1), and the calculation of the initial step size.
13861 ! The error weights in EWT are inverted after being loaded.
13862 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13863 100  UROUND = DUMACH()
13864 TN = T
13865 IF (ITASK .NE. 4 .AND. ITASK .NE. 5) GOTO 105
13866 TCRIT = RWORK(1)
13867 IF ((TCRIT - TOUT)*(TOUT - T) .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 625
13868 IF (H0 .NE. 0.0D0 .AND. (T + H0 - TCRIT)*H0 .GT. 0.0D0) H0 = TCRIT - T
13869 105  JSTART = 0
13870 RWORK(LWM) = SQRT(UROUND)
13871 NHNIL = 0
13872 NST = 0
13873 NFE = 0
13874 NJE = 0
13875 NSLAST = 0
13876 HU = 0.0D0
13877 NQU = 0
13878 CCMAX = 0.3D0
13879 MAXCOR = 3
13880 MSBP = 20
13881 MXNCF = 10
13882 ! Compute initial dy/dt, if necessary, and load it and initial Y into YH
13883 LYD0 = LYH + NYH
13884 LP = LWM + 1
13885 IF ( ISTATE .EQ. 1 )  GOTO 120
13886 ! DLSOIBT must compute initial dy/dt (LYD0 points to YH(*,2)). ---------
13887 CALL DAIGBT( RES, ADDA, NEQ, T, Y, RWORK(LYD0), MB, NB, RWORK(LP), IWORK(21), IER )
13888 NFE = NFE + 1
13889 IF (IER .LT. 0) GOTO 560
13890 IF (IER .GT. 0) GOTO 565
13891 DO 115  I = 1,N
13892 115       RWORK(I+LYH-1) = Y(I)
13893 GOTO 130
13894 ! Initial dy/dt was supplied.  Load into YH (LYD0 points to YH(*,2).). -
13895 120    DO 125  I = 1,N
13896 RWORK(I+LYH-1) = Y(I)
13897 125       RWORK(I+LYD0-1) = YDOTI(I)
13898 ! Load and invert the EWT array.  (H is temporarily set to 1.0.) -------
13899 130 CONTINUE
13900 NQ = 1
13901 H = 1.0D0
13902 CALL DEWSET (N, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LEWT))
13903 DO 135 I = 1,N
13904 IF (RWORK(I+LEWT-1) .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 621
13905 135    RWORK(I+LEWT-1) = 1.0D0/RWORK(I+LEWT-1)
13906 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13907 ! The coding below computes the step size, H0, to be attempted on the
13908 ! first step, unless the user has supplied a value for this.
13909 ! First check that TOUT - T differs significantly from zero.
13910 ! A scalar tolerance quantity TOL is computed, as MAX(RTOL(i))
13911 ! if this is positive, or MAX(ATOL(i)/ABS(Y(i))) otherwise, adjusted
13912 ! so as to be between 100*UROUND and 1.0E-3.
13913 ! Then the computed value H0 is given by..
13914 !                                      NEQ
13915 !   H0**2 = TOL / ( w0**-2 + (1/NEQ) * Sum ( YDOT(i)/ywt(i) )**2  )
13916 !                                       1
13917 ! where   w0      = MAX ( ABS(T), ABS(TOUT) ),
13918 !         YDOT(i) = i-th component of initial value of dy/dt,
13919 !         ywt(i)  = EWT(i)/TOL  (a weight for y(i)).
13920 ! The sign of H0 is inferred from the initial values of TOUT and T.
13921 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13922 IF (H0 .NE. 0.0D0) GOTO 180
13923 TDIST = ABS(TOUT - T)
13924 W0 = MAX(ABS(T),ABS(TOUT))
13925 IF (TDIST .LT. 2.0D0*UROUND*W0) GOTO 622
13926 TOL = RTOL(1)
13927 IF (ITOL .LE. 2) GOTO 145
13928 DO 140 I = 1,N
13929 140    TOL = MAX(TOL,RTOL(I))
13930 145  IF (TOL .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 160
13931 ATOLI = ATOL(1)
13932 DO 150 I = 1,N
13933 IF (ITOL .EQ. 2 .OR. ITOL .EQ. 4) ATOLI = ATOL(I)
13934 AYI = ABS(Y(I))
13935 IF (AYI .NE. 0.0D0) TOL = MAX(TOL,ATOLI/AYI)
13936 150    CONTINUE
13937 160  TOL = MAX(TOL,100.0D0*UROUND)
13938 TOL = MIN(TOL,0.001D0)
13939 SUM = DVNORM (N, RWORK(LYD0), RWORK(LEWT))
13940 SUM = 1.0D0/(TOL*W0*W0) + TOL*SUM**2
13941 H0 = 1.0D0/SQRT(SUM)
13942 H0 = MIN(H0,TDIST)
13943 H0 = SIGN(H0,TOUT-T)
13944 ! Adjust H0 if necessary to meet HMAX bound. ---------------------------
13945 180  RH = ABS(H0)*HMXI
13946 IF (RH .GT. 1.0D0) H0 = H0/RH
13947 ! Load H with H0 and scale YH(*,2) by H0. ------------------------------
13948 H = H0
13949 DO 190 I = 1,N
13950 190    RWORK(I+LYD0-1) = H0*RWORK(I+LYD0-1)
13951 GOTO 270
13952 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13953 ! Block D.
13954 ! The next code block is for continuation calls only (ISTATE = 2 or 3)
13955 ! and is to check stop conditions before taking a step.
13956 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13957 200  NSLAST = NST
13958 GOTO (210, 250, 220, 230, 240), ITASK
13959 210  IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
13960 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
13961 IF (IFLAG .NE. 0) GOTO 627
13962 T = TOUT
13963 GOTO 420
13964 220  TP = TN - HU*(1.0D0 + 100.0D0*UROUND)
13965 IF ((TP - TOUT)*H .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 623
13966 IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
13967 GOTO 400
13968 230  TCRIT = RWORK(1)
13969 IF ((TN - TCRIT)*H .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 624
13970 IF ((TCRIT - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 625
13971 IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 245
13972 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
13973 IF (IFLAG .NE. 0) GOTO 627
13974 T = TOUT
13975 GOTO 420
13976 240  TCRIT = RWORK(1)
13977 IF ((TN - TCRIT)*H .GT. 0.0D0) GOTO 624
13978 245  HMX = ABS(TN) + ABS(H)
13979 IHIT = ABS(TN - TCRIT) .LE. 100.0D0*UROUND*HMX
13980 IF (IHIT) GOTO 400
13981 TNEXT = TN + H*(1.0D0 + 4.0D0*UROUND)
13982 IF ((TNEXT - TCRIT)*H .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
13983 H = (TCRIT - TN)*(1.0D0 - 4.0D0*UROUND)
13984 IF (ISTATE .EQ. 2) JSTART = -2
13985 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13986 ! Block E.
13987 ! The next block is normally executed for all calls and contains
13988 ! the call to the one-step core integrator DSTODI.
13989 !
13990 ! This is a looping point for the integration steps.
13991 !
13992 ! First check for too many steps being taken, update EWT (if not at
13993 ! start of problem), check for too much accuracy being requested, and
13994 ! check for H below the roundoff level in T.
13995 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
13996 250  CONTINUE
13997 IF ((NST-NSLAST) .GE. MXSTEP) GOTO 500
13998 CALL DEWSET (N, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LEWT))
13999 DO 260 I = 1,N
14000 IF (RWORK(I+LEWT-1) .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 510
14001 260    RWORK(I+LEWT-1) = 1.0D0/RWORK(I+LEWT-1)
14002 270  TOLSF = UROUND*DVNORM (N, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LEWT))
14003 IF (TOLSF .LE. 1.0D0) GOTO 280
14004 TOLSF = TOLSF*2.0D0
14005 IF (NST .EQ. 0) GOTO 626
14006 GOTO 520
14007 280  IF ((TN + H) .NE. TN) GOTO 290
14008 NHNIL = NHNIL + 1
14009 IF (NHNIL .GT. MXHNIL) GOTO 290
14010 MSG = 'DLSOIBT- Warning..Internal T (=R1) and H (=R2) are'
14011 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 101, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14012 MSG='      such that in the machine, T + H = T on the next step  '
14013 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 101, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14014 MSG = '     (H = step size). Solver will continue anyway.'
14015 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 101, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, H)
14016 IF (NHNIL .LT. MXHNIL) GOTO 290
14017 MSG = 'DLSOIBT- Above warning has been issued I1 times.  '
14018 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 102, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14019 MSG = '     It will not be issued again for this problem.'
14020 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 102, 0, 1, MXHNIL, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14021 290  CONTINUE
14022 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
14023 !     CALL DSTODI(NEQ,Y,YH,NYH,YH1,EWT,SAVF,SAVR,ACOR,WM,IWM,RES,
14024 !                 ADDA,JAC,DPJIBT,DSLSBT)
14025 ! Note: SAVF in DSTODI occupies the same space as YDOTI in DLSOIBT.
14026 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
14027 CALL DSTODI(NEQ, Y, RWORK(LYH), NYH, RWORK(LYH), RWORK(LEWT), YDOTI, RWORK(LSAVF), RWORK(LACOR), RWORK(LWM), IWORK(LIWM), &
14028 RES, ADDA, JAC, DPJIBT, DSLSBT)
14029 KGO = 1 - KFLAG
14030 GOTO (300, 530, 540, 400, 550), KGO
14031 !
14032 ! KGO = 1:success; 2:error test failure; 3:convergence failure;
14033 !       4:RES ordered return; 5:RES returned error.
14034 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
14035 ! Block F.
14036 ! The following block handles the case of a successful return from the
14037 ! core integrator (KFLAG = 0).  Test for stop conditions.
14038 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
14039 300  INIT = 1
14040 GOTO (310, 400, 330, 340, 350), ITASK
14041 ! ITASK = 1.  If TOUT has been reached, interpolate. -------------------
14042 310  IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
14043 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
14044 T = TOUT
14045 GOTO 420
14046 ! ITASK = 3.  Jump to exit if TOUT was reached. ------------------------
14047 330  IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .GE. 0.0D0) GOTO 400
14048 GOTO 250
14049 ! ITASK = 4.  See if TOUT or TCRIT was reached.  Adjust H if necessary.
14050 340  IF ((TN - TOUT)*H .LT. 0.0D0) GOTO 345
14051 CALL DINTDY (TOUT, 0, RWORK(LYH), NYH, Y, IFLAG)
14052 T = TOUT
14053 GOTO 420
14054 345  HMX = ABS(TN) + ABS(H)
14055 IHIT = ABS(TN - TCRIT) .LE. 100.0D0*UROUND*HMX
14056 IF (IHIT) GOTO 400
14057 TNEXT = TN + H*(1.0D0 + 4.0D0*UROUND)
14058 IF ((TNEXT - TCRIT)*H .LE. 0.0D0) GOTO 250
14059 H = (TCRIT - TN)*(1.0D0 - 4.0D0*UROUND)
14060 JSTART = -2
14061 GOTO 250
14062 ! ITASK = 5.  see if TCRIT was reached and jump to exit. ---------------
14063 350  HMX = ABS(TN) + ABS(H)
14064 IHIT = ABS(TN - TCRIT) .LE. 100.0D0*UROUND*HMX
14065 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
14066 ! Block G.
14067 ! The following block handles all successful returns from DLSOIBT.
14068 ! If ITASK .ne. 1, Y is loaded from YH and T is set accordingly.
14069 ! ISTATE is set to 2, and the optional outputs are loaded into the
14070 ! work arrays before returning.
14071 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
14072 400  DO 410 I = 1,N
14073 410    Y(I) = RWORK(I+LYH-1)
14074 T = TN
14075 IF (ITASK .NE. 4 .AND. ITASK .NE. 5) GOTO 420
14076 IF (IHIT) T = TCRIT
14077 420 ISTATE = 2
14078 IF ( KFLAG .EQ. -3 )  ISTATE = 3
14079 RWORK(11) = HU
14080 RWORK(12) = H
14081 RWORK(13) = TN
14082 IWORK(11) = NST
14083 IWORK(12) = NFE
14084 IWORK(13) = NJE
14085 IWORK(14) = NQU
14086 IWORK(15) = NQ
14087 RETURN
14088 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
14089 ! Block H.
14090 ! The following block handles all unsuccessful returns other than
14091 ! those for illegal input.  First the error message routine is called.
14092 ! If there was an error test or convergence test failure, IMXER is set.
14093 ! Then Y is loaded from YH and T is set to TN.
14094 ! The optional outputs are loaded into the work arrays before returning.
14095 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
14096 ! The maximum number of steps was taken before reaching TOUT. ----------
14097 500  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- At current T (=R1), MXSTEP (=I1) steps   '
14098 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 201, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14099 MSG = '      taken on this call before reaching TOUT     '
14100 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 201, 0, 1, MXSTEP, 0, 1, TN, 0.0D0)
14101 ISTATE = -1
14102 GOTO 580
14103 ! EWT(i) .le. 0.0 for some i (not at start of problem). ----------------
14104 510  EWTI = RWORK(LEWT+I-1)
14105 MSG = 'DLSOIBT- At T (=R1), EWT(I1) has become R2 .le. 0.'
14106 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 202, 0, 1, I, 0, 2, TN, EWTI)
14107 ISTATE = -6
14108 GOTO 590
14109 ! Too much accuracy requested for machine precision. -------------------
14110 520  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- At T (=R1), too much accuracy requested  '
14111 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 203, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14112 MSG = '      for precision of machine..  See TOLSF (=R2) '
14113 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 203, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, TOLSF)
14114 RWORK(14) = TOLSF
14115 ISTATE = -2
14116 GOTO 590
14117 ! KFLAG = -1.  Error test failed repeatedly or with ABS(H) = HMIN. -----
14118 530  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- At T (=R1) and step size H (=R2), the    '
14119 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 204, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14120 MSG = 'error test failed repeatedly or with ABS(H) = HMIN'
14121 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 204, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, H)
14122 ISTATE = -4
14123 GOTO 570
14124 ! KFLAG = -2.  Convergence failed repeatedly or with ABS(H) = HMIN. ----
14125 540  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- At T (=R1) and step size H (=R2), the    '
14126 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 205, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14127 MSG = '      corrector convergence failed repeatedly     '
14128 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 205, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14129 MSG = '      or with ABS(H) = HMIN   '
14130 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 205, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TN, H)
14131 ISTATE = -5
14132 GOTO 570
14133 ! IRES = 3 returned by RES, despite retries by DSTODI.------------------
14134 550  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- At T (=R1) residual routine returned     '
14135 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 206, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14136 MSG = '      error IRES = 3 repeatedly.        '
14137 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 206, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, TN, 0.0D0)
14138 ISTATE = -7
14139 GOTO 590
14140 ! DAIGBT failed because a diagonal block of A matrix was singular. -----
14141 560  IER = -IER
14142 MSG='DLSOIBT- Attempt to initialize dy/dt failed:  Matrix A has a'
14143 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 207, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14144 MSG = '      singular diagonal block, block no. = (I1)   '
14145 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 207, 0, 1, IER, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14146 ISTATE = -8
14147 RETURN
14148 ! DAIGBT failed because RES set IRES to 2 or 3. ------------------------
14149 565  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- Attempt to initialize dy/dt failed       '
14150 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 208, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14151 MSG = '      because residual routine set its error flag '
14152 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 208, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14153 MSG = '      to IRES = (I1)'
14154 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 20, 208, 0, 1, IER, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14155 ISTATE = -8
14156 RETURN
14157 ! Compute IMXER if relevant. -------------------------------------------
14158 570  BIG = 0.0D0
14159 IMXER = 1
14160 DO 575 I = 1,N
14161 SIZE = ABS(RWORK(I+LACOR-1)*RWORK(I+LEWT-1))
14162 IF (BIG .GE. SIZE) GOTO 575
14163 BIG = SIZE
14164 IMXER = I
14165 575    CONTINUE
14166 IWORK(16) = IMXER
14167 ! Compute residual if relevant. ----------------------------------------
14168 580  LYD0 = LYH + NYH
14169 DO 585 I = 1,N
14170 RWORK(I+LSAVF-1) = RWORK(I+LYD0-1)/H
14171 585     Y(I) = RWORK(I+LYH-1)
14172 IRES = 1
14173 CALL RES (NEQ, TN, Y, RWORK(LSAVF), YDOTI, IRES)
14174 NFE = NFE + 1
14175 IF (IRES .LE. 1)  GOTO 595
14176 MSG = 'DLSOIBT- Residual routine set its flag IRES       '
14177 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 210, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14178 MSG = '      to (I1) when called for final output.       '
14179 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 210, 0, 1, IRES, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14180 GOTO 595
14181 ! Set Y vector, T, and optional outputs. -------------------------------
14182 590  DO 592 I = 1,N
14183 592    Y(I) = RWORK(I+LYH-1)
14184 595  T = TN
14185 RWORK(11) = HU
14186 RWORK(12) = H
14187 RWORK(13) = TN
14188 IWORK(11) = NST
14189 IWORK(12) = NFE
14190 IWORK(13) = NJE
14191 IWORK(14) = NQU
14192 IWORK(15) = NQ
14193 RETURN
14194 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
14195 ! Block I.
14196 ! The following block handles all error returns due to illegal input
14197 ! (ISTATE = -3), as detected before calling the core integrator.
14198 ! First the error message routine is called.  If the illegal input
14199 ! is a negative ISTATE, the run is aborted (apparent infinite loop).
14200 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
14201 601  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- ISTATE (=I1) illegal.'
14202 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 1, 0, 1, ISTATE, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14203 IF (ISTATE .LT. 0) GOTO 800
14204 GOTO 700
14205 602  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- ITASK (=I1) illegal. '
14206 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 2, 0, 1, ITASK, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14207 GOTO 700
14208 603  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- ISTATE.gt.1 but DLSOIBT not initialized. '
14209 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 3, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14210 GOTO 700
14211 604  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- NEQ (=I1) .lt. 1     '
14212 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 4, 0, 1, NEQ(1), 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14213 GOTO 700
14214 605  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- ISTATE = 3 and NEQ increased (I1 to I2). '
14215 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 5, 0, 2, N, NEQ(1), 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14216 GOTO 700
14217 606  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- ITOL (=I1) illegal.  '
14218 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 6, 0, 1, ITOL, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14219 GOTO 700
14220 607  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- IOPT (=I1) illegal.  '
14221 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 7, 0, 1, IOPT, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14222 GOTO 700
14223 608  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- MF (=I1) illegal.    '
14224 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 8, 0, 1, MF, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14225 GOTO 700
14226 609  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- MB (=I1) or NB (=I2) illegal.  '
14227 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 9, 0, 2, MB, NB, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14228 GOTO 700
14229 610  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- NB (=I1) .lt. 4 illegal.       '
14230 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 10, 0, 1, NB, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14231 GOTO 700
14232 611  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- MAXORD (=I1) .lt. 0  '
14233 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 11, 0, 1, MAXORD, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14234 GOTO 700
14235 612  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- MXSTEP (=I1) .lt. 0  '
14236 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 12, 0, 1, MXSTEP, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14237 GOTO 700
14238 613  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- MXHNIL (=I1) .lt. 0  '
14239 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 13, 0, 1, MXHNIL, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14240 GOTO 700
14241 614  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- TOUT (=R1) behind T (=R2)      '
14242 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 14, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TOUT, T)
14243 MSG = '      Integration direction is given by H0 (=R1)  '
14244 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 14, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, H0, 0.0D0)
14245 GOTO 700
14246 615  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- HMAX (=R1) .lt. 0.0  '
14247 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 15, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, HMAX, 0.0D0)
14248 GOTO 700
14249 616  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- HMIN (=R1) .lt. 0.0  '
14250 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 30, 16, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, HMIN, 0.0D0)
14251 GOTO 700
14252 617  MSG='DLSOIBT- RWORK length needed, LENRW (=I1), exceeds LRW (=I2)'
14253 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 17, 0, 2, LENRW, LRW, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14254 GOTO 700
14255 618  MSG='DLSOIBT- IWORK length needed, LENIW (=I1), exceeds LIW (=I2)'
14256 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 18, 0, 2, LENIW, LIW, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14257 GOTO 700
14258 619  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- RTOL(=I1) is R1 .lt. 0.0       '
14259 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 19, 0, 1, I, 0, 1, RTOLI, 0.0D0)
14260 GOTO 700
14261 620  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- ATOL(=I1) is R1 .lt. 0.0       '
14262 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 20, 0, 1, I, 0, 1, ATOLI, 0.0D0)
14263 GOTO 700
14264 621  EWTI = RWORK(LEWT+I-1)
14265 MSG = 'DLSOIBT- EWT(I1) is R1 .le. 0.0         '
14266 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 40, 21, 0, 1, I, 0, 1, EWTI, 0.0D0)
14267 GOTO 700
14268 622  MSG='DLSOIBT- TOUT(=R1) too close to T(=R2) to start integration.'
14269 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 22, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TOUT, T)
14270 GOTO 700
14271 623  MSG='DLSOIBT- ITASK = I1 and TOUT (=R1) behind TCUR - HU (= R2)  '
14272 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 23, 0, 1, ITASK, 0, 2, TOUT, TP)
14273 GOTO 700
14274 624  MSG='DLSOIBT- ITASK = 4 or 5 and TCRIT (=R1) behind TCUR (=R2)   '
14275 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 24, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TCRIT, TN)
14276 GOTO 700
14277 625  MSG='DLSOIBT- ITASK = 4 or 5 and TCRIT (=R1) behind TOUT (=R2)   '
14278 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 25, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, TCRIT, TOUT)
14279 GOTO 700
14280 626  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- At start of problem, too much accuracy   '
14281 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 26, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14282 MSG='      requested for precision of machine..  See TOLSF (=R1) '
14283 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 60, 26, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, TOLSF, 0.0D0)
14284 RWORK(14) = TOLSF
14285 GOTO 700
14286 627  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- Trouble in DINTDY.  ITASK = I1, TOUT = R1'
14287 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 27, 0, 1, ITASK, 0, 1, TOUT, 0.0D0)
14288 !
14289 700  ISTATE = -3
14290 RETURN
14291 !
14292 800  MSG = 'DLSOIBT- Run aborted.. apparent infinite loop.    '
14293 CALL XERRWD (MSG, 50, 303, 2, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.0D0, 0.0D0)
14294 RETURN
14295 !----------------------- End of Subroutine DLSOIBT ---------------------
14296 END
14297 
14298 SUBROUTINE DLSODIS(RES, ADDA, JAC, NEQ, Y, YDOTI, T, TOUT, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, ITASK, ISTATE, IOPT, RWORK, LRW, IWORK, LIW, MF)
14299 EXTERNAL RES, ADDA, JAC
14300 INTEGER NEQ, ITOL, ITASK, ISTATE, IOPT, LRW, IWORK, LIW, MF
14301 DOUBLE PRECISION Y, YDOTI, T, TOUT, RTOL, ATOL, RWORK
14302 DIMENSION NEQ(*), Y(*), YDOTI(*), RTOL(*), ATOL(*), RWORK(LRW), IWORK(LIW)
14303 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
14304 ! This is the 18 November 2003 version of
14305 ! DLSODIS: Livermore Solver for Ordinary Differential equations
14306 !          (Implicit form) with general Sparse Jacobian matrices.
14307 !
14308 ! This version is in double precision.
14309 !
14310 ! DLSODIS solves the initial value problem for linearly implicit
14311 ! systems of first order ODEs,
14312 !     A(t,y) * dy/dt = g(t,y) ,  where A(t,y) is a square matrix,
14313 ! or, in component form,
14314 !     ( a   * ( dy / dt ))  + ... +  ( a     * ( dy   / dt ))  =
14315 !        i,1      1                     i,NEQ      NEQ
14316 !
14317 !      =   g ( t, y , y ,..., y    )   ( i = 1,...,NEQ )
14318 !           i      1   2       NEQ
14319 !
14320 ! If A is singular, this is a differential-algebraic system.
14321 !
14322 ! DLSODIS is a variant version of the DLSODI package, and is intended
14323 ! for stiff problems in which the matrix A and the Jacobian matrix
14324 ! d(g - A*s)/dy have arbitrary sparse structures.
14325 !
14326 ! Authors:       Alan C. Hindmarsh
14327 !                Center for Applied Scientific Computing, L-561
14328 !                Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
14329 !                Livermore, CA 94551
14330 ! and
14331 !                Sheila Balsdon
14332 !                Zycor, Inc.
14333 !                Austin, TX 78741
14334 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
14335 ! References:
14336 ! 1.  M. K. Seager and S. Balsdon,  LSODIS, A Sparse Implicit
14337 !     ODE Solver, in Proceedings of the IMACS 10th World Congress,
14338 !     Montreal, August 8-13, 1982.
14339 !
14340 ! 2.  Alan C. Hindmarsh,  LSODE and LSODI, Two New Initial Value
14341 !     Ordinary Differential Equation Solvers,
14342 !     ACM-SIGNUM Newsletter, vol. 15, no. 4 (1980), pp. 10-11.
14343 !
14344 ! 3.  S. C. Eisenstat, M. C. Gursky, M. H. Schultz, and A. H. Sherman,
14345 !     Yale Sparse Matrix Package: I. The Symmetric Codes,
14346 !     Int. J. Num. Meth. Eng., vol. 18 (1982), pp. 1145-1151.
14347 !
14348 ! 4.  S. C. Eisenstat, M. C. Gursky, M. H. Schultz, and A. H. Sherman,
14349 !     Yale Sparse Matrix Package: II. The Nonsymmetric Codes,
14350 !     Research Report No. 114, Dept. of Computer Sciences, Yale
14351 !     University, 1977.
14352 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
14353 ! Summary of Usage.
14354 !
14355 ! Communication between the user and the DLSODIS package, for normal
14356 ! situations, is summarized here.  This summary describes only a subset
14357 ! of the full set of options available.  See the full description for
14358 ! details, including optional communication, nonstandard options,
14359 ! and instructions for special situations.  See also the example
14360 ! problem (with program and output) following this summary.
14361 !
14362 ! A. First, provide a subroutine of the form:
14363 !                SUBROUTINE RES (NEQ, T, Y, S, R, IRES)
14364 !                DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), S(*), R(*)
14365 ! which computes the residual function
14366 !      r = g(t,y)  -  A(t,y) * s ,
14367 ! as a function of t and the vectors y and s.  (s is an internally
14368 ! generated approximation to dy/dt.)  The arrays Y and S are inputs
14369 ! to the RES routine and should not be altered.  The residual
14370 ! vector is to be stored in the array R.  The argument IRES should be
14371 ! ignored for casual use of DLSODIS.  (For uses of IRES, see the
14372 ! paragraph on RES in the full description below.)
14373 !
14374 ! B. DLSODIS must deal internally with the matrices A and dr/dy, where
14375 ! r is the residual function defined above.  DLSODIS generates a linear
14376 ! combination of these two matrices in sparse form.
14377 !      The matrix structure is communicated by a method flag, MF:
14378 !         MF =  21 or  22     when the user provides the structures of
14379 !                             matrix A and dr/dy,
14380 !         MF = 121 or 222     when the user does not provide structure
14381 !                             information, and
14382 !         MF = 321 or 422     when the user provides the structure
14383 !                             of matrix A.
14384 !
14385 ! C. You must also provide a subroutine of the form:
14386 !                SUBROUTINE ADDA (NEQ, T, Y, J, IAN, JAN, P)
14387 !                DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), P(*)
14388 !                INTEGER IAN(*), JAN(*)
14389 ! which adds the matrix A = A(t,y) to the contents of the array P.
14390 ! NEQ, T, Y, and J are input arguments and should not be altered.
14391 ! This routine should add the J-th column of matrix A to the array
14392 ! P (of length NEQ).  I.e. add A(i,J) to P(i) for all relevant
14393 ! values of i.  The arguments IAN and JAN should be ignored for normal
14394 ! situations.  DLSODIS will call the ADDA routine with J = 1,2,...,NEQ.
14395 !
14396 ! D. For the sake of efficiency, you are encouraged to supply the
14397 ! Jacobian matrix dr/dy in closed form, where r = g(t,y) - A(t,y)*s
14398 ! (s = a fixed vector) as above.  If dr/dy is being supplied,
14399 ! use MF = 21, 121, or 321, and provide a subroutine of the form:
14400 !               SUBROUTINE JAC (NEQ, T, Y, S, J, IAN, JAN, PDJ)
14401 !               DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), S(*), PDJ(*)
14402 !               INTEGER IAN(*), JAN(*)
14403 ! which computes dr/dy as a function of t, y, and s.  Here NEQ, T, Y, S,
14404 ! and J are input arguments, and the JAC routine is to load the array
14405 ! PDJ (of length NEQ) with the J-th column of dr/dy.  I.e. load PDJ(i)
14406 ! with dr(i)/dy(J) for all relevant values of i.  The arguments IAN and
14407 ! JAN should be ignored for normal situations.  DLSODIS will call the
14408 ! JAC routine with J = 1,2,...,NEQ.
14409 !      Only nonzero elements need be loaded.  A crude approximation
14410 ! to dr/dy, possibly with fewer nonzero elememts, will suffice.
14411 ! Note that if A is independent of y (or this dependence
14412 ! is weak enough to be ignored) then JAC is to compute dg/dy.
14413 !      If it is not feasible to provide a JAC routine, use
14414 ! MF = 22, 222, or 422 and DLSODIS will compute an approximate
14415 ! Jacobian internally by difference quotients.
14416 !
14417 ! E. Next decide whether or not to provide the initial value of the
14418 ! derivative vector dy/dt.  If the initial value of A(t,y) is
14419 ! nonsingular (and not too ill-conditioned), you may let DLSODIS compute
14420 ! this vector (ISTATE = 0).  (DLSODIS will solve the system A*s = g for
14421 ! s, with initial values of A and g.)  If A(t,y) is initially
14422 ! singular, then the system is a differential-algebraic system, and
14423 ! you must make use of the particular form of the system to compute the
14424 ! initial values of y and dy/dt.  In that case, use ISTATE = 1 and
14425 ! load the initial value of dy/dt into the array YDOTI.
14426 ! The input array YDOTI and the initial Y array must be consistent with
14427 ! the equations A*dy/dt = g.  This implies that the initial residual
14428 ! r = g(t,y) - A(t,y)*YDOTI   must be approximately zero.
14429 !
14430 ! F. Write a main program which calls Subroutine DLSODIS once for
14431 ! each point at which answers are desired.  This should also provide
14432 ! for possible use of logical unit 6 for output of error messages by
14433 ! DLSODIS.  On the first call to DLSODIS, supply arguments as follows:
14434 ! RES    = name of user subroutine for residual function r.
14435 ! ADDA   = name of user subroutine for computing and adding A(t,y).
14436 ! JAC    = name of user subroutine for Jacobian matrix dr/dy
14437 !          (MF = 121).  If not used, pass a dummy name.
14438 ! Note: The names for the RES and ADDA routines and (if used) the
14439 !        JAC routine must be declared External in the calling program.
14440 ! NEQ    = number of scalar equations in the system.
14441 ! Y      = array of initial values, of length NEQ.
14442 ! YDOTI  = array of length NEQ (containing initial dy/dt if ISTATE = 1).
14443 ! T      = the initial value of the independent variable.
14444 ! TOUT   = first point where output is desired (.ne. T).
14445 ! ITOL   = 1 or 2 according as ATOL (below) is a scalar or array.
14446 ! RTOL   = relative tolerance parameter (scalar).
14447 ! ATOL   = absolute tolerance parameter (scalar or array).
14448 !          The estimated local error in y(i) will be controlled so as
14449 !          to be roughly less (in magnitude) than
14450 !             EWT(i) = RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL     if ITOL = 1, or
14451 !             EWT(i) = RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i)  if ITOL = 2.
14452 !          Thus the local error test passes if, in each component,
14453 !          either the absolute error is less than ATOL (or ATOL(i)),
14454 !          or the relative error is less than RTOL.
14455 !          Use RTOL = 0.0 for pure absolute error control, and
14456 !          use ATOL = 0.0 (or ATOL(i) = 0.0) for pure relative error
14457 !          control.  Caution: Actual (global) errors may exceed these
14458 !          local tolerances, so choose them conservatively.
14459 ! ITASK  = 1 for normal computation of output values of y at t = TOUT.
14460 ! ISTATE = integer flag (input and output).  Set ISTATE = 1 if the
14461 !          initial dy/dt is supplied, and 0 otherwise.
14462 ! IOPT   = 0 to indicate no optional inputs used.
14463 ! RWORK  = real work array of length at least:
14464 !             20 + (2 + 1./LENRAT)*NNZ + (11 + 9./LENRAT)*NEQ
14465 !          where:
14466 !          NNZ    = the number of nonzero elements in the sparse
14467 !                   iteration matrix  P = A - con*dr/dy (con = scalar)
14468 !                   (If NNZ is unknown, use an estimate of it.)
14469 !          LENRAT = the real to integer wordlength ratio (usually 1 in
14470 !                   single precision and 2 in double precision).
14471 !          In any case, the required size of RWORK cannot generally
14472 !          be predicted in advance for any value of MF, and the
14473 !          value above is a rough estimate of a crude lower bound.
14474 !          Some experimentation with this size may be necessary.
14475 !          (When known, the correct required length is an optional
14476 !          output, available in IWORK(17).)
14477 ! LRW    = declared length of RWORK (in user's dimension).
14478 ! IWORK  = integer work array of length at least 30.
14479 ! LIW    = declared length of IWORK (in user's dimension).
14480 ! MF     = method flag.  Standard values are:
14481 !          121 for a user-supplied sparse Jacobian.
14482 !          222 for an internally generated sparse Jacobian.
14483 !          For other choices of MF, see the paragraph on MF in
14484 !          the full description below.
14485 ! Note that the main program must declare arrays Y, YDOTI, RWORK, IWORK,
14486 ! and possibly ATOL.
14487 !
14488 ! G. The output from the first call, or any call, is:
14489 !      Y = array of computed values of y(t) vector.
14490 !      T = corresponding value of independent variable (normally TOUT).
14491 ! ISTATE =  2  if DLSODIS was successful, negative otherwise.
14492 !          -1 means excess work done on this call (check all inputs).
14493 !          -2 means excess accuracy requested (tolerances too small).
14494 !          -3 means illegal input detected (see printed message).
14495 !          -4 means repeated error test failures (check all inputs).
14496 !          -5 means repeated convergence failures (perhaps bad Jacobian
14497 !             supplied or wrong choice of tolerances).
14498 !          -6 means error weight became zero during problem. (Solution
14499 !             component i vanished, and ATOL or ATOL(i) = 0.)
14500 !          -7 cannot occur in casual use.
14501 !          -8 means DLSODIS was unable to compute the initial dy/dt.
14502 !             in casual use, this means A(t,y) is initially singular.
14503 !             Supply YDOTI and use ISTATE = 1 on the first call.
14504 !          -9 means a fatal error return flag came from sparse solver
14505 !             CDRV by way of DPRJIS or DSOLSS.  Should never happen.
14506 !
14507 !          A return with ISTATE = -1, -4, or -5, may result from using
14508 !          an inappropriate sparsity structure, one that is quite
14509 !          different from the initial structure.  Consider calling
14510 !          DLSODIS again with ISTATE = 3 to force the structure to be
14511 !          reevaluated.  See the full description of ISTATE below.
14512 !
14513 !  If DLSODIS returns ISTATE = -1, -4  or -5, then the output of
14514 !  DLSODIS also includes YDOTI = array containing residual vector
14515 !  r = g - A * dy/dt  evaluated at the current t, y, and dy/dt.
14516 !
14517 ! H. To continue the integration after a successful return, simply
14518 ! reset TOUT and call DLSODIS again.  No other parameters need be reset.
14519 !
14520 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
14521 ! Example Problem.
14522 !
14523 ! The following is an example problem, with the coding needed
14524 ! for its solution by DLSODIS.  The problem comes from the partial
14525 ! differential equation (the Burgers equation)
14526 !   du/dt  =  - u * du/dx  +  eta * d**2 u/dx**2,   eta = .05,
14527 ! on -1 .le. x .le. 1.  The boundary conditions are periodic:
14528 !   u(-1,t) = u(1,t)  and  du/dx(-1,t) = du/dx(1,t)
14529 ! The initial profile is a square wave,
14530 !   u = 1 in ABS(x) .lt. .5,  u = .5 at ABS(x) = .5,  u = 0 elsewhere.
14531 ! The PDE is discretized in x by a simplified Galerkin method,
14532 ! using piecewise linear basis functions, on a grid of 40 intervals.
14533 ! The result is a system A * dy/dt = g(y), of size NEQ = 40,
14534 ! where y(i) is the approximation to u at x = x(i), with
14535 ! x(i) = -1 + (i-1)*delx, delx = 2/NEQ = .05.
14536 ! The individual equations in the system are (in order):
14537 !  (1/6)dy(NEQ)/dt+(4/6)dy(1)/dt+(1/6)dy(2)/dt
14538 !       = r4d*(y(NEQ)**2-y(2)**2)+eodsq*(y(2)-2*y(1)+y(NEQ))
14539 ! for i = 2,3,...,nm1,
14540 !  (1/6)dy(i-1)/dt+(4/6)dy(i)/dt+(1/6)dy(i+1)/dt
14541 !       = r4d*(y(i-1)**2-y(i+1)**2)+eodsq*(y(i+1)-2*y(i)+y(i-1))
14542 ! and finally
14543 !  (1/6)dy(nm1)/dt+(4/6)dy(NEQ)/dt+(1/6)dy(1)/dt
14544 !       = r4d*(y(nm1)**2-y(1)**2)+eodsq*(y(1)-2*y(NEQ)+y(nm1))
14545 ! where r4d = 1/(4*delx), eodsq = eta/delx**2 and nm1 = NEQ-1.
14546 ! The following coding solves the problem with MF = 121, with output
14547 ! of solution statistics at t = .1, .2, .3, and .4, and of the
14548 ! solution vector at t = .4.  Optional outputs (run statistics) are
14549 ! also printed.
14550 !
14551 !     EXTERNAL RESID, ADDASP, JACSP
14552 !     DOUBLE PRECISION ATOL, RTOL, RW, T, TOUT, Y, YDOTI, R4D, EODSQ, DELX
14553 !     DIMENSION Y(40), YDOTI(40), RW(1409), IW(30)
14554 !     COMMON /TEST1/ R4D, EODSQ, NM1
14555 !     DATA ITOL/1/, RTOL/1.0D-3/, ATOL/1.0D-3/, ITASK/1/, IOPT/0/
14556 !     DATA NEQ/40/, LRW/1409/, LIW/30/, MF/121/
14557 !
14558 !     DELX = 2.0/NEQ
14559 !     R4D = 0.25/DELX
14560 !     EODSQ = 0.05/DELX**2
14561 !     NM1 = NEQ - 1
14562 !     DO 10 I = 1,NEQ
14563 ! 10    Y(I) = 0.0
14564 !     Y(11) = 0.5
14565 !     DO 15 I = 12,30
14566 ! 15    Y(I) = 1.0
14567 !     Y(31) = 0.5
14568 !     T = 0.0
14569 !     TOUT = 0.1
14570 !     ISTATE = 0
14571 !     DO 30 IO = 1,4
14572 !       CALL DLSODIS (RESID, ADDASP, JACSP, NEQ, Y, YDOTI, T, TOUT,
14573 !    1    ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, ITASK, ISTATE, IOPT, RW, LRW, IW, LIW, MF)
14574 !       WRITE(6,20) T,IW(11),RW(11)
14575 ! 20    FORMAT(' At t =',F5.2,'   No. steps =',I4,
14576 !    1    '    Last step =',D12.4)
14577 !       IF (ISTATE .NE. 2) GOTO 90
14578 !       TOUT = TOUT + 0.1
14579 ! 30  CONTINUE
14580 !     WRITE (6,40) (Y(I),I=1,NEQ)
14581 ! 40  FORMAT(/' Final solution values..'/8(5D12.4/))
14582 !     WRITE(6,50) IW(17),IW(18),IW(11),IW(12),IW(13)
14583 !     NNZLU = IW(25) + IW(26) + NEQ
14584 !     WRITE(6,60) IW(19),NNZLU
14585 ! 50  FORMAT(/' Required RW size =',I5,'   IW size =',I4/
14586 !    1  ' No. steps =',I4,'   No. r-s =',I4,'   No. J-s =',i4)
14587 ! 60  FORMAT(' No. of nonzeros in P matrix =',I4,
14588 !    1  '   No. of nonzeros in LU =',I4)
14589 !     STOP
14590 ! 90  WRITE (6,95) ISTATE
14591 ! 95  FORMAT(///' Error halt.. ISTATE =',I3)
14592 !     STOP
14593 !     END
14594 !
14595 !     SUBROUTINE GFUN (N, T, Y, G)
14596 !     DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y, G, R4D, EODSQ
14597 !     DIMENSION G(N), Y(N)
14598 !     COMMON /TEST1/ R4D, EODSQ, NM1
14599 !     G(1) = R4D*(Y(N)**2-Y(2)**2) + EODSQ*(Y(2)-2.0*Y(1)+Y(N))
14600 !     DO 10 I = 2,NM1
14601 !       G(I) = R4D*(Y(I-1)**2 - Y(I+1)**2)
14602 !    1        + EODSQ*(Y(I+1) - 2.0*Y(I) + Y(I-1))
14603 ! 10    CONTINUE
14604 !     G(N) = R4D*(Y(NM1)**2-Y(1)**2) + EODSQ*(Y(1)-2.0*Y(N)+Y(NM1))
14605 !     RETURN
14606 !     END
14607 !
14608 !     SUBROUTINE RESID (N, T, Y, S, R, IRES)
14609 !     DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y, S, R, R4D, EODSQ
14610 !     DIMENSION Y(N), S(N), R(N)
14611 !     COMMON /TEST1/ R4D, EODSQ, NM1
14612 !     CALL GFUN (N, T, Y, R)
14613 !     R(1) = R(1) - (S(N) + 4.0*S(1) + S(2))/6.0
14614 !     DO 10 I = 2,NM1
14615 ! 10    R(I) = R(I) - (S(I-1) + 4.0*S(I) + S(I+1))/6.0
14616 !     R(N) = R(N) - (S(NM1) + 4.0*S(N) + S(1))/6.0
14617 !     RETURN
14618 !     END
14619 !
14620 !     SUBROUTINE ADDASP (N, T, Y, J, IP, JP, P)
14621 !     DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y, P
14622 !     DIMENSION Y(N), IP(*), JP(*), P(N)
14623 !     JM1 = J - 1
14624 !     JP1 = J + 1
14625 !     IF (J .EQ. N) JP1 = 1
14626 !     IF (J .EQ. 1) JM1 = N
14627 !     P(J) = P(J) + (2.0/3.0)
14628 !     P(JP1) = P(JP1) + (1.0/6.0)
14629 !     P(JM1) = P(JM1) + (1.0/6.0)
14630 !     RETURN
14631 !     END
14632 !
14633 !     SUBROUTINE JACSP (N, T, Y, S, J, IP, JP, PDJ)
14634 !     DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y, S, PDJ, R4D, EODSQ
14635 !     DIMENSION Y(N), S(N), IP(*), JP(*), PDJ(N)
14636 !     COMMON /TEST1/ R4D, EODSQ, NM1
14637 !     JM1 = J - 1
14638 !     JP1 = J + 1
14639 !     IF (J .EQ. 1) JM1 = N
14640 !     IF (J .EQ. N) JP1 = 1
14641 !     PDJ(JM1) = -2.0*R4D*Y(J) + EODSQ
14642 !     PDJ(J) = -2.0*EODSQ
14643 !     PDJ(JP1) = 2.0*R4D*Y(J) + EODSQ
14644 !     RETURN
14645 !     END
14646 !
14647 ! The output of this program (on a CDC-7600 in single precision)
14648 ! is as follows:
14649 !
14650 ! At t = 0.10   No. steps =  15    Last step =  1.6863e-02
14651 ! At t = 0.20   No. steps =  19    Last step =  2.4101e-02
14652 ! At t = 0.30   No. steps =  22    Last step =  4.3143e-02
14653 ! At t = 0.40   No. steps =  24    Last step =  5.7819e-02
14654 !
14655 ! Final solution values..
14656 !  1.8371e-02  1.3578e-02  1.5864e-02  2.3805e-02  3.7245e-02
14657 !  5.6630e-02  8.2538e-02  1.1538e-01  1.5522e-01  2.0172e-01
14658 !  2.5414e-01  3.1150e-01  3.7259e-01  4.3608e-01  5.0060e-01
14659 !  5.6482e-01  6.2751e-01  6.8758e-01  7.4415e-01  7.9646e-01
14660 !  8.4363e-01  8.8462e-01  9.1853e-01  9.4500e-01  9.6433e-01
14661 !  9.7730e-01  9.8464e-01  9.8645e-01  9.8138e-01  9.6584e-01
14662 !  9.3336e-01  8.7497e-01  7.8213e-01  6.5315e-01  4.9997e-01
14663 !  3.4672e-01  2.1758e-01  1.2461e-01  6.6208e-02  3.3784e-02
14664 !
14665 ! Required RW size = 1409   IW size =  30
14666 ! No. steps =  24   No. r-s =  33   No. J-s =   8
14667 ! No. of nonzeros in P matrix = 120   No. of nonzeros in LU = 194
14668 !
14669 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
14670 ! Full Description of User Interface to DLSODIS.
14671 !
14672 ! The user interface to DLSODIS consists of the following parts.
14673 !
14674 ! 1.   The call sequence to Subroutine DLSODIS, which is a driver
14675 !      routine for the solver.  This includes descriptions of both
14676 !      the call sequence arguments and of user-supplied routines.
14677 !      Following these descriptions is a description of
14678 !      optional inputs available through the call sequence, and then
14679 !      a description of optional outputs (in the work arrays).
14680 !
14681 ! 2.   Descriptions of other routines in the DLSODIS package that may be
14682 !      (optionally) called by the user.  These provide the ability to
14683 !      alter error message handling, save and restore the internal
14684 !      Common, and obtain specified derivatives of the solution y(t).
14685 !
14686 ! 3.   Descriptions of Common blocks to be declared in overlay
14687 !      or similar environments, or to be saved when doing an interrupt
14688 !      of the problem and continued solution later.
14689 !
14690 ! 4.   Description of two routines in the DLSODIS package, either of
14691 !      which the user may replace with his/her own version, if desired.
14692 !      These relate to the measurement of errors.
14693 !
14694 !-----------------------------------------------------------------------
14695 ! Part 1.  Call Sequence.
14696 !
14697 ! The call sequence parameters used for input only are
14698 !     RES, ADDA, JAC, NEQ, TOUT, ITOL, RTOL, ATOL, ITASK,
14699 !     IOPT, LRW, LIW, MF,
14700 ! and those used for both input and output are
14701 !     Y, T, ISTATE, YDOTI.
14702 ! The work arrays RWORK and IWORK are also used for conditional and
14703 ! optional inputs and optional outputs.  (The term output here refers
14704 ! to the return from Subroutine DLSODIS to the user's calling program.)
14705 !
14706 ! The legality of input parameters will be thoroughly checked on the
14707 ! initial call for the problem, but not checked thereafter unless a
14708 ! change in input parameters is flagged by ISTATE = 3 on input.
14709 !
14710 ! The descriptions of the call arguments are as follows.
14711 !
14712 ! RES    = the name of the user-supplied subroutine which supplies
14713 !          the residual vector for the ODE system, defined by
14714 !            r = g(t,y) - A(t,y) * s
14715 !          as a function of the scalar t and the vectors
14716 !          s and y (s approximates dy/dt).  This subroutine
14717 !          is to have the form
14718 !               SUBROUTINE RES (NEQ, T, Y, S, R, IRES)
14719 !               DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), S(*), R(*)
14720 !          where NEQ, T, Y, S, and IRES are input, and R and
14721 !          IRES are output.  Y, S, and R are arrays of length NEQ.
14722 !             On input, IRES indicates how DLSODIS will use the
14723 !          returned array R, as follows:
14724 !             IRES = 1  means that DLSODIS needs the full residual,
14725 !                       r = g - A*s, exactly.
14726 !             IRES = -1 means that DLSODIS is using R only to compute
14727 !                       the Jacobian dr/dy by difference quotients.
14728 !          The RES routine can ignore IRES, or it can omit some terms
14729 !          if IRES = -1.  If A does not depend on y, then RES can
14730 !          just return R = g when IRES = -1.  If g - A*s contains other
14731 !          additive terms that are independent of y, these can also be
14732 !          dropped, if done consistently, when IRES = -1.
14733 !             The subroutine should set the flag IRES if it
14734 !          encounters a halt condition or illegal input.
14735 !          Otherwise, it should not reset IRES.  On output,
14736 !             IRES = 1 or -1 represents a normal return, and
14737 !          DLSODIS continues integrating the ODE.  Leave IRES
14738 !          unchanged from its input value.
14739 !             IRES = 2 tells DLSODIS to immediately return control
14740 !          to the calling program, with ISTATE = 3.  This lets
14741 !          the calling program change parameters of the problem
14742 !          if necessary.
14743 !             IRES = 3 represents an error condition (for example, an
14744 !          illegal value of y).  DLSODIS tries to integrate the system
14745 !          without getting IRES = 3 from RES.  If it cannot, DLSODIS
14746 !          returns with ISTATE = -7 or -1.
14747 !             On a return with ISTATE = 3, -1, or -7, the values
14748 !          of T and Y returned correspond to the last point reached
14749 !          successfully without getting the flag IRES = 2 or 3.
14750 !             The flag values IRES = 2 and 3 should not be used to
14751 !          handle switches or root-stop conditions.  This is better
14752 !          done by calling DLSODIS in a one-step mode and checking the
14753 !          stopping function for a sign change at each step.
14754 !             If quantities computed in the RES routine are needed
14755 !          externally to DLSODIS, an extra call to RES should be made
14756 !          for this purpose, for consistent and accurate results.
14757 !          To get the current dy/dt for the S argument, use DINTDY.
14758 !             RES must be declared External in the calling
14759 !          program.  See note below for more about RES.
14760 !
14761 ! ADDA   = the name of the user-supplied subroutine which adds the
14762 !          matrix A = A(t,y) to another matrix stored in sparse form.
14763 !          This subroutine is to have the form
14764 !               SUBROUTINE ADDA (NEQ, T, Y, J, IAN, JAN, P)
14765 !               DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), P(*)
14766 !               INTEGER IAN(*), JAN(*)
14767 !          where NEQ, T, Y, J, IAN, JAN, and P  are input.  This routine
14768 !          should add the J-th column of matrix A to the array P, of
14769 !          length NEQ.  Thus a(i,J) is to be added to P(i) for all
14770 !          relevant values of i.  Here T and Y have the same meaning as
14771 !          in Subroutine RES, and J is a column index (1 to NEQ).
14772 !          IAN and JAN are undefined in calls to ADDA for structure
14773 !          determination (MOSS .ne. 0).  Otherwise, IAN and JAN are
14774 !          structure descriptors, as defined under optional outputs
14775 !          below, and so can be used to determine the relevant row
14776 !          indices i, if desired.
14777 !               Calls to ADDA are made with J = 1,...,NEQ, in that
14778 !          order.  ADDA must not alter its input arguments.
14779 !               ADDA must be declared External in the calling program.
14780 !          See note below for more information about ADDA.
14781 !
14782 ! JAC    = the name of the user-supplied subroutine which supplies
14783 !          the Jacobian matrix, dr/dy, where r = g - A*s.  JAC is
14784 !          required if MITER = 1, or MOSS = 1 or 3.  Otherwise a dummy
14785 !          name can be passed.  This subroutine is to have the form
14786 !               SUBROUTINE JAC (NEQ, T, Y, S, J, IAN, JAN, PDJ)
14787 !               DOUBLE PRECISION T, Y(*), S(*), PDJ(*)
14788 !               INTEGER IAN(*), JAN(*)
14789 !         where NEQ, T, Y, S, J, IAN, and JAN are input.  The
14790 !         array PDJ, of length NEQ, is to be loaded with column J
14791 !         of the Jacobian on output.  Thus dr(i)/dy(J) is to be
14792 !         loaded into PDJ(i) for all relevant values of i.
14793 !         Here T, Y, and S have the same meaning as in Subroutine RES,
14794 !         and J is a column index (1 to NEQ).  IAN and JAN
14795 !         are undefined in calls to JAC for structure determination
14796 !         (MOSS .ne. 0).  Otherwise, IAN and JAN are structure
14797 !         descriptors, as defined under optional outputs below, and
14798 !         so can be used to determine the relevant row indices i, if
14799 !         desired.
14800 !              JAC need not provide dr/dy exactly.  A crude
14801 !         approximation (possibly with greater sparsity) will do.
14802 !              In any case, PDJ is preset to zero by the solver,
14803 !         so that only the nonzero elements need be loaded by JAC.
14804 !         Calls to JAC are made with J = 1,...,NEQ, in that order, and
14805 !         each such set of calls is preceded by a call to RES with the
14806 !         same arguments NEQ, T, Y, S, and IRES.  Thus to gain some
14807 !         efficiency intermediate quantities shared by both calculations
14808 !         may be saved in a user Common block by RES and not recomputed
14809 !         by JAC, if desired.  JAC must not alter its input arguments.
14810 !              JAC must be declared External in the calling program.
14811 !              See note below for more about JAC.
14812 !
14813 !    Note on RES, ADDA, and JAC:
14814 !          These subroutines may access user-defined quantities in
14815 !          NEQ(2),... and/or in Y(NEQ(1)+1),... if NEQ is an array
14816 !          (dimensioned in the subroutines) and/or Y has length
14817 !          exceeding NEQ(1).  However, these subroutines should not
14818 !          alter NEQ(1), Y(1),...,Y(NEQ) or any other input variables.
14819 !          See the descriptions of NEQ and Y below.
14820 !
14821 ! NEQ    = the size of the system (number of first order ordinary
14822 !          differential equations or scalar algebraic equations).
14823 !          Used only for input.
14824 !          NEQ may be decreased, but not increased, during the problem.
14825 !          If NEQ is decreased (with ISTATE = 3 on input), the
14826 !          remaining components of Y should be left undisturbed, if
14827 !          these are to be accessed in RES, ADDA, or JAC.
14828 !
14829 !          Normally, NEQ is a scalar, and it is generally referred to
14830 !          as a scalar in this user interface description.  However,
14831 !          NEQ may be an array, with NEQ(1) set to the system size.
14832 !          (The DLSODIS package accesses only NEQ(1).)  In either case,
14833 !          this parameter is passed as the NEQ argument in all calls
14834 !          to RES, ADDA, and JAC.  Hence, if it is an array,
14835 !          locations NEQ(2),... may be used to store other integer data
14836 !          and pass it to RES, ADDA, or JAC.  Each such subroutine
14837 !          must include NEQ in a Dimension statement in that case.
14838 !
14839 ! Y      = a real array for the vector of dependent variables, of
14840 !          length NEQ or more.  Used for both input and output on the
14841 !          first call (ISTATE = 0 or 1), and only for output on other
14842 !          calls.  On the first call, Y must contain the vector of
14843 !          initial values.  On output, Y contains the computed solution
14844 !          vector, evaluated at T.  If desired, the Y array may be used
14845 !          for other purposes between calls to the solver.
14846 !
14847 !          This array is passed as the Y argument in all calls to RES,
14848 !          ADDA, and JAC.  Hence its length may exceed NEQ,
14849 !          and locations Y(NEQ+1),... may be used to store other real
14850 !          data and pass it to RES, ADDA, or JAC.  (The DLSODIS
14851 !          package accesses only Y(1),...,Y(NEQ). )
14852 !
14853 ! YDOTI  = a real array for the initial value of the vector
14854 !          dy/dt and for work space, of dimension at least NEQ.
14855 !
14856 !          On input:
14857 !            If ISTATE = 0 then DLSODIS will compute the initial value
14858 !          of dy/dt, if A is nonsingular.  Thus YDOTI will
14859 !          serve only as work space and may have any value.
14860 !            If ISTATE = 1 then YDOTI must contain the initial value
14861 !          of dy/dt.
14862 !            If ISTATE = 2 or 3 (continuation calls) then YDOTI
14863 !          may have any value.
14864 !            Note: If the initial value of A is singular, then
14865 !          DLSODIS cannot compute the initial value of dy/dt, so
14866 !          it must be provided in YDOTI, with ISTATE = 1.
14867 !
14868 !          On output, when DLSODIS terminates abnormally with ISTATE =
14869 !          -1, -4, or -5, YDOTI will contain the residual
14870 !          r = g(t,y) - A(t,y)*(dy/dt).  If r is large, t is near
14871 !          its initial value, and YDOTI is supplied with ISTATE = 1,
14872 !          there may have been an incorrect input value of
14873 !          YDOTI = dy/dt, or the problem (as given to DLSODIS)
14874 !          may not have a solution.
14875 !
14876 !          If desired, the YDOTI array may be used for other
14877 !          purposes between calls to the solver.
14878 !
14879 ! T      = the independent variable.  On input, T is used only on the
14880 !          first call, as the initial point of the integration.
14881 !          On output, after each call, T is the value at which a
14882 !          computed solution y is evaluated (usually the same as TOUT).
14883 !          On an error return, T is the farthest point reached.
14884 !
14885 ! TOUT   = the next value of t at which a computed solution is desired.
14886 !          Used only for input.
14887 !
14888 !          When starting the problem (ISTATE = 0 or 1), TOUT may be
14889 !          equal to T for one call, then should .ne. T for the next
14890 !          call.  For the initial T, an input value of TOUT .ne. T is
14891 !          used in order to determine the direction of the integration
14892 !          (i.e. the algebraic sign of the step sizes) and the rough
14893 !          scale of the problem.  Integration in either direction
14894 !          (forward or backward in t) is permitted.
14895 !
14896 !          If ITASK = 2 or 5 (one-step modes), TOUT is ignored after
14897 !          the first call (i.e. the first call with TOUT .ne. T).
14898 !          Otherwise, TOUT is required on every call.
14899 !
14900 !          If ITASK = 1, 3, or 4, the values of TOUT need not be
14901 !          monotone, but a value of TOUT which backs up is limited
14902 !          to the current internal T interval, whose endpoints are
14903 !          TCUR - HU and TCUR (see optional outputs, below, for
14904 !          TCUR and HU).
14905 !
14906 ! ITOL   = an indicator for the type of error control.  See
14907 !          description below under ATOL.  Used only for input.
14908 !
14909 ! RTOL   = a relative error tolerance parameter, either a scalar or
14910 !          an array of length NEQ.  See description below under ATOL.
14911 !          Input only.
14912 !
14913 ! ATOL   = an absolute error tolerance parameter, either a scalar or
14914 !          an array of length NEQ.  Input only.
14915 !
14916 !             The input parameters ITOL, RTOL, and ATOL determine
14917 !          the error control performed by the solver.  The solver will
14918 !          control the vector E = (E(i)) of estimated local errors
14919 !          in y, according to an inequality of the form
14920 !                      RMS-norm of ( E(i)/EWT(i) )   .le.   1,
14921 !          where       EWT(i) = RTOL(i)*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i),
14922 !          and the RMS-norm (root-mean-square norm) here is
14923 !          RMS-norm(v) = SQRT(sum v(i)**2 / NEQ).  Here EWT = (EWT(i))
14924 !          is a vector of weights which must always be positive, and
14925 !          the values of RTOL and ATOL should all be non-negative.
14926 !          The following table gives the types (scalar/array) of
14927 !          RTOL and ATOL, and the corresponding form of EWT(i).
14928 !
14929 !             ITOL    RTOL       ATOL          EWT(i)
14930 !              1     scalar     scalar     RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL
14931 !              2     scalar     array      RTOL*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i)
14932 !              3     array      scalar     RTOL(i)*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL
14933 !              4     array      scalar     RTOL(i)*ABS(Y(i)) + ATOL(i)
14934 !
14935 !          When either of these parameters is a scalar, it need not
14936 !          be dimensioned in the user's calling program.
14937 !
14938 !          If none of the above choices (with ITOL, RTOL, and ATOL
14939 !          fixed throughout the problem) is suitable, more general
14940 !          error controls can be obtained by substituting
14941 !          user-supplied routines for the setting of EWT and/or for
14942 !          the norm calculation.  See Part 4 below.
14943 !
14944 !          If global errors are to be estimated by making a repeated
14945 !          run on the same problem with smaller tolerances, then all
14946 !          components of RTOL and ATOL (i.e. of EWT) should be scaled
14947 !          down uniformly.
14948 !
14949 ! ITASK  = an index specifying the task to be performed.
14950 !          Input only.  ITASK has the following values and meanings.
14951 !          1  means normal computation of output values of y(t) at
14952 !             t = TOUT (by overshooting and interpolating).
14953 !          2  means take one step only and return.
14954 !          3  means stop at the first internal mesh point at or
14955 !             beyond t = TOUT and return.
14956 !          4  means normal computation of output values of y(t) at
14957 !             t = TOUT but without overshooting t = TCRIT.
14958 !             TCRIT must be input as RWORK(1).  TCRIT may be equal to
14959 !             or beyond TOUT, but not behind it in the direction of
14960 !             integration.  This option is useful if the problem
14961 !             has a singularity at or beyond t = TCRIT.
14962 !          5  means take one step, without passing TCRIT, and return.
14963 !             TCRIT must be input as RWORK(1).
14964 !
14965 !          Note:  If ITASK = 4 or 5 and the solver reaches TCRIT
14966 !          (within roundoff), it will return T = TCRIT (exactly) to
14967 !          indicate this (unless ITASK = 4 and TOUT comes before TCRIT,
14968 !          in which case answers at t = TOUT are returned first).
14969 !
14970 ! ISTATE = an index used for input and output to specify the
14971 !          state of the calculation.
14972 !
14973 !          On input, the values of ISTATE are as follows.
14974 !          0  means this is the first call for the problem, and
14975 !             DLSODIS is to compute the initial value of dy/dt
14976 !             (while doing other initializations).  See note below.
14977 !          1  means this is the first call for the problem, and
14978 !             the initial value of dy/dt has been supplied in
14979 !             YDOTI (DLSODIS will do other initializations).
14980 !             See note below.
14981 !          2  means this is not the first call, and the calculation
14982 !             is to continue normally, with no change in any input
14983 !             parameters except possibly TOUT and ITASK.
14984 !             (If ITOL, RTOL, and/or ATOL are changed between calls
14985 !             with ISTATE = 2, the new values will be used but not
14986 !             tested for legality.)
14987 !          3  means this is not the first call, and the
14988 !             calculation is to continue normally, but with
